This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

The western populations probably belong to an undescribed species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). The distinction between this species and Phlyctimantis leonardi is in question (Largen and Dowsett-Lemaire 1991, Schiøtz 1999).

The distinction between this species and Phlyctimantis boulengeri is in question (Largen and Dowsett-Lemaire 1991, Schiøtz 1999). Records from Bioko Island (Equatorial Guinea) refer to Phlyctimantis boulengeri.
There is a suggestion that this taxon is likely to represent more than  one species based on molecular evidence (David Blackburn and Simon  Loader, pers. comm. Nov 2012).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. This species' name, Arthroleptis zimmeri, cannot yet be assigned with certainty to any known species in the wild.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. There is still a lot of taxonomic confusion particularly with this species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016), and specimens currently referred to as Arthroleptis adelphus might possibly belong to this species (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

This is a complex of undescribed species and work on this group is either planned or in progress (Blackburn and Gvozdík unpublished). There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. It is very likely that this name covers more than one species.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

This taxon was traditionally treated as a synonym of Hyperolius nasutus. However, Schiøtz (2006b) considered it to be closer to H. benguellensis, and it is treated here as a distinct species, pending clarification of its status.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.  It is possible that montane biological populations may refer to a different species (Poynton and Loader in Frost 2014).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. In the past, Arthroleptis bivittatus has been confused with Arthroleptis taeniatus, which is clearly a distinct species. It is possible that A. bivitattatus is a synonym of A. poecilinotus, but more field observations are needed to confirm this (Perret 1991).

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Arthroleptis stenodactylus. However, this species was resurrected simply "since it's the earliest applicable name [Pickersgill] could find" (Pickersgill, 2007; p. 309) and without reference to the type material. Specimens referred to this species by Pickersgill (2007) may indeed represent a valid species, although it is unlikely to correspond to Arthroleptis lonnbergi (D. Blackburn pers. comm. July 2010).

This species was removed from the synonymy of M. lonnbergi by Poynton (1997) and included within M. mocquardi. However, we follow Channing and Howell (2006) in giving M. nairobiensis full species status. M. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers both M. mocquardi and M. nairobiensis to be synonyms of M. lonnbergi. More work is needed to resolve its taxonomic status.

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in treating mainland populations of frogs previously known as Hyperolius puncticulatus as H. substriatus. Under this arrangement, H. puncticulatus is endemic to Unguja (Zanzibar) island.

We follow Perret (1976), Rödel (2000) and Pickersgill (in prep.) in separating Afrixalus fulvovittatus from the so-called Afrixalus vittatus complex of Schiøtz (1999), which includes Afrixalus quadrivittatus, A. upembae and A. vittiger.
This species is closely related to Afrixalus nigeriensis and A. leucostictus (Schiøtz 1999).

Perret (1960; 1976) considers this to be an unmistakeable species on the basis of its morphology. However, Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that the type (and only) specimen is probably an aberrant Afrixalus paradorsalis.

We follow Rödel (2000) and Pickersgill (2000.) in considering Afrixalus quadrivittatus to be specifically distinct from Afrixalus vittiger. A. quadrivittus is part of a complex that includes A. upembae and A. vittiger.
The relationship between this species and Afrixalus equatorialis requires further examination (Schiøtz 1999).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Mertensophryne lonnbergi by Poynton (1997), who also included M. nairobiensis within it. However, we follow Channing and Howell (2006) in giving M. nairobiensis full species status. M. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers both M. mocquardi and M. nairobiensis to be synonyms of M. lonnbergi. More work is needed to resolve the taxonomic status of these species.
According to Perret (1976) this form is possibly a member of the genus Leptopelis (the type specimen is a juvenile). It cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
Schiøtz (1999) considers the validity of this species to be questionable.

This species is a member of the still unresolved Afrixalus quadrivittatus complex. It is not yet clear whether or not it will prove to be a valid species, or whether or not it is a synonym of another species within this complex.

We follow Rödel (2000) and Pickersgill (2007) in considering Afrixalus vittiger to be specifically distinct from Afrixalus quadrivittatus. A. vittiger is part of a complex that includes A. upembae and A. quadrivittatus.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius pusillus. It cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

This species is a taxonomic complex which requires further taxonomic research (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
Earlier records of Breviceps mossambicus from northern Tanzania might belong to B. fichus.
This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
This is a restricted concept of H. cinereus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. raymondi (Conradie et al. 2013)
The type specimen of this species has been lost, and it is not possible to apply this name to any known species in the wild (A. Schiøtz pers. comm.).
Lawson (1993) suggested that this species might be conspecific with Hyperolius pardalis, but this is not accepted by J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.).

Some of the older K. senegalensis records in the Nigerian, Cameroonian, and central Chad (and maybe even further west) require re-checking as there is a possibility of being K. wazae (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

This species is part of the Hyperolius tuberculatus Group in the H. viridiflavus complex (Schiøtz 1999). It might be conspecific with H. tuberculatus, but according to Laurent (1976) they are possibly sympatric in Ubangi.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Phrynomantis bifasciata by Lanza (1990), where it had been placed by Laurent (1965).
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius viridiflavus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

The four subspecies are likely to constitute four separate species, especially since H. f. lamtoensis Schiøtz, 1967 occurs sympatrically with H. f. fusciventris in southwestern Côte d’Ivoire, and with H. f. burtoni Schiøtz, 1963 in southeastern Côte d’Ivoire (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). However, Leaché et al. (2006) consider that subspecies H. f. burtoni, H. f. fusciventris and H. f. lamtoensis would be more appropriately treated as full species. Herein we retain these subspecies until their taxonomic status can be resolved.
The relationship between this species and Hyperolius platyceps requires clarification.

The taxonomy of this species is confused. Records from Uganda might belong to Hyperolius langi (Schiøtz 1999). In this account, we assign all records of H. langi from Uganda to H. kuligae, pending resolution of their taxonomic status.
We follow Rödel and Ernst (2003), Schiøtz (1999), and Channing et al. (2013) rather than Channing et al. (2002), in considering this to be a species distinct from Hyperolius nasutus.

The relationship of this species to Hyperolius kuligae and H. platyceps needs clarification. We follow Schiøtz (1999) in assigning records of this species from Uganda (e.g., Drewes and Vindum 1994, Vonesh 2001) to H. kuligae.

Poynton and Broadley (1987) questioned whether or not this species is is different from Hyperolius bocagei. Schiøtz and van Daele (2003) examined the type of H. bocagei, and found it to be a synonym of the the Hyperolius viridiflavus Group, probably H. parallelus. It therefore seems likely that some of the more recent records in the literature of H. bocagei actually refer to H. kachalolae.
This species is apparently closely related to Hyperolius atrigularis, according to Laurent (1957).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any of their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated renschi as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including it under H. mariae.
The former understanding of this concept has been revised and certain parts of its range have been assigned to other species (both newly described and previously synonymized).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously.
This species probably comprises at least two cryptic species (Schiøtz 1999).
This poorly known species possibly intergrades with Phrynomantis bifasciatus (Poynton and Broadley 1985).

This species is sometimes regarded as a subspecies of Hyperolius steindachneri. Lawson (1993) suggested that Hyperolius bolifambae might be a synonym of this species, but this is not accepted by J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.). We follow J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) in considering records from Korup National Park in southwestern Cameroon to belong to H. bolifambae.
This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius kivuensis, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously.

During the 2004 assessment of this species, it was treated as a likely synonym with Hyperolius wermuthi, which followed Schiøtz (1999). However, the 2015 update of the assessment for this species now considers H. wermuthi as synonymous with this concept (L. Sandberger and D. Frost pers. comm. July 2016).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated broadleyi as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including it under H. swynnertoni.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius concolor, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
The type specimen of this species has been lost, and it is not possible to apply this name to any known species in the wild (Schiøtz pers. comm.).
This species could be an aberrant form of Hyperolius discodactylus (Laurent 1972).
This species is closely related to Leptopelis nordequatorialis and L. oryi (Perret 1976).
Leptolelis broadleyi has been synonymized under this species by Channing (2001). This species is closely related to Leptopelis concolor.
This species is sometimes considered to be a subspecies of Kassina senegalensis (see, for example, Schiøtz (1999).
We follow Amiet (2007) in removing Kassina decorata from the synonymy of this species. The relationship between Kassina maculosa and K. merstensi also requires clarification.
There are doubts about the taxonomic validity of this taxon.
This species might be a synonym of Leptopelis brevirostris (Perret pers. comm.).

The use of the name Leptopelis bocagii does not appear to match the species originally described by Günther in 1864 (Amiet 2004), and so the name is used here in the sense used by Schiøtz (1999) pending clarification of its status. In any case, it is probably a complex of more than one species (Amiet 2004; A. Schiøtz pers. comm.).
This name has not been matched to any known species in the wild.
This species is probably closely related to Leptopelis modestus, and is perhaps conspecific with it (Schiøtz 1999).

The taxonomic status of this form, in particular its relationship to Leptopelis parbocagii, L. mossambicus and L. broadleyi, still requires further clarification (Poynton and Broadley 1987, Schiøtz 1999).
This species is closely related to Leptopelis argenteus and Leptopelis broadleyi. We follow Schiøtz (1999) in considering all three to be separate species.

It is not yet known whether or not specimens from Cameroon belong to a different, undescribed species (Amiet 2004). The large gap between the eastern and western populations could be due to under-sampling (Amiet 2004).

The taxonomic status of this species is very uncertain. It was placed in the synonymy of Leptopelis flavomaculatus by Laurent (1973), but it was provisionally resurrected by Poynton (1985) and Poynton and Broadley (1987). Schiøtz (1999) suggested that might be conspecific with L. mossambicus.

This species was traditionally called Leptopelis hyloides. However, Rödel (2007) and Schiøtz (1999) showed that L. hyloides is in fact a synonym of Leptopelis viridis. As a result, Rödel (2007) provided a new name for this taxon, Leptopelis spiritusnoctis.
This species is closely related to Leptopelis anchietae and L. oryi (Perret 1976).

If Hylambates cubito-albus Boulenger, 1906 (type locality: Kribi, Cameroon, and Unyoro, east of Lake Albert) is a synonym of this species, as is generally supposed, then this species has a much wider distribution. However, such a range seems improbable, and this synonymy should be re-examined.

Records from western Kenya previously assigned to this species were assigned to Leptopelis mackayi by Köhler et al. (2006). Records from eastern Democratic Republic of Congo have been assigned to Leptopelis mtoewaate by Portillo and Greenbaum (2014). In addition, Leptopelis aubryioides has been removed from the broader concept of this species by Köhler (2009) and occurs from Southeastern Nigeria through southern Cameroon to Gabon and southern Republic of Congo.

Taxonomic work still needs to be carried out on this species as the complex remains unresolved (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
This species is closely related to Leptopelis nordequatorialis and L. anchietae (Perret 1976).

Hylambates rufus aubryioides was elevated from the subspecies level of Leptopelis modestus and made a senior synonym of Leptopelis omissus by Köhler (2009), which has led to this species concept of Leptopelis aubryoides.

This species is referred to as Leptopelis sp. 1 in Amiet (1983) and as Leptopelis sp. aff. calcaratus in Largen and Dowsett-Lemaire (1991).
The distinction between this species and Leptopelis bocagii remains unclear (Schiøtz 1999).

The name Leptopelis hyloides (Boulenger, 1906) has traditionally been used for a widespread West African forest treefrog. However, Rödel (2007) and Schiøtz (1999) show that this name is a synonym of Leptopelis viridis. The frogs previously known as L. hyloides have now been named as Leptopelis spiritusnoctis (Rödel 2007).
This species has previously been assigned to the genus Nesionixalus.
Astylosternus laticephalus was split from this species (Rödel et al. 2012).
This is comprised of a complex of species and ongoing work by Barej, Blackburn, Rödel, Stuart, and colleagues will result in recognizing multiple species.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and P. vulpiae (Barej et al. 2010). Also, this species was synonymized with P. johsntoni (Barej et al. 2010) until its revalidation as a distinct species by Sánchez-Vialas et al. (2018).
This is a restricted concept of Petropedetes parkeri following the split of the broader concept into this and Petropedetes euskircheni (Barej et al. 2010).
This is a complex of at least four or five species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
It is likely a complex of species (Gvozdik pers. comm., Nov 2012). It is possible that the eastern populations of this species should be separated as Phrynobatrachus discodactylus.
It is likely that animals from more than one species have been assigned to this name (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).
This species is a complex comprising of several species (Zimkus et al. 2010, Gvozdik pers. comm. November 2012).
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear.
Phrynobatrachus cryptotis might be a junior synonym of P. mababiensis (Poynton and Broadley 1985b).
We follow Uyeda et al. (2007) in restricting Phrynobatrachus dispar to Príncipe. Frogs from São Tomé previously included within this species are now treated as Phrynobatrachus leveleve.
It is likely that more than one species is referred to under this name (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).
It is probable that the West African and eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo populations comprise separate species.

J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that this species, together with Phrynobatrachus manengoubensis, might be synonyms of Phrynobatrachus werneri (or they might collectively constitute parts of a complex of more than one species).
Phrynobatrachus albolabris has been synonymized under this species by Frétey (2008) and P. vogti has been synonymized under this concept by Ofori-Boateng et al (2018).
We follow Largen (2001) in removing Phrynobatrachus scheffleri from the synonymy of this specie and also recognize P. albifer as a valid species.
This species was moved from the genus Phrynobatrachus to the genus Arthroleptis by Zimkus and Larsen (2009).
This species might be a synonym of Phrynobatrachus acridoides (see Inger (1968)).
The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Phrynobatrachus mababiensis and P. ukingensis requires clarification (Poynton and Broadley 1985b).
It is likely that the northern and southern populations belong to separate species.

The taxonomy of this species is not yet clarified. Laurent (1972) considered it to be a synonym of Phrynobatrachus calcaratus, and Perret (pers. comm.) considers that it might be conspecific with P. cornutus.
This form is probably a complex of at least three species (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.).
We follow Largen (2001) in removing this species from the synonymy of Phrynobatrachus minutus. It is a poorly circumscribed species taxonomically (Pickersgill 2007).
This species' taxonomic status is not clear.
This species' taxonomic status is unclear (Rödel pers. comm.).

This species was known only from the type locality, but the more widespread Phrynobatrachus alticola was later determined to be a synonym (Rödel et al. 2005). The type specimen of P. alticola has been lost, hence the synonymy was difficult to confirm.
This species could be a complex of more than one species of several cryptic species (R.C. Tinsley pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear.
The taxonomic status of this form requires further investigation.
The taxonomic status of this form is uncertain.

There is long-recognized undescribed species richness in X. tropicalis and X. epitropicalis and in progress work by Evans, Blackburn, and colleagues (D. Blackburn pers. comm. 2012).This form is a tetraploid species. There are probably other species to be discovered in this genus (R.C. Tinsley pers. comm.). The Sanaga River in Cameroon has arbitrarily been set as the boundary between this species and Xenopus tropicalis, pending more information (Loumont 1983).
This form is one of a group of cryptic species resembling Xenopus fraseri but distinguished from it by chromosome number (2n=72) and mating call.

Xenopus allofraseri and Xenopus parafraseri have previously been confused with this species and subpopulations from Bioko Island (Equatorial Guinea), Cameroon, Congo, DRC and Gabon have now been allocated to these two species (Evans et al. 2015).
This species is a diploid species in the Xenopus fraseri Group (Loumont, 1986).
We follow Channing and Howell (2006) and Pickersgill (2007) in treating this as a species distinct from Xenopus laevis.
This species was previously confused with Ptychadena bibroni (Perret 1997, 1999).

This species was previously mistakenly referred to as Ptychadena maccarthyensis. The species previously called Ptychadena bibroni in several publications is in fact Ptychadena pujoli (see Lamotte and Ohler (1997) for details).
Records from Angola, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Malawi and southern Democratic Republic of Congo refer to Ptychadena guibei.
This form is sometimes considered to be a synonym of Ptychadena mossambica.
This species was previously confused with Ptychadena tournieri (Perret 1991).
This form might prove to be a complex of several species (Largen 2001).
This species was previously mistakenly assigned to Ptychadena bibroni (see Lamotte and Ohler 1997).
The southern and eastern populations are now separated as Ptychadena taenioscelis, following Poynton and Broadley (1985b).

We follow Perret (1987) and Channing (1993) in considering Ptychadena floweri to be a synonym of P. schillukorum, but note that this opinion is not shared by Poynton and Broadley (1985b). Rödel (2000) considers the matter to be still unresolved. S. Baha El Din (pers. comm.) supports the current arrangement.
This form probably comprises several species.
This species is commonly referred to as Ptychadena schubotzi, but it was shown by Largen (2001) to be a synonym of P. tellinii.
A record for Hildebrantia ornata from Guelta Metraucha, Mauritania, was determined to be Ptychadena trinodis (Padial and De la Riva 2004).
Tarrant et al. (2008) note that there are still taxonomic difficulties associated with this genus and good delimitation of species still requires further taxonomic work.
This species occurs in sympatry with A. fuscigula.
Perret (1994) cast doubt on the distinctiveness of this species from Aubria subsigillata. This taxon was discussed and revalidated by Ohler (1996).
Recent studies of the specimens of this species have confirmed that Cacosternum leleupi is a valid species (E. Scott pers. comm.).
We follow Channing et al. (2005) in separating this species from Cacosternum boettgeri.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Cacosternum boettgeri by Lambiris (1988), where it had been placed by Poynton (1964).

Channing and Davenport (2002) synonymized this species with Strongylopus merumontanus, and Channing and Howell (2006) follow this arrangement. However, Poynton (2004) shows that S. merumontanus is a separate species known only from higher elevations on Mount Meru in northern Tanzania.
This species was recently changed from the genus Arthroleptis to Tomopterna by Ohler and Frétey (2008).
The subpopulation in central DRC is likely to be another species, as the name Amnirana amnicola is currently thought to be a complex of about three species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

Largen (1997) examined the only known specimen (a syntype) of this species and concluded that it was most similar to Pelophylax ridibundus. It should, therefore, be placed in the genus Pelophylax. It is possibly a synonym of a member of the P. ridibundus complex.

This species was removed from synonymy with Chiromantis petersi by Poynton (2000). However, taxonomic problems with this Chiromantis in northeastern Africa remain (Poynton 2000; Largen 2001), and it appears that there are undescribed species in Somalia and Uganda.

We follow Poynton (2000) in considering Chiromantis kelleri to be a separate species from C. petersi. However, taxonomic problems with this Chiromantis in northeastern Africa remain (Poynton 2000; Largen 2001), and it appears that there are undescribed species in Somalia and Uganda.

This diploid species has recently been separated from the tetraploid nominal form Odontophrynus americanus; the geographical range of O. maisuma is narrower than O. americanus, and nestled in the range of this species (Rosset 2008).

It is a cryptic diploid species that is confused with the tetraploid O. americanus. It is therefore possible that some records (e.g. Braun and Braun 1980, Nuñez et al. 2004 and others) or specimens in herpetological collections belong to O. maisuma (S. Rossett pers. comm. October 2012).

This is a newly described species (Channing 2012) from coastal Namaqualand, South Africa. The description is based on morphology and mitochondrial DNA (16S rRNA). The species is most closely related to Breviceps namaquensis.

This taxon is a complex of more than one species (S. Rosset pers. comm. January 2018).

Diploid subpopulations in Cordoba, Argentina were separated from the tetraploid nominal form americanus to create the species Odontophrynus cordobae (Martino and Sinsch 2002). In addition, diploid subpopulations along coastal areas of Uruguay and Brazil belong to the newly described O. maisuma (Rosset 2008). Other diploid subpopulations elsewhere in the range of O. americanus might represent new species.

Grandisonia diminutiva was considered as a junior synonym of G. larvata following Nussbaum and Wilkinson (1989). It is now considered a synonym of Grandisonia sechellensis by Wilkinson and Nussbaum (2006), hence it is no longer included here.
Grandisonia diminutiva, previously assessed under synonymy of Grandisonia larvata, has been subsequently placed in the synonymy of Grandisonia sechellensis by Wilkinson and Nussbaum (2006).
This species was removed from synonymy of Tomopterna cryptosis based on molecular and morphological data (Zimkus and Larson, 2011).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Tomopterna cryptosis based on molecular and morphology data (Zimkus and Larson 2011).

The morphological similarity of the Osteocephalus duellmani holotype with Osteocephalus festae specimens deposited in the QCAZ collection suggests that it could be a junior synonym (S.R. Ron pers. obs. In: Ortiz and Ron 2020).
Kok and Kalamandeen (2008) provided an account for this species as Rhinatrema cf bivittatum.
The taxonomic concept excludes Gastrotheca marsupiata lojana Parker, 1932, which is recognized by Duellman et al. (2014) as a good species, i.e. G. lojana.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Limnonectes kuhlii by McLeod et al. (2011).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

This is a newly described species (Channing and Baptista 2013) from southern Africa as a result of a systematic review including analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology and advertisement calls. This form was previously known as Amietia fuscigula and occurs in sympatry with A. delalandii and A. fuscigula.
This species can be distinguished from the other species in the genus based on several morphological and molecular characters.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.
This species excludes the southern forms known as Alsodes coppingeri, previously synonymized under Alsodes monticola by Lynch (1968) but subsequently removed from synonymy by Formas et al. (2008).

Removed from the synonymy of Alsodes monticola by Formas et al. (2008) where it had been placed by Lynch (1968). 

It has been suggested that Alsodes australis could be a synonym of a this species (Blotto et al. 2013), however, further taxonomic work is required to verify this.
Blotto et al. (2013) redelimited the species and removed Alsodes neuquensis from synonymy as a distinct species.
Blotto et al. (2013) removed Alsodes neuquensis from synonymy as a distinct species from A. gargola.

This species was previously known as Eusophus aff. roseus due to morphological similarities (Nuñez et al. 2012). Although, Correa et al. (2017) synonymized Eupsophus altor with E. migueli, Suárez-Villota et al. (2018) hypothesised that both are good species restoring the previous taxonomic arrangement. The taxonomic criteria used by Cuevas and Sanhueza (2020) agrees with the results obtained by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), recognizing E. migueli and E. altor as different taxonomic units.
Similar to Pleurodema diplolister and previously confused with that species (Maciel and Nunes 2010).
Confused with Pleurodema kriegi prior to its naming (Valetti et al. 2009).

Removed from the synonymy of Pseudopaludicola mystacalis on the basis of karyology by Fávero et al. (2011), where it had been placed by Haddad and Cardoso (1987). Pseudopaludicola ameghini and P. ternetzi share similar external morphologies, advertisement calls with overlapping ranges (Pansonato et al. 2013, Cardozo and Toledo 2013), and chromosome number 2n=20 (Fávero et al. 2011, Cardozo et al. 2016, as P. ternetzi), making identification difficult. Paraguayan records formerly considered P. ternetzi are assigned to this species (Lavilla et al. 2016; F. Brusquetti pers. comm. 2020).

authority: Pansonato, Morais, Ávila, Kawashita-Ribeiro, Strussmann & Martins, 2012
Toledo, Siqueira, Duarte, Veiga-Menoncello, Recco-Pimentel & Haddad, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Atelopus spumarius (Lötters et al. 2005). Silva et al. (2020) provided molecular evidence that this is a species complex with subpopulations south of the Amazon River being a distinct, but unnamed species.

Removed from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2011) where it had been placed by Goin (1964). Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2011) also placed H. crurifasciatum, H. eccentricum and H. ignioculus into synonymy under this species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptodactylus bolivianus (Heyer and de Sá 2011). According to Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019), records from eastern part of Venezuelan Guayana previously assigned to Leptodactylus bolivianus are actually L. guianensis (e.g., Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) from Triunfo, Sierra de Lema).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachium nigrops (Hamidy et al. 2012).

This species is split from the Leptobrachium nigrops (complex). Although in mtDNA data, the genetic distances between two allopatric subpopulations from Belitung and costal area of Borneo are not small (5.5–5.8%), nuclear data show that the two subpopulations should be recognized as a single species (Hamidy et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Kalophrynus pleurostigma (Matsui et al. 2012).

This is a restricted concept of Kalophrynus pleurostigma following the split of the broader concept into this, K. tiomanensis (Chan et al. 2011), K. limbooliati (Matsui et al. 2012), and K. meizon (Zug 2015), K. anya, which was split from this species and from K. interlineatus (Zug 2015), and K. kiewi (Matsui et al. 2017).

Taylor (1943) first described Tomodactylus albolabris, which Hedges (1989) later reclassified as a species of Eleutherodactylus (Syrrhophus). Prompted by this merger, Lynch (1991) proposed E. dixoni as a replacement name for E. albolabris, believing it to be a junior secondary homonym of Microbatrachylus albolabris (Taylor 1939) because that genus had also been combined with Eleutherodactylus (Lynch 1965). However, M. albolabris had already been synonymized with M. pygmaeus by Duellman (1961), obviating the need for a replacement name. Thus, the earliest name available for this taxon is Eleutherodactylus (Syrrhophus) albolabris.

Eleutherodactylus dixoni has now been synonymized under E. albolabris (Frost 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Kalophrynus pleurostigma (Chan et al. 2011).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Microhyla borneensis by Matsui (2011). Accounts prior to 2011 conflated Microhyla malang and Microhyla borneensis (= Microhyla nepenthicola) as Microhyla borneensis, but presumably are mostly based on Microhyla malang (Frost 2018).

Microhyla nepenthicola has been placed in synonymy with this species, and this is a restricted concept of Microhyla borneensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Microhyla malang (Matsui 2011). Accounts prior to 2011 conflated Microhyla malang and Microhyla borneensis (= Microhyla nepenthicola) as Microhyla borneensis, but presumably are mostly based on Microhyla malang (Frost 2018). 

Taxonomic work is ongoing with this species and related species, which may revise the species status (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Amolops marmoratus by Dever et al. (2012).

This is a restricted concept of Amolops marmoratus following the split of the broader concept into this, A. afghanus and A. indoburmanensis (Dever et al. 2012).

This species was previously synonymized with Amolops cremnobatus and Rana senchalensis by Dubois (2000).

Amolops nepalicus was synonymized with Amolops marmoratus by Dubois (2000), however, A. nepalicus was later revalidated as a distinct species by Khatiwada et al. (2020).
This species has been moved from Metamagnusia to Asterophrys (Rivera et al. 2017).
Formerly Callulops slateri (Dubois, 1988) according to Günther (2009).
In the Amolops monticola group according to the original publication (Frost 2014).
Dever et al. (2012) noted that this taxon, formerly confused with Amolops marmoratus, is composed of distinctive populations that may represent distinct lineages.
A number of different forms are currently included in Leptolalax pelodytoides that might prove to be taxonomically recognizable.

Phylogenetic analysis of this genus showed the presence of multiple lineages in what had originally been attributed to two species (Capensibufo rosei and C. tradouwi). Within C. rosei, at least five distinct lineages are present, such that Capensibufo rosei on the Cape Peninsula is now recognized as the only member of this taxon, with others being Capensibufo deceptus, C. magistratus and C. selenophos (Tolley et al. 2010, Cressey et al. 2014, Channing et al. 2017).
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.
This species has been allocated to the Proceratophrys cristatus group (Ávila et al. 2011).

authority: (Ohler, Wollenberg, Grosjean, Hendrix, Vences, Ziegler & Dubois, 2011)
taxonomicNotes: Confused with Leptolalax bourreti prior to to its naming according to the original publication (Frost 2022).

authority: (Ohler, Wollenberg, Grosjean, Hendrix, Vences, Ziegler & Dubois, 2011)
taxonomicNotes: Confused with Leptolalax bourreti prior to its naming according to the original publication (Frost 2022).
Confused with Xenophrys parva (as Megophrys parva) according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
Removed from the synonymy of Leptolalax oshanensis by Ohler et al. (2011) where it had been placed by Dubois (1981).
This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella oshanensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Leptolax minimus [now Leptobrachella minima] by Ohler et al. (2011).

authority: (Bain, Lathrop, Murphy, Orlov & Ho Thu Cuc, 2003)
taxonomicNotes: Stuart et al. (2010) discussed and rejected the synonymy of Amolops daorum with Amolops mengyangensis.

This species was treated as part of Amolops chunganensis, until it was described as a separate taxon by Wu and Tian (1995). However, Fei et al. (1999) treated it as a synonym of A. chunganensis, but Ohler (2007) demonstrated its validity, and also treated Rana daorum as a synonym of this species.

Amolops daorum was removed from synonymy with this species by Stuart et al. (2010).
Confused with Hylarana chalconota prior to its naming according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Orlov, Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Ananjeva, Nguyen, Sang & Geissler, 2012
taxonomicNotes: In the Rhacophorus calcaneus group of Orlov et al. (2012). Confused with Rhacophorus calcaneus prior to its naming by Inger et al. (1999). The original publication noted the following localities (originally as Rhacophorus calcaneus) as doubtful: Tam Dao, Vinh Phuc and Huong Son, Ha Tinh (likely based on Rhacophorus orlovi); Chu Yang Sin, Dak Lake and Bidoup, Lac Duong, Lam Dong (likely based on Rhacophorus vampyrus); Da Teh, Lam Dong (likely confused with Rhacophorus rhodopus) (Frost 2013).

Split from Rhacophorus reinwardtii by Chan and Grismer (2010) as the subpopulation from Southern Thailand and Peninsular Malaysia was found to be morphologically distinct from Javan and Bornean subpopulations.
Split from the Limnonectes kuhlii complex by McLeod, Kelly and Barley (2012).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Andrias sligoi (Turvey et al. 2019).
The original name Rana gracilis (Wiegmann 1834), was already occupied by Rana gracilis (Gravenhorst 1829). This species was removed from synonymy with F. limnocharis by Dubois and Ohler (2000).
This species was split from F. limnocharis by Matsui, Toda and Ota (2007).
This species was split from Fejervarya limnocharis by Djong et al. (2011).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Zhangixalus (Rhacophorus) hongchibaensis (Li et al. 2012) and Z. franki (Ninh et al. 2020). This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This form was previously thought to be conspecific with Rhacophorus dugritei (Orlov et al. 2001), but was removed from its synonymy by Li et al. (2012).

Tadpoles of this species have never been recorded, and so it has been argued that this form should not be assigned to the genus Amolops but instead to Odorrana. It has since been placed in Odorrana (Fei et al. 2009).
For the purposes of this assessment both the western and eastern subpopulations are considered to be this species (see Crottini et al. 2012).

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011
Andreone, Rosa, Noël, Crottini, Vences & Raxworthy, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been considered to be a synonym of Bufo gargarizans (Cantor, 1842).
In the Peltophryne peltocephala group.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Cardioglossa inornata (elevated from subspecies level) (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
Assessors of the Andes GAA workshop in Ecuador raised questions as to the taxonomic validity of this species, but V.R. Morales (pers. comm.) is convinced that it is a valid species.

The morphological characters of the specimens from Guiviare are very similar to those of the type series of Allobates picachos. Based on this data, the specimens from Guaviare are thought to correspond to this species. However, the possibility that there are molecular differences between the populations, such that they are different species, cannot be not ruled out (M. Anganoy pers. comm. February 2019).
This species was transferred to the genus Andinophryne by Hoogmoed (1985) and subsequently transferred to Rhaebo (Ron et al. 2015).
This species is similar to Ectopoglossus (was Anomaloglossus) lacrimosus according to Grant, Humphrey and Myers (1997).
It is likely that this species is a complex and further taxonomic work is needed to determine whether there are undescribed species in this complex (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. December 2018).
It seems very unlikely that the Panamanian and Colombian specimens refer to the same species (Grant pers. comm.).
Specimens from the Cordillera de Mérida in Venezuela are now referred to Bolitoglossa guaramacalensis (Wake pers. comm.).

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. Lynch (1999) points out that the taxonomic identity may be doubtful and the only specimen from Valdivia in Antioquia may be associated with Caecilia subnigricans.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. Lynch (1999) suggested that this species is restricted to the eastern Andes of Colombia, with specimens from Cundinamarca.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. Not all known subpopulations necessarily belong to the same species, and some subpopulations might be conspecific with Caecilia isthmica (Lynch 1999).

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It was removed from the synonymy of Caecilia tentaculata by Savage and Wake (2001). In this account, we provisionally assign all of Lynch's (1999) Pacific records of C. tentaculata to C. isthmica. However, Savage and Wake (2001) do not cite Lynch (1999), and they did not examine the more extensive Colombian material studied by Lynch. This means that they place C. isthmica in Colombia based only on Dunn's (1942) record. However, Lynch (1999) reports that none of the Colombian specimens that he examined matches Dunn's (1942) description, and, further, that he suspects that C. guntheri and the Pacific C. tentaculata (= C. isthmica sensu Savage and Wake 2001) might be conspecific. If this is the case, C. isthmica would be the valid name.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

According to Fletcher-Lazo (2002), this species is endemic to Ecuador. Lynch (1999) considers that this species does not belong to the Colombian fauna. Nonetheless, he uses the name C. "pachynema" referring to an endemic species on the northern part of the Colombian Cordillera Central. Arteaga-Navarro et al. (2013) suggested that Caecilia buckleyi is not synonymous with Caecilia pachynema, although evidence has yet to be presented. This account includes both the Ecuadorian and Colombian subpopulations.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this species as incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
Catenazzi et al. (2012) confirmed the placement of this species in Centrolene.
Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this species as incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this species as incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
This species is potentially conspecific with Colostethus fraterdanieli (Grant and Castro 1998).
This form might be a synonym of another species (J.D. Lynch pers. comm.).
This is possibly a species complex (D. Mejía pers. comm. November 2018).

There is taxonomic confusion surrounding this species (T. Grant and J.D. Lynch pers. comm.). Grant et al. (2006) could not allocate the species beyond Dendrobatidae, merely retaining it in a non-taxon "Colostethus". Most recently, it was transferred to Leucostethus on phylogenetic grounds by Marín-Castaño et al. (2018).
This species is possibly conspecific with Colostethus fraterdanieli (T. Grant pers. comm.).
Removed from synonymy with Boophis rhodoscelis by Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010.

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: The first data on this species were possibly recorded by Andreone (1994), who noted a small brown Boophis from the Ranomafana area as B. miniatus. Glaw et al. (2001) gave further information on the corresponding voucher specimens from Ifanadiana, a locality not far from Mahakajy (Glaw et al. 2010).
The subspecies occidentalis has now been raised to full specific rank (Andreone et al. 2002).

Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the status of the Colostethus fraterdanieli group. This species was transferred from Colostethus to Leucostethus on phylogenetic grounds by Marín-Castaño et al. (2018).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis majori group, and previously confused with Boophis brachychir, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Köhler, Glaw, Rosa, Gehring, Pabijan, Andreone & Vences, 2011
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis goudoti group, the sister taxon of Boophis boehmei, and prior to its naming confused with Boophis boehmei, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis albipunctatus group, according to the original publication (Frost 2013). It has also been referred to as Boophis sp. aff. ankaratra "Andohahela fast" by Glaw & Vences (2007:172–173) and as Boophis sp. 20 by Vieites et al. (2009).
The species rank of this taxon is supported by phenotypic and genetic data (Díaz et al. 2003, Rodríguez et al. 2011).

Four subspecies have been described: Peltophryne longinasus longinasus in Pinar del Río; P. l. cajalbanensis in the Cajálbana Plateau, also in Pinar del Río; P. l. dunni in the mountains of Guamuhaya; and P. l. ramsdeni in the Sierra del Guaso (González Alonso et al. 2012). Two of the subspecies (dunni and ramsdeni) have been elevated to species status (Hedges et al. 2019).
We follow Coloma (2002) in considering Atelopus leoperezii as a synonym of this species.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Atelopus marinkellei (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005).
The subpopulation on Gorgona Island could be recognized as a distinct species, A. gracilis (Rueda-Almonacid et al. 2005), but is retained here pending a formal taxonomic treatment.
This species was previously confused with Atelopus longirostris and Atelopus lynchi, according to Rivero and Morales (1995).
Specimens discussed by Cochran and Goin (1970) were subsequently named as Atelopus echeverrii.

Atelopus pachydermus was redescribed by Coloma et al. (2007). Atelopus pachydermus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of body size and different colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Atelopus barbotini (Lötters et al. 2011) and Atelopus hoogmoedi (Lötters et al. 2005). Some specimens from Brazilian Amazonia were previously confused with both Atelopus pulcher and Atelopus spumarius (e.g., Lötters et al. 2002, Lima et al. 2006, Rojas-Ahumada and Menin 2010, Jorge et al. 2016), both of which differ in morphology and advertisement call, and now belong to a separate species, Atelopus manauensis (Jorge et al. 2020). Nevertheless, this is still a complex of species, with the possibly of up to three species occurring in Ecuador alone (D. Armijos, L. Oyagata, J. Webster and J. Caceres pers. comms. 2020).
Some subpopulations from the central and northern part of its range are considered a species complex (D. Mejía pers. comm. August 2016).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelopus ignescens by Lynch (1986).

The species may be a misidentification of Atelopus nahumae (L.A. Rueda-Solano pers. comm. February 2017). The description of the paratopotypes in Rivero (1963) show no difference with A. nahumae, which was described by Ruíz-Carranza et al. (1994) and this species is also found in Serranía de San Lorenzo (L.A. Rueda-Solano pers. comm. February 2017).

authority: Acosta-Galvis, Rueda-Almonacid, Velásquez-Álvarez, Sánchez-Pacheco & Peña Prieto, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Atelopus mittermeieri is distinguished from other species of the genus in the region by its colour patterns (Acosta-Galvis et al. 2006).
Referred to as Boophis sp. aff. rappiodes "South" by Glaw and Vences (2007).

authority: Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis albipunctatus group, according to the original publication (Frost 2014).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis albipunctatus group, not morphologically distinguishable from Boophis ankaratra and Boophis schoboeae, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
The sister species of Boophis majori according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
Redescribed and removed from the synonymy of Boophis goudotii by Glaw et al. 2010.
Boophis obscura was removed from synonymy with this species (Glaw et al. 2010).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis majori group, and previously confused with Boophis rhodoscelis, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Köhler, Glaw, Rosa, Gehring, Pabijan, Andreone & Vences, 2011
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis goudoti group, the sister taxon of Boophis boehmei + Boophis fayi, and prior to its naming confused with Boophis boehmei, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis albilabris group according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
Removed from synonymy with Boophis boehmei by Vences et al. (2010) and in the Boophis goudotii group according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis majori group, and previously confused with Boophis madagascariensis, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis luteus group and previously confused with Boophis elenae according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Glaw, Köhler, De la Riva, Vieites & Vences, 2010
taxonomicNotes: In the Boophis goudoti group according to the original publication (Frost 2013). There is uncertainty about the taxonomy of the two known specimens (F. Glaw pers. comm. Nov. 2014).

In the Boophis luteus group and the sister species of Boophis luteus according to the original publication (Frost 2013). Vences et al. 2011 found that there are two genetic lineages with significant divergence.
In the Boophis albilabris group, most similar to Boophis occidentalis and previously confused with it, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

In the Boophis ulftunni group, probably related to the Boophis microtympanum group, and with related populations (likely different species) in the Tsararano, Marojejy, and Anjanaharibe-Sud regions, according to the original publication (Frost 2013). The population from Marojejy differs genetically from the population at the type locality, but it has been included in this taxon (Wollenberg et al. 2008)

authority: Crottini, Glaw, Casiraghi, Jenkins, Mercurio, Randrianantoandro, Randrianirina & Andreone, 2011
taxonomicNotes: This species has been referred to as Gephyromantis sp. aff . corvus “Bemaraha” by Glaw and Vences (2007), as Gephyromantis sp. 10 “Bemaraha” by Vieites et al. (2009), and Gephyromantis sp. aff . corvus by Bora et al. (2010) (Crottini et al. 2011).
This species is similar to and can be confused with sympatrically occurring Gephyromantis corvus from which it can be distinguished from its advertisment calls (Mercurio and Andreone 2007).
In the Gephyromantis decaryi complex and formerly referred to as Gephryomantis sp. 8 according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
Closely related to Gephyromantis eiselti and Gephyromantis thelenae according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
This species has been addressed before as Gephyromantis spec. aff. horridus "Marojejy" by Glaw and Vences (2007) and as confirmed candidate species Gephyromantis spec. 11 by Vieites et al. (2009).
In the Gephyromantis boulengeri group according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
Resurrected from the synonymy of Gephryomantis boulengeri by Wollenberg et al. 2012 (Frost 2013).
Gephyromantis verrucosus was removed from synonymy with this species; its taxonomy is in need of further revision (F. Glaw pers. comm., Nov. 2014).

Most similar to Guibemantis punctatus according to the original publication, where it was also noted that a population in Anjananaharibe-Sud Special Reserve may apply to this species or a closely related one (Frost 2013).
Most similar to Guibemantis bicalcaratus according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
Referred to by Glaw and Vences (2007) as Platypelis sp. aff. mavomavo 2, by Wollenberg et al. (2008) and as Platypelis sp. 4 by Vieites et al. (2009).
The species rank of this taxon, originally assessed with morphologic data, has not been validated by genetic data.
The species rank of this taxon originally assessed with morphologic data has not been validated by genetic data.
The species rank of this taxon originally assessed with morphologic data has not been validated by genetic data.
This is a restricted concept of Eleutherodactylus glamyrus following the split of the broader concept into this and E. cattus (Rodríguez et al. 2017).

Genetic evidence suggests that this taxa belongs to the Eleutherodactylus planirostris guanahacabibes species complex (Heinicke et al. 2011) genetic introgression might be common among these frogs and additional studies are needed to validate its species rank.
Genetic evidence suggests that this taxon is conspecific with Eleutherodactylus limbatus (Rodríguez et al. 2013). Additional taxonomic studies are needed to validate its species rank.

authority: Hasan, Kuramoto, Islam, Alam, Khan & Sumida, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Eleutherodactylus michaelschmidi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of external characters, advertisement call and chromosome patterns (Díaz et al. 2007).

According to recent studies, molecular and morphological characters are not sufficiently suitable to differentiate between N. derjugini and N. microspilotus, contrary to previous assumptions (Schneider and Schneider 2011, Najafimajd et al. 2013, Schneider and Schneider 2013, Hendrix et al. 2014). Therefore, we follow regarding papers, accept N. derjugini as a valid species and N. microspilotus as its junior synonym due to taxonomical priority reasons.
Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this species as incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
This species could be a synonym of Incilius coniferus (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019).
This species was confused with Incilius occidentalis prior to naming, and has since been split off as a new species (Santos-Barrera and Flores-Villela 2011).
This was formerly classified as Rhinella granulosa, but all specimens from Panama are now classified as Rhinella centralis (Narvaes and Rodrigues 2009).
This species belongs to the Craugastor rugulosus group and there may be more than one cryptic species occurring sympatrically with this species, further taxonomic molecular work should be conducted.
García-Rodríguez et al. (2016) provided molecular, acoustic, and ecological evidence of the distinctiveness of this species from Diasporus tigrillo.
This species was removed from synonymy with Gastrophryne olivacea by Streicher et al. (2012).

authority: Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Confused with Bolitoglossa rufescens prior to its naming (Rovito et al. 2012).
Removed from the synonymy of Bolitoglossa morio by Campbell et al. 2010, where it had been placed by Wake and Elias, 1983.

authority: Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012
Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic work is underway to clarify the validity of this species. Genetic analysis suggests that this taxon may be conspecific with Nototriton picadoi (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
Bolitoglossa omniumsanctorum has been removed from synonymy with B. morio by Campbell et al. 2010.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Bolitoglossa nympha (Campbell et al. 2010) and B. chinateca (Rovito et al. 2012). The records from Los Tuxtlas may represent another species (Rovito et al. 2012).
This is a restricted concept of Gastrophryne olivacea following the split of the broader concept into this and G. mazatlanensis (Streicher et al. 2012).

This is a restricted concept of Incilius occidentalis following the split of the broader concept into this and I. mccoyi (Santos-Barrera and Flores-Villela 2011). Incilius intermedius has also been placed with synonymy with this species (Mendelson et al. 2016).

Brodie et al. (2012) described this species from a locality in the Guatemalan portion of Cerro Montecristo. A series of morphologically similar salamanders is available from the Honduran side of Cerro Montecristo. DNA data from one of those Honduran specimens was reported on by García-París and Wake (2000; as Oedipina sp. B). McCranie (2006) and McCranie and Castañeda (2007) had identified those salamanders as O. ignea. There is no reason to expect that the Honduran Cerro Montecristo species is not conspecific with those on the Guatemalan side of that same mountain range (although the Guatemalan locality for this species is in open pine forest [see Brodie et al. 2012, 238] and the Honduran locality assigned to O. chortiorum were found in Mesic broadleaf forest.

authority: Sunyer, Townsend, Wake, Travers, Gonzalez, Obando & Quintana, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Confused with Oedipina pseudouniformis prior to its discovery according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
This is a restricted concept of Oedipina pseudouniformis following the split of the broader concept into this and Oedipina koehleri (Sunyer et al. 2011).
Previously confused with Oedipina taylori according to the original publication (Brodie et al. 2012).

authority: Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species has been removed from synonymy of Oedipina taylori by Brodie et al. (2012). Records from the northern zone of the departments of Santa Ana and Morazán (Joateca, Perquín, Arambala) bordering Guatemala and Honduras are suspected to belong to different species such as Oedipina ignea and O. chortiorum; however, it is necessary to carry out taxonomic studies to corroborate this (E. Morán pers. comm. June 2019).

Diagnosis: This species is closely related to Scutiger chintingensis (Liu et Hu), but differs from the latter by 1) upper jaw toothless, and 2) very rough skin with black spines as much as scuttered over the whole body.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Amolops sinesis and A. yatseni (Lyu et al. 2019).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus.

This is a new taxonomic concept as a result of splitting out Clinotarsus penelope (Grosjean et al. 2015). Clinotarsus alticola (Boulenger, 1882) was coined as a replacement name of Hylorana pipiens Jerdon, 1870 (R. Thapa pers. comm. September 2020).
There are multiple cryptic species under this species name (Wogan et al. 2016). Duttaphrynus tienhoensis was synonymized with D. melanostictus by Dubois and Ohler (1999).
Fejervarya raja has been synonymized with this species by Kurniawan et al. (2010).
This is a species complex (A. Borzee pers. comm. September 2019).

This taxon is now believed to consist of a complex of several cryptic species. Ongoing taxonomic research in Sri Lanka has revealed that records in this country are uncertain, however, it is unclear as to whether these records belong to Hoplobatrachus tigerinus or H. crassus (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
The taxonomic validity of this species is confirmed, on the basis of morphology, allozymes, and mtDNA (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).
Mendelson et al. (2005) recently separated I. pisinnus (endemic to Mexico), I. porteri (endemic to Honduras), and I. signifer (endemic to Panama) from I. coccifer.
This species is currently under taxonomic review.

This is a restricted concept of Incilius macrocristatus following the split of the broader concept into this, I. valliceps and Incilius aurarius (Mendelson 1997, Mendelson et al. 2012). I. aurarius represents a split from the broader concepts of both I. macrocristatus and I. valliceps (Mendelson et al. 2012).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Incilius valliceps by Mulcahy and Mendelson (2000).
Anaxyrus fowleri was formerly included in this species (Dodd 2013).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Acris blanchardi (Gamble et al. 2008).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Hyla exima by Elioso León (2002). The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
This is a restricted concept of Sarcohyla bistincta following the split of the broader concept into this S. labeculata and S. hapsa (Campbell et al. 2018).

This species was elevated from subspecies status under Exerodonta melanomma by Campbell and Duellman (2000). It was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.

Toal and Mendelson (1995) considered S. celata to occur in the Sierra de Juárez and also tentatively near Totontepec in the Sierra Mixe, but specimens from the Sierra Mixe were reassigned to S. cyclada (Campbell and Duellman 2000).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla. This taxon may be a junior synonym of S. arborescandens (Caviedes-Solis 2012).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Bromeliohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

Until recently, Hyla wrightorum was regarded as a synonym of Hyla eximia, but Duellman (2001) recognized H. wrightorum as a distinct species.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Tlalocohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005) and since then to Charadrahyla (Faivovitch et al. 2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Megastomatohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla. This is a restricted concept of Sarcohyla pentheter following the split of the broader concept into this and S. floresi (Kaplan et al. 2020).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Tlalocohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005) and since then to Charadrahyla (Faivovitch et al. 2018).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
