This is a restricted concept of Boana multifasciata following the split of the broader concept into this and B. paranaiba (de Carvalho et al. 2010). Subpopulations previously identified as B. multifasciata from the Guiana Shield are tentatively assigned to B. albopunctata (as B. aff. albopunctata), but probably belong to an as yet undescribed species (Fouquet et al. 2021). The Amazonian subpopulations identified as B. multifasciata are suggested to belong to a distinct species (Fouquet et al. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is definitely a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was redelimited by the exclusion of Dendropsophus kubricki and D. kamagarini by Rivadeneira et al. (2018), who revised the Dendropsophus parviceps complex and reviewed this species but did not address the Venezuelan records. Subpopulations from northeastern and central Peru were assigned to D. kubricki and subpopulations from southeastern Peru (Cusco and Madre de Dios regions), northwestern Brazil (Acre and Rondônia states), and northeastern Bolivia were assigned to D. kamagarini.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic identity of this species since it is known only from the type series and no subsequent surveys have been made back to the type locality (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). It could belong to another better-known species in the Dendropsophus parviceps group such as D. koechlini with which it could be synonymous (V.G. Dill Orrico pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has now been moved to the new genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). 

The taxonomy and synonymy of this name is convoluted and unstable. It certainly includes many species (Hoogmoed and Gruber 1983, Lima et al. 2019, Sturaro et al. 2020). The name Hypsiboas hobbsi has been employed for Venezuelan specimens (e.g. McDiarmid and Paolillo 1988). Based on molecular evidence, there appears to be two species under this binomial within the Colombian subpopulations (Guarnizo et al. 2016).

Hypsiboas roeschmanni has been synonymized with this species by Padial et al. (2006). It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which has recently been considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017).

This is a restricted concept of Dendropsophus riveroi following the split of the broader concept into this and D. shiwiarum (Ortega-Andrade and Ron 2013). Specimens from Rondônia, Nova Brasilia, Brazil (USNM 304058–074, 304174–186) have intermediate characters between D. riveroi and D. shiwiarum and, thus, their taxonomic status needs to be clarified (Ortega-Andrade and Ron 2013).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005), and transferred to Boana by Dubois (2017). Its phylogenetic relationships have been assessed by Sturaro et al. (2020) and recovered as the sister taxon of the Boana benitezi group, although with no significant support.

Careful examination of morphological characters, colour patterns, and advertisement calls strongly supports the placement of Dendropsophus allenorum into the synonymy of Dendropsophus timbeba (Orrico et al. 2013).

This is a restricted concept of Dendrosophus triangulum following the revalidation of Osteocephalus mimeticus (Jungfer 2010) and Dendropsophus reticulatus (Caminer et al. 2017), which were previously placed in synonymy with this species. Caminer et al. (2017) redelimited the species, noting that pre-revision Dendropsophus triangulum is a complex of nine candidate species, several of which remain unnamed.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Dendropsophus rozenmani (Jansen et al. 2019).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Some specimens identified as Hyla boans in the literature for Venezuelan localities, might represent Hypsiboas wavrini (see Hoogmoed 1990, La Marca 1992).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This is a restricted concept of Osteocephalus buckleyi following the split of the broader concept into this, O. cannatellai (Ron et al. 2012), O. carri (Lynch 2006), O. festae (Jungfer 2010) and O. camufatus (Jungfer et al. 2016). Some subpopulations from Guiana Shield have also been assigned to Osteocephalus helenae (Jungfer et al. 2013).

This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Osteocephalus buckleyi by Duellman and Mendelson III (1995). However, its taxonomy is still unclear.

Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted that previous records from Venezuela are based on specimens of Osteocephalus helenae.

A taxonomic revision of this species is needed, as it includes a number of unnamed cryptic species within its range (Figueiredo et al. 2021). We follow Jungfer and Hödl (2002) in considering Osteocephalus ayarzaguenai (Gorzula and Señaris, 1997 "1996") to be a synonym of O. leprieurii.
Osteocephalus mutabor was previously confused with O. leprieurii, from the Amazon Basin of Ecuador (Jungfer and Hödl 2002).

This species was removed from synonymy of Osteocephalus taurinus by Duellman and Mendelson (1995). Further revision of available Osteocephalus collections revealed that the specimens of Osteocephalus reported from Jaú National Park by Gordo and Neckel-Oliveira (2004) actually represent O. vilarsi (Ferrão et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of Osteocephalus taurinus following the revalidation of O. vilarsi which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Jungfer 2010). Jungfer et al. (2013) noted that four unnamed species from the eastern part of the Guiana Shield, eastern Mato Grosso, Brazil, western Guiana Shield, and Pasco, Peru, are masquerading under the name Osteocephalus taurinus, which is actually restricted to Amazonia of Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Brazil, and Bolivia. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted that only unnamed members of this complex occur in Venezuela. Fouquet et al. (2019) noted the French Guiana subpopulations as an unnamed species, part of the Osteocephalus taurinus complex.
There are serious taxonomic problems with this species (K.-H. Jungfer pers comm.).
This is a restricted concept of Trachycephalus coriaceus following the split of the broader concept into this and Trachycephalus quadrangulum (Ron et al. 2016).

This is a restricted concept of Trachycephalus resinifictrix following the split of the broader concept into this and T. cunauaru (Gordo et al. 2013). The status of subpopulations (whether Trachycephalus cunauaru or Trachycephalus resinifictrix) in Venezuela (Amazon Basin), Peru, and southeastern Colombia (Amazonas) is provisional and requires genetic confirmation.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to Agalychnis (Frost 2014). The distribution in Colombia would suggest that there are perhaps two different species in that country.
Phyllomedusa chaparroi was previously confused with this species according to Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2017).
The species is poorly known in Ecuador, but is probably overlooked due to its similarity with other Phyllomedusa (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010). A taxonomic review is pending for this species and A. buckleyi (Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2014).

This species was under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016). This is a restricted concept of Pithecopus hypochondrialis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. araguaius (Haga et al. 2017).

Pithecopus hypochondrialis is represented by two clades, one Amazonian as “P. hypochondrialis North” and one associated with the Cerrado biome as “P. hypochondrialis South” (Haga et al. 2017).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

Duellman (1997) doubted that the subpopulation on Trinidad (the type locality of Phyllomedusa trinitatis) were distinct from P. tarsius.

Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) doubt the presence of Phyllomedusa tarsius sensu stricto in Venezuela. Previous reports from southeastern Venezuela were meant to be P. trinitatis (Barrio-Amorós 2009) or are very distinct from P. tarsius sensu stricto, as individuals from the Andean piedmont reported by La Marca (1996) and Markezich (1998) are much smaller and the iris pattern is much less reticulated than on Ecuadorian (near type locality) specimens. This could indicate a putative new species of the tarsius group in western Venezuela.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).

De la Riva et al. (2000) point out that the males in the Peruvian site have pronounced coloration patterns, very different from those in Bolivia. The taxonomic status of the Peruvian specimens should be reviewed.
This species might consist of a complex of more than one species.

Scinax villasboasi and S. madeirae were split from S. fuscomarginatus by Brusquetti et al. (2014), which remains a complex of more than one species. Following genetic, morphological and bioacoustic analyses, S. parkeri, S. lutzorum, S. pusillus and S. trilineatus have been synonymized with this species providing records for Venezuela, Guyana and Suriname (Brusquetti et al. 2014). COI barcodes suggest that cryptic species are likely to still exist within this species (Estupiñán et al. 2016).

This form is probably a complex of several species. Scinax trachythorax and S. megapodius are treated as separate species by some authors, but the most recent review of Hylidae considers them both to be a synonym of S. fuscovarius (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Some specimens of this taxon in Venezuela have been referred to as Hyla boulengeri and H. garbei.
Scinax lindsayi seems similar to S. baumgardneri, and could be a synonym. Fresh material of both taxa and direct comparison with types could corroborate this supposition (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
This form is a complex of more than one species.
Lescure and Marty (2000) placed Scinax cynocephala in the synonymy of Scinax nebulosus. This is probably a complex of more than one species.
There is a good possibility that many or all specimens referred to Scinax nebulosus from central and western Brazil and Bolivia in fact are S. pedromedinae (Hoogmoed and Ávila-Pires 2012 "2011").

It is probably a complex of more than one species. Geographic variation amongst subpopulations of Scinax squalirostris shows evidence that the subpopulation from Cristalina Municipality (state of Goiás, Brazil) might be a distinct species (Faria et al. 2013).
This is most likely a species complex. There are at least five species in Venezuela under this name (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

This is the new concept of Pristimantis acuminatus without P. limoncochensis, P. omeviridis and P. enigmaticus (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). Following genetic and morphological analysis, subpopulations from eastern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago, Orellana, and Pastaza provinces) and northern Loreto Department in Peru, up to 960 m asl, have now been assigned to Pristimantis enigmaticus; subpopulations from southern Ecuador (Napo, Sucumbíos, and Orellana provinces), two localities from Putumayo and Caquetá Departments in Colombia, up to 593 m asl, and possibly records from Brazil, have been assigned to P. limoncochensis; and subpopulations from northern Ecuador (Napo and Orellana provinces) and one locality from Loreto Department in Peru, up to 382 m asl, and possibly records from Brazil, have been assigned to P. omeviridis (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).

Ortega-Andrade et al. (2017) resurrected Pristimantis brevicrus from the synonymy of this species and noted two allied unnamed species in Bolivia and Brazil, usually referred to as Pristimantis altamazonicus.
This species requires taxonomic revision (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
Fouquet et al. (2019) suggested that this nominal species is a complex.

Motta et al. (2018) on the basis of 16S rRNA sequence divergence suggested that this nominal species is composed of at least two species. Records from Acre, Pará, and Maranhão states, Brazil, were excluded by Araujo de Oliveira et al. (2019), as applying to unnamed species, recognized on molecular evidence.
The taxonomy of this species requires resolution.
This taxon is believed to consist of a complex of more than one species.
There might be several species confused under this name.
A taxonomic revision is necessary (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

Hylodes grandoculis was placed in synonymy with this species (M.S. Hoogmoed In Frost 1985), although the taxonomic status of H. grandoculis should be reassessed according to Kok et al. (2018).

This is probably a species complex (Kok et al. 2018, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019; C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020). Kok et al. (2018) suggested that records from French Guiana by Lescure (1981) for example, and later by Lescure and Marty (2000) represent at least two unnamed lowland species (Fouquet et al. 2013), and records from the slopes of Marahuaka-tepui, Amazonas State in Venezuela (Rivero 1961), the Mabura Hill Forest Reserve in central Guyana (Ernst et al. 2005), Suriname (Ouboter and Jairam 2012), Amapá State in Brazil (Dias Lima 2008) and northern Pará State in Brazil (Avila-Pires et al. 2010) are misidentifications with other related species.
This form might consist of more than one species.

Elmer and Cannatella (2008) recognized Pristimantis achuar (now a synonym of P. luscombei; Ortega-Andrade and Venegas 2014), P. altamnis, and P. kichwarum from within the range of nominal P. ockendeni, and noted other ongoing difficulties in the elucidation of the species masquerading under the name Pristimantis "ockendeni".
A taxonomic review to resolve the status of the species complex is needed (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
This species is possibly a complex of more than one species (De la Riva et al. 2000).

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Rivero 1968) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) neither by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships within Pristimantis have been assessed by Kok et al. (2012, 2018), Padial et al. (2014), and Jablonski et al. (2017) on the basis of molecular data. Records of P. pulvinatus documented by Duellman (1997) from La Escalera, and the sequence used by Hedges et al. (2008) from the same region, actually correspond to misidentified specimens of P. marmoratus (Kok et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis rhabdolaemus following the revalidation of P. pharangobates which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Duellman and Lehr 2009).

Padial and De la Riva (2005) discussed the taxonomic status of Eleutherodactylus karcharias and placed it in synonymy with this species. The Ecuadorian specimens assigned to this species are taxonomically uncertain (Padial et al. 2016).
This taxon may be a multi-complex of more than one species.

The species was redescribed by Barrio-Amorós and Molina (2006) based on morphological features and colour patterns of additional specimens. Eleutherodactylus stegolepis (Schlüter and Rödder 2007 "2006") is a junior synonym according to Kok and Barrio-Amorós (2013).

Subpopulations in highland areas have different calls and morphology when compared to lowland subpopulations. Nonetheless, a molecular study by McLister et al. (1991) did not find any difference between highland and lowland subpopulations.
This species has at least two allopatric subpopulations, and taxonomic work is needed to determine whether or not these are truly conspecific.
Acosta-Galvis et al. (2016) cast doubt on the distinctiveness of this nominal species from Pipa pipa.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).

This is a very poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2003). Most attenuate caecilians in the Amazon basin and the Guianas are associated with this name, but their conspecificity is uncertain.

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is probable that specimens from Colombia and Ecuador belong to different species (J. Lynch pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
Caecilia pressula was placed in synonymy with this species by Wilkinson (2020).
Typhlonectes cunhai has been synonymized under this species by Wilkinson and Nussbaum (2006).
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).
Pristimantis bellator is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al., 2007).

In the Eleutherodactylus orestes group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis according to Heinicke et al. (2007). Pristimantis corrugatus is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman, 2007).

This species was tentatively assigned to the Hypsiboas punctatus group in the original publication, diagnosed by its morphological, ecological and advertisement call features (Kok 2006); it was previously moved to the genus Boana by Dubois (2017), and has now been moved to Myersiohyla by Pinheiro et al. (2018).
This species was confused with Pristimantis ockendeni prior to its naming (Elmer and Cannatella 2008).
This species was confused with Pristimantis ockendeni prior to its naming (Elmer and Cannatella 2008).

This species was assigned to the Boana benitezi group in its original description (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias 2008), and encompasses all the eastern Guiana populations previously determined as B. benitezi. The only specimen of B. tepuiana included in phylogenetics studies, comes from Vila Pacaraima in Brazil (Faivovich et al. 2005, Sturaro et al. 2020), but was erroneously determined as B. benitezi (USNM 302435).

authority: Moravec, Aparicio, Guerrero-Reinhard, Calderón, Jungfer & Gvoždík, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Székely et al. (2016) states that the "records from Peru, Brazil and Bolivia are controversial and need confirmation".
This taxon was resurrected from synonymy with Ambystoma veslasci by Webb (2004) on the basis of morphology. Additional taxonomic work is required to determine the validity of this species.

Occidozyga vittata has been synonymised with this species by Poyarkov et al. (2020).

This species was moved from Occidozyga to Phrynoglossus by Köhler et al. (2021) but was then moved back again.

Sphaerotheca pluvialis has been resurrected from the synonymy of this species (Dahanukar et al. 2017). S. magadha and S. swani were synonymized under this species by Dubois (2004), were temporarily recognised as distinct species by Dahanukar et al. (2017), and synonymized again by Jablonski et al. (2021).
Genetic data indicate that Eleutherodactylus principalis is nested within one of the four lineages of E. auriculatus and a thorough taxonomic revision of this group is needed (Rodríguez et al. 2010).
This species was elevated from subspecies status under Eleutherodactylus planirostris by Estrada and Hedges (1997a).
The appreciable genetic distance among localities suggests the existence of cryptic or 'candidate' species (Alonso Bosch et al. 2012).

Taxonomy of Cuban bromeliad frogs need to be revisited since populations of Eleutherodactylus ionthus and E. guantanamera could be confused at some localities; thus, even distributions must be reassessed in the future. The advertisement call as it was originally described is difficult to distinguish between both species (L.M. Díaz pers. comm. 2020). Colouration pattern is not a completely diagnostic character for these and other species of the E. varians group (Díaz and Cádiz 2008).
Some historic records of Eleutherodactylus pinarensis might refer to juveniles of E. klinikowskii, and so are not included here (L. Díaz pers. comm.).
Eleutherodactylus thomasi is composed by three subspecies (Díaz and Cádiz 2008). Hedges et al. (2008) announced that they may be distinct species.
Two of the subspecies of Eleutherodactylus varians (olibrus and staurometopon) have been elevated to the species level.
This is a restricted concept of Eleutherodactylus zugi following the split of the broader concept into this and E. erythroproctus (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species has several subspecies (Fei et al. 2009).
This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Hyla chinensis. Old records of H. chinensis from Viet Nam are probably attributable to this taxon (see Bourret 1942).
This species was previously known as Dendropsophus labialis (now molitor), but genetic and acoustic data have confirmed the Northern Clade to be this separate species (Guarnizo et al. 2012).

authority: Acevedo, Wake, Márquez, Silva, Franco & Amézquita, 2013

taxonomicNotes: A taxonomic review of this species is needed (A. Ohler pers. comm.).

This species includes the mainland subpopulations previously referred to as Leptobrachium hasseltii, a taxon now restricted to the Indo-Malayan Archipelago. It also includes previous records of L. pullum in Thailand.

H. castaneus and H. constellatus were recognized as recently diverged and distinct species by Greenbaum et al. (2013). The subspecies H. c. submarginatus from the Kabobo Plateau was transferred to the synonymy of H. constellatus, but the status of the unsampled subspecies H. c. rhodogaster, described from mid-elevations of the western Itombwe Plateau, remains problematic (Greenbaum et al. 2013).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999).
The taxonomy of this species is not well studied.

The subpopulation on Hainan Island might belong to an undescribed species. Ohler (2007) treated Rana megatympanum, described by Bain et al. (2003), and Rana heatwolei, described by Stuart and Bain (2005), as synonyms of this species. Rana tabaca was separated from R. megatympanum by Bain and Nguyen (2004), but was re-treated as a junior synonym by Stuart and Bain (2005) (and hence is now a synonym of Odorrana tiannensis).

This species was synonymized with Pelophylax nigromaculatus by Fei, Ye and Huang (1990), and this synonymy was accepted by Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (1996). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) still consider this to be a valid species and hence it is included here pending a definitive decision on its taxonomic status.

Animals formerly assigned to Hylarana taipehensis from South Asia are now included within Hylarana tytleri following the revision by Ohler and Mallick (2002). However, this species may be a species complex (Hasan et al. 2012). Thus taxonomic revision is needed as morphometric description suggests that both species might occur in Bangladesh (Md. K. Hasan pers. comm. 2020).
This species is placed in the genus Liurana (Fei et al. 1999).
We follow Matsui (1994) in considering Rana taiwaniana to be a synonym of this species.
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain.

All records from eastern and southern Taiwan, Province of China apply to a distinct species (Buergeria otai Wang et al. 2018). Populations from Southern Ryukyus and north-western Taiwan have been recently described as Buergeria choui (Matsui and Tominaga 2020).
Jiang, Hu and Zhao (1987) considered this species to belong to the genus Buergeria, rather than Rhacophorus, and this is now widely accepted.
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).

This species was in the past mistaken to be Rana japonica (Ye et al. 1995). This is a restricted concept of Rana zhenaiensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Rana culaiensis (Li et al. 2008).

The validity of this species has been questioned in the past and it was previously considered to be a synonym of Theloderma asperum by Yu et al. (2007, 2008). However, this was disputed by Poyarkov et al. (2015) and it is now recognised as a distinct species. It is part of the Theloderma asperum species group (Poyarkov et al. 2015).
This species is in the Theloderma leprosum species group (Poyarkov et al. 2015).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Kurixalus beryllineniris and K. wangi (Wu et al. 2016).
We follow Wilkinson et al. (2002) in transferring this species from Chirixalus to Kurixalus.
This species requires taxonomic revision across its wide range (A. Ohler pers. comm. September 2020).
Amolops daiyunensis was considered a synonym of A. hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei et al. (1999), Jin et al. (2005) and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Amolops liangshanensis but Liu and Yang (1995) provided evidence to show that both species are valid.

Although Liu (1950) synonymized this species with Amolops mantzorum (as Staurois mantzorum), he stated that in the wild it was easy to distinguish the two taxa. Wu et al. (1987) resurrected this species based on cytological evidence. However, two different species of Amolops were confounded, one found above 3,000 m in the Yalong River Basin of Sichuan, and another found at 1,200 to 2,400 m elevation in the Dadu River basin, Sichuan, China.

Fei et al. (2017) reexamined the types of kangtingensis and, more importantly, noted that the original type locality had to be corrected to "Yalagou of Kangding" (in the Dadu River Basin). This meant that the name A. kangtinensis applied not to the high-elevation subpopulation which had been previously thought by Wu et al. (1987), who found nominal A. mantzorum to be a complex of species and explicitly retained A. kangtingensis, but from the wrong subpopulation.

Fei et al. (2017) sorted the problem by correcting the type locality of A. kangtingensis, placing A. kangtingensis into the synonymy of A. mantzorum, and naming as A. xinduqiao the population formerly incorrectly assigned the name A. kangtingensis.
Amolops liangshanensis was assessed in 2004 as a separate species, but is now considered to be a synonym of A. loloensis  (Lu et al. 2014, Zhang 2015, Lyu et al. 2019).
This taxon is probably a complex of more than one species (Jin et al. 2005).
This is a restricted concept of this species which excludes subpopulations which are now assigned to other segregate species in the Amolops monticola group (Patel et al. 2021).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species was placed in the genus Amolops by Dubois (1986).

This is a restricted concept of Onychodactylus fischeri following the split of the broader concept into this and Onychodactylus koreanus by Min, Poyarkov & Vieites in Poyarkov et al. (2012), and Onychodactylus zhangyapingi and Onychodactylus zhaoermii by Che, Poyarkov, & Yan in Poyarkov et al. (2012).
It was originally described as Amolops gerbillus but is now considered to be the same as the species recently described from China.

This species has been alternatively attributed to Leptobrachium, or possibly to Ophryophryne (Orlov et al. 2000).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys.  Dubois et al. (2021) recognized that Panophrys is proccupied and employed Boulenophrys as the generic name rather than Tianophrys under the Principle of First Revisor. This assessment retains it under Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

There is some uncertainty as to the identification of the type specimen of this species (Shi et al. 2020).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species probably belongs to the genus Xenophrys, but taxonomic studies of the genera Megophrys and Xenophrys are needed (Xie Feng pers. comm.).

The validity of this species is in doubt and the exact delineation of the range of this taxon and of Pelophylax plancyi is not clear (Mou and Zhao 1992, Zhao and Adler 1993). It may be a synonym of P. plancyi (A. Borzée pers. comm. June 2019).

This is a restricted concept of Megophrys major following the split of the broader concept into this and M. flavipunctata, M. oreocrypta, M. himalayana, M. periosa (Mahony et al. 2018), and  M. maosonensis (Chen et al. 2016). 

This species is sometimes erroneously called Megophrys lateralis (A. Ohler pers. comm., Frost 2019). Complicated nomenclatural history, and sexual dimorphism in leg proportions (Taylor 1962; but see Inger et al. 1999) might be partly at fault for records of Xenophrys longipes from Viet Nam.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

This is a restricted concept of Megophrys minor following the split of the broader concept into this and M. insularis (Wang et al. 2017) and M. angka (Wu et al. 2019).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
This species is thought to be a complex, and the population in southern China is believed to contain three distinct species (Xiong et al. 2015).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Atympanophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Although originally described as a subspecies of Xenophrys minor, this taxon was treated as a full species by Delorme et al. (2006).
This is a restricted concept of Rana longicrus following the split of the broader concept into this and R. jiemuxiensis (Yan et al. 2011).
The population in Thailand and specimens collected from Xieng Khouang Province of Lao People's Democratic Republic had previously been mistaken for Babina chapaensis (Chuaynkern et al. 2010).
This species is only represented by the description and the iconotype.

authority: Huang, Fei & Ye in Fei & Ye, 2001

taxonomicNotes: Hynobius yiwuensis is here treated as a valid species, separate from H. chinensis, following Fei et al. (1999) and Fu et al. (2003).
This species was elevated to full species status by Inger et al. (1999) and Fei et al. (1999).
Hynobius yunanicus has been synonymized with this species by Xiong et al. (2007).

We follow Bordoloi et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Rhacophorus bipunctatus, where it has been placed by Inger et al. (1999), and in treating Rhacophorus namdaphaensis as a synonym of this species.

This species is a complex (Li et al. 2012, Dang et al. 2016).
This is a restricted concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus following the split of the broader concept into this and Pseudohynobius jinfo (Wei et al. 2009).
Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon. However, we follow Huang, Fei and Ye (1992) in moving it to the genus Liua.

Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus was considered to be a synonym of this species by Zhao and Hu (1983) and Zhao and Wu (1995), but is considered a valid species by Ye et al. (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and S. tridactyla (Malyarchuk et al. 2010). Following genetic analysis, some subpopulations in Primorsky Krai in Russia, in eastern China and at the extreme northeast of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea have now been assigned to Salamandrella tridactyla (Malyarchuk et al. 2010).
Records from Malaysia refer to Humerana miopus (Taylor 1962). We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana nigrolineata Liu & Hu, 1959 as a synonym of this species.
Inger et al. (1990) considered Oreolalax puxiongensis to be synonymous with O. schmidti.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes. Dryophytes suweonensis was synonymised with this species by Dufresnes et al. (2016), but was resurrected again by Borzée et al. (2018).
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Oreolalax major but did not give any reason.

This species is a member of the “Dryophytes japonicus group” (Hua et al. 2009), recently renamed from Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016), and as a clear split with the “Hyla arborea group” (sensu stricto Anderson and Green 1991). Borzée et al. (2020) doubt the synonymy of this species and Hyla stepheni.

Following a molecular phylogeography study, this species is thought to be a complex of two or more species, one with the range of Honshu and Hokkaido, Japan, and the Russian Far East islands of Kunashir and Sakhalin, and another with the range of southwestern Japan, the Korean peninsula, Transiberian China, Russia, and Mongolia (Dufresnes et al. 2016).

We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus. The former species name of Ophryophophryne pachyproctus is a secondary homonym so a new species name was needed, hence the use of Megophrys koui.
We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana bannanica, described by Rao and Yang (1997) as a synonym of this species.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Megophrys vegrandis (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Investigations of mitochondrial DNA suggest that subpopulations from the southern Caucasus and Central Asia might represent separate species. The taxonomy of Anatolian water frogs (including this species) is still unclear; some authors suggest that the presence of this species in Türkiye cannot be established on the basis of morphometric data.

There are studies that claim that this species represents a species complex and therefore are questioning the identity of marsh frogs e.g. from western Caucasus area (Ermakov et al. 2016). Some studies suggest that parts of its range, at least in the Balkan Peninsula, actually belong to Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Kolenda et al. 2017).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Odorrana huangangensis and O. tianmuii (Chen et al. 2010).
Leptobrachium echinatum has been synonymised with this species (Matsui et al. 2010).
Records of Scutiger sikkimensis from northern Myanmar refer to S. adungensis (Dubois 1979).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Scutiger spinosus (Jiang et al. 2016), and Scutiger occidentalis (Hoffman et al. 2017).
Scutiger ruginosus has been synonymized under this species by Ye and Fei (1993).
Zhao and Adler (1993) regarded this species to be synonymous with Scutiger ruginosus (= S. mammatus) without discussion.
According to Fei et al. (1977), Scutiger alticola is synonymous with S. boulengeri.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Scutiger glandulatus by Fu, Lathrop and Murphy (1997), where it had been placed by Liu and Hu (1961).
The subpopulation in Liaoning might belong to a different species, Pelophylax chosenicus.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Paramesotriton wulingensis (Wang et al. 2013).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Pachytriton granulosus and Pachytriton inexpectatus (Nishikawa et al. 2011). Paramesotriton ermizhaoi has also been synonymised with this species (Nishikawa et al. 2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Pachytriton granulosus, which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Hou et al. 2009).
This species was synonymized under Kurixalus bisacculus by Yu et al. (2010). However, was then subsequently recognised as valid and split out again by Yu et al. (2017).
We consider Cynops chenggongensis to be separate from C. cyanurus, following Zhao and Adler (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).
This is a restricted concept of this species following Hypselotriton yunnanensis being removed from synonymy by Dubois and Raffaëll (2012).
Rana multidenticulata has been synonymized under this species by Hsu et al. (2011).
Bufo burmanus was synonymized with B. pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). The genus Torrentophryne (Yang, Liu and Rao 1996) was synonymized with Bufo by Liu et al. (2000).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Theloderma pyaukkya (Dever 2017).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Tylotriton pasmansi and T. sparreboomi (Bernardes et al. 2020).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Rhacophorus leucofasciatus which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Fei et al. 2009). Zhangixalus burmanus was elevated from subspecies level under this species by Ohler (2009).

This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
There is a nomenclatural problem with this species, and the name might change (A. Ohler pers. comm.). Tylototriton pulcherrima has been synonymized with this species (Nishikawa et al. 2013).
The Yuexi subpopulation of Tylotriton wenxianensis has been described as T. anhuiensis according to Qian et al. (2017).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Tylototriton shanorum (Nishikawa et al. 2014), T. panhai and T. uyenoi (Nishikawa et al. 2013), T. podichthys (Phimmachak et al. 2015), and T. phukhaensis (Pomchote et al. 2020).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of Paramesotriton chinensis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. ermizhaoi (Wu et al. 2009) which has since been synonymised with P. labiatus (Nishikawa et al. 2011). Additionally, records that were previously thought to represent this species have now been allocated to P. longliensis and P. zhijinensis (Raffaëlli 2013).
We follow Thorn and Raffaëlli (2001) in recognizing this as a full species distinct from Paramesotriton chinensis.
This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella liui following the split of the broader concept into this and Leptobrachella mangshanensis (Hou et al. 2018) and Leptobrachella laui (Sung et al. 2014).

Babina caldwelli was removed from the synonymy of this species by Dubois (1992). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) and Fei (1999), continued to include it as a synonym, but for the purpose of consistency with the Amphibian Species of the World database, we consider B. caldwelli as a valid species.

The identity of this species is unclear as it was originally described from a juvenile specimen (B.L. Stuart pers. comm. February 2021). This species was originally described as Polypedates yunnanensis, but when it was transferred to Rana it needed a replacement name which was Rana andersonii. Now that it has been transferred to Odorrana it no longer needs the replacement name so O. yunnanensis is available for use.
Inger et al. (1990) regarded this taxon as a junior synonym of Batrachuperus pinchonii. It was removed from the synonymy of B. pinchonii by Ye et al. (1993).
It is believed by some researchers that this species may be a synonym of M. boettgeri (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019). Further taxonomic work is required to clarify this.
This species was first described by Tian, Gu, Sun and Li (1998), who are the valid authors of this species. It was redescribed by Tian, Li and Gu (2006).

The subpopulation in northwestern Yunnan is sometimes assigned to the species Duttaphrynus cyphosus (now a synonym of D. stuarti). It is considered here to be a synonym of Duttaphrynus himalayanus following Yang (1991) and Zhao and Adler (1993).

This species may be a taxonomic complex (India Red List Assessment September 2020).

The intraspecific systematics of this species needs further study. Animals from the Altai Mountains have for a long time been considered as a separate subspecies of Rana arvalis or as the species Rana altaica. This has largely been on the basis of their shorter shins and large inner metatarsal tubercle. Similar frogs have since been found in other parts of the range of Rana arvalis (e.g., in the north of European Russia and in the Urals) and in Siberia some animals display transient characters between Rana arvalis and the Altaic taxon. Until this taxonomic issue is fully resolved we include Rana altaica within Rana arvalis.

The population currently allocated to Hynobius chinensis from Fujian Province, China, might represent a new species. We retain the Fujian population in H. chinensis until further taxonomic studies are undertaken. We consider H. yiwuensis (Cai 1985) to be a valid species separate from H. chinensis following Fei et al. (1990) and Fu et al. (2003).

This form is a complex of more than one species that needs further investigation, most especially with regards to its relationship with Rana dybowskii. We follow Xie et al. (2000) in separating R. kukunoris from R. chensinensis. Included in this account are subpopulations from China and Mongolia only (this includes the isolated Mongolian subpopulation of Dariganga Sum, Sukhbaatar Aimag). Some researchers regard the subpopulation in northeastern China to refer to Rana dybowskii, this requires further investigation.

We follow Bain et al. (2003) in recognising that this is a wide ranging species previously erroneously referred to as Odorrana livida. O. livida is restricted to the neotype locality in the Dawna Mountains of southern Myanmar. Bain et al. (2003) provided a partial revision of the O. chloronota complex, and considered it likely that previously undescribed species in the O. chloronota complex will be found, both in the wild and in current museum collections.

Subpopulations of this species in Viet Nam are believed to be a species complex (Vassilieva et al. 2016).

We consider Glandirana emeljanovi to be distinct from G. rugosa following Dubois (1992). The identity of animals from the Korean Peninsula remains unclear, and until more information becomes available on these populations we restrict G. rugulosa to Japan and consider animals from China and the Korean Peninsula to belong to G. emeljanovi.
This species might be a synonym of Kurixalus verrucosus (Ohler et al. 2000).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). It could comprise more than one species.
This is a restricted concept of Gracixalus jinxiuensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Gracixalus yunnanensis (Yu et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Micryletta aishani (Das et al. 2019), and Micryletta lineata (Zug and Mulcahy 2020, Miller et al. 2021). This species is thought to be a species complex (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). Its taxonomy is under review and M. inornata sensu stricto is thought to be restricted to Sumatra in Indonesia (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017). 

Recognition of the genus Micryletta as distinct from Microhyla, is based on a subjective and partially poor character set (Dubois 1987) and is not followed by some authors (Zhao and Adler 1993).
Subpopulations from southern Yunnan Province, China might have been incorrectly identified as this species, and may actually belong to Raorochestes parvulus (Yu et al. 2019).
Amolops splendissimus and A. caelumnoctis appear to be synonyms for the same species (R. Bain pers. comm. 2009). Until their taxonomic status is resolved, we herein treat both as valid species.
This species has also been reported as belonging in the genus Torrentophryne (Yang Datong pers. comm.).
This species was treated as a synonym of Amolops hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei (1999), Jin et al. (2005), and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.

Specimens collected in Pakistan by Annandale (1917) and assigned to Rana pleskei (= Nanorana pleskei) were allocated to Scutiger occidentalis (= S. nyingchiensis) by Dubois (1978, 1987). The Kashmir specimen reported by Mertens (1969), is referable to R. vicina (= Paa vicina) (Dubois and Khan 1979). Other reports of N. pleskei in Pakistan and Kashmir are references to the above collections that have now been allocated to other species.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Polypedates dugritei by Li et al. (2006), who also treated P. zhaojuensis as a synonym of this species. Rhacophorus wui has been split from this species (Li et al. 2012). This species was reassigned from Polypedates to Rhacophorus by Rao et al. (2006), and was most recently reassigned from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

This is a changed concept of Polypedates megacephalus following the revalidation of P. braueri, which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Kurashi et al. 2011). The concept has also changed with the inclusion of Chalcorana (Rana) scutigera as a synonym (see Frost 2022).
This species is commonly misidentified as Polypedates leucomystax.
This species was formerly treated under the genus Rhacophorus but is now placed under Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into Polypedates impresus (Yang 2008), P. iskandari (Riyanto et al. 2011) and P. discantus (Rujirawan et al. 2013). P. teraiensis has also been split from this species, although the split is not well documented (see Frost 2017).
Subpopulations from the Nicobar Islands are possibly a distinct species (Garg et al. 2018).
Paa chayuensis was previously considered a synonym of this species in 2004, but is now widely accepted to be distinct (Frost 2022)
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

This form is likely to be a complex of species (R. Inger pers. comm.). Until this complex of more than one species is resolved, Microhyla fowleri is considered to be a synonym of M. berdmorei, contra Dubois (1987). It might be that M. fowleri will be elevated to species status again once species boundaries in the M. berdmorei complex have been resolved (Garg et al. 2018).
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear. It was considered a synonym of Nanorana yunnanensis by Bourret (1942).
This species is a taxonomic complex (Gorin et al. 2020). Microhyla fusca has been synonymized under this species by Poyarkov et al. (2020).
This species is endemic to China and records of this species from Tibet are in fact Nanorana chayuensis (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
Liu et al. (2021) transferred this species from Kalophrynus to Micryletta on the basis of phylogenetic and morphological analysis.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Quasipaa courtoisi, which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Dubois and Ohler 2009).

This species requires further taxonomic work as it may be a species complex (Yu et al. 2016).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Kalophrynus anya, which was also split from K. pleurostigma (previously confused with both - Zug 2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nanorana sichuanensis and the revalidation of N. phrynoides (Huang et al. 2016). Nanorana bourreti has been synonymized with this species (Che et al. 2009, Chen et al. 2011, Huang et al. 2016).

We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in separating this species from Microhyla ornata. Call properties of this species vary, and it is believed to be a species complex (A. Borzee pers. comm. September 2019).
Kaloula macrocephala has been synonymized under this species by Ohler (2003).
Available information (Bourret 1942) indicates that this taxon closely resembles Rhacophorus verrucosus.
This is a restricted concept of Ansonia malayana following the split of the broader concept into this and A. lumut (Chan et al. 2014).

We follow Harvey et al. (2002) by including records of Rhacophorus dulitensis Boulenger, 1892 from Sumatra in R. prominanus, and in considering R. tunkui (Kiew 1987) to be a synonym of R. prominanus. Leong (2004) argued for the recognition of R. tunkui as a valid species, and believed that Harvey et al. (2002) had misread the original description of the species.

This species was formerly included in the genus Huia, but Ngo et al. (2006) suggested that it might belong in the genus Odorrana, an arrangement that we follow here. Liu and Hu (1961) reported Odorrana nasica from Mengyang, in Yunnan Province, China, and Fei et al. (1999) also reported it from Guangxi Province, China. When Yang (1991) reviewed the genus Amolops, he considered the Mengyang specimens to be different from the true Amolops nasicus (as Odorrana nasica) from Southeast Asia. Subsequently, Amolops mengyangensis Wu and Tian, 1995 was described, and we treat all records of O. nasica from China as belonging to A. mengyangensis, following Ohler (2007).
Mainland Southeast Asian records of Rhacophorus appendiculatus are referred to this taxon. Kurixalus odontotarsus might be a synonym of this species (Ohler et al. 2000).

Megophrys platyparietus was considered to be a synonym of this species for a while, however, it has been removed from synonymy and is recognised as a distinct species once again (Li et al. 2020). Li et al. (2020) placed this species in the genus Brachytarsophrys, however, no reason was provided for why Brachytarsophrys was elevated from sub-genus level as per Mahony et al. (2017). Lyu et al. (2021) also listed this species in Brachytarsophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

Records from the Tay Nguyen plateau of south-central Viet Nam represent Mehophrys [Brachytarsophrys] intermedia (Orlov et al. 2000)

Past records of Rhacophorus bimaculatus (Peters, 1867) from Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra and Borneo refer to Leptomantis. cyanopunctatus, 'typical' bimaculatus now being restricted to the Philippines.

Kurixalus hainanus was first described as an endemic of Hainan Island in China by Zhao, Wang and Shi (2005). It was then synonymized under Kurixalus bisacculus by Yu et al. (2010). However, it was subsequently recognised as valid and split out again by Yu et al. (2017). Records of K. bisacculus from southeastern China and northeastern Viet Nam were reassigned to K. hainanus.

Records from northern Thailand, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Viet Nam and China are tentatively referred to Rhacophorus reinwardtii for the purposes of this assessment, but further taxonomic work is needed. Previously, R. maximus, R. dennysii and R. feae were considered to be subspecies of R. nigropalmatus.
Taxonomic studies of this species are needed. If it proves to be a complex of related taxa, reassessment will be necessary.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Amolops australis and A. gerutu (Chan et al. 2018).

We follow Matsui and Nabhitabhata (2006) in treating most populations from Thailand, formerly included in this species, as Amolops panhai.

Philautus larutensis was removed from the synonymy of this species by Wostl et al. (2017). The type locality is in Borneo, but the distribution has been restricted by lectotype designation to Natuna Island.
This was split from the broader concept of Microhyla borneensis (Das et al. 2007).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Megophrys damrei (Mahony 2011), M. oropedion (Mahony et al. 2013) and Megophrys monticola, which was removed from synonymy with this species (Mahony et al. 2018).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
It is possible that this is a complex of species. The erroneous spelling "hosei" is widely used in the literature.
This species might comprise a complex of closely related taxa. It is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This species has sometimes been placed in the genus Rhacophorus.

We consider this species to be separate from Chalcorana chalconota following Dubois (1992). 

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Chalcorana labialis (as Hylarana - Stuart et al. 2006). We restrict the range of this species to Borneo where it occurs symptrically with C. megalonesa, and consider the Thai range to be C. eschatia, the Peninsular Malaysian range to be C. labialis, the Sumatran part of the range to be C. rufipes and C. parvaccola. Records from the Nicobar Islands require confirmation.

This species was moved from Hylarana to Chalcorana by Oliver et al. (2015).

Jacobs (1987) examined allozyme variation and concluded that the Eurycea bislineata subspecies (bislineata, cirrigera and wilderae) should be regarded as distinct species. Most subsequent authors, including Sever (1999), have followed this treatment, but Petranka (1998) retained these taxa as subspecies of Eurycea bislineata, pending study of genetic interactions in contact zones. Camp et al. (2000) examined allozyme and morphological variation in Eurycea at a contact zone between E. cirrigera and E. wilderae in Georgia and concluded that the two are distinct species. Kozak and Montanucci (2001) examined genetic variation across a wilderae-cirrigera contact zone in South Carolina, found evidence of an extended history of reduced gene exchange, and concluded that the two are distinct species.

The status of Eurycea aquatica has been resolved. Sever (1999) reasoned that E. aquatica might be a valid species, but some checklists did not regard E. aquatica as a valid species and instead included it in Eurycea cirrigera (Crother et al. 2000, 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) or E. bislineata (sensu lato, Petranka 1998). However, it is now recognized as distinct from both Eurycea cirrigera and Eurycea bislineata (Frost 2015).

The Maud Island population was previously considered to belong to this species, but was described as a new species, Leiopelma pakeka, in 1998 (Bell et al. 1998). However, Holyoake et al. (2001) considered them to be evolutionarily significant units of the same species based on a study of partial 12 S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome b gene sequences, although no formal taxonomic change was made as a result of this study. There is ongoing discussion and research into this subject.

DNA analyses have indicated that L. hochstetteri consists of ten or more evolutionarily significant units (Gemmell et al. 2003, Fouquet et al. 2010, Gleeson et al. 2010, Newman et al. 2013). Management should maintain these distinctive populations until further research into speciation within the group has been carried out.

This species was previously considered to belong to L. hamiltoni, but was described as a new species, Leiopelma pakeka, in 1998 (Bell et al. 1998). There is ongoing discussion over the taxonomic status of these two species, which were subsequently declared evolutionarily significant units of the same species based on a study of partial 12 S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome b gene sequences (Holyoake et al. 2001) although no formal taxonomic changes were made. There is ongoing discussion and research into this subject.
In the Boophis goudotii group (Frost 2013). Boophis roseipalmatus has recently been split from this species (Glaw et al. 2010).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Boophis luteus by Andreone and Randriamahazo (1997).
This form might be confused with Gephyromantis thelenae, G. blanci and G. leucocephalus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm.).
This species occurs in sympatry with Gephyromantis eiselti from which it is distinguished mainly by its call, so museum records might confuse these two species (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).

A subpopulation similar to G. tschenki was found in the Ambodiriana Forest on the east coast of Madagascar, far north of the known range for this species; the identity of this population requires confirmation and this record is excluded for the purposes of this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).
This species' taxonomy is unclear.
The taxonomy of this species is extremely confused and requires urgent revision (F. Glaw pers. comm. Nov. 2014).
We follow Litvinchuk et al. (2005) in separating Ommatotriton ophryticus from this species.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

This species is part of a taxonomically poorly defined group of frogs (R. Zweifel pers. comm.).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Fejevarya multistriata (Hallowell, 1861), which was removed from synonymy, and the two newly described species of F. kawamurai (Djong et al. 2011) in Japan, China and Taiwan, Province of China, and F. sakishimensis (Matsui et al. 2008) in Japan. This is still species complex is certain to contain a large number of cryptic species (Zug et al. 1998).

authority: Ndriantsoa, Riemann, Vences, Klages, Raminosoa, Rödel & Glos, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Originally described as Mantella pollicaris by Boettger (1913), and later synonymized with Anodonthyla boulengerii (Noble and Parker 1926). Removed from this synonymy by Vences et al. (2010) on the basis of molecular and acoustic data.

authority: Penny, Andreone, Crottini, Holderied, Rakotizafy, Schwitzer & Rosa, 2014

taxonomicNotes: We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016), and retain this species as Litoria as per Menzies and Riyanto (2015) and Frost et al. (2006).
This form probably represents two separate species.
Brown (1965) described two subspecies within Platymantis parkeri: P. p. parkeri from Bougainville; and P. p. bukanensis from Buka.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and E. kalasgramensis (Howlader et al. 2015) now renamed as E. adolfi. Euphlyctis mudigere (Khajeh et al. 2014) was split from this species, but has since been re-synonymised (Dinesh et al. 2021).
Gracixalus waza has been synonymised with this species (Nguyen et al. 2020).

authority: Geissler, Poyarkov, Grismer, Nguyen, An, Neang, Kupfer, Ziegler, Böhme & Müller, 2015
Geissler, Poyarkov, Grismer, Nguyen, An, Neang, Kupfer, Ziegler, Böhme & Müller, 2015
Geissler, Poyarkov, Grismer, Nguyen, An, Neang, Kupfer, Ziegler, Böhme & Müller, 2015
Chan, Blackburn, Murphy, Stuart, Emmett, Ho & Brown, 2013
