taxonomicNotes: This species is most likely a junior synonym of Rhacophorus orlovi (Tao T. Nguyen pers. comm. February 2017).

This species was split from the broader concept of Leptopelis modestus (Portillo and Greenbaum 2014). It is part of the Leptopelis modestus complex, together with a currently unnamed species, the sister taxon of Leptopelis modestus sensu stricto, according to the original publication.
This species was split from the higher elevations of Raorchestes tinniens (S.R. Chandramouli and S.R. Ganesh pers comm. October 2020).

This is a restricted concept of Hylarana temporalis following the split the broader concept into this and H. flavescens, H. intermedia and H. montana (Biju et al. 2014).

This species was moved from Hylarana to Indosylvirana by Oliver et al. (2015) and then back again to Hylarana by Dubois et al. (2021).
Biju et al. (2014) recognized the species as distinct from Indirana temporalis.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Indosylvirana (Hylarana) flavescens by Biju et al. (2014), which was recognized as distinct from Indirana temporalis by the same authors. This species was moved from Hylarana to Indosylvirana by Oliver et al. (2015) then moved back again by Dubois et al. (2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Indirana temporalis (Biju et al. 2014). These species are now treated under Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Senevirathne & Meggaskumbara, 2014

taxonomicNotes: It is possible that there is another species existing under this concept in the northern Western Ghats (A.D. Padhye pers. comm. September 2020).

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species was moved from Hylarana to Indosylvirana by Oliver et al. (2015) and back again to Hylorana by Dubois et al. (2001).

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Indosylvirana aurantiaca (Biju et al. 2014).

Chaitanya et al. (2018) assigned to Micrixalus cf. adonis specimens found in Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary, although precise recording sites were not provided and they are not included in the distribution map or extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work has been carried out.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Micrixalus sali (Biju et al. 2014). According to Biju et al. (2014), subpopulations from Siruvani and surrounding regions now belong to M. thampii.
This is a split from the broader concept of Micrixalus nudis (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Micraxalus specca (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Micrixalus saxicola (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split into this and Micrixalus herrei (Biju et al. 2014).
This species has been removed from the synonymy of Micrixalus fuscus (Biju et al. 2014).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nyctimystes cheesemani (Kraus 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nyctimystes cheesemani (Kraus 2012).
Previously confused with Nyctimystes narinosus according to the original publication (Frost, 2014).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nyctimystes bivocalis and N. intercastellus (Kraus 2012), N. traunae, N. latratus, N. eucavatus and N. calcaratus (Menzies 2014).
This is the restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Phrynobatrachus brongersmai (Frétey 2008).
This is a new concept split from the broader concept of Barygenys exsul (Kraus 2013).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, B. apodasta and B. resima (Kraus 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Barygenys exsul (Kraus 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Callulops robustus (Günther et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Callulops robustus, which it was previously confused with (Kraus and Allison 2009).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Callulops eremnosphax (Kraus and Allison 2009), C. microtis (Kraus 2012), C. valvifer (Günther 2013), C. biakensis and C. yapensis (Günther et al. 2012).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Callulops robustus by Kraus (2012).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Callulops robustus by Günther (2013). Günther (2013) discussed the taxon, provided an extensive account, and placed it within Callulops.
This is a split from the broader concept of Callulops robustus (Günther et al. 2012).
This species was confused with Cacosternum platys, but it is now known to occur only in the southern Cape region (Channing et al. 2013).

authority: Blackburn, Kosuch, Schmitz, Burger, Wagner, Gonwouo, Hillers & Rödel, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Cardioglossa leucomystax - the subpopulations from Guinea to Ghana previously assigned to the latter have now been assigned to this species (Blackburn et al. 2008).
This species has been split from Hyperolius cinereus by Conradie et al. (2013).

authority: Rödel, Doherty-Bone, Kouete, Janzen, Garrett, Browne, Gonwouo, Barej & Sandberger, 2012
taxonomicNotes: There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Phrynobatrachus horsti due to morphological similarities (Rödel et al. 2015).
Removed from synonymy with Pyxicephalus edulis by Scott et al. (2013). Some subpopulations in Kenya, Tanzania and Mozambique previously thought to be P. edulis have now been assigned to this species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Xenopus petersii (Furman et al. 2015). Subpopulations previously thought to be a subspecies of Xenopus laevis (X. l. sudanensis -elevated to species level X. sudanensis) have also been assigned to this species due to subsequent synonymy (Furman et al. 2015).

There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.

Hoskin et al. (2011) found three deeply divergent genetic lineages of this species that Hoskin (2012) resolved by redescribing this species and describing two new species; Cophixalus australis and Cophixalus hinchinbrookensis.

This is a restricted concept of Hyperolius adspersus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. dartevellei (Channing et al. 2013). Hyperolius nobrei was synonymised with this species by Ceríaco et al. (2014).
Leptopelis grandiceps has been removed from synonymy with this species.
Removed from the synonymy of Acris crepitans crepitans by Gamble et al. (2008).
This species was recently found to belong in the genus Anhydrophryne rather than Arthroleptella (Dawood and Stam 2006).
A question hangs over the taxonomic significance of disjunct populations of this species (A. Channing pers. comm.).

The validity of this species is in question. It has variously been considered as a subspecies of both Poyntonophrynus dombensis and P. fenoulheti, and Channing (pers. comm.) considers that it might be a synonym of P. hoeschi. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers that it is probably a synonym of P. dombensis.
The taxonomy of A. landdrosia is under revision and is presently best considered complex. The current assessment will be an evaluation of the entire complex.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Tandy and Keith (1972) tentatively assigned this species to the synonymy of Sclerophrys funereus. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers that it is almost certainly a synonym of S. funereus. Ruas (1996) considered it as a synonym of Sclerophrys funereus (as Amietophrynus).

Reports of this species occurring between Agulhas and Wilderness, the westernmost record of Sclerophrys pardalis (Minter et al. 2004) remain unconfirmed.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. It is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).

Ceríaco et al. (2014) consider it as a valid species, and assign two specimens collected about 135 km north of the type locality to this species, on a morphological basis.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. This species is known from a single specimen, and it is not yet known whether or not it is a valid species.
There is considerable doubt as to whether or not this form represents a valid species (Schiøtz pers. comm.). It is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).

Afrixalus spinifrons is an endemic species complex comprising Afrixalus knysnae and two subspecies, Afrixalus spinifrons spinifrons confined to the central KwaZulu-Natal coast and A. s. intermedius from the KwaZulu-Natal midlands (sensu Pickersgill 1996). Subpopulations from the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal previously assigned to Afrixalus knysnae were re-assigned to A. spinifrons (Pickersgill 1996). Tarrant (2012) showed that, according to molecular and morphological descriptions, Eastern Cape populations should be referred to A. s. intermedius instead of A. s. spinifrons as previously thought. Tarrant (2012) also suggested that the uMkomaas River is a possible boundary to A. s. spinifrons. The two subspecies are distinguishable on the basis of morphology, genetics and calls.
This species is closely related to Afrixalus spinifrons (Cope 1862). Species boundaries in this complex are uncertain and taxonomic studies using calls, morphology and genetics are necessary.

It was removed from the synonymy of Hildebrandtia ornata by Perret (1976), although this was implicitly not accepted by Poynton and Haacke (1993), or Channing (2001).

The taxonomic status of this species, H. ornata and their relationship need urgent review; however as this species' type locality is Angola, it seems justified to recognise the majority of the Angolan records to belong to it (N. Baptista pers. comm. August 2016). The records from the Cunene region collected by Poynton and Haacke (1993) could probably correspond to H. ornata, although the authors suggested that the subpopulations approached this species morphologically (Marques and Ceríaco pers. comm.).
There is some evidence that disjunct populations may contain cryptic species.

The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Phrynobatrachus mababiensis and P. parvulus is not clear (Poynton and Broadley 1985b).

In addition, molecular analysis recorded in Zimkus and Schick (2010) suggests that P. ungujae may be synonymous with P. ukingensis. However, only one specimen of P. ukingensis was included in the analysis. Synonymy seems highly unlikely on distributional grounds (Poyton pers. comm. June 2012). Future collections of P. ukingensis are required to resolve this issue.
This species, originally named Rana gibbosa, was the first African frog species to be entered into the Linnean system of nomenclature in 1758.
There are questions regarding the validity of two subspecies: Breviceps sylvestris sylvestris and B. s. taeniatus.
The relationships between this and other species without toe discs requires a detailed taxonomic study using molecular and morphological methodologies.

Probably a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus insignis Bocage, 1867 (R. Laurent IN Frost, 1985, Amph. Species World: 208). Junior secondary homonym of Hyperolius bicolor (Gray, 1842) (= Litoria bicolor).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.

This species is only known from holotype, lost in fire. It is not mentioned in the review of African treefrogs by Schiøtz (1999), nor in the Field Guide to the Amphibians of Central and Southern Africa by Channing (2001). It was considered as a synonym of Leptopelis bocagei by Loveridge (1933), but Perret (1976) considered it to be a valid species.
A deep genetic split characterises the disjunct distribution of this species.

Known only from the type locality: Luanda. This species might be a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. This species is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain.

Known only from the type specimen, lost in the 1978 fire. This species is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001) and is a nomen dubium according to Perret (1976). This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

Known only from the type locality (Cabinda, Angola). This species is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001). This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius ocellatus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. It is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).

There are serious taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

Until 2008, the Maluti River Frog was referred to Amietia vertebralis and the Phofung River Frog to Strongylopus hymenopus; a recent revision of type specimens has clarified the confusion between the two species, showing that Amietia vertebralis is widespread in Lesotho, KwaZulu-Natal and the Eastern Cape Province in South Africa, while Amietia hymenopus occurs within a more restricted range range in north-eastern Lesotho and the Drakensberg highlands (Channing 2015).

authority: Lourenço de Moraes, Ferreira, Fouquet & Bastos, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Based on surveys and molecular work by Lourenço-de-Moraes et al. (2012, 2018), there are five undescribed species in this genus. Some of the records currently assigned to the concept of Adelophryne mucronata are likely to be reassigned to these new species once they are formally described.
This is a split from the broader concept of Adenomera martinezi (Carvalho and Giaretta 2013).

This is a split from the broader concept of Adenomera marmorata (Angulo and Icochea 2010). The specimens reported as A. andreae from the eastern slopes of Venezuelan Andes (Barrio-Amorós 2004) have been identified as Adenomera aff. simonstuarti (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). Eight lineages have been detected within this nominal taxon which differ in calls and molecular markers; the lineage containing the type locality is thought tot be restricted to south-central Amazonian Peru and adjacent Amazonian Brazil (Carvalho et al. 2020).
This is a restricted concept of A. opisthomelas following the split of the broader concept into this and A. cassidyhornae (Amézquita et al. 2013).
This is a restricted concept of Arenophryne rotunda following the split of the broader concept into this and Arenophryne xiphorhyncha (Doughty and Edwards 2008).
This is a restricted concept of Bokermannohyla hylax following the split of the broader concept into this and B. capra. It is suspected to contain additional undescribed species.
Some populations previously treated as B. pseudopseudis are now considered a distinct species B. sapiranga (Brandão et al. 2012) based on morphological, bioacoustic, and ecological traits.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and A. hodli (Simões et al. 2010). Bioacoustic analysis has confirmed that this is a complex of species, but further taxonomic research is warranted to fully delineate it (A. Fouquet and P. Kok pers. comm. 2017).

Allobates spumaponens was placed in synonymy with this species by Simões et al. (2013). This nominal species is probably composed of at least two species, one in central Amazonia and the other in Pará (Motta et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Aneides flavipunctatus following the split of the broader concept into this, A. niger, A. iecanus, and A. klamathensis (Reilly and Wake 2019).
Atelognathus jeinimenensis was synonymized under Atelognathus salai by Díaz-Páez et al. (2011).

There is ongoing debate about the distinctiveness between this species and Bombina pachypus (e.g. Hofman et al. 2007, Speybroeck et al. 2010,  Fijarczyk et al. 2011). Bombina pachypus was synonymized with this species by Pabijan et al. (2013) that however, consider this taxon as an incipient species. We follow multiple European checklists (e.g. Speybroeck et al. 2010, Sillero et al. 2014, Speybroeck et al. 2020) and retain B. pachypus as a synonym of this species and should be considered valid at subspecies level (B.v. pachypus). Frost (2022) also treats B. pachypus as a synonym.
Espadarana fernandoi has been synonymized with E. audax (Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin 2014).

Zachaenus roseus is considered a junior synonym of Eupsophus calcaratus by Lavilla et al. (2010). 

The geographic limits between this species and E. roseus in Chile and Argentina are difficult to define because some specimens of E. roseus can be mistaken for E. calcaratus and vice versa, when considering some external features (Correa-Quezada et al. 2017). Subpopulations from around Villarrica, Chile originally identified as this species belong to E. roseus (Correa-Quezada et al. 2017).
This is a restricted concept of Litoria meiriana following the split of the broader concept into this and L. aurifera (Anstis et al. 2010).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Ranoidea (Litoria) serrata (Richards et al. 2010). This species is considered to be a taxonomic complex, which requires further work to be carried out (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

Neobatarchus centralis was synonymized under this species by Roberts (2010).

The ending of this species name was emended from sudelli to sudellae to reflect the gender of the person for which the species was named (Shea 2012). Following Dubois (2007) this emendation is rejected as being unjustified.
This is a restricted concept of Crinia riparia following the split of the broader concept into this and Crinia flindersensis (Donnellan et al. 2012).
Uperoleia capitulata was synonymised under U. rugosa by Catullo and Keogh (2014).
This is a restricted concept of Uperoleia trachyderma following the split of the broader concept into this and U. stridera (Catullo et al. 2014).

A genetic study by Donnellan (2008) identified a northern and southern lineage of this species that apparently meet in the Barrington Tops region of central coastal New South Wales. The divergence between these two lineages is greater than levels of divergence observed among other Mixophyes species (Donnellan 2008), which suggests the likelihood that more than one taxon currently exists within this species. Hunter and Gillespie (2011) recommend that "until this taxonomic issue is resolved, the northern and southern lineages of the Stuttering Frog should be given the highest level of conservation priority and managed independently".

We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois et al. (2021), who synonymized this genus with Platyplectrum. This assessment retains Lechriodus as a distinct genus until further data has been acquired.
This is the only species of the Ranidae family in Australia.

A recent taxonomic revision of this species has restricted this species' range (Catullo et al. 2011). It was previously considered to have a very wide distribution, but Catullo et al. (2011) found that over 70% of museum records actually belong to other Uperoleia species in the arid zone.
Taxonomic revision of this species has increased its range and preferred habitats (Catullo et al. 2011)

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

According to Tyler et al. (1981), the identity of the animals in New Guinea is Uperoleia lithomoda. However, vocal data are needed to confirm whether or not the animals belong to this species or to U. mimula.
This species was redefined by Davies et al. (1992).

Pseudophryne covacevichae was split from this species based on differences in colouration and breeding season (Ingram and Corben 1994). Now with the help of genetics as well as range extensions for both species and other information, Zozaya and Hoskin (2015) have questioned whether P. covacevichae warrants separate species status. However, they recommend further phylogenetic analysis to provide clarity before any taxonomic changes are made.
This is a restricted concept of Pseudophyrne occidentalis following the split of the broader concept into this and Pseudophyrne robinsoni (Donnellan et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Litoria meiriana (Anstis et al. 2010).
We follow Read et al. (2001) in moving this species from Bryobatrachus to Crinia.

Litoria daviesae was separated from L. subglandulosa by Mahony et al. (2001).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Litoria watsoni (Mahony et al. 2020).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

The Minjerriba subpopulation is genetically distinct from the northern subpopulations but there is limited morphological or call divergence, so it is questionable whether or not this is considered species level divergence (H. Hines pers. comm. April 2021).
This species was split from the broader concept of Arenophryne rotunda (Doughty and Edwards 2008).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognized. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

The isolated and genetically distinct Kroombit Tops subpopulation was split from this concept and described as Litoria kroombitensis (Hoskin et al. 2013).

Gillespie and Hines 1999, suggested that this species may represent unusually coloured individuals of Litoria pearsoniana. Donnellan et al. (1999) investigated further and included individuals conforming to the colour pattern and general geographic region described for L. piperata, in a genetic analysis and found that these were not divergent from other north-east New South Wales populations in the L. pearsoniana clade. However, morphologically, it is possible to distinguish between specimens of L. piperata and L. pearsoniana (J. Rowley pers. comm. September 2021). Hoskin et al. (2013) considers that the description of L. piperata (Tyler and Davies 1985) lacks a sufficiently detailed diagnosis to determine the validity of the name, and hence that the validity of L. piperata will remain unresolved without genetic or call data from the type locality. Despite extensive survey effort, the species has not been recorded within its historic range since 1973 (J. Rowley pers. comm. August 2021). The original type material has also been fixed in formalin which has to date prevented the sequencing of sufficient genetic material to further resolve its taxonomic status (Donnellan et al. 1999, Gillespie and Hines 1999; J. Rowley pers. comm. August 2021).


We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognized. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

There is currently uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species. It occurs in two disjunct isolates separated by 500 km, but the most recent taxonomic study by Thomson et al. (1996) suggests that they represent one species. More recently the genetic distinctness of this species from closely related Litoria species, in particular L. raniformis, is also being questioned and additional taxonomic research is required (Voros et al. 2010 in Threatened Species Scientific Committee 2019). For the purposes of this assessment, the species is considered to be valid and contain a northern and southern subpopulation, pending further taxonomic resolution.
Rowley et al. (2021) revised the taxonomy and range of this species and named two new species, L. balatus and L. quiritatus from within the previous concept.

Litoria jungguy and L. wilcoxii were separated from this species by Donnellan and Mahony (2004).

This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species includes three deeply divergent mitochondrial DNA lineages, distributed from Paluma to Tully River, Tully River to Lamb Range, and Mount Lewis to Big Tableland (Schneider, Cunningham and Moritz 1998).
The northern and southern populations could comprise different species (Penman et al. 2004, Hunter et al. 2018), but this requires further taxonomic research.

Zozaya and Hoskin (2015) discuss the taxonomic status of this species relative to Pseudophryne major, and recommend a phylogenetic analysis be done to resolve whether or not it may be a synonym of this wide ranging species.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

There is clear division in mt and nuclear DNA between subpopulations north and south of the Black Mountain Corridor (Bell et al. 2012).
Hoskin (2004) suggested that Cophixalus peninsularis may be a synonym of C. crepitans, but recommended that further field work and taxonomic research is needed to confirm this.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species is comprised of two distinct subspecies, Litoria verreauxii verreauxii from the coast and ranges, and L. v. alpina from the southern Alps. However, recent taxonomic studies do not support the recognition of these two subspecies, although they suggest further research is still needed to assess the validity of their taxonomic status (Smith et al. 2003, Banks et al. 2020).

We follow Donnellan et al. (1999) and Mahony et al. (2001) in treating this as a species distinct from Litoria phyllochroa. This species was revalidated by Donnellan and Mahony (2004).

This is a restricted concept of Assa darlingtoni following the split of the broader concept into this and Assa wollumbin (Mahony et al. 2021). A. wollumbin is restricted to only one mountain, and the two species are separated by only about 15 km. The original description of A. wollumbin also includes some localities for which the identity of specimens are still uncertain. For this assessment they have been kept within Assa darlingtoni.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. Martin (1972) split this species from Limnodynastes dorsalis in southwestern Australia and revived several subspecies of L. dumerilii - L.d. dumerili, L.d. insularis, L.d. grayi and L.d. fryi. The subspecies reflect spatial variation in body pattern and shape which is not always supported by clear differences in male call. The status of L.d. dumerili, L.d. variegatus, L.d. insularis and L.d. fryi are also supported by mt DNA sequence data (Schauble et al. 2000). However, data in Schauble et al. (2000) suggest that L.d. grayi is more closely related to L. terrareginae than to any L. dumerilii subspecies suggesting the taxonomy is in need of revision (J.D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016).
Mahony et al. (2006) separated Mixophyes carbinensis and M. coggeri from this species.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain with Catullo and Keogh (2014) claiming this species has not been collected since the 1900s despite several “records” in the Atlas of Living Australia data base (ALA). Paul Doughty was not confident about identifications of specimens in the Northern Territory Museum (several records in ALA data) following Catullo’s comprehensive work on this genus (D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016). Specimens have been variously accepted and rejected as being this species (e.g. see Davies 1989).

Only the type specimen of this species is known and that cannot be attributed to any currently described Uperoleia species based on its morphology. Ancient DNA techniques might be able to resolve its taxonomic status in regards to currently recognised species which might result in the synonymy of a currently used species name with Uperoleia marmorata (D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016).

This species is genetically identical to Litoria moorei, a claim supported by data from 24 allozyme loci (Cale 1991), immunological comparisons of albumin (Roberts and Maxson 1988) and comparisons of mt DNA markers (ND4 sequences, Burns and Crayn 2006).  Synonymy with L. moorei is justified despite pattern differences (D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016), but has not yet been confirmed.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Litoria barringtonensis that was previously considered a synonym of this species (Tyler and Knight 2009), an arrangement supported by Hoskin et al. (2013). In addition, the isolated population at Kroombit Tops in Queensland has been described as Litoria kroombitensis by Hoskin et al. (2013).

Departing from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognized. Litoria corbeni was considered a synonym of this species by Ingram et al. 1982. This arrangement is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018) and is followed here pending further taxonomic research.

Litoria spaldingi was resurrected from the synonymy of this species by Donnellan et al. (2021). The specific name is sometimes incorrectly spelled wotjulumensis.

This species was revalidated and removed from the synonymy of L. phyllochroa by Tyler and Knight (2009) and supported by Hoskin at al. (2013).

Previously recognised as an outlying population of frogs in the Litoria phyllochroa group – specifically L. pearsoniana and L. barringtonensis (Hoskin et al. 2013).

Australian subpopulations formerly known as Litoria genimaculata were separated from New Guinea forms by Richards et al. (2010).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This is a split from the broader concept of Crinia riparia (Donnellan et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudophryne occidentalis (Donnellan et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Uperoleia trachyderma (Catullo et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Chiasmocleis royi (Peloso et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of Epipedobates boulengeri following the split of this broader concept into this and E. darwinwallacei (Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2011 "2010").

This is a restricted concept of Epipedobates espinosai following the split of the broader concept into this and E. darwinwallacei (Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2011 "2010"). Preliminary results from phylogenetic analyses suggest that E. espinosai, E. darwinwallacei and E. boulengeri are synonymous under the name of E. espinosai, but further work is needed to untangle the E. boulengeri complex (López Hervas 2017, R. Tarvin pers. comm. 2018).

Rulyrana saxiscandens, Cochranella croceopodes and Rulyrana tangarana are considered to be synonymous based on available morphological, bioacoustic, and phylogenetic evidence (Twomey et al. 2014). Under the Principle of the First Reviser of the ICZN (article 24.2.2) precedence is given to saxiscandens, rendering R. tangarana and C. croceopodes junior synonyms of R. saxiscandens.
This is a restricted concept of Batrachoseps relictus following the split of the broader concept into this and B. altasierrae (Jockusch et al. 2012).

Specimens from the Upper Kern River were originally assigned to Batrachoseps simatus by Brame and Murray (1968), who noted that there were morphological differences. Jockusch and Wake (2002) and Jennings (2004) treated these specimens as an undescribed lineage, until Jockusch et al. (2012) described them as B. bramei. Additionally, subpopulations from Breckenridge Mountain that were tentatively assigned to this species by Stebbins (1985) are now recognized as B. relictus (Jockusch et al. 2012).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the splits of the broader concept into this and Bufo spinosus (García-Porta et al. 2012, Recuero et al. 2012).

Following genetic analysis, parts of the former range of this species (e.g. Jersey, western and southern France, Andorra, and the Iberian Peninsula) have been assigned to Bufo spinosus which has been elevated from subspecies level (García-Porta et al. 2012, Recuero et al. 2012).

Crossodactylus boulengeri was removed from the synonymy of this species and C. werneri was split from this species by Pimenta et al. (2014). A single specimen from 1961 in the Argentinean province of Misiones previously assigned to this species is now recognised as Crossodactylus schmidti (Pimenta et al. 2014, Ferraro et al. 2018). Records from Itatiaia in Pimenta et al. (2014) are now treated as belonging to C. werneri (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Rana luteiventris was previously included in this species before being elevated to species status by Green et al. (1996, 1997).
This is a restricted concept of Desmognathus wrighti following the split of the broader concept into this and D. organi (Crespi et al. 2010).
Pereyra et al. (2013) noted that the record of Elachistocleis bicolor for Tarija Province, southeastern Bolivia, is assignable to Elachistocleis haroi (Frost 2020).

This species was removed from synonymy with Elachistocleis ovalis by Lavilla et al. (2003). This is a restricted concept of Elachistocleis bicolor following the split of the broader concept into  Elachistocleis cesarii (Toledo et al. 2010) and Elachistocleis haroi (Pereyra et al. 2013). This taxon may represent a species complex (Pereyra et al. 2013, Marsà and Agnolín 2018).

Jacobs (1987) examined allozyme variation and concluded that the Eurycea bislineata subspecies (bislineata, cirrigera and wilderae) should be regarded as distinct species. Most subsequent authors, including Sever (1999), have followed this treatment, but Petranka (1998) retained these taxa as subspecies of E. bislineata, pending study of genetic interactions in contact zones. Camp et al. (2000) examined allozyme and morphological variation in Eurycea at a contact zone between E. cirrigera and E. wilderae in Georgia and concluded that the two are distinct species. Kozak and Montanucci (2001) examined genetic variation across a wilderae-cirrigera contact zone in South Carolina, found evidence of an extended history of reduced gene exchange, and concluded that the two are distinct species.

The status of Eurycea aquatica has been resolved. Sever (1999) sugggested that E. aquatica might be a valid species, but some checklists did not regard E. aquatica as a valid species and instead included it in E. cirrigera (Crother et al. 2000, 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) or E. bislineata (sensu lato, Petranka 1998). However, it is now recognized as distinct from both E. cirrigera and E. bislineata (Frost 2015).

Furthermore, E. arenicola was split from this species by Stuart et al. (2020). Pierson (2019) and Kozak et al. (2006) noted that E. cirrigera likely represents a complex of several different species that are not closely related. A study conducted by Pierson et al. (2021) in the contact zone within Georgia further confirmed that there are distinct species currently in the area.
Eurcea subfluvicola is a recently described species which is split from E. multiplicata (Steffen et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyla felixarabica (Gvoždík et al. 2010).

This is a restricted concept of Hylarana siberu following the split of the broader concept into this and Hylarana centropeninsularis (Chan et al. 2014) and is now known as Pulchrana siberu after a phylogenetic review by Oliver et al. (2015).

Records from mainland Sumatra are considered to belong to an undescribed species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017), but are treated here as Pulchrana siberu pending the description of the new species.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Chalcorana parvaccola (as Hylarana parvaccola - Inger et al. 2009) and Chalcorana rufipes (as Hylarana rufipes - Inger et al. 2009).

This species was moved from the genus Hylarana to Chalcorana by Oliver et al. (2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Hyloscirtus criptico (Coloma et al. 2012) and Hyloscirtus antioquia (Rivera-Correa and Faivovich 2013).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Hyloxalus italoi and Hyloxalus yasuni (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010). Specimens from Colombia are provisionally assigned to this taxon pending future taxonomic revision to clarify their status.

The Kyushu populations formerly assigned to this species have now been described as new species; Hynobius amakusaensis, Hynobius osumiensis and Hynobius shinichisatoi by Nishikawa and Matsui 2014. Hynobius hirosei, from Shikoku, was removed from the synonymy of this species by Nishikawa et al. 2007.
According to Faivovich et al. (2020), Boana bandeirantes, B. beckeri, and B. latistriata, are junior synonym of B. polytaenia.

This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachium abbotti following the split of the broader concept into this and L. kantonishikawai (Hamidy and Matsui 2010, 2014).

This species is believed to taxonomic complex, with only the sensu stricto species only known from eastern Kalimantan and possibly Sabah, but further taxonomic work needs to be carried out (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Lissotriton graecus, L. kosswigi and L. lantzi (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009). L. schmidtleri, previously assigned as a separate species (Pabijanet al. 2017, Wielstra et al. 2018), has been recognized as a subspecies of L.vulgaris by Taxonomic Committee of Societas Europaea Herpetologica (Speybroeck et al. 2021).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Lissotriton maltzani (Sequiera et al. 2020, Speybroeck et al. 2020).
Manzanilla et al. (2007) named the subpopulations from the mainland of Venezuela as Mannophryne venezuelensis.
This is a restricted concept of Meristogenys whiteheadi following the split of the broader concept into this, M. stenocephalus and M. stigmachilus (Shimada et al. 2011).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Microcaecilia marvaleewakeae (Maciel and Hoogmoed 2013). There is some doubt regarding the identity of the two widely separated subpopulations in Suriname and Brazil, and whether they both belong to this species or if there is simply a sampling gap (Maciel and Hoogmoed 2013).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Microhyla mukhlesuri and M. mymensinghensis (Hasan et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Microhyla orientalis (Matsui et al. 2013).
The distribution of this species has been significantly reduced following significant taxonomic revision (see Frost 2020 for a summary of changes).

In the Physalaemus cuvieri clade, Physalaemus olfersii species group (Lourenço et al. 2015). Species redelimited and discussed by Cassini et al. (2010), but remains a complex comprised of several undescribed species.
This is a restricted concept of Polypedates otilophus following the split of the broader concept into this and Polypedates pseudotilophus (Matsui et al. 2014).

This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis luscombei following the split of the broader concept into this and P. miktos (Ortega-Andrade and Venegas 2014). Pristimantis achuar is now considered a junior synonym of P. luscombei, based on morphological and genetic evidence (Ortega-Andrade and Venegas 2014).
This a restricted concept of Proceratophrys cristiceps following the split of Proceratophrys ararype (Mângia et al. 2018).

The species has been a complex for many decades. Proceratophrys melanopogon was split from this species by Heyer et al. (1990), which was also subsequently split into a number of new species. This is a restricted concept of P. appendiculata following the split of the broader concept into this, P. belzebul and P. izecksohni (Dias et al. 2013).
This is a restricted concept of Proceratophrys melanopogon following the split of the broader concept into this and P. gladius, P. itamari, P. mantiqueira and P. pombali (Mângia et al. 2014).
Eto amd Matsui (2014) documented that this is a species complex which will be divided into multiple taxa.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Rana uenoi (Matsui 2014).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split into this and Raorchestes ghatei (Padhye et al. 2013). 

There still may be some cryptic species existing under this concept (N. Modak and A. Padhye pers. comm. September 2020). A comparative study of this species with R. sanctisilvaticus was undertaken by Garg et al. (2021) with the findings supporting the synonymy of R. sanctisilvaticus with this species, but with the recommendation that further population level studies and more comprehensive sampling across the entire range of R. bombayensis are needed before this can be confirmed.
This is a restricted concept of Rhacophorus catamitus following the split of the broader concept into this and Rhacophorus bengkuluensis (Streicher et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of Rhacophorus angulirostris following the split of the broader concept into this and Rhacophorus pseudacutirostris (Dehling 2011).

This is a new concept of Rhinella crucifer following the split of the old concept into this and Rhinella casconi (Roberto et al. 2014), and the synonymization of Rhinella pombali with this species (Chaparro et al. 2007). Records from Misiones and northwestern Corrientes, Argentina are now considered to be Rhinella ornata (Baldissera et al. 2004, D. Baldo pers. comm. 2017). Records from eastern Paraguay remain unresolved, but are unlikely to refer to Rhinella crucifer.

This taxon is a complex currently under revision. Records of this species from Anjanaharibe and Tsaratanana (Raxworthy et al. 1998), Andringitra (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996), and Ambolokopatrika (Andreone et al. 2000) are highly likely to refer to other species, e.g. R. ornata, R. tany, R. vaventy and other undescribed species (Scherz et al. 2014). In the framework of ongoing revision of the Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014, 2015), all available specimens of this complex in European and Malagasy collections have been examined and found only a single specimen was found to correspond to the R. serratopalpebrosa holotype and it is thus considered to be restricted to Marojejy. For this reason, we exclude all uncertain records of this species (F. Glaw and M.D. Scherz pers. comm. November 2015). Records from further south in Madagascar might refer to Plethodontohyla coronata.

The type specimens of Alsodes laevis were re-examined by Cuevas (2013) and one was identified as this species leading to it be reassigned to this species, while the other specimen was identified as Telmatobius laevis.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Scinax catharinae, without comment, by Carvalho-e-Silva and Peixoto (1991). It was treated as a synonym of Scinax rubra by Duellman and Wiens (1993). Pombal et al. (1995) and S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva (pers. comm. 2003) noted that there might be several species covered by the name Scinax alter. Nunes et al. (2012) revised and re-delimited the species, removing Scinax imbegue and Scinax tymbamirim, which were previously confused with S. alter. This reduced concept of Scinax alter is still thought to contain undescribed species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This reassessment is based on the restricted concept of Vitreorana eurygnatha following the split of the broader concept into this and V. baliomma by Pontes et al. (2014).

The broader concept has been restricted following the split of Scinax rogerioi by Pugliese et al. (2009). This new concept remains a complex containing at least one undescribed species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). This species was confused with Scinax duartei prior to its description (Pugliese et al. 2004) and there remains uncertainty regarding its distribution and that of S. curicica and S. rogerioi (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Scinax melanodactylus (now Ololygon melanodactyla) was split from this species by Lourenço et al. (2014). O. melanodactyla and O. agilis overlap in the states of Espirito Santo, Bahia, Sergipe, and Alagoas. This is probably due to confusion between the two species and requires further taxonomic work (Lourenço et al. 2014).

This species previously belonged to the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005) and was subsequently moved from the genus Flectonotus by Duellman et al. (2011). Fritziana ulei was split from this species by Folly et al. (2014).
Tepuihyla phasmatus has been synonymized with this species (Jungfer et al. 2013).

The taxonomy of this species is unclear, and it is likely that is a complex of several undescribed species (F. Andreone and M. Vences pers. comm.). It has been confused with Guibemantis albolineatus, and Guibemantis methueni has recently been removed from the synonymy of this species (Vences et al. 2015). Its southernmost range is now attributed to Guibemantis annulatus and Guibemantis wattersoni. Clarification of the complex and its distribution is therefore required.
This species was moved from Atelognathus to a new genus Chaltenobatrachus, a sister taxon, based on molecular evidence (Basso et al. 2011).

authority: Veloso, Sallaberry A., Navarro, Iturra-C., Valencia, Penna & Díaz, 1982

taxonomicNotes: There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.

This taxonomic identity of this species is an open question due to confusion between Alsodes australis, A. gargola and A. coppingeri. Using molecular and morphological data, Blotto et al. (2013) suggested that previous records of nominal A. australis from Argentina are referable to A. gargola as is a specimen from Futaleufú, Chile.

It has been suggested that this species could be a synonym of A. coppingeri or of A. gargola (Blotto et al. 2013), however, further taxonomic work is required to verify this (Frost 2018).

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes pehuenche, despite resembling this species (C. Correa and D. Vásquez unpubl. data). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, these records are not included within this species' distribution map.

Its tadpole was briefly described as belonging to Telmatobius montanus (Cei and Roig 1965), but was later re-assigned as this species (Cei 1976).

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes hugoi, despite resembling this species (Correa et al. 2018). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, it has not been included within this species' distribution map.

It is possible that Argentinean subpopulations of Alsodes from the forests of Neuquén and Río Negro Provinces might belong to A. verrucosus, although until this can be verified these records have not been included in attempts to map its range.

Only the biological subpopulation at the type locality is known for certain as Eupsophus contulmoensis (C. Castro and F. Rabanal pers. comm. 2015). Biological subpopulations outside of the type locality have varying morphs and their identity is unclear. However, for the purposes of this assessment and until such time as these subpopulations' identities are resolved, they are considered under the nominal form of Eupsophus contulmoensis.

It was removed from the synonymy of Eupsophus roseus by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), where it had been placed by Correa-Quezada et al. (2017).
Removed from the synonymy of Eupsophus roseus by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), where it had been placed by Correa-Quezada et al. (2017).
This form might be a complex of more than one species, and further taxonomic study is required.

Diagnosis of Telmatobius chusmisensis is based on external morphology and osteology of adults, external morphology of tadpoles, karyotype, chromosomal C-banded patterns and Ag-NOR (nucleolar organizer region) position (Formas et al. 2006).

This very widely distributed species is a complex of several species. A phylogeographic study by Vences et al. (2004) suggests that the populations of this species on the Seychelles and the Mascarene islands were introduced from Madagascar. However, the animals on Madagascar appear to have arrived on that island prior to its colonization by humans. Pickersgill (2007) treated Ptychadena hylaea as a separate species, but here we retain it within P. mascareniensis pending a more comprehensive resolution of this species complex. Records from Rwanda, Uganda, Kenya and Egypt were assigned to P. nilotica by Dehling and Sinsch (2013).

This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachium hasseltii following the split of the broader concept into this, Leptobrachium lumadorum, Leptobrachium mangyanorum and Leptobrachium tagbanorum (Brown et al. 2010 "2009").

This species was revalidated by Cuevas (2013) in the context of taxonomic analyses of Alsodes nodosus. As a by-product of re-examining the two type specimens of Alsodes laevis [one icontype of Philippi (an Alsodes specimen), and the syntype FMNHC 9978 (a Telmatobius specimen)]. The icontype of Philippi was assigned as synonym of Alsodes nodosus (by their typical nuptial spiny patches on the chest), and specimen FMNHC 9978 was revalidated as Telmatobius laevis (see Cuevas 2013). 

Following further study by Correa (2017), this species is now considered as a species inquirenda pending additional studies to clarify the uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic status and origin of the one existing specimen.
Adenomus dasi has been synonymized under this species by Meegaskumbura et al. (2015).
This species was previously confused with Eleutherodactylus varleyi (Díaz et al. 2012).

The Brachycephalus ephippium species group is composed of B. bufonoides, B. crispus, B. darkside, B. ephippium, B. garbeanus, B. guarani, B. margaritatus, B. nodoterga, B. pitanga, B. toby, B. rotenbergae, and B. vertebralis.

Brachycephalus atelopoide was initially split from the broader concept by Pombal et al. (2010). However, due to taxonomic problems, there was no recognized population of B. atelopoide. The species has been formalized as a nomen inquirenda (Nunes et al. 2021) and synonymized with this restricted concept of B. ephippium by Bornschein et al. (2021).
Cacosternum poyntoni has been synonymised with this species (Channing et al. 2013).
This is a revised concept following the split of Crossodactylus franciscanus and synonymy of C. bokermanni with this taxon by Pimenta et al. (2015).

Cryptobranchus guildayi synonymized with this species by Bredehoeft and Schubert (2015).

There are likely multiple species currently retained within this concept (T. Pierson pers. comm. June 2021). It is necessary to investigate this species complex and elucidate the taxonomic identity of its members.
Dendropsophus baileyi has been placed in synonymy with this species.
Gower et al. (2013) synonymised Gegeneophis nadkarnii under this species.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Hyla molleri and H. orientalis, which were both elevated from subspecies level (Stöck et al. 2008).
This is a restricted concept of H. ornatus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. japi (de Sá et al. 2015).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Limnonectes kuhlii by Dubois (1987) and Limnonectes laticeps has since been synonymized with this species (Ohler and Deuti 2013). Limnonectes deinodon was removed from synonymy with this species by Dehling (2014), however, more recently it has been suggested that it should remain a synonym (A. Ohler pers. comm. November 2020).

The differences between this species and Dyscophus guineti are not clear. Studies suggest the possibility that this species may be a colour variant of the more widespread D. guineti (Andreone et al. 2006, Glaw and Vences 2007) or support the definition of these two taxa as different evolutionary significant units under the adaptive evolutionary conservation concept (Chiari et al. 2006). The most recent study by Orozco-ter Wengel et al. (2013) suggests a process of introgressive hybridization as the most likely explanation for the genetic pattern observed.
This species is probably in a complex of more than one species with Heterixalus boettgeri and H. madagascariensis.
This species is probably in a complex of more than one species with Heterixalus alboguttatus and H. madagascariensis.
This species is probably in a complex with Heterixalus alboguttatus and H. boettgeri.
It is likely that Heterixalus variabilis is a synonym of this species. It is possible that the population at Kirindy is specifically distinct from those further north (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The identification and validity of this species are uncertain; it is probably a synonym of Heterixalus tricolor (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
Based on genetic and bioacoustic data, Aglyptodactlyus inguinalis has been removed from synonymy of this species (Köhler et al. 2015).
This species is morphologically similar to Boophis sibilans (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
Unidentified specimens from places other than the type locality might belong to this species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Boophis tephraeomystax by Vences and Glaw (2002), where it had been placed by Guibé (1978) and Blommers-Schlösser (1979).
Many previous records of this species refer to Boophis tasymena (Vences and Glaw 2002). This account covers only confirmed records of Boophis erythrodactylus.
The nomenclatural history of this species is discussed by Ohler (1996).

The relationship between this species and Boophis microtympanum has not yet been clarified. Boophis laurenti might simply be a colour morph, but a distinct call has been recorded. More species could be involved, and the whole complex needs revision (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The former subspecies, septentrionalis, was elevated to species rank by Andreone and Randriamahazo (1997).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
Boophis bottae has been separated from this species (Vences and Glaw 2002).
This species was separated from Boophis erythrodactylus by Vences and Glaw (2002).

Specimens from western Madagascar previously assigned to this species can now be reffered to Boophis doulioti (Vences and Glaw 2002). Records from Mayotte (a French island in the Comoro archipelago) belong to undescribed species (Vences et al. 2003).

We follow Vences et al. (2000) in considering this species to belong to the genus Laliostoma in the family Mantellidae, rather than to the genus Tomopterna in the family Pyxicephalidae. A recent paper by Pabijan et al. (2015) found only a shallow genetic differentiation between its subpopulations.
The southernmost populations are assigned to this species only tentatively.

Molecular data indicate the existence of at least two different management units for conservation in this species, corresponding to the north and south of its distribution range (Andreone et al. 2006, Vieites et al. 2006).

We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) and Rabemananjara et al. (2007) in treating populations from northeastern Madagascar and the Sambirano region of northwestern Madagascar, previously assigned to Mantella betsileo, as a separate species: Mantella ebenaui. Several populations resembling M. betsileo have been found in the drier regions of southwestern Madagascar, and are considered here to belong to this species. However, their taxonomic status requires further investigation, as they probably comprise one or two undescribed species (Rabemananjara et al. 2007).

Records of Mantella expectata or M. betsileo from the arid west and southwest Madagascar (including from from Tsingy de Bemaraha) probably refer to a separate, undescribed, species that is not characterized by blue legs (F. Andreone pers. comm., Rabemananjara et al. 2007). Here we consider as Mantella expectata to refer only the populations from Isalo and the thin band further south (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species is genetically very closely related to Mantella baroni (Vences et al. 2004).
This species is closely related to Mantella pulchra (F. Glaw pers. comm.).

This species and Mantella crocea might represent colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm. August 2016, Chiari et al. 2004). Subpopulations with intermediate characteristics between M. crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).
This species was elevated from subspecific to specific status by Vences, Glaw and Böhme (1999). Genetically, it is extremely closely related to Mantella baroni (Perl et al. 2014).
This species is closely related to Mantella madagascariensis (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
This species is probably a species complex (Perl et al. 2014).
This species was redefined, and two new species, Mantidactylus charlotteae and M. zipperi, were described by Vences and Glaw (2004).
The subpopulations in central and northern Madagascar are suspected to belong to an undescribed species or part of the G. bicalcaratus complex (F. Glaw pers. comm. February 2016).
The taxonomic identity of this species is uncertain and in need of clarification (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).

This species belongs to the Gephyromantis asper group and was split from it prior to its first assessment in 2004. The population from Manongarivo is genetically distinct (F. Glaw pers.comm. November 2015).
This species was revised by Vences and Glaw (2001) and Gephyromantis ambohitra was named as a new species. Northernmost records are now attributed to G. ambohitra and G. tahotra (Glaw et al. 2011).
This species is a complex of at least five species (M. Vences pers. comm.).

This species is probably a complex of at least five cryptic species (M. Vences and F. Andreone pers. comm.). Mantidactylus tricinctus was removed from the synonymy of this species by Glaw and Vences (1999).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Gephyromantis decaryi by Glaw and Vences (2000).

Glaw and Vences (1994) pointed out that similar species with different calls might be confused with Blommersia blommersae. Glaw and Vences (2002) described a sibling species, Blommersia sarotra. Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Blommersia cf. blommersae from Sainte Luce and Mandena; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.

Some individuals of this species were previously confused with Mantidactylus aerumnalis, according to Andreone and Gavetti (1994). It belongs to the subgenus Chonomantis (Vences and Glaw 2004). Glaw and Vences (2006) removed Mantidactylus delormei from the synonymy of this species.

This recently described species is similar to Spinomantis peraccae and S. elegans. There is confustion regarding the taxonomy of this Group (additional species might be involved), and a revision is needed.
This species was separated from Mantidactylus albofrenatus (Vences and Glaw 2003). The taxonomy of this species complex is in need of taxonomic revision (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species was revised by Glaw and Vences (2001) who described two sibling species: Gephyromantis tandroka and G. tschenki.
Records from Tsingy de Bemaraha now refer to Gephyromantis atsingy, records from Analavelona and the Kelifely Plateau are in need of confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).

This species is a complex of at least five species, and many localities where it is said to occur are based on misidentifications (M. Vences pers. comm.). We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating Mantidactylus bellyi and M. bourgati from this species.
This species can be confused with Gephyromantis boulengeri and G. leucomaculatus (F. Andreone pers. comm.). Gephyromantis blanci was removed from the synonymy of G. decaryi by Glaw and Vences (2000).
For a definition of Guibemantis depressiceps, see Glaw et al. (2000).
This species is extremely similar to Mantidactylus mocquardi. Together, they probably represent a complex of at least four species (F. Andreone and M. Vences pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species is confused (F. Andreone pers. comm.).

This species is closely related to, and has been confused with, Mantidactylus guttulatus and an undescribed species from the northeast of Madagascar (F. Andreone pers. comm.). Revision of this complex is urgently needed.
Specimens from mid altitude at Tsaratanana (northwestern Madagascar) belong to a newly described species, Gephyromantis zavona (Vences et al. 2002).

This species is closely related to, and has been confused with, Mantidactylus grandidieri and an undescribed species from the northeast of Madagascar (F. Andreone pers. comm.). Revision of this complex is urgently needed.

This species was revised by Vences et al. (2002).

It was described from Nosy Be Island over 100 years ago and never seen there again (many species have Nosy Be as their type locality because an important port was situated there, but those species never actually occurred on the island and this record of G. horridus was suspected to one such mistake; however, the natural history museum in Vienna traced a specimen collected by Brancsik in 1890 from the island confirming that the species actually occured on Nosy Be (Glaw and Vences 2011).
This species was previously considered to be part of Gephyromantis boulengeri (Glaw and Vences 2002).
This species was considered to be Boophis maculatus by Blommers-Schlosser and Blanc (1991).
This species is a complex of at least four species (M. Vences pers. comm.). We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating Mantidactylus cowanii from the synonymy of this species.
Some published records of this species refer to Gephyromantis plicifer and G. sculpturatus, both of which have recently been resurrected by Vences and Glaw (2001).
The taxonomic distinction between Mantidactylus madecassus and M. pauliani has recently been corroborated on the basis of genetic studies (M. Vences pers. comm.).
A related species, Gephyromantis striatus, was described by Vences et al. (2002).

The specific name was emended to massorum by Vences et al. (2003). However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.2, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2008: http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Mantidactylus opiparis by Vences and Glaw (2004).
This species is here considered to belong to the genus Spinomantis, rather than Boophis, following Glaw and Vences (2006).
This species is extremely similar to Mantidactylus femoralis. Together, they represent a complex of several species (Perl et al. 2014).
This species is a complex of two species, and it is currently under revision (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is in doubt. Some populations assigned to it might belong to other species (Andreone et al. 1998).
This species is similar to Gephyromantis luteus, and some specimens and populations might be confused between these two species. It was recently revised by Vences and Glaw (2001).

Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Guibemantis cf. pulcher from Sainte Luce and Mandena; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Gephyromantis plicifer by Vences and Glaw (2001).
This species was previously included in Gephyromantis malagasius (Vences et al. 2002).
Lowland populations previously attributed to this species have now been described as Guibemantis timidus (Vences and Glaw, 2005).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Mantidactylus biporus by Glaw and Vences (1999) and tentatively redefined by Glaw and Vences (2007). However, additional candidate species have been identified by Vieites et al. (2009) demonstrating that the taxonomic identity of the species is still uncertain and in need of further revision. Candidate species from the subgenus Brygoomantis (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).

This wide-ranging species, which occurs in both wet and dry forest, is probably a complex of many species. Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Rhombophryne cf. tetradactyla from Sainte Luce and Mandena, but the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included in this concept of the Mantidactylus ulcerosus. Records from Isalo have been confirmed as belonging to an undescribed species, and the same is the case for Ranomafana records where other closely related species are present instead of M. ulcerosus, but these are retained within the current concept pending formal description (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016). The same might be true for the populations in the southeast; an expedition a few years ago to the area of Saint Luce and Tsitongambarika and did not record the species - specimens were found to be from other closely related species (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016). For the Mantadia area there was no confirmation of the species' presence using molecular data and Gehring et al. (2010) did not record M. ulcerosus in their extensive survey of the northeast cost (above Toamasina) or the Betampona area (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016).
This species was recently revised by Vences et al. (2002).

This form is a wide-ranging species that occurs in many habitats. It seems likely that it will prove to be a complex of sibling and cryptic species. The sub-population that occurs in Isalo Massif appears to be genetically differentiated from sub-populations of the eastern slope, although phylogenetic relationships need to be confirmed (Mercurio et al. 2008).
This species is similar to Mantidactylus albofrenatus (Vences and Glaw 2004).
Undescribed species of Cophyla exist, and taxonomic studies are under way. Some specimens currently assigned to Cophyla phyllodactyla might belong to unnamed species.
The differences between this species and Dyscophus antongilii are not clear.
The wide range of habitats occupied by this species and obvious geographic variation in morphology and color suggest that more than one species is involved.
This form is a complex of more than one species comprising many undescribed species (F. Andreone pers. comm.).
The taxonomic validity of this species is unknown (F. Glaw pers. comm. Nov. 2014).
This species could be a complex of several species (C. Raxworthy pers. comm.). Glaw and Vences (2007) restricted the species to its northern range.

Plethodontohyla mihanika has been separated from this species (Vences et al. 2004). However, it is likely that P. notosticta, as redefined, still comprises more than one species. M. Vences, F. Glaw, R.A. Nussbaum, and C.J. Raxworthy are currently studying the taxonomy of the forms previously referred to Plethodontohyla notosticta.
Some records of this species might be confused with Scaphiophryne calcarata.
This species has sometimes been confused with Scaphiophryne brevis; its taxonomy requires revision, since it is a complex of more than one species (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The name Scaphiophryne madagascariensis applies to populations formerly included in S. pustulosa (Vences et al. 2002).
Scaphiophryne spinosa has been separated from this species by Vences et al. (2003). The western subpopulations have also been separated as S. menabensis (Glos et al. 2005).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Scaphiophryne marmorata by Vences et al. (2002).
The taxonomy of this species is unclear and is currently under taxonomic revision (M.D. Scherz pers. comm., February 2016).

This species was synonymized with Stumpffia psologlossa by Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc (1991). However, we follow Glaw and Vences (1994) in treating it as a separate species. D'Cruze et al. (2007) recorded Stumpffia cf. roseifemoralis from Montagne des Français; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.

This species is under taxonomic revision. It is possible that the populations assigned to this name belong to more than one species.
 

Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Stumpffia cf. tetradactyla from Sainte Luce and Mandena; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.
This species is undergoing taxonomic revision. It has probably been confused with Stumpffia tetradactyla.
This species was separated from Guibemantis tornieri (Vences and Glaw 2005).

We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) and Rabemananjara et al. (2007) in treating populations from northeastern Madagascar and the Sambirano region of northwestern Madagascar, previously assigned to Mantella betsileo, as a separate species: Mantella ebenaui.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating this species from Mantidactylus curtus.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating this species from Mantidactylus curtus.

We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in treating this as a species distinct from Mantidactylus lugubris. Candidate species from the subgenus Hylobatrachus (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in removing this species from the synonymy of Mantidactylus brevipalmatus.

authority: Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: H. okarkarri was synonymized under this species by Channing and Howell (2006).
H. reesi has been synonymized under this species by Channing and Howell (2006).

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Afrixalus uluguruensis. However, molecular data show that this might represent more than one species (S. Loader pers. comm. Oct 2015).

Pickersgill (2000, 2005) considers this form to be a subspecies of Afrixalus stuhlmanni, with which it hybridizes as forests are cleared. We follow Schiøtz (1999, and pers. comm.) in considering it to be a valid species. However, we follow Pickersgill (2005) and K. Howell (pers. comm.) in considering it to occur in the coastal areas of Tanzania, as well as in the Shimba Hills in Kenya.
This species has been resurrected from synonymy with Sclerophrys maculatus by Poynton et al. (2016).

authority: Wang, Lau, Yang, Chen, Liu, Pang & Liu, 2015

taxonomicNotes: A record from Marojejy (Köhler et al. 2015) is currently assigned to A. inguinalis, but further study is expected to place it under A. chorus.

This species has been removed from synonymy of Aglyptodactylus madagascariensis (Köhler et al. 2015). A record from Marojejy (Köhler et al. 2015) currently assigned to A. inguinalis is included in this concept, but is expected to be assigned to A. chorus following further study. It is possible this species could be a taxonomic complex with different lineages at Marojejy, Tampolo/Betampona and in the southeast, although further research is required and confirmation of the identity the sub-population in Anzahamaru (type locality) is needed through new collections (Köhler et al. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. The paratypes and other specimens from outside the general vicinity of the type locality might include more than one species.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
