It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic relationships have been elucidated by Faivovich et al. (2014) based on molecular data. The taxonomic status of the disjunct population from Venezuelan Amazonas state is currently under study (Rojas-Runjaic pers. comm.).

This form is a complex of more than one species currently undergoing revision (A. Angulo pers. comm. 2008). Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) suggested that Paraguayan records previously assigned to this species are based on misidentifications, probably belonging to Adenomera diptyx following De la Riva (1996). Fouquet et al. (2019) noted that the inselberg subpopulation of southern French Guiana and farther south is unlikely to be conspecific with the nominate species found along the coast. 

Morphology of toe tip fragments and the original species description suggest that A. hylaedactyla could correspond to at least two described species (A. andreae or A. simonstuarti) or additional unnamed genetic lineages of the A. andreae clade. While additional data can be obtained from the holotype of A. hylaedactyla, at this time this type cannot be unequivocally assigned to any species of Adenomera distributed across eastern Ecuador and Peru’s northernmost region of Loreto (de Carvalho et al. 2019).

Several linages belonging to the Adenomera hylaedactyla clade have been identified in the Brazilian biomes of Amazonia, Cerrado and Atlantic Forest (de Carvalho et al. 2019). These authors attributed a pan-Amazonian distribution for the nominal A. hylaedactyla and discussed that linages outside the Amazon biome may be undescribed species and needs to be studied further.
This taxon is probably a complex of 2–3 species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. January 2021).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This taxon is a complex of species and requires rigorous revision through an integrative taxonomic approach (T. Angarita-Sierra pers. comm. June 2019).
This species was mistakenly reported as Pristimantis cabrerai by Kattan (1984).
Mention of this species by Kattan (1984) refers to P. capitonis.
Lynch (1996b) notes misidentifications in earlier accounts.
This species is a complex of more than one species.

Records from the western slope of the Serranía de los Paraguas in Chocó Department and Valle de Cauca Department (Castro-Herrera and Vargas-Salinas 2008) might actually refer to another species, P. molybrignus (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018), and therefore are excluded from this species' extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work is carried out.
This species was redescribed by Lynch (1970).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species is closely related to Pristimantis fallax, P. gutturalis and P. lanthanites. Lynch and Suarez (2000), in describing the species, repeatedly used the incorrect spelling P. epicurus instead of P. epacrus.

Rhaebo anderssoni has been synonymized under this species by Barrio-Amorós and Castroviejo-Fisher (2007). Following the description of Rhaebo ecuadorensis, specimens previously identified as Rhaebo guttatus and “Rhaebo glaberrimus” collected from central and southern Peru, Bolivia, and Brazil are recommended for re-examination to verify their identity (Mueses-Cisneros et al. 2012). 

In Peru, the subpopulations of Madre de Dios are considered to be Rhaebo guttatus. However, all Peruvian subpopulations have been included in this assessment until such time as their taxonomic identity can be clarified (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
Following genetic and morphological studies, this species was moved from Pristimantis to the newly described Tachiramantis (Heinicke et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This is the sister species of Pristimantis bellona according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996b).
The records reported from Chocó Department are not reliable and require confirmation (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016).

The diagnostic differences between this form and geographically proximate members of the taxon are not well documented, nor are the species' distributions.

In the 2004 and 2014 assessments, it was reported to occur in Panama, however, this is an error and the species does not occur in this country (R. Ibáñez pers. comm. 2019).
Crawford et al. (2013) detected potential cryptic lineages within this taxon.
According to the original description, some records of Pristimantis cruentus from western Colombia and western Ecuador might actually be this species.
Confused with Epipedobates boulengeri prior to its naming (Mueses-Cisneros et al. 2008).

Due to a typographic error on the title of the paper describing this species (Lynch 1995), the name was given as P. lasallorum. However, the correct spelling is P. lasalleorum. Lynch (1995) gives the correct spelling elsewhere in the original description.
This taxon has previously been confused with Pristimantis calcaratus (Lynch 1998). It was previously assessed under the name Pristimantis kelephas; this was an incorrect subsequent spelling.

Duellman (1981) originally placed the taxon in the genus Centrolenella, which was subsequently designated to Cochranella by Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) based on the absence of humeral spines in males from specimens collected at Campamento Chancos, Valle del Cauca. However, Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006) verified the presence of humeral spines in the material described by Duellman (1981), thus combining the taxon with Centrolene; the Colombian material reported by Lynch and Ruiz-Carranza (1996) were therefore presumed to be of a distinct lineage (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006). The lack of clarity regarding Colombian specimens is reflected in many published accounts (e.g. Acosta-Galvis 2000, Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007, Guayasamin and Frenkel 2018).

Later, in a monographic revision of the glassfrog family, Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) underscored the difficulty of substantively designating the taxon at the generic level, and regarded the taxon as incertae sedis within the subfamily Centroleninae. Finally, after incorporating mitochondrial sequences into a phylogenetic analysis of the family, Guayasamin et al. (2019) determined its placement within Nymphargus based on recent material from the Río Manduriacu Reserve, Imbabura, Ecuador (Maynard et al. 2020). New material for N. balionotus from Colombia has not been reported in recent decades. Thus, it is not currently possible to resolve whether or not the subpopulation from Campamento Chancos is representative of a distinct lineage from those in Ecuador, as suggested by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006). However, it is plausible that this scenario is correct based on available information; in addition to lacking humeral spines, the records from Campamento Chancos are well separated from, and substantially lower in elevation than all other specimens (Maynard et al. 2020).
Guayasamin et al. 2009 considered this species to be incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
This is a species complex (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.)
Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007) noted that this species may occur in Ecuador.
Eleutherodactylus chlorosoma was synonymized with P. prolixodiscus by Lynch (2003). Heinicke et al. (2015) assigned prolixodiscus as type species to Tachiramantis.

Given the morphological similarity of Nymphargus garciae with N. nephelophila and N. oreonympha, it is possible that they are the same species with phenotypic geographic variation (Guayasamín et al. 2018).
Named as Cochranella punctulata by Ruiz-Carranza and Linch in 1995, the genus has then been reviewed and replaced with Sachatamia by Guayasamin et al. in 2009.
Taxonomic status of the subpopulation on Gorgona Island should be reviewed, as it probably corresponds to a different species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2016)

This species is regarded as an incertae sedis within Centroleninae by Guayasamin et al. (2009). The species is very similar to Rulyrana susatamai and further taxonomic research is needed to determine the species boundaries (M. Rada pers. comm. February 2017).
This is the sister species of Rhinella acrolopha, according to the original description.
Subpopulations of the south and the dry coast are believed to correspond to another undescribed species (M. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2020).
This species has not been included in phylogenies based on molecular characters, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2018).

This is a species complex that requires formal subdivision (Guayasamín et al. 2006, 2020; Amador et al. 2018). Amador et al. (2018) provided molecular evidence that nominal Centrolene buckleyi is composed of at least three species, none of which is each other's closest relative, one in southern Ecuador, two (including Centrolene buckleyi sensu stricto) in northern Ecuador, and another in central Andean Colombia, with the edges remaining unknown (Frost 2021).

Two specimens from Huancabamba in Piura Department in northern Peru (Duellman and Wild 1993) previously assigned to this species are actually metamorphs of another species (Amador et al. 2018; D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021). All records of this species from Venezuela formerly assigned to this taxon are now assigned to Centrolene venezuelense.
In spite of its Amazonian type locality, this species is in fact known only from the Andes.
Phylogenetic relationships in Guayasamin et al. (2009), whom proposed the new genus Espadarana with Centrolenella andina Rivero 1968 as type species.
As used by Lynch and Duellman (1973) this name applies to the species currently recognized as Centrolenella lynchi.
This species was considered to be a synonym of Hylopsis platycephalus Werner, 1894, by Lynch (1981b), but this was not accepted by McDiarmid and Savage (1984).
This is a taxonomic complex and requires review (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018).
Eleutherodactylus pulidoi was synonymized with this species by Lynch (2003).

Although this appears to be a relatively widespread species, it apears to be composed of multiple species with restricted distributions, with considerable variation in ecological requirements (T. Grant and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.). Páez-Moscoso and Guayasamin (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this taxon is a species complex.
It may be a complex of more than one species (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2010).

The Colombian subpopulations have different skin texture and some morphological differences compared to Ecuadorian subpopulations. More research is needed to determine whether or not this is in fact two separate species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Initial records proposed for this species in Colombia (Lynch et al. 1994), subsequently cited by Ruiz-Carranza et al. (1996) and Acosta-Galvis (2000), were previously identified as Pristimantis cruentus.

This species appears closely related to the Rhinella margaritifera and R. veraguensis species groups (Pereyra et al. 2016) and is considered a species complex (O. Armesto-Sanguino pers. comm. March 2017).
This form is a complex of species.
The form is the sister species of Pristimantis appendiculatus according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996).

This species is in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex, according to the original description. Heyer (1998) suggested that this species might be the sister taxon of Vanzolinius.
Records from Putumayo previously ascribed to this species likely pertain to Ameerega bilinguis (J. Mueses-Cisneros pers. comm. August 2016)

The name Leptodactylus lithometes by La Marca (1997) is a lapsus calami. This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus pentadactylus group. It is a sister species of Leptodactylus rugosus (De Sá et al. 2014), with which it was confused in the past (e.g., Rivero 1961 [in part], Gorzula and Señaris 1998 [in part]).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus wagneri by Heyer (1994), who provided an account and considered it to be in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex.

Magalhães et al. (2020) reviewed and revised this species, noting that one lineage is linked to nominal L. latrans, one lineage is revalidated as Leptodactylus luctator, and the other two lineages are formally named and described as L. payaya and L. paranaru.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Ranitomeya ventrimaculata by Symula et al. (2001), where it had been placed by Caldwell and Myers (1990). Following the results from Brown et al. (2011), the highland and lowland frogs actually belonged to the same species, and due to incorrect usage of ventrimaculata, R. variabilis became the valid name.
It is possible that this is a complex of several species (Lötters et al. 1999), with true Oophaga sylvatica occurring in Ecuador.

The frogs identified as Leptodactylus mystaceus in Paraguay are actually L. elenae (Brusquetti and Lavilla 2006). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) comment on its range and literature, noting that subpopulations north of the Río Orinoco probably represent an unnamed species, and Alves da Silva et al. (2020) reported an unnamed species that differs in advertisement call in the state of Tocantins, Brazil. Three lineages of the L. mystaceus complex were named and described as new species by Alves da Silva et al. (2020). Lineages referred to as L. cf. mystaceus that occur in the northeastern, central and southeastern regions of Brazil, outside of the Amazon biome, are possibly a species not yet described (Alves da Silva et al. 2020; T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020), however, they are considered in this assessment pending further taxonomic work.
It is considered a species complex (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop 2016).

Fouquet et al. (2019) suggested that this binomial represents a species complex. Records from southern Venezuela are misidentified specimens of Leptodactylus riveroi (Heyer and Pyburn 1983). Gorzula and Señaris (1998) confused a large specimen of L. guianensis (as L. bolivianus) with L. rhodomystax (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Central American records of Leptodactylus formerly allocated to L. pentadactylus are now recognized as the distinct species L. savagei (Heyer 2005).

Vouchers absent from Venezuelan museums (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019); all pentadactylus-like frogs from southern Venezuela identified as Leptodactylus knudseni. Heyer’s (2005) review of the pentadactylus species group does not mention any voucher from Venezuela. De Sá et al. (2014) show four Venezuelan localities in a distribution map, but without vouchers. Nonetheless, this species is maintained in the Catalogue of the amphibians of Venezuela by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019).

Currently, the species is well delimited after a systematic review of the Leptodactylus melanonotus species group (de Sá et al. 2014, Gazoni et al. 2021). Gazoni et al. (2021) did not find any specimen of L. petersii from Ecuador at the QCAZ collection using DNA sequences and morphological evidence. A previous report from Ecuador by Ron (2002) was based on a series of specimens from Provincia Sucumbíos (QCAZ 20242–7). Subsequently, the specimens were examined by Thiago R. de Carvalho, who suggested that the series should probably be conspecific with L. wagneri.
It is likely that some reports from the southern coast of Ecuador and northern Peru (e.g., Frost 2019) actually correspond to Leptodactylus labrosus (Ron et al. 2016).

This species is in the Leptodactylus melanonotus group, Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex (Heyer 1994). Fouquet et al. (2007) provided molecular evidence that this is a species complex
This species was considered a synonym of Hyloxalus fuliginosus by Edwards (1974b).

Allobates was formerly included within Dendrobatidae (Grant et al. 2006). Three subpopulations assigned to this species in the original description are included only tentatively (Lima et al. 2010), and the taxonomy of this species remains to be resolved (A. Lima and I. Kaefer pers. comm. October 2010).
Fouquet et al. (2019) referred to specimens from the Manaus region of Brazil and of the Mitaraka Massif of French Guiana as Pristimantis aff. zimmermanae.

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) restricted the range of Allobates fuscellus based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and noted that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.

Réjaud et al. (2020) noted a cryptic species within this taxon. Jaramillo-Martinez et al. (2021) provided a re-description of the species, including the recognition of a cryptic species including what they referred to as Allobates aff. trilineatus from the Brazilian state of Acre and from southern Peru in Panguana, Huanuco, and Puerto Maldonado, Madre de Dios and Allobates sp. from Requena, Loreto, Peru.
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was redescribed as Hydrolaetare schmidti by Gallardo (1963).
The subpopulations from the Carchi basin might represent a distinct species (Coloma 1995).
This species is considered to be a derivative of Oophaga histrionica by Myers and Daly (1976).

Lötters (1992) doubted the distinction of this species from Oophaga histrionica.

Records from the Serrania de Baudo and Alto del Oso in the Department of Chocó that were previously questioned to belonging to this species have now been verified and assigned as Oophaga solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
There are taxonomic doubts about the identity of the species and it has to be reviewed along with A. fulguritus (D. Mejía pers. comm. August 2016).

Specimens from French Guiana formerly described as Dendrobates quinquevittatus by Silverstone in 1975 actually correspond to this species (Brown et al. 2011). Genetic studies allowed the taxonomic separation between this species and Ranitomeya ventrimaculata (Brown et al. 2011).

Many have suspected that R. amazonica and its sister taxon R. variabilis should be considered a single species. Brown et al. (2011) presented considerable genetic and bioacoustic data that supports the retention of R. amazonica as a valid species, sister to R. variabilis.

This taxon is assigned to the Leptodactylus melanonotus group based on five osteological cranial synapomorphies and molecular evidence (Heyer 1994, De Sá et al. 2014, Acosta Galvis and de Sá 2018). Studies based on molecular evidence, have suggested that two species are likely to exist under this name (Guarnizo et al. 2016, Frost 2020).
Colostethus cacerensis is considered to be a synonym of C. inguinalis following Grant (2004). C. panamensis was removed from synonymy with this species (Grant 2004).
The subpopulations in Ecuador might not be conspecific with the Colombian subpopulations (T. Grant and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Physalaemus enesefae Heatwole, Solano and Heatwole, 1965 is a junior synonym of P. fischeri (Gorzula and Señaris 1999). Ruíz-Carranza et al. (1996) included the species in the fauna of Colombia, and considered Physalaemus neglectus dunni Cochran and Goin (1970) to be a synonym. Its phylogenetic relationships within Physalaemus have been assessed by Lourenço et al. (2015), whom assigned this species to the Physalaemus cuvieri species group.
This form is probably a synonym of another species (Lynch pers. comm.).
The validity of this species was previously in question (Lynch pers. comm; Grant and Myers 2013). However, Grant et al. (2017) recognize this taxon as a distinct species.
This form is potentially a complex of more than one species according to Grant and Castro (1998).

The results of molecular phylogeny suggest that this is probably a complex of more than one species, where the subpopulations separated by the Magdalena Valley, as well as, those present on both sides of the Cordillera Oriental may correspond to different species (Muñoz-Ortiz et al. 2015).

Grant et al. 2006 suggested that this species might be conspecific with Rheobates palmatus, but then Muñoz-Ortiz et al. 2015 confirmed, based on molecular information, that this species could be redescribed, restricting R. pseudopalmatus to the Central Cordillera and R. palmatus to the Eastern Cordillera.
There is ongoing debate about whether this is a valid species or whether it is a synonym of Hyloxalus pulchellus (T. Grant pers. comm., G. Pisso pers. comm. October 2018).

Pseudopaludicola mirandae has been synonymized under this species by Cardozo and Lobo (2009). In addition, this is a restricted concept of Pseudopaludicola boliviana following the allocation of subpopulations from southwestern Brazil (Mato Grosso State) and Santa Cruz, Bolivia to P. motorzinho (Pansonato et al. 2016).

It is thought that the subpopulations in the Guiana Shield and Roraima state in Brazil do not belong to this species, but a new undescribed species for which further taxonomic research must still be carried out (A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2017).

All reports of Allobates brunneus from Venezeula are considered A. aff. marchesianus rather than aff. brunneus as the marchesianus type locality is closer to the Venezuelan southern border (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019; C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020).

Guayasamin et al. (2009) assigned a subpopulation from the eastern versant of the Andes, reported as Hyalinobatrachium ibama by Barrio-Amorós (2006), to H. cf. pallidum. Based on molecular work of Guayasamin et al. (2009) and others, it is doubtful that H. ibama is the species occupying the eastern versant of the Cordillera de Mérida (Barrio-Amorós 2006), but is more likely H. pallidum (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). Moreover, H. ibama from Colombia could be a junior synonym of H. pallidum (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
This is likely a species complex and requires taxonomic revision (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Originally described as Nototrema pygmaeum (Boettger, 1893) and subsequently transferred to Flectonotus (Miranda-Ribeiro 1926), Gastrotheca (Noble 1931), Nototheca (Bokermann 1950) and again to Flectonotus (Duellman 1977). The more recently and exhaustive phylogenetic study, based in total evidence, corroborates its phylogenetic position as part of Flectonotus and sister to F. fitzgeraldi (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015). Barrio-Amorós (2004) stated that Colombian populations actually correspond to a different and yet unnamed species, but later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) appointed that the populations of Venezuelan Coastal Range and those of the Andes are genetically indistinguishable.
This genus has recently been removed from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Originally described under the genus Corythomantis (Mertens 1950), it was later reassigned by Trueb (1970) to the genus Aparasphenon based on morphological characteristics. Recently, Blotto et al. (2021) transferred it to Trachycephalus based on a phylogenetic analysis of the Lophyohylini tribe.
This species was previously within the genus Agalychnis but has since been moved to the genus Cruziohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyloscirtus mashpi (Guayasamin et al. 2015). Duellman (1972) mentions the morphological differences of the subpopulations in the department of Chocó compared to the forms recognized in Ecuador and southern Colombia and Myers and Duellman (1982) point out that morphologically they are more related to Hyloscirtus palmeri.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This form is probably a complex of several species. Brazilian populations assigned to this species presumably belong to another species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This name has been widely used for certain frogs from Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianas and the lower Amazon basin. It is highly likely that the subpopulations along the Caribbean lowlands and the Amazon basin are either specifically distinct (Duellman 1985 In: Frost (ed.), Amph. Species World: 123) or misidentified Boana punctata or Boana cinerascens (Hoogmoed and Gruber 1983; M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2018) or other species. For the purpose of this assessment, we treat B. albomarginata as a Brazilian endemic.
This genus has moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The disjunct subpopulations in Colombia and Ecuador could pertain to different taxa. Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the identity of these subpopulations.
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018). It is probably a synonym of Hyloscirtus lindae.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

The reports of this species in the department of Cauca correspond to a species erroneously identified as Hyla bogotensis by Duellman (1972), see discussion in Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1982).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This species was removed from the synonymy of Dendropsophus carnifex by Kaplan (1997), where it had been placed by Duellman (1974).

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2008), but referred as unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships with P. taeniatus should be further explored, since its position makes the latter paraphyletic in the phylogeny of González-Durán et al. (2017).

authority: Acevedo, Wake, Márquez, Silva, Franco & Amézquita, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Ruiz-Carranza et al. (1996) noted that one of the paratypes of this species is referable to Hyloscirtus palmeri.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and is a complex within which the records from the Cordillera de la Costa, Venezuela have been identified as D. aff. goughi (C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Smilisca phaeota where it had been placed by Duellman (1968). Jungfer (2017) discussed Hyla molitor Schmidt, 1857 and concluded that it was a senior synonym of Hyla labialis Peters, 1853. This is a restricted concept of Dendropsophus molitor (labialis) following the split of the broader concept into this and D. luddeckei (Guarnizo et al. 2012).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Genus changed from Hypsiboas rubracylus to Boana rubracyla following Dubois (2017).

In Ecuador, this species is probably overlooked due to its resemblance with other Boana in western Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).

The vast majority of Synapturanus mirandaribeiroi records represent undescribed species (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). Fouquet et al. (2019) suggested that the subpopulation in the eastern Guyana Shield represents a distinct species. Also, some records from northern Amazonas state in Brazil have been identified as Synapturanus cf. mirandaribeiroi (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
We follow Duellman (2001) and Savage (2002) in considering this as a species distinct from Ecnomiohyla miliaria.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

Ranitomeya toraro, described from western Brazil, had long been misidentified under the names Dendrobates quiquevittatus [now Adelphobates quinquevittaus] and D. ventrimaculatus [now Ranitomeya ventrimaculata] but morphological and phylogenetic data place it sister to R. defleri (Brown et al. 2011).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005), and has now subsequently been moved to Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This taxon, previously included in the genus Hyla, has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). In the Hyloscirtus bogotensis group based on its mtDNA phylogenetic relationships (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018).

Originally described in the genus Hyla, and suggested to be a member of the genera Pseudis (Suárez-Mayorga 2001) and  Scinax (see Frost 2020). It is currently recognized as a member of the genus Scarthyla by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2006), Duellman et al. (2016), also in the most recent Venezuelan and Trinidad checklists (C. Señaris pers. comm. 2020).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Comparisons of DNA sequences, external morphology, and advertisement calls between Tepuihyla tuberculosa from Ecuador and Peru indicate that a Peruvian specimen represents Tepuihyla shushupe (Ron et al. 2016).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Some specimens identified in the past as Otophryne robusta, are now included under this species, especially the subpopulations in the state of Amazonas, Venezuela. Fouquet et al. (2019) suggested that this represents a species complex. The subpopulations of the Eastern Guiana Shield (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, and Amapá and Pará states in northern Brazil) likely belong to an undescribed species (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021; Fouquet et al. 2019, 2021).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form might represent a species complex.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Atelopus ebenoides (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005)
Zweifel and Myers (1989) have posited that the name Ctenophryne geayi actually represents two species (northern and southern populations).

This species is considered to be within the Eleutherodactylus conspicillatus group according to the original publication (Mueses-Cisneros 2006), although superficially the species is very similar to E. douglasi [assigned to the E. galdi group] (J.J. Mueses-Cisneros pers. comm. 2008) E. carranguerorum, and E. savagei. It has been placed in the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007). Removed from the Pristimantis conspicillatus species group and left unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). The species is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Mueses-Cisneros 2006).
This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and transferred again to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010).
Bolitoglossa tatamae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Acosta and Hoyos 2006).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species' genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010).

Taylor (1968) recognized two subspecies, the status of which require more research. It is likely to be a complex of more than one species, and biological subpopulations on the eastern versant of the Andes could possibly correspond to one or more taxa (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2014), but until such time as this is clarified they are included in the current assessment.

High morphological variation associated with geographical distribution has been reported for this species, and museum specimens have been incorrectly identified as belonging this species due to the poor condition of the holotype (Peloso and Sturaro 2008). It is possible that further studies may uncover more misidentified subpopulations. Specimens reported from Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, and Iquitos, Peru show distinctive characteristics which may suggest that they do not belong to this species (Morales and McDiarmid 2009), although this has not been confirmed.
Chiasmocleis jimi was synonymized with this species by Peloso et al. (2014), but this was reversed by da Sá et al. 2018 "2019".
Formerly included within Leptodactylus pentadactylus, but separated by Heyer (2005).
Prior to its description in 2006, Ranitomeya uakarii was commonly referred to as a morph of R. ventrimaculata (then classified as Dendrobates duellmani).

Scinax tsachila is recognized as distinct from this taxon based on genetic, morphologic, and bioacoustic evidence (Ron et al. 2018).

This form might be a complex of more than one species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.). The relationship between this species and Scinax elaeochroa needs to be investigated; they might be conspecific (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.). J. Lynch and K.-H. Jungfer (pers. comm.) consider that Colombian subpopulations might belong to S. elaeochroa.

This species is assigned to the Scinax ruber clade, but not assigned to any species group (Faivovich et al. 2005). Scinax flavidus and Scinax manriquei were described almost simultaneously, and although La Marca (2007) regarded S. flavidus as senior synonym, later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) showed evidence on the seniority of Scinax manriquei over Scinax flavidus (Frost 2020). Mentioned as Scinax sp. 2 in Colombia by Nieto-Castro (1999).

authority: Amézquita, Márquez, Mejía-Vargas, Kahn, Suárez & Mazariegos, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of A. opisthomelas (Amézquita et al. 2013).
Rhaebo lynchi differs from other congeners by a combination of morphological features (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
Allobates niputidea can be differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, including those of tadpoles (Grant et al. 2007).

Espadarana callistommum differs from congenerics by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Guayasamin and Trueb 2007). It is suspected that this species is a synonym of Espadarana prosoblepon, however this requires confirmation through further taxonomic studies (M. Rada pers. comm. December 2018).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis zoilae was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis colonensis was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
Some records of Cochranella euknemos have been reassigned to this species (Jaramillo-Martinez et al. 2015).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004).

Santos et al. (2015) re-delimited Rhinella alata to be restricted to Panama and Chocoan Colombia and Ecuador on the basis of molecular and morphological data. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted that no specifically identified vouchers exist for Venezuela. Like all species of the R. margaritifera complex, there are many taxonomic uncertainties with this taxon.
Nymphargus vicenteruedai is distinguished from other glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Velásquez-Álvarez et al. 2007).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Heinicke et al. (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis jubatus was based on morphological features (García and Lynch, 2006).

Colostethus ucumari can be distinguished from other Colostethus by means of morphological differences and colour patterns; it is also the second species of Colostethus known to possess skin toxins (Grant 2007).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
Magalhães et al. (2020) placed Leptodactylus chaquensis in synonymy with this taxon.
Removed from the synonymy of Osteocephalus buckleyi by Lynch (2006).

There have been some doubts as to whether Rhinella beebei may be a synonym of R. humboldti (E. La Marca pers. comm.). While it was synonymised with R. humboldti for a time following morphological analysis (Narvaes and Rodrigues 2009), the two species are now believed to be distinct and valid in their own right (Murphy et al. 2017).

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptodactylus bolivianus (Heyer and de Sá 2011). Following investigation of the Leptodactylus genus, the species previously known to be L. bolivianus was found to be three separate species L. bolivianus, L. insularum and L. macrosternum. Many papers referring to L. bolivianum refer to L. insularum and this is relatively easy to resolve by looking at study location. The current concept of L. insularum might represent more than one species (T. Angarita-Sierra pers. comm. June 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Dendropsophus riveroi (Ortega-Andrade and Ron 2013).
Specimens from Leticia, Amazonas, Colombia were previously misidentified as Boana fasciata (Acosta-Galvis et al. 2018a).

Páez-Moscoso and Guayasamin (2012) suggested that this taxon is part of an Osornophryne bufoniformis species complex that is poorly elucidated (Frost 2021). It has been suggested that this species is actually a junior synonym of O. bufoniformis (L. Coloma pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Gordo, Toledo, Suárez, Kawashita-Ribeiro, Ávila, Morais & Nunes, 2013
taxonomicNotes:
Trachycephalus cunauaru has a complex taxonomic history and was only recently formally described as a distinct species from Trachycephalus resinifictrix (Gordo et al. 2013). The Ecuadorian records previously considered T. resinifictrix actually belong to this species (Ortiz et al. 2019), and the status of subpopulations (whether T. cunauaru or T. resinifictrix) in Venezuela (Amazon Basin), Peru, and south-eastern Colombia (Amazonas) is provisional and requires genetic confirmation.

A specimen analyzed by Wiens et al. (2010) and Pyron and Wiens (2011) was collected near a "tributary" (east) of “Rio Negro“ in the Venezuelan Amazon. Since the “Rio Negro“ has been suggested as a natural boundary between T. cunauaru (west) and T. resinifictrix (east) (Gordo et al. 2013), the individual analysed by Wiens et al. (2010) and Pyron and Wiens (2011) would be from the transition zone between the two species, so morphological inspection is needed to determine its true identity.
Two new species, Proceratophrys belzebul and P. izecksohni, were described following a taxonomic revision of P. appendiculata (Dias et al. 2013).
It is suspected that this species may be synonymous with Dendrophryniscus proboscideus (V.G. Dill Orrico and M. Sole pers. comm. 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhinella crucifer (Roberto et al. 2014).

authority: Pansonato, Mudrek, Veiga-Menoncello, Rossa-Feres, Martins & Strüssmann, 2014
Orrico, Peloso, Sturaro, Silva, Neckel-Oliveira, Gordo, Faivovich & Haddad, 2014

taxonomicNotes: The subpopulations of this species recorded in São Paulo and Mangaratiba have taxonomic problems and are under revision.
This was removed from the synonymy of Fritziana fissilis by Folly et al. (2014) where it had been placed by Bokermann (1966).
This taxon was confused with Bolitoglossa altamazonica and Bolitoglossa paraensis prior to its naming according to Brcko et al. (2013).
Two new species, Proceratophrys belzebul and P. izecksohni, were described following a taxonomic revision of P. appendiculata (Dias et al. 2013).
This taxon was confused with Bolitoglossa altamazonica and Bolitoglossa paraensis prior to its naming according to Brcko et al. (2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Vitreorana eurygnatha (Pontes et al. 2014).

Parra-Olea et al. (2004) removed Bolitoglossa paraensis from synonymy with Bolitoglossa altamazonica. M.S. Hoogmoed (pers. comm. 2008) indicated that B. paraensis was a complex of 3–4 species; Bolitoglossa caldwellae, Bolitoglossa madeira, and Bolitoglossa tapajonica have since been split from this species by Brcko et al. (2013).

Specimens identified as this species have been detected in the Volta Grande region of the Xingu River (Vaz-Silva et al. 2015). These records would extend this species range approximately 350 km west, potentially overlapping with B. tapajonica, and therefore should be confirmed by future studies.

In 2006, an expedition to the Serra do Tumucumaque (=Tumuc Humac Mountains), Amapá State, Brazil, north of the Amazon river, reported the occurrence of a specimen (IEPA TQ 849) identified as Bolitoglossa cf. paraensis by Lima (2008), but because it is a juvenile its specific identity cannot be confirmed.
This species has been assigned to the Scinax catherinae clade (Cruz et al. 2011).

This is a split from the broader concept of Scinax agilis (now Ololygon agilis) (Lourenço et al. 2014). Ololygon melanodactyla and O. agilis overlap in the states of Espirito Santo, Bahia, Sergipe, and Alagoas. This is probably due to confusion between the two species and requires further taxonomic work (Lourenço et al. 2014).

Species described in 2015, allocated in the group of Brachycephalus pernix, a group composed of 18 formally recognized species (Monteiro et al. 2018). Based on molecular data they confirmed the species delimitation (Firkowski et al. 2016). However, Condez et al. (2017) discuss the need for a taxonomic re-evaluation of B. mariaeterezae, due to problems in its diagnosis and original description. Pie et al. (2017) refute the arguments in Condez et al. (2017).

This species was confused with Elachistocleis ovalis prior to its naming according to Toledo (2010). The spelling of the species name has also been corrected from magnus to magna to match the gender of the genus name.

authority: Teixeira, Recoder, Amaro, Damasceno, Cassimiro & Rodrigues, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Genetic analysis showed a large genetic distance between the type series and records from Salesópolis, which may indicate that these are different species (M.T.T. Santos pers. comm. 2021). As a result, the Salesópolis records are not included in the assessment.
This species has been assigned to the Scinax catharinae group (Cruz et al. 2011).
This form requires taxonomic reassessment due to problems in the original diagnosis and description (Condez et al. 2017).

The Crossodactylus dispar complex is thought to contain may microendemics, such that subpopulations assigned to this species but recorded outside Santa Teresa Massif (e.g. Cachoeiro de Itapemirim), probably belong to other undescribed species (J.V. Lacerda pers. comm. 2021).

With the limited number of localities known for each species, low genetic divergence, and limited number of individuals, there remains the possibility that Ranitomeya yavaricola and R. cyanovittata are morphs of the same species (Pérez-Peña et al. 2010). Given the extreme morphological differences between the two species, however, it is believed that they are distinct species that are sister to each other (Pérez-Peña et al. 2010).
This is a split from the broader concept of Physalaemus olfersii (Cassini et al. 2010)
This is a split from the broader concept of Elachistocleis bicolor (Toledo et al. 2010).
Following a taxonomic revision of Proceratophrys melanopogon by Mângia et al. (2014), four new species were described: P. gladius, P. itamari, P. mantiqueira and P. pombali.
Removed from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Pombal Jr. and Izecksohn (2011).
Subpopulations of Scinax fuscomarginatus from Serra do Cachimbo in Pará, Brazil have been assigned to this species (Brusquetti et al. 2014).
This species was confused with Microcaecilia taylori prior to its naming according to Maciel and Hoogmoed (2013).
Removed from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Pombal (2010).

According to Conndez et al. (2017), this species belongs to the Brachycephalus pernix group and requires a taxonomic reassessment due to errors present in the original diagnosis and description considering the use of doubtful diagnostic characters, such as body colour and skin roughness; characteristics that can vary intra-specifically as a consequence of a polymorphism or even be an artefact of specimen preservation.

Following a taxonomic revision of Proceratophrys melanopogon by Mângia et al. (2014), four new species were described: P. gladius, P. itamari, P. mantiqueira and P. pombali. This species may still have taxonomic problems, since it can be confused with P. mantiqueira (D. Santana pers. comm. 2021).
This form requires taxonomic reassessment due to problems in the original diagnosis and description (Condez et al. 2017).

This is a split from the broader concept of Crossodactylus dispar (Pimenta et al. 2014). Records from Teresópolis, Rio de Janeiro are misidentifications of C. aeneus (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

authority: (Pombal, Menezes, Fontes, Nunes, Rocha & Van Sluys, 2012)
taxonomicNotes: This species has been moved to the genus Nyctimantis by Blotto et al. (2021).

Following a taxonomic revision of Proceratophrys melanopogon by Mângia et al. (2014), four new species were described; P. gladius, P. itamari, P. mantiqueira and P. pombali. This species may still have taxonomic problems, since it can be confused with P. itamari (D. Santana pers. comm. 2021).

Pristimantis sp. “J” from the summit of Mount Roraima in Venezuela (see McDiarmid and Donnelly 2005) could be P. aureoventris, but tissue samples and specimens are necessary to corroborate this assumption (Jablonski et al. 2017).
This species has been assigned to the Scinax ruber clade, and is considered part of the Scinax auratus species complex (Nunes and Pombal Jr. 2011).
This is a split from the broader concept of Physalaemus olfersi (Cassini et al. 2010).
This taxon was confused with Bolitoglossa altamazonica and Bolitoglossa paraensis prior to its naming according to Brcko et al. (2013).

authority: Teixeira, Vechio, Recoder, Carnaval, Strangas, Damasceno, Sena & Rodrigues, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Gastrotheca fissipes (Izecksohn et al. 2009).

authority: Teixeira, Vechio, Recoder, Carnaval, Strangas, Damasceno, Sena & Rodrigues, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hylodes ornatus (de Sá et al. 2015).
Removed from the synonymy of Crossodactylus dispar by Pimenta et al. (2014).

This is a split from the broader concept of Scinax duartei (Pugliese et al. 2009). This concept is probably a complex comprised of several undescribed species and there remains uncertainty regarding its distribution and that of S. duartei and S. curicica (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Scinax alter (Nunes et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Boana multifasciata (Carvalho et al. 2010).
Following a taxonomic revision of Proceratophrys melanopogon by Mângia et al. (2014), four new species were described; P. gladius, P. itamari, P. mantiqueira and P. pombali.
This is a restricted concept of Adenomera martinezi following the split of the broader concept into this and A. saci (Carvalho and Giaretta 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Allobates femoralis (Simões et al. 2010).

Twomey and Brown (2008) elevated a morph of Ameerega hahneli to specific status by describing A. altamazonica. Brown et al. (2019) subsequently restricted the range with the naming of A. imasmari and A. panguana.

authority: Fouquet, Souza, Nunes, Kok, Curcio, Carvalho, Grant & Rodrigues, 2015
Fouquet, Souza, Nunes, Kok, Curcio, Carvalho, Grant & Rodrigues, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species was provisionally allocated to Aparasphenodon when first described by de Assis et al. (2013). Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.
This species was removed from synonymy with Bokermannohyla hylax by Napoli and Pimenta (2009).

Bokermannohyla napolii is a newly described species on the basis of adult morphology, morphometrics, and mainly vocalizations. Adult specimens of B. napolii are most closely related to those of B. luctuosa and B. circumdata.

authority: Brandão, Magalhães, Garda, Campos, Sebben & Maciel, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a recent split from the broader concept of Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis. B. sapiranga differs from B. pseudopseudis mostly in the presence of a dermal ridge along outer tarsi, and colour patterns of the eyes and dorsal surface of hand/toe disks (De Carvalho et al. 2013).

Further molecular work is required to better understand the relationship between Brachycephalus crispus, B. guarani, B. pitanga, and B. toby, as it is possible that these represent a single species (T. Condez pers. comm. 2021).

Further molecular work is required to better understand the relationship between Brachycephalus crispus, B. guarani, B. pitanga, and B. toby, as it is possible that these represent a single species (T. Condez pers. comm. 2021).

Further molecular work is required to better understand the relationship between Brachycephalus crispus, B. guarani, B. pitanga, and B. toby, as it is possible that these represent a single species (T. Condez pers. comm. 2021).

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This taxon likely compromises two different species (A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014
Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Chiasmocleis royi has been historically confounded with C. ventrimaculata (De la Riva 1995, Morales and McDiarmid 1996, Peloso and Sturaro 2008, Von May et al. 2009), and most of the data on ecology published on the latter actually refers to C. royi (Cocroft and Hambler 1989, Schlüter and Salas 1991).
This species was first reported as Chiasmocleis sp. in Morales and McDiarmid 1996.

Prior to its description (Jungfer et al. 2010), some subpopulations of this species were identified as either Dendropsophus bifurcus or Dendropsophus leucophyllatus. All Bolivian subpopulations of Dendropsophus bifurcus now belong to this species (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
This species was reported as Leptobrachium pullum by Inger et al. (1999).

authority: Chan, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Quah, Sumarli & Grismer, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Ansonia malayana (Chan et al. 2014).

This is a split from Limnonectes laticeps and L. khasianus. It is a species of the Limnonectes kuhlii group, traditionally regarded as L. laticeps which has been recently synonymized with L. khasianus. Subpopulations of L. khasianus from Peninsular Malaysia, and possibly from southern Thailand, are now assigned to L. deinodon (Dehling 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Limnonectes kuhlii, for which it was previously confused (Matsui et al. 2014).

This is a split from Limnonectes kuhlii, which has recently been identified as a species complex composed of at least six distinct species in mainland Southeast Asia and two in Peninsular Malaysia (Matsui et al. 2014).

There has been considerable debate on the taxonomic status of this species and others in the Hyperolius nasutus complex. Here we follow Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002) in considering Hyperolius acuticeps to be distinct from H. nasutus. However, we also follow Amiet (2005) in assigning West and Central African populations to H. adspersus and H. igbettensis, and Channing et al. (2013) in restricting H. acuticeps to Tanzania and Malawi, assigning the South African part of its range to H. poweri.

We follow Poynton and Broadley (1987) and Schiøtz and van Daele (2003) in regarding this to be a species distinct from, and sympatric with, Hyperolius nasutus and H. acuticeps, and in this respect we do not follow the taxonomic re-arrangement of this Group proposed by Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002). A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) believes that Channing, Moyer and Burger might have confused H. benguellensis and H. viridis.
This species was removed from synonymy of Hyperolius nasutus (or Hyperolius acuticeps sensu Channing et al. (2002)) by Amiet (2005).
Amolops splendissimus and A. caelumnoctis appear to be synonyms for the same species (R. Bain pers. comm. 2009). Until their taxonomic status is resolved, we herein treat both as valid species.

We follow the definition of this species as given by Poynton and Broadley (1987), and Schiøtz (1999), rather than that given by Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002). Schiøtz (pers. comm.) believes that Channing, Moyer and Burger might have confused Hyperolius benguellensis and H. viridis.

According to recent studies, molecular and morphological characters are not sufficiently suitable to differentiate between N. derjugini and N. microspilotus, contrary to previous assumptions (Schneider and Schneider 2011, Najafimajd et al. 2013, Schneider and Schneider 2013, Hendrix et al. 2014). Therefore, we follow regarding papers, accept N. derjugini as a valid species and N. microspilotus as its junior synonym due to taxonomical priority reasons.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).

authority: Ohler, Deuti, Grosjean, Paul, Ayyaswamy, Ahmed & Dutta, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Ferrão et al. (2017) suggested that given the colouration and morphological characters provided by Melo-Sampaio and Souza (2015) and Machado et al. (2015), earlier Brazilian records of Scinax iquitorum (species closely related to S. onca) in the state of Acre should be assigned to S. onca.

This species was split from Eleutherodactylus audanti (Hedges et al. 2008). On the basis of preliminary molecular data, Díaz et al. (2018) suggested that E. melatrigonum may be conspecific with E. notidodes.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus weinlandi (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological populations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including this one.
This species has been assigned to the genus Amolops following Stuart (2008); in the Amolops monticola group of Stuart et al. (2010).

This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Heyer et al. (1990). The population to which this name has been applied by Heyer et al. (1990) does not agree with the diagnosis of B. nodoterga, and so questions remain over the taxonomic validity of this species.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Ischnocnema nigriventris by Heyer (1985). This concept remains a complex of several species. Furthermore, it is easily confused with several congeners: Ischnocnema bolbodactyla, I. gehrti, I. nigriventris (Targino et al. 2018).
This species may be a species complex and further taxonomic work is required (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Eleutherodactylus bolbodactylus (Pombal and Cruz 1999).
This species is stated to be similar to Limnonectes macrodon (Bourret 1942).
We follow Ohler et al. (2002) in treating Limnonectes poilani as a species distinct from L. kohchangae.

Specimens recorded at Estação Biológica de Boracéia, in the municipality of Salesópolis, São Paulo State, were assigned to Paratelmatobius gaigeae by Heyer et al. (1990). Later, Pombal and Haddad (1999) reallocated these specimens to P. poecilogaster (1990).
This species was split from Incilius valliceps and Incilius macrocristatus (Mendelson III et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Thorius schmidti (Rovito et al. 2013) where it had been placed by Hanken and Wake (1998).
This is a restricted concept of P. edulis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. angusticeps (Scott et al. 2013).

Leptopelis grandiceps was resurrected from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis and L. usambarae was transferred from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis to the synonymy L. grandiceps by Gvoždík et al. (2014). It is likely to represent multiple species (S. Loader pers. comm. December 2015).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Phyllodytes luteolus by Caramaschi et al. (2004).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Raorchestes hassanensis (Abraham et al. 2015).

Up until recently this species was known only from the type series collected in 1882. It was rediscovered and published as a new species, R. emeraldi, by Vijayakumar et al. (2014), but Abraham et al. (2015) determined that these new specimens actually belonged to this species that had not been recorded for over 100 years.

Narvaes and Rodrigues (2009) revised the Rhinella granulosa group and elevated Rhinella granulosa natterei to the species level. The identity of this species is dubious and it may be a synonym of another taxon, so further taxonomic research is warranted (P. Kok pers. comm. 2017). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) suggested that this species should be carefully compared to Rhinella beebei and Rhinella merianae to confirm the species distinction.

authority: Ortega-Andrade, Rojas-Soto, Valencia, Espinosa de los Monteros, Morrone, Ron & Cannatella, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Pristimantis acuminatus by Ortega-Andrade et al. (2015).

authority: Ortega-Andrade, Rojas-Soto, Valencia, Espinosa de los Monteros, Morrone, Ron & Cannatella, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Pristimantis acuminatus by Ortega-Andrade et al. (2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Chiropterotriton multidentatus (Rovito and Parra-Olea 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Chiropterotriton multidentatus (Rovito and Parra-Olea 2015).

authority: Abraham, Jobin, Cyriac, Zachariah, Raju & Zachariah, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species has been removed from the synonymy of Raorchestes flaviventris by Abraham et al. (2015). However, further taxonomic work is required to verify this change, and Garg et al. (2021) retain it as a junior synonym of R. flaviventris.

authority: Fouquet, Orrico, Ernst, Blanc, Martinez, Vacher, Rodrigues, Ouboter, Jairam & Ron, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Dendropsophus brevifrons (Fouquet et al. 2015).
New concept as a result of splitting out Theloderma vietnamense Poyarkov, Orlov, Moiseeva, Pawangkhanant, Ruangsuwan, Vassilieva, Galoyan, Nguyen, and Gogoleva, 2015.
Narvaes and Rodrigues (2009) revised the Rhinella granulosa group and elevated Rhinella granulosa azarai to the species level.
Narvaes and Rodrigues (2009) revised the Rhinella granulosa group and elevated Rhinella granulosa major to the species level. Taxonomic review of subpopulations in northern Brazil is required.
Narvaes and Rodrigues (2009) revised the Rhinella granulosa group and elevated Rhinella granulosa merianae to the species level.
Narvaes and Rodrigues (2009) revised the Rhinella granulosa group and elevated Rhinella granulosa mirandaribeiroi to the species level.

It has been suggested that this species is a synonym of Phrynobatrachus acridoides, but recent surveys indicate that it differs both in vocalizations and ecology (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.). Phrynobatrachus nigripes, described by Pickersgill (2007), is in fact a synonym of this species (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.).
Gastrotheca ernestoi was revalidated by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007) based on morphological features.

In the Rhacophorus calcaneus group of Orlov et al. (2012), who noted extensive confusion with Rhacophorus robertingeri in the literature and who discussed previous confusion in the range. Rhacophorus chuyangsinensis was also synonymised with this species by Orlov et al. (2012).
We follow Stuart (2008) in assigning this species to the genus Amolops.
This species has been assigned to the genus Amolops following Stuart (2008); in the Amolops monticola group of Stuart et al. (2010).

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Polypedates leucomystax (Rujirawan et al. 2013).

Heyer (2000) reviewed the nomenclatural and taxonomic history of the nominal species, re-described the lectotype, and posited that it represents a species of Leptodactylus currently known only from the type specimen. However, Heyer pointed out that this appears to be a juvenile individual, making it unreliable for identifying the species. In view of the lack of records despite surveys over the decades, it is likely that the specimen assigned this name is a misidentification of a syntopic species such as L. vastus or L. natalensis (E. Dias pers. comm. 2021).

This is a revised concept of Oreobates heterodactylus following the split of the broader concept into this and Oreobates chiquitanus, as well as, the placement of Oreobates crepitans in synonymy with this taxon (Pansonato et al. 2020).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis by Brandão (2002). Specimens associated with this name from the Serra do Cipó are not conspecific with the holotype (Brandão 2002). The species was redescribed by Caramaschi (2006). This species has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016). Ramos et al. (2017) found genetic structure along the spatial distribution of the species in the South Espinhaço Mountain Range corresponding to three population groups: northern, central and southern. These groups may represent separate species.
Taylor (1962) appeared to doubt the placement of this species in Theloderma (although his argument is confused by reference to the genus Phrynoderma).
Vitreorana oyampiensis has been synonymized under this species by Cisneros-Heredia (2013). Fouquet et al. (2019) were sceptical of this synonymy.

authority: Poyarkov, Orlov, Moiseeva, Pawangkhanant, Ruangsuwan, Vassilieva, Galoyan, Nguyen & Gogoleva, 2015

taxonomicNotes:
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic identity of this species since only one specimen has been found despite subsequent surveys in the type locality. The specimen most likely belongs to another well-known species from the area (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. January 2016), such as D. minusculus with which it could be synonymous. The type specimen is a juvenile and quite deteriorated, making it very difficult to compare it with the morphology of other species in the genus (M. Hoogmoed and V.G. Dill Orrico pers. comm. 2021).
This species is considered incertae sedis, and is presently left in the genus Hyla pending resolution (Faivovich et al. 2005). The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
Removed from the synonymy of Gastrotheca microdiscus by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007).

authority: Le, Nguyen, Nishikawa, Nguyen, Pham, Matsui, Bernardes & Nguyen, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton verrucosus and T. shanjing (Matsui 2013).
This is a restricted concept of Phrynobatrachus dendrobates following the revalidation of P. petropedetoides which was previously placed in synonymy with this species.

Reynolds and Foster (1992) indicated that Atelopus rugulosus is a synonym of A. tricolor. Subsequently, Lötters and De la Riva (1998) confirmed this and pointed out that in evaluating the types of A. rugulosus from south-east Peru, and A. wilimani from Bolivia, both are synonyms of A. tricolor.
This species is possibly a synonym of Rhinella veraguensis.
This species was considered to be a subspecies of Rhinella limensis by Leviton and Duellman (1978).

Juveniles of this species can be confused with juveniles of the Rhinella margaritifera complex, and hence its distribution is poorly known. This might be a species complex (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Guayasamin et al. (2009) listed Centrolene azulae as "incertae sedis" within Centroleninae because molecular data are not available, and morphological and behavioral characters do not provide unambiguous evidence on their generic placement. There is a chance that this is a synonym of a previously described species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. September 2018).
This species is sympatric with Hyalinobatrachium bergeri (Lötters and Köhler 2000).

Morphologically, the populations from Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, Brazil, and Ecuador are remarkably similar (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009). Genetic analyses with a very limited sample size (three individuals) have shown genetic divergence that might correspond to, at least, two cryptic lineages (Guayasamin et al. 2008). However, a much more complete analysis is required in order to understand the variation within what is now identified as Hyalinobatrachium iaspidiense (Guayasamin and North 2009).

Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007) suggested that Hyalinobatrachium nouraguense might be a junior synonym and Yánez-Muñoz et al. (2009) placed H. nouraguense in synonymy.
We follow Vences et al. (2003) in assigning this species to the genus Allobates.

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) provided a corrected morphological diagnosis, restricted the range of the species based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and discussed the identities of some of the paratypes of this species noting that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.
This species is likely to be a complex of several cryptic species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).

Assessors of the Amazon Global Amphibian Assessment workshop in Brazil raised questions as to the taxonomic validity of this species, but Morales (pers. comm.) is convinced that it is a valid species.

This taxon might be comprised of several species, specimens from the type locality in the highlands being very different to specimens from the main part of the range. The Brazilian records reported as Colostethus peruvianus in Heyer (1976) from the Amazon basin in Brazil definitely do not correspond to this species, and probably belong to Allobates bacurau, A. caeruleodactylus, A. grillisimilis or A. masniger (T. Grant pers. comm. 2021).
Grant et al. (2006) could not allocate it beyond Dendrobatoidea (Aromobatidae + Dendrobatidae), merely retaining it in a non-taxon "Colostethus".

The nominal form formerly referred to as Ranitomeya fantastica was found to be a complex of three closely related species: R. fantastica, R. benedicta and R. summersi (Brown et al. 2008). Ranitomeya fantastica is herein reassessed considering this change in taxonomic concept.

Most records of this species before 1990 refer to Dendrobates ventrimaculatus. Caldwell and Myers (1990) and Martins and Haddad (1990) independently concluded that the name Dendrobates (now Adelphobates) quinquevittatus Steindachner, 1864, had been misapplied in recent literature. It is currently restricted to a species that is neither as variable or widespread as previously thought, and which is known only from the upper Rio Madeira drainage of Rondonia and adjacent (southern) Amazonas, Brazil. In this account we follow the traditional, broader definition of the species.
This species and Epipedobates tricolor were separated by Schulte (1999). We follow Graham et al. (2004) in restricting the distribution of E. anthonyi to southern Ecuador and northern Peru.

This species is comprised of a well-supported monophyletic group and shows higher levels of genetic divergence among its populations than those of Ameerega hahneli from the same region (Roberts et al. 2007).
This species is very similar to Ameerega petersi. There might be a need to re-examine the relationship between these two taxa.

The status of Ameerega rubriventris as a valid species is still in dispute by some, though the unusual ventral colors and genetic distinctness suggest that this species is indeed different from A. altamazonica (Twomey and Brown 2017).
Prior to the official description in 1979, this species was known to many people but under incorrect names, such as Phyllobates bicolor.
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This form is a complex of several species. Gastrotheca piperata was recently separated out by Duellman and Köhler (2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Severe taxonomic difficulties exist with this species. This taxon is considered to be a species complex, with possibly more than three species involved, with known subpopulations in Bolivia differing in advertisement calls and morphological characters (Reichle 2006, M. Pacheco pers. comm 2020).
This species was originally described as Hyla joannae, but Faivovich et al. (2005) transferred it (along with many other Neotropical hylids) to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
Two subspecies are recognized: Ceratophrys stolzmanni ssp. scaphiopeza in Ecuador, and C. stolzmanni ssp. stolzmanni in Peru.

This species is part of the Pristimantis lacrimosus complex, which is characterized by challenging taxonomic identification. The Peruvian subpopulations could pertain to different species, pending further study. For the purposes of this assessment, all Peruvian subpopulations are considered to belong to this taxon until determined otherwise.

This species was previously confused with Pristimantis reichle. These two species are essentially in distinguishable morphologically, but the two species they have distinct molecular and call differences (Padial and De la Riva 2009, Duellman and Lehr 2009).
This species might consist of a complex of more than one species.
Pristimantis vermiculatus is considered to be a junior synonym of Pristimantis petrobardus (Duellman and Lehr 2009).

This species is a complex of more than one species and it is likely that it contains several cryptic species. De la Riva described the variation of this species with data about its biology and distribution, and about the taxonomic status of Pristimantis bockermanni. It is an extremely polymorphic species, that presents a great intra- and inter-population variation in coloration, body size and skin texture (Köhler 2000).
This species is part of the Pristimantis platydactylus complex and it is possible that specimens of this species have been mistaken for P. platydactylus.
The record from Mitobamba, Cajamarca Department, Peru, provided by Duellman and Lehr (2009) might represent an unnamed species.
According to Lehr and Catenazzi (2009), Psychrophrynella bagrecito (Lynch 1986) seems to be related to Noblella rather than to Psychrophrynella (Lehr 2006, De la Riva et al. 2008).
The specimen from Cajamarca, Peru previously attributed to Lynchius parkeri by Lehr (2006) has been assigned to Lynchius oblitus based on phylogenetic analyses (Motta et al. 2016).

Reflecting some taxonomic uncertainty, Pristimantis simonsii has been included in other genera over the recent past. Currently, there is apparent consensus that the species should be in the genus Pristimantis.
Lehr (2006) synonymized Phrynopus laplacai under Microkayla wettsteini.
Telmatobius arequipensis is likely a species complex with more than one species (Gutiérrez et al. 2010).
This species was originally described as Altigius alios (Wild 1995), but de Sá et al. (2012) transferred it to the genus Hamptophryne.
This species is currently under taxonomic revision and the southern populations might be described as a new species.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This is a species of uncertain taxonomic validity.
The taxonomy of this species' genus is in need of revision (Wilkinson pers. comm.).

It is possible that the subpopulations of this form comprise more than one species (J. Icochea pers comm.). Taylor (1968) recognized two subspecies. The taxonomy of the genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
Its former position in Cryptophyllobates or now in Hyloxalus might be doubtful (R. Schulte pers. comm. April 2018).
This is likely a species complex (E. Lehr, R. von May and A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017).
This species might be synonymous with Pristimantis lirellus (E. Lehr pers. comm.).

authority: Duellman, Lehr, Rodriguez and von May, 2004

taxonomicNotes: The biological identities of some of the Peruvian subpopulations need to be clarified (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2014). Until such time, all subpopulations currently allocated to Telmatobius timens are encompassed in this assessment.
Pristimantis stictoboubonus is distinguished from other similar species by its colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).
Cochranella erminea is diagnosed from other centrolenids by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Torres-Gastello et al. 2007).
Cochranella amelie is diagnosed from other similar species by an unusual combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cisneros-Heredia and Meza-Ramos 2007).

Included in the genus Pristimantis sensu Heinicke et al. (2007) (Frost 2007). In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original description (Lehr et al. 2007). The species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al. 2007).

Not placed in a species group in the original publication, although the authors implied a possible relationship to what is now Isthmohyla. Faivovich et al. (2005) could not allocate several members of former "Hyla" to any of the new genera, but believed that they would be so allocated with additional work. As a provisional measure they allocated these species to the non-taxon "Hyla", but which is not part of the North American-Eurasian clade which bears the name Hyla (Frost, 2007). Catenazzi and Lehr (2009) assigned “Hyla” antoniiochoai to the genus Gastrotheca because it shares with species of that genus the presence of a closed brood pouch, overall morphological similarity, and similar structure of the advertisement call.
Gastrotheca carinaceps can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Duellman et al. 2006).
Pristimantis caeruleonotus is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al. 2007).
The identity and relations of Pristimantis minutulus are assessed through DNA analyses (Duellman and Hedges 2007). Recently placed in the family Strabomantidae by Hedges et al. (2008).
