In the genus Nymphargus according to Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Nymphargus mixomaculatus is diagnosed from other similar glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Guayasamin et al. 2006).
Atelopus pyrodactylus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas and Barrio 2006).
The identity and relations of Pristimantis albertus are assessed through DNA analyses (Duellman and Hedges 2007).

Included in the genus Pristimantis by Frost (2007). Recently placed in the family Strabomantidae by Hedges et al. (2008). Pristimantis amydrotus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Duellman and Lehr 2007).
Microkayla boettgeri can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Lehr 2006).

In the Chaunus veraguensis group according to the original publication. In the genus Rhinella following Chaparro et al. (2007). Rhinella tacana can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Padial et al. 2006).

In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis according to AmphibiaWeb (2008). Pristimantis wagteri is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas 2007).

authority: (Chaparro, De la Riva, Padial, Ochoa & Lehr, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: Bryophryne bustamantei can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Chaparro et al. 2007).
This species was reassigned from Phrynopus to Oreobates by Padial et al. (2012).
Pristimantis seorsus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Lehr 2007).

In the Eleutherodactylus (Eleutherodactylus) orestes group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007). Pristimantis cordovae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).

In the Pristimantis orestes group according to the original publication. Pristimantis ventriguttatus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr and Köhler 2007).
Pristimantis coronatus is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).
Pristimantis phalaroinguinis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Duellman and Lehr 2007).
Recently placed in the family Strabomantidae by Hedges et al. (2008).
A member of the Pristimantis orestes group according to the original publication (Lehr 2007).

Based on morphometric and call differences, Funk et al. (2007, 2008) suggested that Engystomops petersi (termed Physalaemus petersi by those authors) encompasses the north-western Amazon clade while the south-western Amazon clade corresponds with E. freibergi (termed Physalaemus freibergi) corroborating the proposal of Ron et al. (2006).
Atelopus epikeisthos can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lötters et al. 2004).

Rulyrana mcdiarmidi, R. saxiscandens, and R. flavopunctata are morphologically very similar and genetically non-monophyletic, thus it is suspected that synonyms exist and/or specimens of some subpopulations have been misidentified (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. March 2018).

Individuals of Psychrophrynella usurpator were traditionally misidentified as Phrynopus peruvianus (now = Noblella peruviana) (De la Riva et al. 2008). The assessment for Phrynopus peruvianus, that previously appeared on the IUCN Red List is now more correctly placed under Psychophrynella usurpator.
Tentatively placed in the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Duellman and Chaparro 2008).
This species was first described as Colostethus eleutherodactylus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described as Colostethus insulatus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was described as Colostethus leucophaeus (Duellman 2004). It was assigned to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described as Colostethus pulcherrimus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described as Colostethus sordidatus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described belonging to the genus Colostethus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).

This species was described as belonging to the genus Colostethus by Duellman (2004). In their revision of the poison frogs, Grant et al. (2006) split Colostethus and transferred this species to Allobates. Santos et al. (2009) rejected a number of nomenclatural changes proposed by Grant et al. (2006), and their analysis recovered this species within Hyloxalus, and these authors therefore erected the new combination Hyloxalus craspedoceps for this species.

This species was preliminarily assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Lehr and von May 2009). Pristimantis divnae was removed from the P. unistrigatus group and left as unassigned by Padial et al. (2014).
This species was formerly included within Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).
Originally described under the genus Phyllonastes by Lehr et al. (2004), this species was subsequently allocated to the genus Noblella by De la Riva et al. (2008).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Brown and Twomey et al. (2011) provided bioacoustic, genetic, and behavioural evidence that R. lamasi, R. sirensis, and R. biolat were all members of a single, widespread and highly polymorphic species. Due to rules of precedence, R. sirensis is the valid name, and R. lamasi and R. biolat are considered junior synonyms of R. sirensis.
Hyalinobatrachium lemur was synonymized under Hyalinobatrachium pellucidum by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009).
The phylogenetic position of Centrolene charapita might change as more molecular and/or phenotypic data are analyzed, or if more species are included in the genus (Twomey et al. 2014)

authority: Catenazzi, von May, Lehr, Gagliardi-Urrutia & Guayasamin, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species was formerly confused with Cochrannella croceopodes, which has since been synonymised with Rulyrana saxiscandens (Twomey et al. 2014).

authority: (Köhler, Koscinski, Padial, Chaparro, Handford, Lougheed & De la Riva, 2010)
Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Oreobates lehri (Padial et al. 2012). O. lehri was initially ascribed to two distant populations, one in Cordillera Vilcabamba, which is now considered typical O. lehri, and one in the Andean hills of the Kosñipata Valley, which is now recognized as O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012).

authority: Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Phrynopus chaparroi might belong to Pristimantis, but molecular characters need to be applied to confirm this suspicion (Lehr and von May 2017).
This is likely to be a junior synonym of Phrynopus tribulosus (E. Lehr and R. von May pers. comm. December 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloxalus bocagei (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).

authority: Ron, Venegas, Toral, Read, Ortiz & Manzano, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Osteocephalus buckleyi (Ron et al. 2012).
This species was previously confused with Pristimantis luscombei prior to its description by Ortega-Andrade and Venegas (2014) from within the range of the latter species.

authority: Rojas, Carvalho, Ávila, Farias, Gordo & Hrbek, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Until recently, this new species was considered under the taxon Amazophrynella minuta (Rojas-Zamora et al. 2015)

authority: Rojas, Carvalho, Ávila, Farias, Gordo & Hrbek, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Until recently, this new species was considered part of the taxon Amazophrynella minuta (Rojas-Zamora et al. 2015)
Oreobates granulosus has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of O. cruralis (Padial et al. 2008).

Jungfer (2010) resurrected Osteocephalus festae on the basis of the distinctiveness between the holotype of O. festae and O. buckleyi. Some of the specimens assigned to O. festae by Jungfer (2010) may belong to a different species (Ron et al. 2010).

This frog has been confused many times since its description. Two juvenile frogs from the Peruvian eastern Andean foothills were described as Hyla mimetica by Melin (1941) and Hyla elkejunginerae by Henle et al. (1983), respectively. Henle (1992) found that the specimens were juveniles and the adults actually pertained to Osteocephalus, however Hyla mimetica was lost in the synonymy of another hylid (now Dendropsophus) (Duellman 1974). Osteocephalus mimeticus has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of Dendropsophus triangulum (Jungfer 2010). Additionally, Osteocephalus elkejungingerae has been synonymised with this species (Jungfer 2010).
This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis incomptus following the revalidation of Pristimantis kirklandi (Heinicke et al. 2007), which was previously placed in synonymy with this species.
Pristimantis pharangobates has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of P. rhabdolaemus (Duellman and Lehr 2009).

Historically, there has been some doubt over the distinctiveness of this taxon from Rhinella spinulosa (Gorham 1974, Córdova 1999). However, it is considered a distinct species from the broader concept of Rhinella spinulosa (Cei 1972, Cei 1980). 

Morphological and molecular studies are needed to clarify the distribution of Rhinella in southern Peru (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Rhinella veraguensis following the revalidation of R. leptoscelis, which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Padial et al. 2009).
This species was first described as Colostethus aeruginosus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
Named as Philautus decoris by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda in 2005, the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. in 2009.
Systematists have long suggested that easternmost populations of this taxon likely correspond to a valid species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. 2012).
This species probably comprises more than one species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Xenopus fraseri prior to its description (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Xenopus fraseri prior to its description (Evans et al. 2015).

Triturus cristatus was formerly considered to include four subspecies: T. cristatus cristatus; T. cristatus dobrogicus; T. cristatus karelinii; and T. cristatus carnifex. These are now recognized as separate species under the Triturus cristatus superspecies. On the basis of results of molecular genetic analyses, Triturus carnifex has been split into Triturus carnifex s.l. and Triturus macedonicus.

This species is a re-description of the previously elevated subspecies of Triturus karelinii which was known as T. arntzeni (Wielstra et al. 2013). T. anatolicus was previously confused with species (Wielstra and Arntzen 2016).
This species was elevated from its previous status as a subspecies of Bufo bufo by Recuero et al. (2012).
This was previously considered a subspecies of Hyla arborea, until it was elevated to species status by Stöck et al. (2008).

Although Schneider and Haxhiu (1994) had difficulty distinguishing the voice of Pelophylax shqipericus from that of P. lessonae, morphology, allozymes, mtDNA sequences, and crossing experiments all indicate that P. shqipericus is distinct from P. lessonae. The species belongs to “lessonae” group and it is sister species to P. lessonae - based on mtDNA and ND3 sequences, 1378 b.p. (Plötner et al. 2012).

This species does not make hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).

There are two well-differentiated clades (a northern one and a southern one); their genetic difference is similar to that separating the other species of European cave salamanders (Carranza et al. 2007).
Two distinct subspecies are recognized, Chioglossa lusitanica lusitanica and C. l. longipes (Arntzen et al. 2007).

This species was separated from Lyciasalamandra luschani by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

The three main recognised phyloclades are highly differentiated from each other, despite relatively small geographical distances among them (Veith et al. 2020). The Kasos Island subpopulation is genetically differentiated from those on the other two islands (Eleftherakos et al. 2007).
Formerly included in the genus Salamandra, this taxon was assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This species does not produce hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).

The currently accepted taxonomy recognizes two subspecies: the whitish, depigmented and blind Proteus anguinus anguinus (“white proteus”), and the dark-colored, eyed P. a. parkelj (“black proteus”). The subspecies P. a. parkelj was considered to be of doubtful validity (Goricki and Trontelj 2006).

The white proteus is distributed throughout the entire range of the species, the black proteus is only known from a few sites in the region of Bela Krajina in southeastern Slovenia. Recent molecular studies revealed that the species is deeply subdivided into nine lineages supported by both mitochondrial DNA and microsatellites (Gorički and Trontelj 2006, Trontelj et al. 2009, Trontelj and Zakšek 2016, Vörös et al. 2019). The black proteus constitutes one of those lineages. Their ranges are mostly allopatric, although they are touching or even overlapping in some areas (Gorički et al. 2017).

The assessment of the exact taxonomic and conservation status of the Proteus lineages is the subject of ongoing research (Bizjak Mali and Sket 2019), but they should be treated as evolutionary significant units, to ensure the survival of diversity in this threatened species.

Morphological, ecological and genetic studies on Salamandra algira indicate that there are two major clades further subdivided in several lineages (Beukema et al. 2010, Ben Hassine et al. 2016, Bouzid et al. 2017, Merabet et al. 2016a, Beddek et al. 2018, Dinis et al. 2019, Hernandez and Escoriza 2019), which are recognized as five distinct subspecies: S. a. tingitana (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003), S. a. splendens (Beukema et al. 2013), S. a. spelaea (Escoriza and Comas 2007), S. a. algira (Bedriaga 1883), and S. a. atlantica (Hernandez and Escoriza 2019).

authority: Lanza, Leo, Forti, Cimmaruta, Caputo & Nascetti, 2001
taxonomicNotes: Lanza et al. (2001) described this taxon as a subspecies of Speleomantes imperialis, but it was elevated to species status by Carranza et al. (2007).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Alytes almogavarii, which was previously considered to be a subspecies (Dufresnes and Martínez-Solano 2020).
Padial and De la Riva (2004) tentatively consider all Bufo regularis and Bufo mauritanicus records from the Adrar as Bufo xeros [all now under Sclerophrys].

Most Moroccan populations previously considered to belong to this species are now separated as Discoglossus scovazzi (García-París and Jockusch 1999, Fromhage et al. 2004, Vences et al. 2014). North African populations have historically been regarded as a separate subspecies, Discoglossus pictus auritus, from those on European islands. There is, however, little genetic divergence between European and North African groups, and Zangari et al. (2006) considers the species monotypic.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Discoglossus pictus (García-París and Jockusch 1999, Fromhage et al. 2004, Vences et al. 2014).

Dufresnes et al.(2019) revised the taxonomy of Hyla meridionalis and described the genetically distinct Tunisian and eastern Algerian populations, previously identified as a candidate species, as the new species H. carthaginiensis on the basis of evidence that limited genetic admixture suggests "putatively advanced reproductive isolation". The species was simultaneously described by Escoriza and Ben Hassine (2019) as Hyla numidica, using a specimen from Nefza, Tunisia, but this name was published later. H. numidica; is consequently a junior synonym of H. carthaginiensis (Dufresnes and Crochet 2020).


As now defined, H. meridionalis consists of two divergent clades: one restricted to Algeria and possibly the Molouya Valley in adjacent Morocco; and the other being naturally endemic to Morocco (from which all studied naturalized populations are derived) (Dufresnes et al. 2019, Dufresnes and Alard 2020).

Carpathian Newt was recently confirmed to be a closely related sister species to Lissotriton vulgaris and a member of the proposed Smooth Newt or Lissotriton vulgaris species complex or group (Litvinchuk et al. 2005; Wielstra et al. 2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this species (which as now defined contains the subspecies Pelobates syriacus syriacus and P. s. boettgeri) and Pelobates balcanicus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pelobates vespertinus, which has been removed from synonymy of this species (Litvinchuk et al. 2013; Suryadnaya 2014).
Following genetic analysis, some subpopulations from Russia and those from Kazakhstan have now been assigned to Pelobates vespertinus which had been removed from synonymy of this species (Suryadnaya 2014). There is a hybrid zone in northeastern Ukraine and the Russian province of Kursk between the range of this species and P. vespertinus.
This species was previously included within Pelodytes punctatus. Further systematic studies are required to more clearly determine the distribution of P. ibericus.
It has been suggested that this is probably a subspecies of Pelophylax lessonae (Crochet and Dubois 2004).

Prior to Uzzell (1982) (who provisionally resurrected the name), this species was considered to be a synonym of Pelophylax perezi, or, following Pasteur and Bons (1959), a synonym of P. ridibundus. Although northwest African members of the "P. esculentus" complex are here tentatively regarded as P. saharicus, Hemmer, Konrad and Bachmann (1980), suggested that two species were hybridizing in North Africa. Steinwarz and Schneider (1991), considered it probable that P. saharicus is a junior synonym of P. perezi.

Cryptic diversity possibly exists in the Libyan subpopulation (Ibrahim 2013). Nicolas et al. (2014) found their sampled populations from Morocco and Algeria to be genetically distinct, suggesting divergence along the Moulouya River valley dating back approximately 2.6 Mya. Some mitochondrial differentiation has been found between northern and southern populations in Morocco (Lansari et al. 2015). Arano et al. (1998) previously found an east-west pattern of allozyme divergence between the subspecies P. s. saharicus and P. s. rioderoi.

Bufotes siculus was synonymized under this species by Speybroeck et al. (2010) and supported by Dufresnes et al. (2019), who note also that this name may not have been validly published. This arrangement has been endorsed by the European Herpetological Society (Speybroeck et al. 2020). This species exhibits little genetic structure across its range, which has been hypothesized to result from recent demographic expansion during interglacial periods (Nicolas et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Rana parvipalmata (Dufresnes et al. 2020).

Four subspecies have been described: Salamandra atra atra; S. a. aurorae; S. a. prenjensis; and S. a. pasobiensis. The status of these subspecies remains questionable. S. a. prenjensis is often not considered to be valid. S. a. aurorae has been sometimes considered to be a separate species. Joger (1996), using serum proteins, showed significant differences, and he proposed the elevation of S. a. aurorae to a full species. Veith et al. (1998), analyzing mitDNA of S. a. aurorae did not find any significant difference. Riberon et al. (2001) indicate a complex pattern of divergence for the alpine populations, without reaching or stressing any taxonomic consequences.
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.

Triturus cristatus formerly was considered to include four subspecies: T. cristatus cristatus; T. c. dobrogicus; T. c. karelinii; and T. c. carnifex. These are now recognized as separate species of the Triturus cristatus superspecies, and the specific name Triturus cristatus (sensu stricto) is attributed to the former nominative subspecies. The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans because of narrow or extensive areas of hybridization.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Triturus ivanbureschi (Wielstra et al. 2013).
We follow Carranza and Amat (2005) in transferring this species from Euproctus to the genus Calotriton.
Lanza et al. (2001) described Speleomantes imperialis sarrabusensis, but it was elevated to full species status by Carranza et al. (2007).

The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans because of narrow or extensive areas of hybridization. Two isolated subspecies have been described, occurring to the east and west of the Iron Gates of the Danube.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The conspecificity of records from Sumatra and Borneo with those from Peninsular Malaysia is unclear.
Taxonomic work still needs to be carried out to verify which genus this species definitely belongs to (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop 2018).

This species was considered by Kiew (1975) to be a synonym of Limnonectes nitidus, but we retain it as a valid species. It is considered to be a species complex (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

Records of Megophrys longipes from northern Viet Nam (Tran et al. 1992) are provisionally placed under Megophrys lateralis; while these animals might represent a taxon distinct from M. lateralis, they are unlikely to be conspecific with M. longipes from Peninsular Malaysia.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

This species might be synonymous with Microhyla superciliaris (see Berry 1975). However, D. Iskandar (pers. comm.) considers that it is a separate species. The records north of Tulang Bawang River in Sumatra are considered to belong to another form (D. Iskandar and A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from synonymy of Craugastor punctariolus (Campbell and Savage 2000).
Ichthyophis husaini was recently synonymised with this species (Kamei and Biju 2016).

authority: Condez, Monteiro, Comitti, Garcia, Amaral & Haddad, 2016
Rojas-Zamora, Chaparro, Carvalho, Ávila, Farias, Hrbek & Gordo, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Amazophrynella minuta (Rojas-Zamora et al. 2016).
This species may be a species complex, and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (K.O. Chan and E. Quah pers. comm. January 2018).

This species was previously thought by Berry (1975) and Kiew (1975) to include Limnonectes tweediei. However, Dring (1979), Grandison (1982) and Leong Tzi Ming (pers. comm.) consider the two forms to be distinct.

authority: (Rowley, Stuart, Neang, Hoang, Dau, Nguyen, & Emmett, 2015)

taxonomicNotes: Removed from the synonymy of Chalcorana raniceps by Stuart et al. (2006). Inger et al. (2009) discussed its phylogenetic placement in the C. chalconota group. This species is a complex and further taxonomic work is required (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

In Hylarana signata complex, this is a split from the broader concept of Hylarana siberu (Chan et al. 2014). Currently known as Pulchrana centropeninsularis after a phylogenetic review by Oliver et al. (2015).

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax gracilis (Dehling 2012).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2006) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2015), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

This species is considered to be incertae sedis within the genera Hoplobatrachus or Fejervarya by Dubois, 1986. Considered as a possible member of Hoplobatrachus by Matsui et al. 2007, but without discussing evidence.

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It has been suggested that taxonomic distinctiveness of Ichthyophis monochrous, I. glutinosus, I. singaporensis and I. paucisulcus needs confirmation via genetic analyses (Grismer and Pan 2008).

Verified records of this species come only from Peninsular Malaysia. Records from other countries are either misidentified or misattributed. Records from peninsular Thailand and Borneo are referrable to Microhyla perparva and M. petrigenea according to Manthey and Denzer (2014).
This species was split from the broader concepts of Kalophrynus interlineatus and Kalophrynus pleurostigmata (Zug 2015).

authority: (Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
Fouquet, Martinez, Zeidler, Courtois, Gaucher, Blanc, Lima, Souza, Rodrigues & Kok, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Boana geographica (as Hypsiboas geographicus) by Fouquet et al. (2016). Dubois (2017) later moved it to the genus Boana.
This species was moved from Fejervarya to Minervarya by Sanchez et al. (2018).

This is a split from the broader concept of Limonectes kuhlii (Suwannapoom et al. 2016). DNA evidence suggests that several species may exist under this name in Myanmar, and further taxonomic research is required (McLeod 2010; D. McLeod pers. comm. August 2020).
Chan et al. (2010), suggested that the dubious records of Leptolalax gracilis from Gunung Tahan might actually represent this species.
Previously confused with Ansonia penangensis (Wood et al. 2008).

Based on genetic analysis, the validity of this species is doubtful and these records are thought to belong to Odorrana hosii (K.O. Chan pers. comm. January 2018). Odorrana hosii displays high levels of morphological variability, and it is possible that this species is a polymorph of it (K.O. Chan pers. comm. October 2018). However, there are no verified tissues of this species to confirm this synonymy so the taxonomic status will remain unconfirmed at this time (K.O. Chan pers. comm. October 2018).

authority: (Chan, Grismer, Anuar, Quah, Grismer, Wood, Muin & Ahmad, 2011)

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hylarana chalconota.
This is a split from the broader concept of Chalcorana chalconota (as Hylarana chalconota) by Inger et al. 2009.
This species belongs to the genus Feihyla (Chan, K.O. unpubl. data January 2018).

This species is provisionally included in the genus Chalcorana by Oliver et al. 2015 but its taxonomy needs to be confirmed because its life history strategy is closer to Amolops (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
In 2009 Van Bocxlaer et al. suggested to transfer this species from genus Bufo to genus Duttaphrynus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Guenther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2015), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Glyphoglossus.

This species is provisionally assigned to the genus Hylarana, but further analyses are needed to solve its taxonomy (Oliver et al. 2015). The identity of the known specimens has been questioned and is probably a synonym of Humerana miopus (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers this to be a high-altitude savanna form of Hylarana albolbris, since there is a gradual transition between the two forms, and there are no call differences.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
It is possible that animals resembling this species on Mount Manenguba and at Buea on Mount Cameroon belong to as yet undescribed forms (Amiet 1977).
This is a split from the broader concept of Cardioglossa nigromaculata (elevated from subspecies level) (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
It is possible that some museum specimens currently assigned to other species might actually belong to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is not clear that all specimens attributed to this name actually belong to the same species.
Records of Cardioglossa pulchra from Tchabal Mbabo (Amiet 1972) now refer to this species (Herrmann et al. 2004).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is possible that some museum specimens currently assigned to other species might actually belong to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Ischnocnema bolbodactyla by Pombal and Cruz (1999).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Sandberger-Loua, Emmrich, Adeba, & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2010).

authority: Rödel, Burger, Zassi-Boulou, Emmrich, Penner, & Barej, 2015

taxonomicNotes: The taxonomic status of this species is unresolved and is likely to represent several species  (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain, and further taxonomic work is required (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

Studies are needed to determine whether or not specimens from Cameroon and Togo belong to the same species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is currently unclear whether there are any Werneria species in Togo, but it has been suggested that if there is one, it could be either W. preussi or alternatively a different, distinct species, Werneria africanus, which would be an endemic species to Togo (see Segniagbeto et al. 2007).

Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here considered a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)). Rödel and Pauwels (2003) provisionally assigned records of L. albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to L. stevarti.
Iskandar (pers. comm.) has examined the type specimen, and considers that this species does not belong to the genus Oreophryne.
We follow Rödel and Pauwels (2003) in provisionally assigning records of Leptodactylodon albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to this newly described species.
The holotype of this species has been lost. From the description, it appears that it might be a synonym of Sylvirana nigrovittata (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
The Atelognathus praebasalticus complex needs to be re-examined taxonomically. There are four known subspecies, some of which may constitute new species. Some of these subspecies may be extinct.

authority: Evans, Carter, Tobias, Kelley, Hanner & Tinsley, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species is considered to be the sister taxon of Xenopus wittei (Evans et al. 2008).
Xenopus calcaratus has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of X. tropicalis (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of H. muelleri (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015

taxonomicNotes: According to the original description, this species closely resembles and is sympatric with Rhacophorus monticola.

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It was described as a subspecies of Amietophrynus funereus (Hulselmans 1977), and was considered a distinct species by Joger (1982) and Böhme and Schneider (1987). J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that it is a junior synonym of Amietophrynus villiersi, an opinion not shared by U. Joger (pers. comm.). Channing and Rödel (2019), regarded this nominal taxon, likely a synonym of Sclerophrys villiersi, as too insufficiently known to treat adequately in their field guide.

Individuals of this species have diverse color variations, and therefore many researchers identify this frog as different species; however molecular analyses show they all belong to a single species (E. Smith pers. comm.).
We follow Matsui et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of S. tuberilinguis.

While Amiet (2012) considers Hyperolius dintelmanni as a synonym of this species which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following Rayna Bell and Stefan Lötters (pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Brede, Hillers & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Sandberger-Loua, Hirschfeld, Brede, Emmrich, Kouamé, Hillers, Gonwouo, Nopper, Adeba, Bangoura, Gage, Anderson & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Hirschfeld, Brede, Bangoura & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
In the Philautus aurifasciatus group according to the original publication (Matsui 2009).
Prior to its naming, this species was confused with Epipedobates boulengeri and Epipedobates espinosai according Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz (2011 "2010").
This species was previously included in the genus Hyloscirtus, then to moved to the genus Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), and later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

authority: Guayasamin, Rivera-Correa, Arteaga-Navarro, Culebras, Bustamante, Pyron, Peñafiel, Morochz, & Hutter, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloscirtus alytolylax (Guayasamín et al. 2015). Museum specimens recorded as H. alytolylax should be reviewed as some may pertain to this species.

authority: Coloma, Carvajal-Endara, Dueñas, Paredes-Recalde, Morales-Mite, Almeida-Reinoso, Tapia, Hutter, Toral-Contreras & Guayasamin, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloxalus bocagei (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).
This is a species complex.
It has not been included in phylogenies based on genetic traits, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain. It has not yet been assigned to any group of species.
Brito et al. (2017) provided records of Pristimantis aff. gualacenio from Tinguichaca, Sambalán and Cisnian, Morona Santiago.
Pristimantis kirklandi has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of Pristimantis incomptus (Heinicke et al. 2007).
There is some taxonomic confusion as this taxon may be synonym of Pristimantis floridus (M. Yánez-Muñóz pers. comm. 2021).

Because of its close resemblance with the abundant and widespread Pristimantis ockendeni, it is probable that specimens of this species are misidentified in museum collections.

Specimens previously reported from Morona Santiago (e.g.,QCAZA41883, QCAZA41884) actually belong to other species, such as Pristimantis incomptus (M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2021). The specimen from the locality Serena Village, Río Jatun Yacu, Napo Province (Elmer 2004) is now assigned to Pristimantis matidiktyo (Ortega-Andrade and Valencia 2012). Specimens reported from Loreto, Peru actually correspond to Pristimantis academicus (QCAZ 55641–42 = IIAP 501/502; M. Ortega-Andrade unpubl. data. 2021).

There is a great deal of uncertainty around the validity of this species. It may be conspecific with R. quechua (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019), as examination of the holotype suggests that it corresponds to the description of R. quechua (Quinteros-Muñoz 2010).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously considered as incertae sedis, however the validity of this species has now been confirmed (Jungfer et al. 2013).
This species has a distinct call from those of Scinax fuscovarius and S. nasius, species with which it shares similar phenotypic characteristics.

Silqueira et al. (2008) suggested on karyological evidence that the population from Aripuanã is unnamed. Subsequently, Padial and De la Riva (2009) named this population as Pristimantis koehleri and noted that the reports of this species from central Bolivia by Köhler (2000) was also based on the new species. In addition, P. ventrigranulosus has been place in synonymy with P. dundeei (Neves et al. in press).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. The Colombian specimens identified as Caecilia dunni were revalidated and assigned to C. leucocephala and C. perdita.

Pristimantis waoranii can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (see McCracken et al. 2007). This species is within the Pristimantis lacrimosus according to Padial et al. (2014) and Hedges et al. (2008). It is possible that this is not a valid species, so taxonomic work is needed for the entire species group (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021).

In the Rhinella margaritifera group according to the original publication. This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and vocalization features (Fouquet et al. 2007).
Tentatively assigned to the Dendropsophus microcephalus group according to the original description (Moravec et al. 2008).

Lötters et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence that this nominal species is a complex of species. The specimens from the Departamento Piura, Peru belong to an undescribed species (Coloma et al. 2000).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelopus ignescens by McDiarmid (1971).

Coloma, Lötters and Salas (2000) redefined Atelopus ignescens and restricted the species to the north-central Andes of Ecuador. Populations in northern Ecuador (in Cachi Province), and adjacent southern Colombia (Narino Department), previously assigned to Atelopus ignescens are now considered to belong to an undescribed species.

The specimens in the lowlands may be a different species as they are based on old museum specimens and doubtful collecting localities. Tapia et al. (2017) excluded these records from the current known range of the species and therefore they are considered as Presence Uncertain in this reassessment until they can be reassigned to another taxon. Reports from Valle del Cauca Department in Colombia, refer to an unidentified, probably unnamed species and are excluded from this assessment.
Yánez-Muñoz et al. (2010) reported this species from Parque Nacaional Podocarpus, but Frenkel et al. (2018) note that this actually corresponds to another species, Atelopus halihelos.
Records other than from the type locality (e.g. Peters 1973) are considered here to refer to Atelopus planispina.

The taxonomic status of A. planispina and A. palmatus was discussed by Coloma (1997). Records of A. palmatus from Napo Province actually belong to this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).

Gluesenkamp and Guayasamin (2008) this species is reported in the Sumaco Volcano, but in fact they are males of Osornophryne sumacoensis verified by Páez-Moscoso et al. (2011). The identity of the specimens from the northern part of Parque Nacional Llanganates requires confirmation.
Nymphargus cochranae might be a species complex (Guayasamín et al. 2020).

Hyloxalus cevallosi and Leucostethus fugax are similar (as originally described in 1991 and 1993 respectively) and their type localities are from the same general area in Río Bobonaza, Provincia Pastaza. The description of H. cevallosi was based on a single male, with no mention of having a Finger III swollen and by having a brownish-grey venter. Whereas the L. fugax description was based on a series of specimens, of which the holotype was a male with a Finger III swollen and a uniform cream venter. After 1993, collections in the area have revealed specimens of only one species with a Finger III swollen in males and having tubercles in the eyelid (present also in other species of Leucostethus). The specimens with these unique two features have been identified in museum collections ambiguously either as L. fugax or H. cevallosi (e.g. QCAZ Bioweb). Until further verification of the identity of H. cevallosi is undertaken we treat H. cevallosi as occurring only from the localities mentioned in the original description (Coloma and Duellman in prep.).
The subpopulation from Pastaza Province reported by Coloma (1995) belongs to an undescribed species (L. Coloma pers. comm.)
This form probably contains a number of undescribed species, according to Rivero (1991).
This may represent a species complex.
Molecular data suggest that Allobates kingsburyi is a species complex (L. Coloma pers. comm.).
This species needs a more detailed taxonomic review, as it may be a species confused with Hyloxalus maculosus (J.C. Sánchez pers. comm. 2021).

Its possible that this is a species complex, with the northern-most subpopulation appearing different from the subpopulation at the type locality in the Cordillera del Condor (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia and M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2021).

The assignment of the specimens from San Francisco de Las Pampas to this species is tentative, but is justified by the absence of significant differences between the original description of Paruwrobates whymperi and these specimens. Paruwrobates erythromos (Vigle and Miyata 1980) is similar to P. whymperi and might be conspecific. However, comparison of P. erythromos and the type specimen of P. whymperi is complicated due to the bad preservation of the holotype of P. whymperi; differences in ventral colour patterns might be a preservation artefact. Comparison of P. erythromos and the specimens from San Francisco de Las Pampas reveal that they are not conspecific (Coloma 1995).

Santos et al. (2014) moved this species from Ameerega to Hyloxalus, then Grant et al. (2017) moved it to the current genus and suggest the possibility that it is the same species as Paruwrobates whymperi.
This species and Epipedobates anthonyi were separated by Schulte (1999). We follow Graham et al. (2004) in restricting the distribution of E. tricolor to central Ecuador.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The genus Gastrotheca has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Ceratophrys cornuta by Mercadal (1988).
This taxon represents a species complex (J.C. Sánchez pers comm. 2016).
Some authors (e.g., Arteaga et al. 2013, Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009) have confused intermediate elevation subpopulations of P. luteolateralis with P. walkeri (Arteaga-Navarro et al. 2016).
Some subpopulations may be misidentifications (J.C. Sánchez, M. Yañez-Muñoz, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016).

This is a species complex and the only confirmed localities are Sigsig in the province of Azuay and Urdaneta in the province of Loja (Székely et al. 2017, Urgilés et al. 2017; M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2021). Urgilés et al. (2017) revised the species, recognizing Pristimantis cajanuma, from within the previous concept. Lynch (1979) states that this species occurs on the eastern Andean Cordillera from the Cuenca hoya to the Loja hoya in southern Ecuador. However, Urgilés et al. (2017). suggest that this distribution might be inaccurate and needs to be reviewed, as many of the records are probably erroneous belonging to very similar, but in fact different species.
This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis ornatissimus following the split of the broader concept into this and Pristimantis ecuadorensis (Guayasamin et al. 2017).
This is a species complex (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

The forms in the north (Imbabura and Pichincha) and south (Bolivar) of this range pertain to undescribed species (Rojas Runjaic 2012, Franco Mena 2020, Ecuador National Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Pristimantis riveti was described from a single specimen collected in Ecuador, El Mirador (Despax 1911). This species name was not associated with any population until Lynch (1969) incorrectly identified subpopulations of P. curtipes as “P. riveti” (Lynch 1979). Subsequently, Lynch (1979) provided a species account based on specimens collected near Cuenca, Azuay Province, in southern Ecuador, but remarkably, excluded the type locality from his account. Subsequent references to the species (e.g., Almendáriz and Orcés 2004, Székely et al. 2016) relied on the morphological characterization provided by Lynch (1979) and ascribed the binomen to subpopulations from Azuay, Cañar and Loja Provinces. 

Various species (e.g., P. gloria, P. lutzae, P. multicolor and P. chomskyi) have been mistakenly identified as P. riveti (Páez and Ron 2019). Therefore, this is a restricted concept of Pristimantis riveti following the split of the broader concept into this, P. gloria, P. lutzae, P. multicolor and P. chomskyi (Páez and Ron 2019).

Some previous authors referred to this species as Eleutherodactylus trepidotus (e.g., Lynch and Duellman 1980, Lynch 1984, Almendáriz et al. 2004, Stuart et al. 2008) until Pristimantis festae was deemed the senior synonym (Heinicke et al. 2007, Hedges et al. 2008).
It is a species complex.

Arteaga-Navarro et al. (2016) suggest that subpopulations of Pristimantis walkeri in northwestern Ecuador are referable to P. nietoi and P. luteolateralis, and those in southwestern Ecuador refer to P. buenaventura.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006). This species is currently under taxonomic revision. The Peruvian population pertains to a different, but closely related species (Ron et al. 2006).
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The northern subpopulation could belong to an undescribed species.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).

In the genus Nymphargus according to Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Nymphargus buenaventura is distinguished from other species of glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007).
Espadarana durrellorum is diagnosed from other centrolenids by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Cisneros-Heredia 2007).

In the genus Nymphargus following Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Guayasamin et al. (2006) indicate that the species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colouration differences and allopatric distributions. Guayasamin et al. (2006) adopt the Evolutionary Species Concept in their description of Nymphargus wileyi.
Hyloxalus parcus was removed from the synonymy of Colostethus exasperatus by Morales (2005).

Frost (2021) indicates that this taxon was removed from the synonymy of Colostethus bocagei by Santos et al. (2003), by implication of their placement of this taxon in a phylogenetic tree away from C. bocagei, where it had been placed by Coloma (1995); but Coloma in Duellman (2004) suggested that C. maculosus remains a synonym of C. bocagei, which is contrary to the results of Santos et al. (2003). Páez-Vacas et al. (2010) considered this species to be part of the Hyloxalus bocagei complex, distinct from H. bocagei.
Atelopus petersi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
Formerly included within Leptodactylus pentadactylus; separated by Heyer (2005).
Atelopus onorei can be distinguished from other similar species by its colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
It is possible that this species could be a taxonomic complex, however the current data cannot confirm this (Guayasamin et al., 2015).
This species was removed from synonymy with Caecilia tentaculata by Taylor (1972).

authority: Arteaga, Pyron, Peñafiel, Romero-Barreto, Culebras, Bustamante, Yánez-Muñoz & Guayasamin, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Some subpopulations of Pristimantis walkeri in northwestern Ecuador belong to P. nietoi (Arteaga-Navarro et al. 2016).

authority: Arteaga, Pyron, Peñafiel, Romero-Barreto, Culebras, Bustamante, Yánez-Muñoz & Guayasamin, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Subpopulations of Pristimantis walkeri in southwestern Ecuador belong to P. buenaventura (Arteaga-Navarro et al. 2016).

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis calcarulatus (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). Despite being nearly morphologically identical, these taxa have considerable genetic distance between them.

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis calcarulatus (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). The Río Guayllabamba south of the two reserves appears to serve as a geographical barrier separating P. cedros from P. calcarulatus and its sister taxon, P. pahuma (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). Despite being nearly morphologically identical, these taxa have considerable genetic distance between them.

Páez and Ron (2019) identify that Pristimantis hampatusami (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2016) and Pristimantis prometeii (Székely et al. 2016) correspond to the same species and propose that P. prometeii is a junior synonym of P. hampatusami.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Pristimantis cedros and P. pahuma (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015).
Chiasmocleis anatipes is apparently close to Chiasmocleis leucosticta and divergent from other species of Chiasmocleis (Walker and Duellman 1974).
Hyperolius fasciatus and H. ferreirai have been synonymized under this species by Frétey et al. (2011).

authority: (Wogan, Win, Thin, Lwin, Shein, Kyi & Tun, 2003)

taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Cacosternum boettgeri by Channing (2001), where it had been placed by Poynton (1964). Channing et al. (2013) described four new species in Cacosternum genus and revised the distribution of known Cacosternum species, so the range of C. platys has been restricted (southern Cape Peninsula populations are now referred to as C. australis, sister species of C. platys).

We follow Veith et al. (2003), in considering this species to be distinct from Rana macrocnemis at the species level. It is confirmed through molecular data to occur in Çakıroluk (type locality) and Girdev Lake (U. Kaya pers. comm. December 2018).

Pickersgill (2007) removed this species from the synonymy of Hyperolius acuticeps based on its voice. It is a member of the H. nasutus complex. A recent reevaluation of the group's taxonomy (Channing et al. 2013) confirmed the validity of this species, based on morphological, genetic, and acoustic evidence.
Céspedez (2000) separated the taxon formerly known as Rhinella pygmaea into two species: R. pygmaea of coastal Brazil and R. bergi in the interior of the continent.

This reassessment is for the new broader concept of Rhinella dorbignyi which includes R. fernandezae as a synonym (Pereyra et al. 2021). This species probably represents a complex of several cryptic species (D. Barrasso pers. comm. 2017).
This species does not occur in Goiás and Bahia states, Brazil; the erroneous records are probably related to Rhinella cerradensis (M. Solé, R. Bastos and D. Silvano pers. comm. 2020).

This species was elevated to species level from Melanophryniscus stelzneri atroluteus by Klappenbach and Langone (1992). However, the external morphology and advertisement calls are almost indistinguishable between M. atroluteus and M. montevidensis (Kwet et al. 2005, Maneyro and Kwet 2008).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.

This species was elevated to species status by Cruz and Caramaschi (2003). Prior to this, it was considered to be a subspecies of Melanophryniscus stelzneri. Reexamination of specimens from the Argentinean provinces of Santa Fe (Baldo and Arzamendia 1997) and Santiago del Estero (Basso and Williams 1996) revealed that these records actually belong to M. klappenbachi (Baldo 2001).
Bolivian subpopulations are in need of taxonomic revision.

Two subspecies recognized: Melanophryniscus stelzneri stelzneri and M. s. spegazzinii. Argentinean subpopulations previously referred to as M .s. fulvoguttatus belong to Melanophryniscus klappenbachi. Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) briefly discussed that records from Paraguay (e.g., Céspedez 1996) are based on misidentifications.

This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This is a restricted concept of Aplastodiscus perviridis following the split of the broader concept into this and Aplastodiscus lutzorum (Berneck et al. 2017).

There are two subspecies: Nyctamantis siemersi siemersi and N. s. pederseni. Taxonomic studies are ongoing to evaluate the taxonomic status of the two subspecies; preliminary results do not support the hypothesis that N. s. pederseni and N. s. siemersi represent distinct species, but rather the same species with colour variants (R. Cajade pers. comm. September 2017).

This species was recently transferred to the genus Nyctimantis as N. siemersi (Suárez et al. 2020, Blotto et al. 2020).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The subpopulation in Sao Paulo might be a different species.
It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was resurrected from the synonymy of Dendropsophus nanus by Basso et al. (1985).

This species was previously with the genus Hyla, but was moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005). Duellman et al. (2016) erected the new genus Julianus for the species in the Scinax uruguayus group. Baldo et al. (2019) treated Julianus as a synonym of Scinax, but that is not followed here.

This is the new reduced concept of Julianus uruguayus which excludes the new species J. fontanarrosi (Baldo et al. 2019).

Lysapsus limellum occurs only in the Prata and Paraguay River Basins; records from the Amazon basin are L. bolivianus (Aguiar et al. 2007, Garda and Cannatella 2007; D. Santana and A. Garda pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the monotypic genus Itapotihyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This form is a complex of more than one species. Scinax eringiophilus has been synonymized with this species by Kwet (2001).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus hylaedactylus by De la Riva (1995).

Subpopulations outside of the Pantanal biome in Brazil possibly do not correspond to this species (Workshop on Assessment of the conservation status of Pantanal amphibian species 2020).
This is a polymorphic species that presents different morphotypes adapted to aquatic or terrestrial environments (Cuello et al. 2008).

Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) suggested that reports of this species for Paraguay are based on specimens of Ceratophrys cranwelli. The historical record of “Montevideo, Uruguay” based on a specimen deposited in the Royal Museum of Natural History of Belgium (Museu Royal d 'Histoire Naturelle, Brussels) (Cochran 1955) requires confirmation (Maneyro et al. 2019).
This species is a complex of more than one species.

Subpopulations from the coastal areas of Venezuela formerly allocated to this taxon, are now considered to be a distinct species, Leptodactylus turimiquensis (Heyer 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Jansen et al. 2011, Jansen and Schultze 2012).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Jansen et al. 2011). This is a restricted concept of Leptodactylus mystacinus following the split of the broader concept into this and L. apepyta (Schneider et al. 2019).
This diploid species was separated from the tetraploid Odontophrynus americanus.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species. Pereyra et al. (2009) reported a natural hybrid with Odonophrynus cordobae in central Argentina.
This species is a sibling species of Physalaemus cuvieri and Physalaemus cuqui. It is probably a complex of more than one species.

Confused in the literature with Physalaemus fuscomaculatus, which has resulted in considerable problems in delimiting ranges (De la Riva et al. 2000). Pleurodema fuscomaculatum has been synonymized under this species by Kolenc et al. (2011). Santos-Pereira et al. (2018) suggested that isolated records from Paraná, Brazil, require confirmation.

The Physalaemus cuvieri species group represents a complex of cryptic species (Lourenço et al. 2015). Nascimento et al. (2019) reported on the phylogenetics of the Physalaemus ephippifer–Physalaemus cuvieri group, suggesting that Physalaemus cuvieri is a complex of at least six species.
The record from Rivera mentioned in the 2004 assessment belongs to Pseudopaludicola falcipes (Maneyro et al. 2019).
This is a restricted concept of Physalaemus gracilis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. carrizorum (Cardozo and Pereyra 2018).

The taxonomic status of Pleurodema borellii is uncertain. This species and P. cinereum have been recognized either as synonymous or as valid species at various points in time (see a synthesis in Faivovich et al. 2012). Duellman and Veloso (1977) used altitudinal range and thigh color to differentiate the species (i.e., P. borellii occurs between 400–3,000 m asl and has purple thighs, while P. cinereum occurs between 2,900–4,100 m asl and has yellow thighs), and this criterion is still used at present.

On the basis of phylogenetic analysis, Faivovich et al. (2012) considered the subpopulations assigned to P. borellii and P. cinereum at least from the east coast of Lake Titicaca southwards to Bolivia and Argentina belong to the same species, P. cinereum. Until specimens from their respective type localities become available, the taxonomic status of both species remains in question.

This species is part of a group of polyploid and cryptic species within the genus Pleurodema (Vaira et al. 2012), along with P. cordobae (octoploid, from Sierras de Comenchingones, Córdoba) and P. bibroni (tetraploid, from Uruguay and southern Brazil).

Valetti et al. (2009) redescribed the species and differentiated it from P. cordobae and P. bibroni.
Proceratophrys palustris is similar to this species.
Populations from Santa Catarina in southern Brazil might belong to a different species.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It has frequently been confused with Chthonerpeton viviparum.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is unclear that all populations are conspecific.
This species was removed from synonymy of Rhinella crucifer by Baldissera et al. (2004). Rhinella abei was recently placed in synonymy with this species (Pereyra et al. 2021).

This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Hyla pulchella by Faivovich et al. (2004). This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

In the Scinax catharinae group, and possibly confused as Scinax berthae in Brazil, according to the original publication. Specimens treated as Scinax cf. berthae by Kwet and Di-Bernardo (1999) and by Kwet (2001) could instead belong to this species (Faivovich 2005).

Allocated to the genus Ischnocnema following Heinicke et al. (2007). The name Ischnocnema henselii is resurrected to accommodate a species that was first detected through differences in advertisement call parameters (Kwet and Solé 2005).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Gehara et al. 2013).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). In the Boana pulchella group. Boana curupi can be distinguished from other species in the group by larval, morphological and advertisement call features (Garcia et al. 2007).

This species was confused with Trachycephalus imitatrix (Miranda-Ribeiro 1926) prior to its naming; however, Blotto et al. (2021) suggested that the taxonomic status of this taxon relative to Trachycephalus imitatrix requires additional study.
This species may be a synonym of M. stelzneri, further taxonomic work is needed to establish the taxonomic status of both species (D. Baldo pers. comm. October 2017)

This is a restricted concept of Pseudopaludicola falcipes following the split of the broader concept into this, P. parnaiba (Roberto et al. 2013 – subsequently synonymized with P. canga by Andrade et al. 2020) and other subpopulations previously confused with this taxon (Langone et al. 2015, D. Cardozo pers. comm. 2017).

This is a revised concept of Rhinella spinulosa following the split of the broader concept into this and R. arequipensis (Cei 1972) and the placement of R. sima in synonymy with this species (De la Riva 2004). More than one species might be involved in Rhinella spinulosa. The form Rhinella spinulosa papillosa of Chile and Argentina is often considered distinct but is not treated as such here.

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). Hypsiboas albovittatus was synonymized with this species by Faivovich et al. (2005).

Boana prasina and B. joaquini are often considered to be subspecies of B. pulchella.
The reported occurrence in Myanmar of this species has now been attributed to Amolops bellulus.
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Aquixalus by Delorme et al. (2005), and from Aquixalus to Kurixalus by Li et al. (2008).

Boophis brachychir is sometimes confused with Boophis madagascariensis and was removed from synonymy with it by Glaw and Vences (1992). Subsequently, Glaw et al. (2010) removed Boophis entingae from synonymy with B. brachychir.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of Boophis sandrae (Glaw et al. 2010).
In the Boophis tephraeomystax group; Boophis hillenii merged into this species concept (Frost 2014).

This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of Boophis albilabris, but it was raised to full specific rank by Andreone et al. (2002). Boophis tsilomaro was previously confused with this species (Vences et al. 2010).

While Amiet (2012) considers this species to be a synonym of Hyperolius tuberculatus which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following expert consensus (R. Bell and S. Lötters pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

authority: Chaparro, Padial, Gutiérrez, & De la Riva, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Based on evidence of separation in the metapopulation lineages of the Craugastor podiciferus species group, Craugastor gabbi has been split from the taxonomic concept of Craugastor stejnegerianus with the premontane subpopulations belonging to C. gabbi (Arias et al. 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pithecopus azureus (Bruschi et al. 2014).

Phyllomedusa itacolomi has been synonymized under this species by Baêta et al. (2009). According to Magalhães et al. (2017), this species may be a complex of at least three undescribed species as it contains at least three evolutionarily significant units isolated in distinct mountain regions. The genetic structure of the subpopulations could represent a typical pattern of campos rupestres habitat endemics (Magalhães et al. 2017).

This is a restricted concept following the recognition of Phyllomedusa rustica [now rusticus] as a separate species (Bruschi et al. 2014) and was previously under Phyllomedusa azureus name. The Pithecopus genus Cope, 1866 was removed from the synonymy of Phyllomedusa Wagler, 1830 based on molecular data by Duellman et al. (2016) and includes the species that were formerly assigned to the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group (sensu Faivovich et  al. 2005,  2010). Phylogenetic inferences for species of Pithecopus recovered two well-supported clades with strong biogeographical cohesiveness (Faivovich et al. 2010, Duellman et al. 2016). A highland clade, and the lowland clade to which Pithecopus azureus belongs. 

The subpopulation noted by Lucas et al. (2010) as an apparently isolated subpopulation in the municipality of Agua Doce, Santa Catarina, Brazil, and which they suggested might represent a species complex, was subsequently named Phyllomedusa rustica by Bruschi et al. (2014), now known as Pithecopus rusticus (Segalla et al. 2016).
The species Phyllomedusa araguari was suggested to be a synonym of Pithecopus oreades by Brandão and Álvarez (2009), and corroborated by Faivovich et al. (2010).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

M.-O. Rödel (pers. comm.) considers that populations from Togo westwards belong to Sclerophrys togoensis. M. Tandy (pers comm.) considers that both Sclerophrys camerunensis and s. togoensis might occur sypatrically in West Africa. In this account we follow the former view, and restrict S. camerunensis to Central Africa.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016). The species name has also changed from rangeri (a replacement name) to capensis, the original combination under Sclerophrys.

This species is in the Amietophrynus blanfordii Group according to Tandy and Keith (1972), who also noted that it was described from inadequate postmetamorphic material making it a nomen dubium. Tandy and Feener (1985), suggested that it might represent A. xeros, A. regularis or A. pentoni.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Although there have been no recent records of this species, even though it occurs in a well-surveyed region, it appears to be taxonomically valid (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Duttaphrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species is sometimes considered to be a synonym of Sclerophrys funerea.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Sclerophrys djohongensis and S. buchneri are sometimes considered to belong to this species.

There is confusion regarding the taxonomy of this species and Amietophrynus poweri (M. Largen, J. Poynton, L. Mazibuko and M. Tandy pers. comm.). It is possible that the true Amietophrynus garmani is restricted to northeastern Africa, with animals from further south belonging to another species (Largen 2001). In this account, we follow the traditional understanding of the species' distribution and taxonomy, pending further information.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

It is possible that this name covers two species (Tandy pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Bufo but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Bufo chudeaui Chabanaud, 1919, which is known only from inadequate post-metamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985).

There is confusion regarding the taxonomy of this species and Amietophrynus garmani (M. Largen, J. Poynton, L. Mazibuko and M. Tandy pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Amietophrynus chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985). The taxon is likely comprised of a complex of species (V. Gvozdik pers.comm. November 2012).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species is known from Uganda, but there are doubts as to whether or not it extends as far north as Egypt. Specimens from Egypt have been separated as Sclerophrys kassasii, but Tandy (pers. comm.) still considers that S. vittatus occurs in Egypt.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Sclerophrys (Amietophrynus) chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Xenopus poweri (Furman et al. 2015).

This is the restricted concept of this species following the split of Xenopus fischbergi (Evans et al. 2015). 

It is part of a complex of poorly understood species closely related to Xenopus laevis.  It seems likely that many records from the inland parts of Tanzania currently assigned to this species should in fact be referred to Xenopus borealis, and the distribution maps probably records this species as occurring much too widely in this country.
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhinella marina (Acevedo-Rincón et al. 2016).
Lötters et al. (2011) rejected the conspecificity of Atelopus barbotini and Atelopus spumarius and suggested that Atelopus barbotini may be a synonym of Atelopus flavescens (Frost 2021).

This species was previously synonymized under Hyperolius viridiflavus. However, Dehling (2015) showed that H. papyri is in fact a member of the H. nasutus group and its synonym pachydermus was wrongly associated with H. viridiflavus (as subspecies pachydermus) by Laurent.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any of their 10 species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been preferable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated mwanzae, variabilis and bayoni as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including them under H. viridiflavus. 
The name Hyperolius viridiflavus pachydermus was wrongly associated with H. viridiflavus (as a subspecies pachydermus) by Laurent (M. Dehling pers. comm. April 2017).
There has not been a formal synonymy, however, genetic data have suggested that Oreophrynella dendronastes is a synonym of this species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).

This species is phylogenetically closely related to Hyalinobatrachium ibama (Guayasamin et al. 2009, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2014). Recently, Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) suggested that Hyalinobatrachium ibama is possibly a synonym of H. pallidum.
