Additional studies must be done to resolve this uncertainty including not only the populations from Colombia, but also those from Sierra de Perijá and Mérida state in the Venezuelan Andes.

Originally described as Colostethus praderioi (La Marca 1997) and later transferred to Anomaloglossus by Grant et al. (2006) on the basis of phylogenetic evidence combining molecular and phenotypic data. Kok (2010) redescribed the species with additional samples from Guyana. In the Anomaloglossus beebei species group sensu Grant et al. (2017).

This species was originally described on the basis of a single immature female (La Marca 1997). It was redescribed based on new material and direct comparison with the holotype by Kok et al. (2013). 

Like many other Anomaloglossus species, A. roraima displays an impressive intraspecific variation in color pattern. This phenotypic variability, coupled with the fact that the species occurs on different tepuis, could lead to inappropriate taxonomic decisions (i.e., describing subpopulations from different tepuis as new), which has been done in the past with other Pantepui taxa (Kok et al. 2013).

This genus was moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005). This species is well-supported. However, as with other species occurring in Trinidad & Tobago as well in northeastern Venezuela, mainly within Paria Peninsula, morphological and molecular assessments of mainland and insular populations are needed (Rivas et al. 2018). Duellman and Gray (1983) confirmed that Trinidad, Tobago and Venezuela populations are morphologically indistinguishable. Work in progress (Michael Jowers, pers. comm.) confirms a lack of significant molecular differences between the three subpopulations.

Originally described in the Hyla geographica group (Duellman and Hoogmoed 1992), but later transferred to the Hypsiboas benitezi group of Faivovich et al. (2005). It was then subsequently moved to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) considered Hypsiboas angelicus Myers and Donnelly 2008 as a junior synonym of this species.

Jowers et al. (2008) demonstrated that the genus Phyllodytes is paraphyletic on the basis of evidence from mitochondrial gene sequences. These authors showed that the levels of divergence of Phyllodytes auratus and the Brazilian Phyllodytes were greater than the intergeneric distance within tribu Lophiohylini and erected the genus Phytotriades for the species then known only from Trinidad (= Phytotriades auratus). Recently Blotto et al. (2020) demonstrated that Phytotriades is the sister taxon of Itapotihyla, and together form the sister group of all other Lophyohylini, supporting its distinctiveness to Phyllodytes spp.

In the Phyllomedusa tarsius group (Faivovich et al. 2010). Phyllomedusa neildi from northwestern Venezuela could be a junior synonym of Phyllomedusa trinitatis, despite the morphological and call differences in both species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
In the Scinax staufferi group, according to Duellman (1986). In the Scinax ruber clade, but unassigned to any group (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was considered to be a synonym of Stefania evansi by Duellman and Hoogmoed (1984), but was revived by Señaris et al. (1997). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2017). Assigned to the evansi clade sensu Kok et al. (2017) whose members are circumscribed to the lowlands and uplands of the Eastern Pantepui District, and its eastern periphery in Guyana.

This species is still missing in phylogenetic analyses, and its relationships with others members of the genus are unknown. Two specimens collected in Serra da Mocidade at 960 m asl, state of Roraima, northern Brazil (Moraes et al. 2017) are morphological similar and apparently closely related to S. tamacuarina, but additional molecular analysis is required to fully identify them.

Two specimens from Serra do Navio, Amapá, Brazil were initially identified as Adelophryne gutturosa (Hoogmoed et al. 1994), but this material was later described as A. amapaensis (Taucce et al. 2020).

Described originally in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Myers and Donnelly 1997), then subsequently transferred to Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007), and posteriorly to Ceuthomantis by Heinicke et al. (2009) whom also erected a new family, Ceuthomantidae, for this taxon. This diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis have been suggested (Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Frost 2022 for a summary). In all these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (New World direct-developing frogs).

The specimens reported as Pristimantis cf. cavernibardus from the Cerro Sarisariñama by Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías (2008), were described two years later as a new species, Ceuthomantis duellmani (Barrio-Amorós 2010).

This species belongs to the L. pentadactylus species group, based on molecular phylogeny and non-molecular characters. It also shows, within the L. pentadactyus group, speciation in rocky outcrops (although not restricted in all; see habitat use), a kind of habitat also used for three species in the L. pentadactyus group, to which L. rugosus is related (De Sá et al. 2014).
This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus melanonotus species group based on its morphology, although it was not included in the molecular analysis by De Sá et al. (2014).
Nascimento et al. (2019) reported on the phylogenetics of the Physalaemus ephippifer–Physalaemus cuvieri group, suggesting that the Guianan/Venezuelan subpopulations belong to an unnamed species.

Recent analyses have shown that there are at least two species under this name. The occurrence in Guyana can be attributed to an undescribed species (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This species is possibly the same species as Elachistocleis ovalis. It is possible that Relictivomer pearsei is a synonym of this species, and it was treated as such by Kenny (1969). However, we treat them here as separate species, pending a review of their relationships.
This taxon was long considered a subspecies of Otophryne robusta, until the taxonomic treatment by Campbell and Clarke (1998).

Venezuelan specimens previously referred as Pipa aspera by La Marca (1992) are in fact P. arrabali. Both species are very similar and mostly sympatric, so the validity of P. arrabali is doubtful, it could be a junior synonym of P. aspera according to Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019).
The conspecificity of the specimens from Venezuela and Suriname is not certain.

The species is sometimes incorrectly cited as Epicrionops nigrus. The taxonomy of the genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). The holotype described by Dunn (1942) is lost, and Taylor (1968) designated UCVMB 5360, described by Roze and Solano (1963), as the neotype (as Epicrionops nigrus). Moraes et al. (2017) noted a specimen from the Serra da Mocidade in the Guiana Shield region of northern Brazil, similar to this species but genetically distinct, presumably representing an unnamed species. Return to the genus Rhinatrema after the phylogenetic revision of Maciel et al. (2018).
This is a problematic taxon that has been assigned to different families (Allophrynidae, Bufonidae, Centrolenidae, Hylidae, Leptodactylidae).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position as part of Allobates is corroborated by Grant et al. (2017). The population from Río Dorado referred as Allobates humilis (Barrio-Amorós and García-Porta 2003) correspond to A. algorei (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009).

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010) but referred as unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). Their phylogenetic relationships within the genus remain unknown.

Faivovich et al. (2013) named Myersiohyla chamaeleo based on a very complete description of adult morphological characters, advertisement calls, tadpoles, natural history, and a phylogenetic analysis of the genus.
This is a split from the broader concept of Tepuihyla edelcae (Kok et al. 2015).

Tepuihyla rimarum, Tepuihyla galani, and Tepuihyla talbergae have been synonymized under this species (Jungfer et al. 2013, Kok et al. 2015). Its phylogenetic relationships have been assessed by Kok et al. (2012, 2015), Jungfer et al. (2013), and Salerno et al. (2012, 2015).
Centrolene lema and Centrolene papillahallicum have been synonymized under this species by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009), and Kok and Castroviejo-Fisher (2008).

We consider this species to be separate from Hynobius leechii, following Yang et al. (1997). This is also a restricted concept of this species now that H. unisacculus has been split from it by Min et al. (2016).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus fisheri (Min et al. in Poyarkov et al. 2012) and is a species complex according to Poyarkov et al. (2012).

authority: Min, Yang, Bonett, Vieites, Brandon & Wake, 2005
taxonomicNotes: While first collected in 1971 (Nishikawa 2009), it was only described in 2005 (Min et al. 2005).
This species was split from Rana dybowskii by Matsui (2014).

This species has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of R. veraguensis (Padial et al. 2009). Several specimens that are now considered to represent R. leptoscelis are those reported as R. fissipes by Köhler (2000) for Bolivia (Padial et al. 2009). Records from the surroundings of Caranavi, Departamento La Paz, Bolivia (deposited at CBF) were erroneously reported as originating from Rurrenabaque, Departamento Beni by Köhler (2000) according to Padial et al. (2009).

Due to the taxonomic confusion of this species and E. coqui, some lowland records of this species are thought to belong to E. coqui and are therefore excluded from this assessment (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment). Furthermore, all historical specimens from the Cordillera Central (up to Maricao) and any references to the extirpation of these subpopulations should be re-evaluated. Initial evidence based on morphology, osteology, bioacoustics, and ecology, reveals that records of E. portoricensis in this region may actually correspond to a presumable subspecies of E. coqui (Ríos-López et al. in prep.).
This is a split from the broader concept of Clinotarsus alticola (Grosjean et al. 2015).

authority: Motta, Chaparro, Pombal, Guayasamin, De la Riva & Padial, 2016
Motta, Chaparro, Pombal, Guayasamin, De la Riva & Padial, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Eleutherodactylus nebulosus Henle, 1992 was discovered to be a junior homonym of Syrrhophus nebulosus Taylor, 1943, hence Eleutherodactylus caliginosus Lynch, 1996 was published as a replacement name. The species is now treated under the genus Pristimantis, so its original specific name of nebulosus has been restored. Duellman and Lehr (2009) suggested that because the holotype is in poor condition that association with a living population is problematic.

Many researchers doubt the validity of this species. The single specimen might belong in the genus Hyla.

Infante-Rivero et al. (2009) suggested that this species, known only from the holotype, is not a member of Cryptobatrachus (the genus it was originally assessed under), but a hyline unassigned to genus, although possibly in Hyloscirtus (Frost 2015). It has been placed under "Hyla" for the interim (Frost 2015).
Taxonomic revision of this species is needed, particularly of the Philippine subpopulations.

authority: (De la Riva, Aparicio, Soto & Ríos in De la Riva & Aparicio, 2016)
(De la Riva, Ríos & Aparicio in De la Riva & Aparicio, 2016)

taxonomicNotes: Following taxonomic revision of the Phrynomedusa genus, many individuals previously assigned to Phrynomedusa marginata have been transferred to this new species P. dryade (Baêta et al. 2016).

authority: Solis, Espinal, Valle, O'Reilly, Itgen & Townsend, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Oedipina stuarti (Solis et al. 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nototriton barbouri (Townsend 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nototriton barbouri (Townsend 2016).

authority: (Suwannapoom, Yuan, Poyarkov, Yan, Kamtaeja, Murphy & Che, 2016)

taxonomicNotes: This is a restricted concept of Zhangixalus dorsoviridis following the split of the broader concept into this and Zhangixalus pinglongensis (Mo et al. 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Zhangixalus dorsoviridis (Mo et al. 2016).
The former species Lyciasalamandra billae, L. arikani, L. irfani and L. yehudai have been designated as subspecies under this new concept (Veith et al. 2016).

This species has previously been identified as Amietia angolensis, which has recently been found to harbour cryptic species (Channing and Baptista 2013). A. viridireticulata was synonymized under this species by Channing et al. (2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Aplastodiscus perviridis (Berneck et al. 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Aplastodiscus callipygius has now been synonymized with this species (Berneck et al. 2016).

authority: Channing, Measey, De Villiers, Turner & Tolley, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Capensibufo rosei (Channing et al. 2017). High-altitude specimens from the Koeël Mountains may represent cryptic species but have been provisionally assigned to Capensibufo deceptus by Channing et al. (2017).

authority: Channing, Measey, De Villiers, Turner & Tolley, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Capensibufo rosei (Channing et al. 2017).

authority: Channing, Measey, De Villiers, Turner & Tolley, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Capensibufo rosei (Channing et al. 2017).

This species has a confusing taxonomic history which has been reviewed several times (Tarrant et al. 2008, Channing 2015). Most recently known as Amietia umbraculata, Channing (2015) reverted the name to A. vertebralis based on examination of type specimens and Zoological Nomenclature rules. Channing et al. (2016) showed that the species forms a well-supported clade and is the sister species to Amietia delalandii with which it is synoptic.

A study by Channing and Baptista (2013) based on mitochondrial DNA, advertisement calls and morphology splits this form into two distantly related taxa, which were previously assessed together: Amietia fuscigula (Duméril and Bibron 1841) from the southwestern Cape and a recently described species, Amietia poyntoni. The species occurs in sympatry with A. delalandii, A. vandijki, and A. poyntoni.

This species was firstly described only from its type locality and a nearby site in French Guiana (Boistel et al. 2006). Its potential distribution was confirmed over most forested parts of the northern Guiana Shield lowlands (Fouquet et al. 2011). Carvalho et al. (2020) revised the systematics and historical biogeography of the Adenomera heyeri clade and uncovered ten new candidate species with interfluve associated distributions across Amazonia, and formally described six new species from the clade.
Peloso and Sturaro (2008) reported considerable morphological variation among populations suggestive of cryptic species.

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Nothophryne broadleyi (Conradie et al. 2018).

authority: Priti, Naik, Seshadri, Singal, Vidisha, Ravikanth & Gururaja, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Euphlyctis hexadactylus (Priti et al. 2016).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Euphlyctis karaavali (Priti et al. 2016).

authority: Rodriguez, Dugo-Cota, Montero-Mendieta, Gonzalez-Voyer, Alonso Bosch, Vences & Vilà, 2017
taxonomicNotes: Specimens assigned to this taxon were originally considered to be Eleutherodactylus glamyrus (Rodríguez et al. 2017).

Orrico et al. (2017) removed this taxon from the synonymy of Boana crepitans and placed Boana fuentei in synonymy with it. Subpopulations from Panama, Colombia, Venezuela (north of the Orinoco River) and the islands of Trinidad and Tobago have been differentiated out of Boana xerophylla and assigned to Boana platanera based on external morphology, molecular markers, and advertisement call (Escalona et al. 2021).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pulchrana guttmani (Brown 2015).
Adults and larvae of this montane species have previously been misidentified as either Hylarana signata or H. glandulosa. The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).

Hylarana laterimaculata was removed from the synonymy of this species by Leong Tzi Ming et al. (2003). The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015). 

Further taxonomic work is required on this species as it is a complex (M. Munir pers. comm. May 2017), and it is morphologically similar to P. laterimaculata and P. glandulosa which could cause confusion for identification in the field (M. Munir pers. comm. May 2017).

authority: Zachariah, Cyriac, Chandramohan, Ansil, Mathew, Raju & Abraham, 2016
Zachariah, Cyriac, Chandramohan, Ansil, Mathew, Raju & Abraham, 2016

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Triturus ivanbureschi (Wielstra and Arntzen 2016).

This species is distributed along the Pacific coast of Costa Rica from the Panamanian border northward to the Cordillera de Tilarán (Crawford 2003). The Cordillera de Tilarán subpopulations could potentially represent yet one more undescribed species (Crawford 2003, J. Savage, pers. comm. in Arias et al. 2016), which could eventually leave this species restricted to the Pacific lowlands, roughly south of the City of Puntarenas (Arias et al. 2016).

There is considerable uncertainty around the taxonomic status of this species (S. Loader pers. comm. November 2015). Hyperolius seabrai was formally synonymised with this species by Frétey et al. (2011).
This species has been split from Hyperolius adspersus (Channing et al. 2013).

Specimens from Viet Nam that are currently allocated to Babina lini might actually be B. chapaensis. This species was previously believed to have been found in Thailand and Xieng Khouang Province in Lao People's Democratic Republic, however the population has now been confirmed as belonging to Babina lini (Chuaynkern et al. 2010).

Some populations of Ingerophrynus galeatus in central Viet Nam are believed to have been misidentified and actually belong to Ingerophrynus macrotis which needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. March 2015).

This species was previously considered a synonym of Leptobrachium hasseltii sensu lato. Records from Thailand (Chan-ard et al. 1999; Manthey and Grossmann 1997) and perhaps from Lao People's Democratic Republic (Stuart 1999) refer to L. smithi, while some records from Viet Nam (Inger et al. 1999) pertain to L. xanthospilum.
Limnonectes toumanoffi has been synonymized under this species by Stuart et al. (2006).
We follow Ohler et al. (2002) in treating this as a species distinct from Limnonectes kohchangae. Records of Limnonectes blythii from Viet Nam actually belong to this species (Frost 2020).
Nanorana fansipani has been synonymized under this species by Dubois and Ohler (2005).
We follow Ohler (2003) in considering Ophryophryne poilani to be a junior synonym of O. microstoma.
We follow Ohler and Delorme (2006) in separating this species from Rhacophorus reinwardtii. Some populations of this species have previously been treated as Rhacophorus nigropalmatus.
Reports of this species from mainland Southeast Asia require confirmation.
This species has been removed from synonymy of Dendropsophus triangulum (Caminer et al. 2017).

authority: Caminer, Milá, Jansen, Fouquet, Venegas, Chávez, Lougheed & Ron, 2017
Waser, Schweizer, Haas, Das, Jankowski, Min & Hertwig, 2017
Smart, Sarker, Arifin, Harvey, Sidik, Hamidy, Kurniawan & Smith, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Kalophrynus pleurostigma (Zug 2015).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Megophrys major (Chen et al. 2016).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Species that have been identified as Platymantis dorsalis need to be re-examined. Frogs of the dorsalis Group share many morphological features and closely resemble one another, which is perhaps the main reason for the failure of earlier herpetologists to separate them as valid species. We consider P. meyeri Günther, 1873 to be a synonym of P. dorsalis following Brown and Inger (1964).

authority: Forlani, Tonini, Cruz, Zaher & de Sá, 2017

taxonomicNotes: Previously confused with Chaismocleis lacrimae and Chaismocleis capixaba according to the original publication.

authority: Forlani, Tonini, Cruz, Zaher & de Sá, 2017
Forlani, Tonini, Cruz, Zaher & de Sá, 2017
Guayasamin, Hutter, Tapia, Culebras, Peñafiel, Pyron, Morochz, Funk & Arteaga-Navarro, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis ornatissimus (Guayasamin et al. 2017). The sister species are elevational replacements of each other; the distribution of P. ornatissimus sensu stricto is limited to the Ecuadorian Chocó ecoregion (<1,100 m asl), whereas the P. ecuadorensis has only been found at Andean localities between 1,450–1,480 m asl (Guayasamin et al. 2017).

Previously thought to be a Vietnamese population of Gracixalus carinensis, G. sapaensis was described in 2017 as a distinct species on the basis of morphological differences (Matsui et al. 2017). True Gracixalus carinensis is likely restricted to Myanmar.

authority: Caminer, Milá, Jansen, Fouquet, Venegas, Chávez, Lougheed & Ron, 2017
taxonomicNotes: All Bolivian subpopulations of Dendropsophus leucophyllatus now belong to this species (Caminer et al. 2017, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
Phrynopus spectabilis was placed in the synonymy with Pleurodema marmoratum by Lehr (2006).
This form is undoubtedly a complex of many species.

The coordinates listed in Siler et al. (2007) for this species' type locality were found to be inaccurate and this has been corrected in the distribution map (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This species was moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).

Brown et al. (2017) used phylogenetic, morphological, and distributional data to resolve species boundaries associated with the southwest Mindanao Stream Frogs, Sanguirana everetti (Boulenger, 1882), its junior synonym, Rana mearnsi, Stejneger, 1905, and the northeast Mindanao Stream Frogs, S. albotuberculata (Inger, 1954). Consideration of relationships, distributions, type localities, phenotypic data, and type specimens clearly indicates that the names R. mearnsi and S. albotuberculata refer to the same lineage, and therefore Brown et al. (2017) recognize S. mearnsi as the oldest available name for that species.

Brown et al. (2017) also define the central Philippine lineage (from Negros, Masbate, and Panay islands) as a distinct new species (S. acai). Long confused with S. everetti, the new taxon is readily diagnosed and biogeographically restricted to the West Visayan faunal region.
This species was previously hidden within the Limnonectes blythii-macrodon complex.
Systematic studies of the taxonomic status of this species is warranted; records of caecilians from several localities on Mindanao Island still need to be properly identified.
This species is a complex of several species that have not yet been described.
This is likely a species complex.

The taxonomic status of the Palawan and Bornean subpopulations needs to be clarified. There is ongoing taxonomic work taking place on the Bornean species, which is likely to result in the description of new species (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

The use of the name Sanguirana sanguinea as applied to both Philippine and Sulawesi taxa is a taxonomic arrangement in need of revision. It is expected that Sulawesi subpopulations referred to this species will soon be described as a new species. Song et al. (2002) reported this species for Hainan I., China, but this is likely a misidentification and thus excluded from this assessment.
It is suspected that Philautus surdus is a complex of species and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018).
There is uncertainty around the identity of many specimens and further work is required to clarify the taxonomy of these records (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
Records of this species from mainland Southeast Asia are probably Ingerophrynus quadriporcatus.
This species is morphologically similar to Ingerophrynus parvus which may cause confusion in identification between the two species (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This rediscovery of this species in 2001 needs to be re-evaluated to confirm the taxonomic placement of these specimens (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
There is some doubt that the subpopulation in Borneo belongs to this species, however, more taxonomic work needs to be done (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).
Provisionally arranged in the genus Rentapia by Chan et al. (2016).
This species is considered to be a synonym of Leptobrachium hasseltii sensu lato by some authors (e.g. Berry 1975).
This species is genetically close to Leptobrachium abboti and several undescribed species are contained within the two concepts (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).

This species is generally recognized as being distinct from Megophrys montana (e.g. Taylor 1962, Inger and Stuebing 1997, Manthey and Grossmann 1997), although other authors have treated it as a subspecies of M. montana (e.g. Grandison 1972, Dring 1979).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Pelobatrachus without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

There are many confusing variants, and erroneous attributions of Xenophrys aceras to Megophrys monticola.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
This species may be a taxonomic complex and further work needs to be carried out (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

There is a subpopulation on the Lesser Sunda Islands that potentially belongs to this species, although its true identity is uncertain and further taxonomic work needs to be carried out. 

Genetic data of the F. verruculosa suggests that it is conspecific with this species. However, the topotypes need to be sequenced to confirm whether this is a synonym of F. verruculosa (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).

Records from the Maluku islands have been sequenced and confirmed as this species, whereas records from Sulawesi are likely to belong to an undescribed species. The subpopulation on New Guinea requires sequencing to confirm its identity (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This species was previously included in Limnonectes blythii.

This species is here considered to be restricted to Java and Sumatra. Records from mainland Southeast Asia are referred to Limnonectes blythii. Records of this species from the Andaman Islands in India belong to an undescribed species (I. Das pers. comm.). An old record from Sikkim in north-east India cannot be traced to a specimen and is not considered here to belong to this species (I. Das pers. comm.).
This species is part of the Limnonectes modestus complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

This species is part of a complex of several species that have not been described but the genetic analysis confirming the presence of these undescribed species has been published by Evans et al. (2003), McLeod (2010) and Setiadi et al. (2011). This concept also includes records attributed to L. heinrichi as this is no longer recognized as a valid species following genetic analysis (Evans et al. 2003).

There are no obvious differences between the adults of this species and Meristogenys penrissenensis (Inger et al. 2017). This species is morphologically similar to M. poecilus, and it is difficult to distinguish between the two (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
This species is morphologically similar to M. poecilus, and it is difficult to distinguish between the two (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
Records of Occidozyga laevis from Sulawesi apply to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
The generic position of this species has not been properly assigned.

We depart from the taxonomy of Amphibian Species of the World, and treat Limnonectes timorensis here as a synonym of this species following Iskandar and Colijn (2000). This form might be the same species as Hylarana florensis (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

Animals formerly assigned to Hylarana erythraea from north-eastern India are now included within H. tytleri following the recent revision by Ohler and Mallick (2002). The subpopulations on the Nicobar Islands are still considered to belong to this species, and have been retained (S.R. Chandramouli and S. Harikrishnan pers. comm. August 2020)
This species might include Hylarana elberti (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
Further taxonomic work is needed because it is suspected that it is a synonym of another species and because its life history strategy is closer to Amolops (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).

Until the recent revalidation of this species by Leong Tzi Ming et al. (2003), Hylarana laterimaculata was regarded as a junior synonym of H. baramica. The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Abavorana nazgul (Quah et al. 2017).

Based on the further findings from Quah et al. (2017), the subpopulations from Borneo are likely to be a species complex.

This species was considered to be distinct from Chalcorana chalconota following Iskandar and Colijn (2000). This species was moved from Hylarana to the genus Chalcorana by Oliver et al. (2015). 

Molecular analyses show the species to contain several undescribed species, but the systematics require some confirmation (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).

The taxonomy of this species is confused. It was previously considered to be a synonym of Hylarana signata, and possible specimens of H. picturata from the Malay Peninsula are still referred to as H. signata. The taxonomy is currently under investigation (R. Brown pers. comm.). The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).

The highland frogs usually attributed to Hylarana signata might represent a separate taxon. The status of the Tioman subpopulation is likewise unclear. The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).
Arifin et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence that this name may cover at least two cryptic species.
We follow Matsui et al. (2007) in separating Staurois parvus from this species.
The subpopulation on Sumatra probably belongs to an undescribed species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).

It is unknown whether this species is distinct or whether it belongs to Philautus fasciatus, therefore further taxonomic work is warranted for verification (Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2017).

Further taxonomic work is required to verify whether both subpopulations are conspecific as other surveys between the two widely distributed localities have not produced any records, suggesting they are two different species (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
Specimens of Rhacophorus dulitensis previously reported from Sumatra are now assigned to R. prominanus (Smith 1924, following Harvey, Pemberton and Smith (2002)).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This is a split from the broader concept of Microhyla achatina (Matsui et al. 2013).

This is a split from the broader concept of Polypedates leucomystax (Riyanto et al. 2011).

The call of this species has been observed to be similar to that of Polypedates leucomystax (Kurniati 2011), but this species remains as distinct until further taxonomic work is carried out (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Polypedates otilophus (Matsui et al. 2014).

authority: Streicher, Hamidy, Harvey, Anders, Shaney, Kurniawan & Smith, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Rhacophorus catamitus by Streicher et al. (2014).
Based on DNA analysis, this species appears to be identical to Rhacophorus modestus (E. Smith and H. Kurniati pers. comm. May 2017).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Rhacophorus everetti by Hertwig et al. (2012) and genetic evidence showed unequivocally that it belongs to Philautus.

This is a split from the broader concept of Limnonectes kuhlii (Matsui 2015). Limnonectes sinuatodorsalis occurs syntopically with L. kuhlii in both of the known localities, possibly through ecological segregation by large body size difference between the two species (Matsui 2015).

Removed from the synonymy of Fejervarya cancrivora by A. Dubois (1987). Kurniawan et al. (2011) and Hasan et al. (2012) associated the name with subpopulations of "mangrove-type" frogs previously associated with F. cancrivora.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Provisionally arranged in the genus Rentapia by Chan et al. (2016). This is an expanded concept of Rentapia everetti following the synonymy of the former nomen with Rentapia rugosa by Chandramouli and Amarasinghe (2016). Further taxonomic work is required to ascertain the status of this species and R. rugosa (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
The incorrect spelling Hylodes glabrus has had some use.
We follow Pauwels and Chérot (2006) in considering Kaloula aureata to be a separate species K. macrocephala, contrary to Ohler (2003).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megaelosia goeldii by Giaretta et al. (1993), where it had been placed by Lutz (1930).

This species was resurrected from synonymy by Heyer (1985). There are taxonomic problems, and it may be synonymous with Vitreorana uranoscapa (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). According to Guayasamin et al. (2009), Vitreorana parvula and V. uranoscopa are hypothesized to be close relatives, and therefore synonymous, with V. eurygnatha.

This species was originally considered to be a subspecies of Rhinella granulosa. However, Rivero et al. (1986) recognized this taxon as a full species. 

There have been some doubts in the previous assessment of this species that it might be a synonym of Rhinella humboldti (E. La Marca pers. comm.). While it was synonymised with R. humboldti for a time following morphological analysis (Narvaes and Rodrigues 2009), the two species are now believed to be distinct and valid in their own right (Murphy et al. 2017).
The taxonomic relationship of this species with Rhacophorus verrucopus, known only from nearby Medog, Xizang Autonomous Region, China, is not clear.

The taxonomic identity of this species compared to Philautus gryllus, P. bisacculus and Rhacophorus verrucosus is not certain, and nor is its allocation to the genus Philautus (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).
This species was previously hidden as a cryptic species within the Odorrana livida complex. We follow Stuart (2008) in assigning this species to the genus Amolops.

Based on M. Napoli pers. comm. (2018), the species Allobates olfersioides (Lutz 1925) is a Brazilian endemic species with a wide geographic distribution throughout the Atlantic Forest, occurring from the southeast to northeast of Brazil. The subpopulations of this taxon were proposed by Bokerman (1967) as four separate species: A. alagoanus, A. capixaba, A. carioca, and A. olfersioides. However, the taxonomic study by Verdade and Rodrigues (2007) considered the variables of external morphology, traditional morphometry, and colour patterns of external surfaces, and did not find support for the maintenance of four distinct species. This resulted in the synonymy of A. alagoanus, A. capixaba, and A. carioca (junior synonyms) with A. olfersioides (senior synonym), a decision that has been maintained until the present day.

A decade has passed since the study of Verdade and Rodrigues (2007), and in the meantime, there has been a considerable increase in the integration of different disciplines in the solution of taxonomic problems. In this context, Forti et al. (2017) performed an acoustic analysis of the advertisement call of specimens from A. olfersioides subpopulations in the states of Rio de Janeiro, Bahia (Igrapiúna), and Alagoas (Passo de Camaragibe), and found differences in the call. This result is in agreement with Bokermann (1967), who indicated possible acoustic differences in relation to the temporal properties between A. olfersioides (Rio de Janeiro) and A. capixaba (Espírito Santo). Finally, the authors indicated the possibility of revalidation of at least two of the junior synonyms (A. alagoanus and A. capixaba). More recently, Grant et al. (2017), in a phylogenetic study of Dendrobatoidea species that included molecular data, found that samples from two subpopulations of A. olfersioides differed strongly from each other, one from the state of Rio de Janeiro (type locality of A. carioca, two specimens) and another from the state of Alagoas (type locality of A. alagoanus, one specimen), which led the authors to state that such populations could represent different species. Although the last two studies have shown important differences between A. olfersioides subpopulations, most notably among those located in the state of Rio de Janeiro (A. olfersioides and A. carioca), Espírito Santo (A. capixaba) and Alagoas (A. alagoanus), such studies did not aim to taxonomically review the above species and, no less important, did not constitute nomenclatural acts concerning the revalidation of the junior synonyms proposed by Verdade and Rodrigues (2007). Thus, all subpopulations remain within the concept of A. olfersioides until further clarification and resolution of these problems is provided (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

One of the clades assigned to this species in French Guiana and Amapá in Brazil may belong to another species, pending further taxonomic work (P. Kok and A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2017). Until this has been verified, these records are retained under this species concept.
Theloderma bambusicolum has been synonymized under T. laeve by Poyarkov et al. (2015).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Based on mtDNA evidence,  A. cingulatum (sensu stricto) inhabiting the eastern Gulf Coastal Plain and the Atlantic Coastal Plain in northern Florida are distinct lineages; the Suwannee River and a large distributional gap separate them (Pauly et al. 2012). Further data are needed to determine whether these two lineages warrant recognition as different species (Pauly et al. 2012).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the formal description of Aneides caryaensis; it is likely a complex comprising two additional undescribed species, following the monophyletic lineages identified in Patton et al. (2019).
Molecular data suggest that this species might be conspecific with Anaxyrus canorus, but this requires further investigation (Shaffer et al. 2000).
Molecular data suggest that Anaxyrus exsul is possibly conspecific with this species, however, this requires further investigation (Shaffer et al. 2000).
This is a restricted concept of Hydromantes shastae following the split of the broader concept into this, H. wintu, and H. samweli (Bingham et al. 2018).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
Plethodon hubrichti and P. shenandoah formerly were included in this species.
This species is morphologically somewhat similar to Plethodon elongatus, however they are genetically distinct (Mahoney 2001, Mead et al. 2005).
This species is sometimes considered to be conspecific with Plethodon ouachitae, with which it intergrades freely in its narrow zone of contact.
Petranka (1998) included Plethodon fourchensis in this species. The two species intergrade freely in their narrow zone of contact.

Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

There has been historical confusion and controversy regarding the taxonomic status of various leopard frog populations in the region occupied by Lithobates onca (Jaeger et al. 2001). The Vegas Valley Leopard Frog, R. fisheri, (now considered extinct) previously was regarded as a subspecies of R. onca. Jennings et al. (1995) conducted morphological comparisons and concluded that R. fisheri and R. onca are distinct species. Jaeger et al. (2001) examined variation in mtDNA, genomic DNA, and morphology and concluded that certain leopard frog populations in the Virgin River/Black Canyon (Colorado River) region represent a species (Lithobates onca) distinct from the lowland leopard frog (L. yavapaiensis). The Relict Leopard Frog was also found to be quite distinct from the Las Vegas Valley Leopard Frog (L. fisheri; now considered extinct) based on a genetic analysis of archival samples of that species (Hekkala et al. 2011). The Relict Leopard Frog was moved from the genus Rana to Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006), although that taxonomic revision remains contentious.
This is a restricted concept of Eurycea spelaea following the split of the broader concept into this, Eurycea nerea, and Eurycea braggi (Phillips et al. 2017).
This species is a member of the Typhlomolge clade of central Texas Eurycea (Hillis et al. 2001).
This species is a member of the Typhlomolge clade of central Texan Eurycea species (Hillis et al. 2001). There is some question as to whether or not it is distinct from E. rathbuni.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
This is a restricted concept of Pseudacris brachyphona following the split of the broader concept into this and P. collinsorum (Ospina et al. 2020).

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now known as P. fouquettei; Lemmon et al. 2008).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Lithobates areolatus by Case (1978) and Young and Crother (2001). This species was placed into the genus Lithobates by Frost et. al (2006). This action has been disputed by Yuan et al. (2016) who retained the name Rana and lowered Lithobates to the level of subgenus. The genus name Lithobates is currently recognized by Amphibian Species of the World and has therefore been retained for the purposes of this assessment. Additional taxonomic work is recommended to clarify this ongoing discussion.
Dubois et al. 20201 moved this species from the genus Lithobates to Aquarana.

We consider Glandirana emeljanovi to be distinct from G. rugosa. The animals from the Korean Peninsula were shown to be distinct from populations in Japan using molecular phylogenetics. Together with animals from China, those from the Korean Peninsula are considered to belong to G. emelijanovi (M. Matsui pers. comm. September 2020).
Part of the populations on Sado island in Japan have been described as a new species Glandirana susurra (Sekiya et al 2012).

Genetic studies showed that this form is distinct from populations of Lithobates capito and L. areolata, and has therefore been established as a separate species (Young and Crother 2001). This species was placed into the genus Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006). This action has been disputed by Yuan et al. (2016) who retained the name Rana and lowered Lithobates to the level of subgenus. The genus name Lithobates is currently recognized by Amphibian Species of the World and has therefore been retained for the purposes of this assessment. Additional taxonomic work is recommended to clarify this ongoing discussion.
This species was formerly included in Ambystoma texanum (Kraus and Petranka 1989).
Aneides vagrans was formerly included in this species.

This species was formerly included in Desmognathus quadramaculatus. It was recognized as a distinct species on the basis of adult size, body proportions, colour pattern, and fixed differences at four allozyme loci (Camp et al. 2002).
This species was formerly included in Eurycea quadridigitata. It was described as a new species by Harrison and Guttman (2003).

Jacobs (1987) found Eurycea junaluska to be genetically similar to E. aquatica and E. cirrigera and questioned the taxonomic status of E. junaluska. Sever (1989) found E. junaluska to be morphologically unique and genetically distinct from all sympatric Eurycea.
This is a broader concept of Eurycea latitans which includes E. tridentifera as a synonym (Devitt et al. 2019).

This species was included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982), but was regarded as a distinct species by Chippindale et al. (1994) and was formally described as Eurycea naufragia by Chippindale et al. (2000).

Most references to Eurycea neotenes in the literature involve populations that Chippindale et al. (2000) considered Fern Bank Salamanders (E. pterophila) or members of the E. latitans or E. troglodytes species complexes
This species was removed from synonymy with Eurycea neotenes by Chippindale et al. (2000). It remains poorly circumscribed taxonomically, and warrants further research.

The record from Barry County, Missouri, reported in 1945, has not been substantiated by more recent collections; Johnson (1987) did not include this species as part of the Missouri herpetofauna. This is the new restricted concept of E. quadridigitata following the split of the broader concept into this, E. hillisi, E. paludicola and E. sphagnicola (Wray et al. 2017).
This species was included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982) and in previous publications. It was formally described as a distinct species by Chippindale et al. (2000).

Sweet (1984) concluded that this species apparently comprises a hybrid swarm resulting from the incorporation of occasional individuals of Eurycea tridentifera into a larger population of E. neotenes. Chippindale et al. (2000) considered additional data and regarded E. troglodytes as a valid complex of more than one species, and not as being of hybrid origin. They noted that the E. troglodytes complex is a heterogeneous group that probably includes several distinct species.

Preliminary electrophoretic data indicate that Eurycea tynerensis is restricted to a few counties in eastern Oklahoma; populations in Arkansas and Missouri are not genetically distinct from E. multiplicata griseogaster (Wilkinson, in Figg 1991). For this assessment, we retain the traditional understanding of E. tynerensis as occurring in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Missouri, pending resolution of this issue. Emel and Bonett (2011) suggest that there is higher genetic diversity within E. tynerensis than was previously known.

Gyrinophilus gulolineatus was formerly regarded as a subspecies of G. palleucus; it was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002) and Crother et al. (2000). Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus.

Three subspecies (palleucus, gulolineatus, and necturoides) have been recognized; intergradation between palleucus and necturoides is evident in some Alabama populations (A. Wynne, in Godwin 1995b). Some populations do not conform well to any of the named subspecies. One form in Tennessee might be sufficiently distinct biochemically to warrant recognition as a separate species (Redmond and Scott 1996). Gyrinophilus gulolineatus (Berry Cave Salamander) was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002), and Crother et al. (2000), but Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus. In this assessment, Gyrinophilus gulolineatus is regarded as a distinct species.

Some authors have regarded this species as conspecific with Gyrinophilus porphyriticus (Blaney and Blaney 1978), but the current consensus is that it is a valid species, based on morphometric analyses (Green and Pauley 1987).
Phillips (2017) found multiple distinct lineages within Eurycea wallacei, including high genetic diversity within multiple sampling sites.
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998).
This species was separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was split from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).

Mahoney (2004) describes high genetic diversity within the Plethodon elongatus complex with two highly differentiated evolutionarily significant units in the central to southern portion of the range in Humboldt County, California.
Highton and Peabody (2000) recently separated Plethodon jordani into multiple species: P. montanus, P. metcalfi, P. amplus, P. meridianus, P. jordani, P. shermani and P. cheoah.
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex.
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998).
This species was separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was separated from Plethodon hoffmani (Highton 1999).

Bart et al. (1997) determined that the name Necturus alabamensis applies only to the waterdog in the upper Black Warrior River drainage. For years, the name had been mistakenly applied to a more common species of waterdog that occurs in the coastal plain. Further taxonomic revisions involving this species are likely (Petranka 1998). See Bart et al. (1997) for an account of the nomenclatural history of this and related species.

This form was originally described as Necturus maculosus lewisi. It was elevated to species status by Viosca (1937). It is considered to be the most primitive form of Necturus by Sessions and Wiley (1985).

The genus Rhyacotriton previously contained a single species R. olympicus. Based on genetic differentiation, Good and Wake (1992) split R. olympicus into four species: R. olympicus, R. variegatus, R. kezeri, and R. cascadae.

The genus Rhyacotriton previously contained a single species R. olympicus. Based on genetic differentiation, Good and Wake (1992) split R. olympicus into 4 species: R. olympicus, R. variegatus, R. kezeri, and R. cascadae.

The genus Rhyacotriton previously contained a single species R. olympicus. Based on genetic differentiation, Good and Wake (1992) split R. olympicus into four species: R. olympicus, R. variegatus, R. kezeri, and R. cascadae.

Taricha sierrae was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Taricha torosa.

Phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data (Tan and Wake 1995) revealed the following clusters in T. torosa: (1) northern Sierra Nevada (Shasta to Nevada counties); (2) central Sierra Nevada (El Dorado to Fresno counties); (3) southern Sierra Nevada (Tulare to Kern counties) (independently derived relative to 1 and 2, above); (4) southern coastal California (San Diego and Orange counties); (5) central coastal California (Los Angeles to central and northern California). This study and additional allozyme data (Kuchta and Tan 2006) provided the basis for a phylogeographical history of T. torosa. Among other things, the data are consistent in indicating that populations in the southern Sierra Nevada are more closely related to T. torosa torosa than to T. t. sierrae.

In the interests of taxonomic stability, Kuchta and Tan (2006) refrained from advocating changes in the taxonomic status of Taricha torosa torosa and Taricha torosa sierrae, pending completion and publication of ongoing studies.

Kuchta (2007) examined genetic and morphological variation in Taricha torosa and concluded that T. torosa and T. sierrae are distinct evolutionary lineages that should be recognized as distinct species.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now described as P. fouquettei; Lemmon et al. 2008).

Taricha sierrae was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Taricha torosa.

Phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data (Tan and Wake 1995) revealed the following clusters in T. torosa: (1) northern Sierra Nevada (Shasta to Nevada counties); (2) central Sierra Nevada (El Dorado to Fresno counties); (3) southern Sierra Nevada (Tulare to Kern counties) (independently derived relative to 1 and 2, above); (4) southern coastal California (San Diego and Orange counties); (5) central coastal California (Los Angeles to central and northern California). This study and additional allozyme data (Kuchta and Tan 2006) provided the basis for a phylogeographical history of T. torosa. Among other things, the data are consistent in indicating that populations in the southern Sierra Nevada are more closely related to T. torosa torosa than to T. t. sierrae.

In the interests of taxonomic stability, Kuchta and Tan (2006) refrained from advocating changes in the taxonomic status of Taricha torosa torosa and Taricha torosa sierrae, pending completion and publication of ongoing studies.

Kuchta (2007) examined genetic and morphological variation in Taricha torosa and concluded that T. torosa and T. sierrae are distinct evolutionary lineages that should be recognized as distinct species.

Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frog populations now recognized as Rana sierrae were formerly included in Rana muscosa. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south, and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum, and found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species.

authority: Camp, Peterman, Milanovich, Lamb, Maerz & Wake, 2009
taxonomicNotes: This is a monotypic genus (Camp et al. 2009).
This is a split from the broader concept of Aneides flavipunctatus (Reilly and Wake 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Batrachoseps relictus (Jockusch et al. 2012).

Specimens from the Upper Kern River were originally assigned to Batrachoseps simatus by Brame and Murray (1968), who noted that there were morphological differences. Jockusch and Wake (2002) and Jennings (2004) treated these specimens as an undescribed lineage, until Jockusch et al. (2012) described them as B. bramei.

This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus fuscus (Titus and Larson 1996, Beamer and Lamb 2008, Beamer and Lamb 2020). Pyron et al (2020) suggested on molecular grounds that this nominal species is a complex.
This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus wrighti (Crespi et al. 2010).

This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of first Eurycea bislineata and then E. cirrigera. It has been split from both and is now recognized as a distinct species (Sever 1999, Timpe et al. 2009, Frost 2015). The species boundary between this species and E. junaluska is unresolved, and warrant further attention (T. Pierson pers. comm. May 2021).

This recently discovered fully aquatic, paedomorphic species is morphologically, ecologically, and genetically distinct from its sister species Eurycea multiplicata with which it occurs syntopically (Steefen et al. 2014). It went undetected due to a lack of herpetological sampling within the confines of Lake Catherine State Park, Hot Spring County, Arkansas (K. Irwin pers. comm. August 2021).

authority: (Feinberg, Newman, Watkins-Colwell, Schlesinger, Zarate, Curry, Shaffer & Burger, 2014)
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Lithobates pipiens (Feinberg et al. 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus fuscus (Titus and Larson 1996, Tilley et al. 2008, Beamer and Lamb 2020).

This is a restricted concept of Necturus punctatus following the revalidation of N. lodingi which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Guyer et al. 2020). Subsequently N. lodingi has been placed into synonymy under N. beyeri.
Necturus louisianensis was removed from synonymy with N. maculosus by Collins (1991) on the basis of their allopatry and diagnosability.
This species is very similar to Amolops viridimaculatus, an endemic of adjacent Yunnan Province, China.
This species was previously confused with Hynobius leechii and H. quelpaertensis and finally described by Min et al. (2016).

authority: Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Records from Anamada in the Nelliyampathy Hills of Palakkad district (Afthab et al. 2018) require molecular studies to confirm its presence (N. Modak pers. comm. October 2020).

authority: Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
MacCulloch, Lathrop, Kok, Minter, Khan & Barrio-Amorós, 2008
(Kok, MacCulloch, Gaucher, Poelman, Bourne, Lathrop & Lenglet, 2006)
taxonomicNotes: This species can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological, bioacoustical and behavioural features (Kok et al. 2006).
This species was redescribed by Kok et al. (2006).

Subpopulations from Suriname that were previously reported as belonging to this species, have now been assigned to Anomaloglossus surinamensis (Ouboter and Jairam 2012). Following genetic, morphological and bioacoustic analysis, a subpopulation from Itoupe Massif in French Guiana have been assigned to A. dewynteri, and subpopulations from northeast French Guiana have been assigned to A. blanci (Fouquet et al. 2018).
This species can be differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, tadpole morphology, advertisement call and ecological traits (Kok et al. 2006).
Atelopus spumarius barbotini has been suggested to represent a junior synonym of this species (Kok 2000, Lötters et al. 2011), as well as A. franciscus (Lötters et al. 2011).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla was moved to the new genus Myersiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has now been moved to the new genus Nesorohyla (Pinheiro et al. 2018).

Oreophrynella dendronastes can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lathrop and MacCulloch 2007).

Kok et al. (2017) suggests that this species may be a synonym of O. macconnelli.
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).

authority: Fouquet, Martinez, Courtois, Dewynter, Pineau, Gaucher, Blanc, Marty & Kok, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).
This species boundaries with other described species that are supposed to occur throughout Amazonia (i.e. the Scinax garbei complex) remain ambiguous (A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2022).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus was moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This a restricted concept of Pseudopaludicola mystacalis, after P. ameghini was removed from the synonymy of this species (Fávero et al. 2011).

A member of the Hyla circumdata group according to the original publication. Bokermannohyla vulcaniae is diagnosed by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De Vasconcelos and Giaretta 2003).

authority: Pansonato, Veiga-Menoncello, Mudrek, Jansen, Recco-Pimentel, Martins & Strüssmann, 2016
taxonomicNotes:
This species had previously been confused with both Pseudopaludicola falcipes and P. boliviana (Pansonato et al. 2016).

Pseudopaludicola motorzinho is morphologically cryptic in relation to P. boliviana, and the difference suggested by Pansonato et al. (2016) (absence of tubercles on upper eyelid) is not diagnostic (Lavilla et al. 2016). The only confirmed records of P. motorzinho for Paraguay are from Estancia Pirá Potrero in Amambay Department, which was based on 13 specimens with 2n = 22 chromosomes, distinguishable from P. boliviana, whose karyotype is 2n = 20 chromosomes (Fávero et al. 2011, as Pseudopaludicola sp.; Cardozo et al. 2016; also see Lavilla et al. 2016; F. Brusquetti pers. comm. December 2020).

There is some doubt as to whether the subpopulations from Bolivia belong to this or another species (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

authority: Pansonato, Veiga-Menoncello, Mudrek, Jansen, Recco-Pimentel, Martins & Strüssmann, 2016
Andrade, Magalhães, Nunes-de-Almeida, Veiga-Menoncello, Santana, Garda, Loebmann, Recco-Pimentel, Giaretta & Toledo, 2016

taxonomicNotes: This species is split from Minervarya rufescens (known as Fejervarya - Garg and Biju 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Minervarya rufescens (as Fejervarya rufescens) by Garg and Biju (2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Minervarya rufescens (Garg and Biju 2017).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Minervarya cepfi, M. kadar, M. manoharani and M. neilcoxi (Garg and Biju 2017).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. It has been now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Aowphol, Cota, Grismer, Murdoch, Aguilar & Grismer, 2016
(Zhang, Li, Xiao, Li, Pan, Wang, Zhang & Zhou, 2017)

taxonomicNotes: This species has been split from the broader concept of Theloderma asperum (Dever 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Ommatotriton ophryticus (Bülbül and Kutrup 2013).

We follow Litvinchuk et al. (2005) in separating this species from Ommatotriton vittatus. This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Ommatotriton nesterovi (Bülbül and Kutrup 2013).

Oreophrynella seegobini is genetically very similar to this species although morphology and ecology do differ, and further taxonomic studies need to be carried out (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). This may indicate a very recent evolutionary split between the species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).

There is an undescribed species within Boana geographica that is aff. with this species and when further taxonomic studies have been done, it may expand this species ranges into the Guianan Shield (P. Kok and A. Fouquet pers. comm. November 2017).
This species is a tetraploid species that is very similar to, and easily confused with, Tomopterna cryptotis, T. delalandii and T. damarensis (Channing and Bogart 1996, Dawood and Channing 2002).

This species was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and Amietia dracomontana and A. quecketti have both been synonymized with this species. 

It occurs in sympatry with A. inyangae, A. fuscigula, A. vertebralis and A. poyntoni. A. quecketti records from Namibia have been assigned to A. poyntoni.

This species was split from the broader concept of Litoria gracilenta (McDonald et al. 2016). We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Frost (2020) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

Rao and Yang (1997) considered the population of Brachytarsophrys occurring in southern China that used to be called B. carinensis to be a distinct species, B. platyparietus.  Fei et al. (2009) synonymized this species with Megophrys carinense, but it was removed from synonymy of Megophrys carinense by Li et al. (2020). 

Li et al. (2020) listed this species in Brachytarsophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Yu et al. (2007) suggest that Bombina microdeladigitora and Bombina fortinuptialis be considered as subspecies of Bombina maxima given the low genetic differences among these taxa, and there is ongoing debate about the distinctiveness of this species, Bombina lichuanensis and B. fortinuptialis (see Pabijan et al. 2013, Fei and Ye 2016 among others). However, we follow Frost and recognize B. microdeladigitora and  B. fortinuptialis to be valid species.

Yu et al. (2007) suggest that Bombina microdeladigitora and Bombina fortinuptialis be considered as subspecies of Bombina maxima given the low genetic differences among these taxa. However, we follow Frost (2022) and recognize Bombina microdeladigitora, B. fortinuptialis and B. lichuanensis as valid species.

authority: Hou, Wu, Yang, Zheng, Yuan & Li, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachella liui, and is now considered a sister species.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This is a split from the broader concept of Odorrana schmackeri (Chen et al. 2010).
Pachytriton xanthospilos has been removed from synonymy of this species (Wu et al. 2012).

authority: Yan, Zhao, Jiang, Hou, He, Murphy & Che, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton chinensis (Yuan et al. 2014). No record of P. chinensis currently exists from the same locality as P. qixilingensis (Yuan et al. 2014).

This is a split from the broader concept of Rana zhenhaiensis (Li et al. 2008). Further taxonomic work is needed to resolve the uncertainty surrounding the identity of records from Chongqing and Guizhou, as Luo et al. (2012) consider these records to belong to R. qianjiang - a species whose 'status is unclear' (Frost 2021- Rana qianjiang).

authority: Jiang, Rao, Yuan, Wang, Li, Hou, Che & Che, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Tylototriton wenxianensis. The subspecies of T. wenxianensis from the north Dabie Mountains in Henan Province has been elevated to T. dabienicus according to Shen et al. 2012. Tylototriton anhuiensis was previously confused with this species, so subpopulations from Anhui Province that were previously attributed to T. dabienicus are now assigned to T. anhuiensis (Qian et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus fischeri (Poyarkov et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus fischeri (Poyarkov et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton caudopunctatus (Wang et al. 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Polypedates leucomystax (Yang and Rao 2008).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus (Wei et al. 2009).

authority: Yan, Jiang, Chen, Fang, Jin, Li, Wang, Murphy, Che & Zhang, 2011
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Rana longicrus (Yan et al. 2011).

authority: (Li, Liu, Chen, Wu, Murphy, Zhao, Wang & Zhang, 2012)
taxonomicNotes:
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus dugritei (Li et al. 2012).

It was moved from the genus Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
Removed from synonymy with Cynops cyanurus by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2012).
Liuixalus jinxiuensis has been synonymised with this species by Pham et al. (2018).

This species was removed as a synonym of Bufo burmanus by Yang and Rao (2008) where it had been placed by Yang et al. (1996) (according to Rao et al. (1998)). Frost (2019) notes that these authors either disagreed with or missed that Bufo burmanus was placed in the synonymy of Bufo pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). This species was previously listed on the IUCN Red List as a synonym of Bufo pageoti (J. Luedtke pers. comm. August 2015).

There is ongoing confusion regarding the taxonomic validity of this species. We follow Delorme et al. (2006) in placing this species in the genus Philautus, following their examination of the type specimen.

This species differs from Pelophylax ridibundus in some minor morphological parameters, but the most valuable discriminators are the biochemical differences, which are considered to be most important in the systematics of the P. ridibundus complex. The differences between P. terentievi and P. ridibundus are comparable to those in other species separated from P. ridibundus.
Populations from southeastern Xizang, China have been identified as Nasutixalus medogensis, and were previously confused with Theloderma moloch (Jiang et al. 2016).

This species was previously described as Odorrana chapaensis by Ngo et al. 2006 and Che et al. 2007, Amolops chapaensis by Bain and Nguyen, 2004 and Rana sp. ‘‘Cao Bang’’ (ROM 26476) by Chen et al. 2005.
This species has been removed from the Limnonectes kuhlii complex by Matsui et al. (2010).

authority: (Li, Liu, Chen, Wu, Murphy, Zhao, Wang & Zhang, 2012)
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus hui (Li et al. 2012). This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton labiatus (Nishikawa et al. 2011).
Quasipaa robertingeri was synonymized with this species by Che et al. (2009) and Zhang et al. (2018).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Rhacophorus dennysi (Fei et al. 2009).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pachytriton changi, which has been removed from synonymy with this species (Wu et al. 2012).
Specimens from Itatiaia, and by implication any records from Serra da Mantiqueira, referred to as Hylodes aff. sazimai, belong to an undescribed species (C. Haddad pers. comm. 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachella mjobergi (Eto et al. 2015).

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax dringi and L. gracilis (Dehling and Matsui 2013).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax hamidi (Matsui et al. 2014) – currently Leptobrachella hamidi.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Meristogenys whiteheadi by Shimada et al. (2011).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Meristogenys whiteheadi by Shimada et al. (2011).
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus reinwardtii (Matsui et al. 2013).

This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus gauni (Dehling 2015). It was previously confused with R. gauni because of its close morphological resemblance. The two species occur sympatrically at Poring Hot Springs on the eastern slope of Gunung Kinabalu.
This is a split from the broader concept of Meristogenys amoropalamus (Shimada et al. 2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Kalophrynus calciphilus (Dehling 2011).
We follow Inger (1966) and Malkmus et al. (2002) in considering Ansonia altitudinis (Smith 1931) to be a synonym of A. fuliginea.
Previously reported records from Gunung Murud in north-eastern Sarawak, Malaysia have now been assigned to Pelophryne murudensis (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

Several specimens that resembles this species have been collected from Kalimantan, but these need to be verified (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017). Shimada et al. (2015) suggest that Meristogenys jerboa is composed of at least two species.
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering Philautus gunungensis to be separate from P. aurantium.
There are no obvious differences between the adults of this species and Meristogenys phaeomerus (Inger et al. 2017).
This species is difficult to identify with certainty, especially in relation to Limnonectes doriae, L. pileata and L. plicatella.

This form is a complex of more than one species (Dubois 1987), and further taxonomic work is required to fully delineate this species (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). Subpopulations in northern Viet Nam and Lao People's Democratic Republic that were previously believed to have been Limnonectes hascheanus have now been assigned to Limnonectes limborgii (T. Nguyen pers. comm. October 2013).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Limnonectes hascheanus by Dubois (1986), where it had been placed by Smith (1929). Limnonectes liui has been synonymised with this species by Huang et al. (2022).

Some subpopulations in central Viet Nam that have been identified as Ingerophrynus galeatus may actually belong to Ingerophrynus macrotis, although this needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. March 2015).
This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachium nigrops following the split of the broader concept into this, L. ingeri and L. kanowitense.
This species was moved from the genus Rhacophorus to Leptomantis by Jiang et al. (2019).

The Leptolalax heteropus-solus complex has not been fully resolved and, due to morphological similarities, further genetic work is required to verify the identity of all Peninsular Malaysia records and determine its' true distribution (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

The Leptolalax heteropus-solus complex has not been fully resolved and, due to morphological similarities, further genetic work is required to verify the identity of all Peninsular Malaysia records and determine its' true distribution (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

This is a restricted concept of Chiasmocleis albopunctata following the split of the broader concept into this and Chiasmocleis bicegoi (de Sá et al. 2018 "2019"). Ferraro et al. (2018) noted that the taxonomic status of the subpopulations in Argentina remain problematic.

authority: Quah, Anuar, Grismer, Wood, Azizah & Muin, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Abavorana luctuosa (Quah et al. 2017).

authority: Davis, Grismer, Klabacka, Muin, Quah, Anuar, Wood & Sites, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Dehling and Dehling (2017) re-examined the type series of this species and found it to contain specimens of three distinct species. One specimen was reallocated to Limnonectes hikidai, and another was described as a new species, L. kong, and L. conspicillatus was removed from the synonymy of L. kuhlii and the holotype was re-described.

Dehling and Dehling (2017) re-examined the type series of Limnonectes conspicillatus and found it to contain specimens of three distinct species. One specimen was reallocated to L. hikidai, and another was described as a new species, L. kong, and L. conspicillatus was removed from the synonymy of L. kuhlii.

authority: Phimmachak, Sivongxay, Seateun, Yodthong, Rujirawan, Neang, Aowphol & Stuart, 2018

taxonomicNotes: Matsui et al. (2013) designated a lectotype for this species and proposed Limnonectes mocquardi as a replacement name (because the original name is a primary homonym of Rana paradoxa Linnaeus 1758 (now Pseudis paradoxa)), and removed it from the synonymy of L. kuhlii.

authority: Pham, Le, Nguyen, Ziegler, Wu & Nguyen, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Plethodon glutinosus (Highton et al. 1989, Vieites et al. 2011).
