This is a split from the broader concept of Plethodon glutinosus (Highton et al. 1989, Vietes et al. 2011).

This is a restricted concept of Plethodon glutinosus following the split of the broader concept into this, P. albagula, P. chattahoochee, P. chlorobryonis, P. cylindraceus, P. grobmani, P. kiamichi, P. kisatchie, P. mississippi, P. ocmulgee, P. savannah, P. sequoyah, and P. variolatus (Highton et al. 1989, Vieties et al. 2011). Plethodon grobmani and P. mississippi have been placed into synonymy with this species (Guyer et al. 2019, Joyce et al. 2019). Dubois et al. (2021), however, did not recover P. mississippi, P. grobmani, and P. glutinosus as nearest relatives. This species constitutes a complex, and its taxonomy requires further work.
This is a split from the broader concept of Plethodon glutinosus (Highton et al. 1989,Vieites et al. 2011).
This is a split from the broader concept of Plethodon glutinosus (Highton et al. 1989, Vieites et al. 2011).
This is a split from the broader concept of Plethodon glutinosus (Highton et al. 1989, Vieites et al. 2011)

authority: Brito M., Almendariz-C., Batallas R. & Ron, 2017
Rada, Jeckel, Caorsi, Barrientos, Rivera-Correa & Grant, 2017

taxonomicNotes: The validity of this species is uncertain. It has been considered "probably" a junior synonym of Sphaerotheca breviceps (Khan 1976) but this recommendation has since been followed inconsistently (summarized in Frost 2021). It is presently treated as valid (Prasad et al. 2019, Frost 2021).
This species was removed from synonymy with Sphaerotheca breviceps (Dahanukar et al. 2017).

According  to Kalaycı et al. (2017), results of phylogenetic analysis of mt DNA gens (CYTB and COI) support the idea of Veith et al. (2003) that Anatolian mountain frogs are represented by two distinct species in Anatolia: Rana macrocnemis and R. tavasensis. There is no significant genetic distance between R. camerani, R. macrocnemis, and R. holtzi. R. camerani and R. holtzi are regarded to be conspecific with R. macrocnemis. Najibzadeh et al. (2017) based on two partial mitochondrial DNA sequences (16S rRNA and cytochrome b genes) and the application of a molecular clock suggested that Anatolian brown frogs lineage diverged into two subclades, R. tavasensis and R. macrocnemis, during the Middle Miocene. Also R. holtzi, R. camerani and R. macrocnemis are not distinct lineages.

This is a split from the broader concept of Hyalinobatrachium mondolfi (Oliveira and Hernández-Ruz 2017). In the description of H. muiraquitan the species is poorly known, and it can be confused with H. mondolfii (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pithecopus hypochondrialis (Haga et al. 2017).

authority: Rocha, Sena, Pezzuti, Leite, Svartman, Rosset, Baldo & Garcia, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontophrynus americanus (Rocha et al. 2017).

authority: Fouquet, Vacher, Courtois, Villette, Reizine, Gaucher, Jairam, Ouboter & Kok, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Anomaloglossus degranvillei (Fouquet et al. 2018).

authority: Fouquet, Vacher, Courtois, Villette, Reizine, Gaucher, Jairam, Ouboter & Kok, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Anomaloglossus degranvillei (Fouquet et al. 2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Craugastor mexicanus by Hedges et al. (2008).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Ixalus lateralis by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).

authority: Brown, Prue, Chan, Gaulke, Sanguila & Siler, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Sanguirana everetti by Brown et al. (2017).

This species is a morphologically very indistinct member of the Limnonectes macrognathus group, characterized mainly by the absence of derived characters, and thus it is easily confused with juveniles or females of other L. macrognathus-type taxa.

This species was removed from synonymy of Hylarana nigrovitatta without comment by Dubois (1992), and treated as a valid species by Inger, Orlov and Darevsky (1999). It was regarded as a synonym of H. nigrovittata by Matsui et al. (2001) but treated as a valid species by Ohler, Swan and Daltry (2002) and hence here also.

This species was moved to the genus Cornufer from Platymantis by Brown et al. (2015).

This species may represent a species complex (R. Günther pers. comm. to R. Crombie August 2018) and there is unusual variation within its calling, however no genetic studies have been carried out to verify this to date (R. Crombie pers. comm. August 2018).
Pristimantis brevicrus was removed from the synonymy of P. altamazonicus by Ortega-Andrade et al. (2017) based on morphological, acoustic and genetic evidence.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The rediscovery of this species in 1976 showed it to be a largely montane frog, occupying an apparently small range in the borderland of Costa Rica and Panama (Savage and Myers 2002).
Further taxonomic work is needed to finally determine whether Duellmanohyla lythrodes is a synonym of Duellmanohyla rufioculis (Federico Bolaños pers. comm. 2007).

This species is frequently considered to be a synonym of Occidozyga martensii. It is possibly a sub-adult stage of O. martensii (Taylor (1962) was uncertain of its status). Its placement in Occidozyga is debatable.
In the Anomaloglossus stepheni group of Vacher et al. (2017) who noted that this clade is composed of several cryptic species in Suriname, French Guiana, and Brazil.
This is a split from the broader concept of Physalaemus gracilis (Cardozo and Pereyra 2018).
Separated from Leptodactylus labyrinthicus by Heyer (2005).

A population known from Perau de Janeiro, Municipality of Arvorezinha, is regarded as belonging to this species (A. Kwet pers. comm. October 2010), although differences noted by the describing author (Kwet 2008) may justify its future description as a separate named species.

This species was originally described as Hyloscirtus antioquia by Rivera-Correa and Faivovich (2013). In 2016, the species was transferred to the genus Colomascirtus (Duellman et al. 2016) and when the first assessment for this species was published (in 2017) it was still under the generic name Colomascirtus. Colomascirtus is now recognised as a junior synonym of Hyloscirtus (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018), hence the species has been returned to the genus Hyloscirtus.

A distinct genetic difference exists between a specimen from Abra Amparaes and two individuals from Abra Acjanaco (Duellman et al. 2011). Much more extensive phylogenetic analyses most likely will reveal that G. excubitor, as it is now recognized, consists of two or more cryptic species (Duellman and Trueb 2015).

In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original species description (Lehr et al. 2004), later assigned to the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) peruvianus species group of Hedges et al. (2008).
This species was been moved from the genus Hyloscirtus to Colomascirtus (Duellman et al. 2016), and then subsequently moved back to Hyloscirtus (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018).

This is a distinct species from the sympatric Hyla japonica (Kuramoto 1984, Yang and Park 1988, Lee and Park 1992, Lee et al. 1999,  Jang et al. 2011, Borzée et al. 2013). The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes. Borzée et al. (2018) demonstrated that this species was distinct from D. immaculatus, and it is therefore retained as a separate species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Salamandrella keyserlingii (Malyarchuk et al. 2010).

Some records in literature for this species are referred to under the name of Salamandrella schrenckii (e.g. Berman et al. 2005, 2009, Matsui et al. 2008, Malyarchuk et al. 2010, Hasumi and Borkin 2012, Bulakhova and Berman 2013). There is some debate over which species name is valid for these records: Berman et al. (2005a, 2005b, 2009) consider the name S. tridactyla to be invalid. Further information can be found on the page for this species on Amphibian Species of the World (https://amphibiansoftheworld.amnh.org/Amphibia/Caudata/Hynobiidae/Hynobiinae/Salamandrella/Salamandrella-tridactyla).
This is a split from the broader concept of Osteocephalus buckleyi (Jungfer et al. 2016).

Jungfer (2010) removed this species from the synonymy of Osteocephalus taurinus, where it had been placed by Bokermann (1966). The individual from the Venezuelan slope of Pico da Neblina, previously considered a candidate species related to O. planiceps (Ca1_Neblina411 sensu Jungfer et al. 2013), nested within the same clade as O. vilarsi (Ferrão et al. 2019). Further revision of available Osteocephalus collections revealed that the specimens of Osteocephalus reported from Jaú National Park by Gordo and Neckel-Oliveira (2004) actually represent O. vilarsi (Ferrão et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Physalaemus olfersii (Cassini et al. 2010).
This species has been elevated from synonymy with Austrochaperina macrorhyncha (Günther 2017).
This species has been elevated from synonymy with Austrochaperina macrorhyncha (Günther 2017).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Austrochaperina punctata and A.rudolfarndti (Günther 2017).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

authority: Grant, Rada, Anganoy-Criollo, Batista, Dias, Jeckel, Machado & Rueda-Almonacid, 2017
Grant, Rada, Anganoy-Criollo, Batista, Dias, Jeckel, Machado & Rueda-Almonacid, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Leptophryne cruentata (Hamidy et al. 2018).
This species is part of the Occidozyga laevis complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

authority: Bornschein, Baldo, Pie, Firkowski, Ribeiro, & Corrêa, 2015
Baldo, Bornschein, Pie, Firkowski, Ribeiro, & Belmonte-Lopes, 2015
Baldo, Bornschein, Pie, Ribeiro, Firkowski & Morato, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This nominal taxon is associated with several unnamed cryptic species (Réjaud et al. 2020).

This species when described was allocated to the Brachycephalus pernix group (Pie and Ribeiro 2015), a group consisting of 18 formally recognized species (Monteiro et al. 2018). Studies with molecular data confirmed the delimitation of the species (Firkowski et al. 2016). However, Condez et al. (2017) suggest the taxonomic revaluation of B. quiririensis, due to problems in its diagnosis and original description. Pie et al. (2017) refute the arguments and point to the absence of evidence to support a taxonomic reassessment of the species. B. auroguttatus and B. leopardus occur in the same region as B. quirirensis but not in sympatry, their populations are isolated from each other by more than 3 km in Serra do Araçatuba/Serra do Quiriri, a single mountain range located on the border of the states from Paraná and Santa Catarina (Bornschein et al. 2016).
Records of Scutiger sikkimensis from northern Myanmar refer to this species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Oophaga histrionica by Posso-Terranova and Andrés (2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Oophaga histrionica by Posso-Terranova and Andrés (2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Oophaga histrionica by Posso-Terranova and Andrés (2018).
This is a restricted concept of Oophaga histrionica following the split of the broader concept into this and Oophaga anchicayensis, O. andresi and O. solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
Honduran subpopulations formerly considered Oedipina cyclocauda have been assigned to this species by McCranie et al. (2008).
Removed from the synonymy of Smilisca baudini by McCranie (2017). There may be two species within this taxon; taxonomic work is underway (J. Cossel pers. comm. September 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Craugastor rostralis (McCranie 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Amolops ricketti (Lyu et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Amolops ricketti (Lyu et al. 2019).

authority: Wang, Hsiao, Lee, Tseng, Lin, Komaki & Lin, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This species is a split from the broader concept of Buergeria japonica (Wang et al. 2018).
This species is the sister taxon of Rhacophorus dorsoviridis, and was previously confused with Rhacophorus nigropunctatus according to Pan et al. (2017).
The taxonomic relationship of this species to Cryptotriton monzoni needs to be investigated (D. Wake and G. Parra-Olea pers. comm. 2007).
Much of the scientific literature uses the name Ptychohyla spinipollex for this species. McCranie and Wilson (1993b) explain the correct usage of the names.
This form is part of a complex of three species that are difficult to separate morphologically, making it hard to know which species occurs where. It might be conspecific with Bolitoglossa mexicana.
McCranie and Rovito (2014) synonymised Cryptotriton wakei with this species.

Ron et al. (2016) initiated the nomenclatural breakup of nominal Trachycephalus typhonius, which, at least for the moment, left subpopulations west of the Andes to southern and eastern Mexico without a name(s), although it is abundantly clear that none of these will be conspecific with T. typhonius. This is a place-holder "taxon" for all names available for former Trachycephalus typhonius from Chocoan South America to southern and eastern Mexico.

Trachycephalus quadrangulum from Chocoan Ecuador may be conspecific with subpopulations in western Colombia and even into Central America (Frost 2021).
Removed from the synonymy of Trachycephalus coriaceus by Ron et al. (2016), where it had been placed by Duellman (1971).
This is a split from the broader concept of Trachycephalus typhonius (Ron et al. 2016).

authority: Li, Xu, Liu, Jiang, Wei & Wang, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species is a split from the broader concept Megophrys minor (Li et al. 2018).

Jansen et al. (2011) suggested on the basis of molecular data the existence of unnamed cryptic species, possibly two, in Bolivia. Schulze et al. (2015) characterised as Physalaemus centralis A and B, noting substantial differences from Brazilian Physalaemus centralis from São Paulo. Description, diagnosis, and picture of the larvae characterised as Physalaemus centralis A and B was published by Schulze et al. (2015), where the authors evidenced substantial differences from Brazilian Physalaemus centralis from São Paulo and genetic differences from each other.

Nascimento et al. (2006) associate Gomphobates marmoratus to the genus Physalaemus, and indicate that this name refers to specimens previously identified as Physalaemus fuscomaculatus. All literature prior to 2006 using the name Physalaemus fuscomaculatus should be used with great caution and with reference to the discussion provided by Nascimento et al. (2006).

authority: Wang, Qian, Zhang, Guo, Pan, Wu, Wang & Zhang, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This species is a split from the broader concept of Rana omeimontis, and has been placed as the sister taxon to R. hanluica (Wang et al. 2017).

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: No notable taxonomical issues.

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: First recorded from Mount Ribáuè by Blake (1965) and Poynton (1996). This is a split from the broader concept of Nothophryne broadleyi (Conradie et al. 2018). No notable taxonomical issues.
The sister taxon of Rana amurensis and Rana coreana (Zhao et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Scutiger nyingchiensis (Jiang et al. 2016).
Recognized as sister taxon to S. spinosus.

Genetic analysis has highlighted four lineages existing under this species name (Rivera et al. 2017); however further taxonomic and molecular studies are required to confirm this (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
There is some doubt whether this species belongs in this genus, and further taxonomic work needs to be carried out to resolve this (Günther 2009).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius naevis prior to its description by Tominaga et al. 2019.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius naevis prior to its description by Tominaga et al. 2019.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).

This species was previously confused as a subpopulation of Hynobius dunni, but was recently elevated to species status by Sugawara et al. (2018). Hynobius dunni is now considered to be endemic to Kyushu and H. tosashimizuensis as endemic to Shikoku.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Hynobius nebulosus by Matsui et al. (2019).

Tominaga and Matsui (2007) elevated the subspecies Hynobius naevius yatsui to full species status. Matsui et al. (2017) showed that the holotype of H. stejnegeri, long applied to another species (now H. ikioi), was the senior synonym for H. yatsui.

Tominaga et al. (2019) revised the Hynobius naevius group and described the subpopulation on Honshu as the new species Hynobius sematonotos, and the subpopulation in north-eastern Kyushu as the new species Hynobius oyamai. Thus, Hynobius naevius is now confined to the population in north-western Kyushu.

The concept of this species has been significantly reduced by Matsui et al. (2019) with the description of the new species H. abuensis, H. akiensis, H. bakan, H. iwami, H. setoi, H. setouchi, H. utsunomiyaorum and H. vandenburghi - the latter was raised from synonymy.

The subpopulation from Shikoku previously attributed to this species has now been described as a new species, Hynobius tosashimizuensis by Sugawara et al. (2018). Hynobius dunni is now considered to be endemic to Kyushu and H. tosashimizuensis endemic to Shikoku.
The sister taxon of Allobates crombiei according to the original publication.

Two lineages of Allobates tinae occurring in the Purus-Madeira Interfluve represent two different species, which can be distinguished from each other by adult morphology, larvae, advertisement call, and molecular data. The species inhabiting open ombrophilous forests in the south represents A. tinae sensu stricto, while the species that inhabits dense ombrophilous forests in the north represents a new species Allobates caldwellae (Lima et al. 2020).

authority: Jiménez-Arcos, Calzada-Arciniega, Alfaro-Juantorena, Vázquez-Reyes, Blair & Parra-Olea, 2019

taxonomicNotes: The holotype of this species was lost and the type locality is unknown. It was suspected to potentially be in the surroundings of Bhamo in Myanmar but this has not been confirmed. A neotype was assigned by Humtsoe et al. (2008) from Nagaland in northeast India.

authority: (Nguyen, Poyarkov, Le, Vo, Ninh, Duong, Murphy & Sang, 2018)

taxonomicNotes: This species corresponds to one of the lineages previously identified as a candidate species (“sp. F”) in Fouquet et al. (2013), which was recently described by Carvalho et al. (2019). Lineages F1 and F2 in Carvalho et al. (2019) are now known represent two more undescribed species, limiting this concept to its type locality.
This is a split from the broader concept of Neurergus strauchii (Rancilhac et al. 2019).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Neurergus barani, which has been elevated from subspecies level (Rancilhac et al. 2019).

authority: Dufresnes, Beddek, Skorinov, Fumagalli, Perrin, Crochet & Litvinchuk, 2019
taxonomicNotes: Dufresnes et al. (2019) revised the taxonomy of Hyla meridionalis and described the genetically distinct Tunisian and eastern Algerian populations, previously identified as a candidate species, as the new species H. carthaginiensis on the basis of evidence that limited genetic admixture suggests "putatively advanced reproductive isolation". The species was simultaneously described by Escoriza and Ben Hassine (2019) as Hyla numidica, using a specimen from Nefza, Tunisia, but this name was published later. H. numidica is consequently a junior synonym of H. meridionalis (Dufresnes and Crochet 2020).

taxonomicNotes: The sister taxon of Pseudopaludicola mineira, with which it was formerly confused prior to its description by Andrade et al. (2018).

The status of this species has been questioned, but it is currently recognized as being distinct from its congeners and is treated as such here.

Mahony pers. comm. September 2020).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Austrochaperina. Peloso et al. (2016) transferred the species to the genus Copiula. It has subsequently been transferred back to Austrochaperina.

authority: Campbell, Brodie, Caviedes-Solis, Nieto-Montes de Oca, Luja, Flores-Villela, García-Vázquez, Sarker & Wostl, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Removed from the synonymy of Sarcohyla bistincta by Campbell et al. (2018). Campbell et al. (2018:378) assigned the only known specimen (IBH 138072) of S. floresi from Estado de Mexico (then S. pentheter) to S. hapsa “based on distribution and morphology,” but did not report which characters they examined. Kaplan et al. (2020) found that this specimen has the diagnostic characters of S. floresi, and thus assign it to that species.

Lynch (1976) elevated this taxon to species status with no further comment. Lynch, Ruíz-Carranza and Ardila-Robayo (1994) redescribed the species, and noted a possible synapomorphy with Pristimantis cremnobates.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Further taxonomic studies are needed to determine the status of populations from the D'Entrecasteaux Islands. Kraus and Allison (2006) tentatively included these subpopulations under this species until additional recordings of calls from D'Entrecasteaux Islands become available.

taxonomicNotes:
This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys kuatunensis (Tapley et al. 2017).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

The species concept is currently restricted to Papua, Indonesia and records from Papua New Guinea require verification and are therefore excluded at present (F. Kraus and S. Richards pers. comm. August 2019).
We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Peloso et al. (2016), moving to Copuila, and retain this species in Austrochaperina.
Records below 1,000 m asl that were previously allocated to this species are now believed to belong to an undescribed species (S. Travers pers. comm. July 2019).

Change in genus from Albericus to Choerophryne according to Peloso et al. 2016.

This form is probably a complex of more than one species.

It is possible that the reports from Indonesia refer to undescribed species (Richards and Iskandar pers. comm.).

This species has been separated from Litoria gracilenta (Menzies and Tyler 2004). We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

The name Litoria hunti was emended to L. huntorum by Shea and Kraus (2007). However, according to Amphibian Species of the World, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2019: http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php). We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Frost et al. (2006) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

Provisionally treated under the genus Litoria.

This is a split from the broader concept of Amolops larutensis (Chan et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Amolops larutensis, which it was previously confused with (Chan et al. 2018).

We previously followed Dubois (1992) and Schleich and Kästle (2002) in considering Amolops himalayanus to be a synonym of A. formosus. However, Nidup et al. (2016) discuss the identification of A. formosus, with which A. himalayanus has been confused and clarify that they should be treated as two separate species.
This species was resurrected from synonymy with Callulops doriae (Kraus 2019).
This is a restricted concept of Callulops doriae; C. bicolor, C. neuhaussi, C. taxispilotus, C. argus have been removed from the broader concept.

Glaw et al. (2019) report that this species "was previously considered as Rhacophorus tephraeomystax (Boettger 1913: 342), Boophis tephraeomystax (Meirte 1999, 2004), Boophis opisthodon (Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc 1993), Boophis n. sp. (Vences et al. 2003), Boophis (Sahona) new species Comoros (Glaw and Vences 2006), Boophis sp. 1 (Vieites et al. 2009), Boophis sp. Ca1 (Perl et al. 2014; Hutter et al. 2018), and Boophis sp. (Hawlitschek et al. 2011)."

According to Glaw et al. (2019), this species was previously considered as Mantidactylus granulatus (Guibé 1978, Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc 1993; Meirte 1999, 2004), Mantidactylus n. sp. (Vences et al. 2003a), Blommersia new species Comoros (Glaw and Vences 2006), Blommersia sp. 4 (Vieites et al. 2009), Blommersia sp. Ca4 (Perl et al. 2014), and Blommersia sp. (Hawlitschek et al. 2011). Some of the records assigned to B. transmarina could, in truth, represent the newly described Blommersia nataliae (Vieites et al. 2020).

Stöck (1999) suggested that Batrachuperus gorganensis was a synonym of this species. However, (T. Papenfuss pers. comm. September 2008) argued that molecular analysis demonstrated that Paradactylodon gorganensis should be treated as a distinct species. They were assessed separately for the Red List up until 2008, and both were then transferred to the genus Iranodon. They have subsequently been transferred back to Paradactylodon by Stöck et al. (2019) with gorganensis being placed into synonymy under P. persicus.

This is a restricted concept following the split of Adenomera kweti by Carvalho et al. (2019) and remains a complex of several undescribed species (Fouquet et al. 2007, Fouquet et al. 2013, Guarnizo et al. 2016, Carvalho et al. 2019).

Richards and Oliver (2006) separated Litoria dux and L. sauroni from this species. The name Litoria graminea has been applied quite widely to canopy-dwelling treefrogs in New Guinea, but in some cases these refer to species that have not yet been described.
This form is a complex of composed of several species (S. Richards pers. comm.).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species (R.W. Zweifel pers. comm.).

The status of populations in Papua New Guinea is unclear. More than one species might be included in this taxon (S. Richards pers. comm.).

The Rossel Island subpopulations of this species are most likely a separate species (F. Kraus pers. comm. 2005). Menzies (2006) suggested that this species might possibly be extant in the Owen Stanley Mountain range, however this is highly unlikely (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).
Choerophyne darlingtoni and C. fafniri are only distinguishable by their calls (R. Zweifel pers. comm.).
This species and Choerophryne darlingtoni are distinguishable only by their calls (Zweifel pers. comm.).

This species is now restricted to the type locality (Ok Tedi headwaters region) as other records have been allocated to Choerophryne alainduboisi and other undescribed species (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).
It is possible that this form comprises more than one species (A. Allison and R. Zweifel pers. comm.).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Austrochaperina. Peloso et al. (2016) transferred the species to the genus Copiula. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

This species has been moved from Genyophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017). However, this genus change is being challenged (Poyarkov et al. 2018). It is possible that this form comprises more than one species (A. Allison pers. comm.).

A single specimen deposited at the University of Papua New Guinea from the eastern end of the Huon Peninsula (Menzies 2006) is considered to be another species (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).

This genus is currently undergoing substantial revision and is being separated into many new species. Furthermore, the insular subspecies, Hylophorbus rufescens extimus from Tagula Island, and H.r. myopicus from Woodlark Island described by Zweifel (1972) clearly warrant full species status.
Genus change from Liophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Liophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Liophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Liophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Liophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Liophryne  to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
This is most likely a species complex (Oliver et al. 2013).
This species was recently redefined by Zweifel et al. (2003).
The taxonomic status of some populations assigned to this species is unclear.
There is uncertainty around the validity of this species (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).
Subpopulations on the two islands may be taxonomically distinct and need to be evaluated with call analysis (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).
Recordings of the call from the type locality are needed to stabilize the identification of this species. We follow Menzies (1976) in recognizing that this species is distinct from Oreophryne biroi.
It is not clear whether or not populations on Yapen Island represent this species.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Oxydactyla. Peloso et al. (2016) transferred the species to the genus Copiula. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.
Following the synonymy of the genus Oxydactyla with Sphenophryne, this species has become Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Oxydactyla to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Oxydactyla to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Genus change from Oxydactyla to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
This species is a species complex, and further taxonomic work is required for delineation (S. Richards and B. Tjaturadi pers. comm. July 2019).
This is a complex of several species (Donnellan et al. 2010).

The name Rana (= Hylarana) grisea has been promiscuously applied to most large members of the Hylarana papua group throughout the uplands of New Guinea (both Indonesia and Papua New Guinea) and from the island of Seram (Indonesia) (Kraus and Allison 2007). However, studies show that name can currently only be applied with certainty to material from the type locality, whereas frogs from everywhere else are currently of uncertain species placement, although some or many of them may turn out to be true H. grisea (Kraus and Allison 2007). For the purposes of this assessment, until new information becomes available, we restrict H. grisea to its type locality.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.

This name is currently used for a complex of more than one species, which collectively range widely in the mountains of New Guinea (Kraus and Allison 2007). True Papurana supragrisea occurs in the southeast of New Guinea, including the D'Entrecasteaux Islands, but its distributional limits are uncertain (Kraus and Allison 2007). In this account we continue to use this name for the whole complex, pending resolution of these taxonomic issues.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

This species was separated from Litoria gracilenta (Menzies and Tyler 2004).

Richards and Oliver (2006) separated this species from Litoria graminea. This species was synonymised with Litoria graminea by Kraus (2018), however it was resurrected again by Oliver et al. (2019) on the basis of genetic distance and morphological differences.
We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Frost et al. (2006) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).
It appears as though there may be two species within this taxonomic concept; further work is needed to clarify its taxonomic status (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012). This species has now been moved to Nyctimystes (Kraus 2018).

Richards and Oliver (2006) separated this species from Litoria graminea.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).
Kraus and Allison (2007) resurrected this species from the synonymy of Rana daemeli. It is closely related to R. aurata and R. volkerjane.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).
F. Kraus (pers. comm.) and S. Richards (pers. comm.) consider that Litoria rostandi Kraus, 2007 is a synonym of L. hilli.
This species has affinities to the Litoria nigropunctata species-group according to the original publication (Günther 2008).

Specimens from coastal northeastern Mozambique and Mount Lico in Mozambique have been shown to be genetically similar to specimens from the type locality at Chirinda in Zimbabwe (W. Conradie pers. comm. 2020, Farooq et al. 2015). They are therefore accepted as valid records of this species. However, the relatively large geographic distances between the different known subpopulations may have resulted in long term isolation and led to distinct and non-interbreeding populations (Farooq et al. 2015). Further taxonomic work would be useful, in particular to determine whether the northeastern coastal Mozambique subpopulation is a separate species. Furthermore, the similarities between Mertensophryne anotis and Mertensophryne loveridgei in Tanzania to the north requires further investigation (W. Conradie pers. comm. 2020) and may provide further clarity regarding the identify of the northeastern coastal Mozambique subpopulation.

authority: Yu, Li, Wang, Rao, Wu & Yang, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species was recently split from the broader concept of Gracixalus jinxiuensis (Yu et al. 2019).

authority: Poyarkov, Gorin, Zaw, Kretova, Gogoleva, Pawangkhanan & Che, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with the old concept of Amazonphrynella minuta (Rojas-Zamora et al. 2018).

authority: Rojas-Zamora, Fouquet, Ron, Hernández-Ruz, Melo-Sampaio, Chaparro, Vogt, Carvalho, Pinheiro, Ávila, Farias, Gordo & Hrbek, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic uncertainty makes it difficult to clearly define the distribution of this species (P. Peloso, M. Hoogmoed, M. Sturaro and I. Kaefer pers. comm. at Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

authority: Neves, Silva, Akieda, Cabrera, Koroiva & Santana, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Ameerega picta (Neves et al. 2017).

taxonomicNotes: Removed from the synonymy of Chiasmocleis albopunctata (de Sá et al. 2018 "2019") where it had been placed by Cruz et al. (1997). There is still confusion around the identities of some museum specimens of Chiasmocleis albopunctata, as some in Brazil could actually belong to this species; further examination of such specimens is needed to fully understand the limits of this species range (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Craugastor podiciferus by Arias et al. (2019) where it had previously been placed by Taylor (1952).
This is a split from the broader concept of Craugastor podiciferus (Arias et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Craugastor podiciferus (Arias et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Dendropsophus parviceps (Rivadeneira et al. 2018).
Records of Dendropsophus parviceps from northeastern and central Peru belong to this species (Rivadeneira et al. 2018).
Despite being described in 2017, there is considerable uncertainty in the identity of the records assigned to this species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus (Hill et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus (Hill et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus (Hill et al. 2018).
This species was previously confused with Ischnocnema oea.

De la Riva, Cortez F. & Burrowes, 2017
Andrade, Haga, Lyra, Leite, Kwet, Haddad, Toledo & Giaretta, 2018

taxonomicNotes:
Pseudopaludicola riopiedadensis was synonymized with this concept by Cardozo and Toledo (2013). 

Pseudopaludicola ameghini and P. ternetzi are easily confused as they share similar external morphologies, advertisement calls, and overlapping ranges (Pansonato et al. 2013, Cardozo and Toledo 2013). Molecular studies are needed to clarify the identity of records to confirm their distributions and identify possible undescribed species contained within both concepts.

authority: Castroviejo-Fisher, Köhler, De la Riva & Padial, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Phyllomedusa camba from which it is morphologically indistinguishable according to Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2017). It is phylogenetically most closely related to a clade composed of Phyllomedusa neildi, P. tarsius, and P. trinitatis (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2017).

This species was originally included within Dendrobates flavopictus (Gans 1960) and later allocated to Ameerega picta by Silverstone (1976). After re-examination of the original material the frogs were subsequently included within Ameerega braccata (Morales 2001). Prior to their description as a full species, Lötters et al. (2007) provisionally restored the massif populations in Ameerega flavopicta.

Following genetic, morphological and bioacoustic analysis, all Bolivian subpopulations of Boana fasciata now belong to this species (Caminer and Ron 2014, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Fouquet et al. (2021) presented an amended diagnosis of B. steinbachi, based on molecular and phenotypic data, and assigned records of B. fasciata from Bolivian Amazonia, south-western, central, and eastern Brazilian Amazonia, and Peruvian Amazonia to B. steinbachi.

authority: Pinheiro, Cintra, Valdujo, Silva, Martins, Silva & Garcia, 2018

taxonomicNotes: This species was confused with Cryptotriton veraepacis prior to its naming by Rovito et al. (2015).
Removed from the synonymy of Scinax fuscomarginatus by Brusquetti et al. (2014).

Harvey and Smith (1993) pointed out that Rhinella echinodes, described by Reynolds and Foster (1992), is a synonym of R. quechua. There is an unconfirmed record in Parque Nacional Cotapata in La Paz (Cortez 2001). This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
Harvey (1996) synonymized Cochranella flavidigitata with N. bejaranoi.

The original type locality of this species was Panama, but this is in error according to Savage and Heyer (1969) who suggested that the type specimen might have come from Colombia, Peru or Bolivia. Subsequently, Duellman and De la Riva (1999) found a single specimen. Based on morphological characters, it is suspected that this species may be the senior synonym of at least two other common species of the region (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was rediscovered by J. Aparicio and S. Reichle in 1997 at the type locality.

De la Riva et al. (2000) registered a slight doubt as to the taxonomic validity of the species. Faivovich and De la Riva (2006), however, continue to recognize it as a valid species, pending a revision of subpopulations associated with the name Hyloscirtus armatus. In the Hyloscirtus armatus group according to Faivovich and De la Riva (2006).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla until it was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was formerly considered a synonym of Pristimantis fenestratus by Lynch (1980), but it was elevated to species status by Köhler (2000).
Differences in acoustic parameters support the specific status of Oreobates ibischi (Padial et al. 2008).

This species was formerly considered to be a synonym of Telmatobius marmoratus (Vellard 1970). It was resurrected as a full species by De la Riva et al. (2000). Telmatobius ifornoi is included as a synonym of this species, following De la Riva (2005).
This species is a complex of more than one species.
We follow De la Riva et al. (2000) in considering this species to be separate from Telmatobius marmoratus, and also follow De la Riva (2004) in considering T. jahuira as a synonym of T. verrucosus.
Differences in acoustic parameters support the specific status of Oreobates madidi (Padial et al. 2008).

authority: (De la Riva & Martínez-Solano in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
In the Cochranella granulosa group according to the original description. This taxon is characterized by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Aguayo and Harvey 2006).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

Previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius marmoratus, T. hintoni was elevated to species category by De la Riva (2005) based on morphological and colour differences.

In addition to the holotype, the type series of T. hintoni is comprised of three specimens from Calacoto, La Paz, but these specimens are not conspecific with the holotype, and they were correctly identified as T. marmoratus by Vellard (De la Riva 2005).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva, 2007).

authority: (Muñoz, Aguayo & De la Riva in De la Riva, 2007)
(De la Riva, Reichle & Cortéz in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

authority: (De la Riva & Padial in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007). It seems that there are two different subpopulations of this species; however, it is not known whether these are conspecific with each other (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2008, 2019)
Hydrolaetare caparu can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and advertisement call features (Jansen et al. 2007).

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De la Riva 2005). It is possible that the two subpopulations are not conspecific, so further taxonomic studies are needed (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).

authority: (De la Riva & Martínez-Solano in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

authority: (De la Riva, Reichle & Bosch in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters, colour patterns, saltatorial behaviour and advertisement call features (De la Riva 2007).
See comments by Garda et al. (2010) regarding the evidentiary ambiguity of distinctiveness from Lysapsus limellus.

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007). There are probably two species contained within this taxon (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
This species was previously confused with Pristimantis dundeei according to Padial and De la Riva (2009).

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological subpopulations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including E. helianneae.
This is a split from the broader concept of Bolitoglossa meliana (Vazquez-Almazán and Rovito 2014).

This concept includes all the records from Duttaphrynus atukoralei, which occurred in Sri Lanka and has now been synonymized (Jayawardena et al. 2017). Bisht et al. (2021) removed Duttaphrynus (now Firouzophrynus) peninsularis from synonymy under this species.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Kaloula. Peloso et al. (2016) transferred the species to the genus Uperodon. It is possible that the Sri Lanka subpopulations belong to a distinct species.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Uperodon rohani (Garg et al. 2018).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.

Krishnamurthy and Shakunthala (1993) reported this species from Karnataka, India. Dutta (1997) rejected the species' presence in India, but notes that there is an unspecified form of Fejervarya in Karnataka and Maharashtra that is closely related to F. greenii (S. Dutta pers. comm.).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.
Minervarya caperata has been synonymized with this species by Phuge et al. (2020), and M. modesta has been synonymised by Garg and Biju (2021).
The five available museum specimens require further comparison with specimens of Nannophrys ceylonensis.

The subpopulations in Sri Lanka have been assigned to Indosylvirana serendipi and Hydrophylax gracilis (Biju et al. 2014). These species have all been moved from Indosylvirana and Hydrophylax back to Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).
Sri Lankan subpopulations from Galle and Udawatta that were previously assigned to I. aurantiaca have now been reallocated to this species (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a species complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus procax to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus hoffmani to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering this species to be separate from Philautus microtympanum, and belonging to the genus Philautus, rather than Polypedates.
This species is considered distinct from Philautus microtympanum, following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).

Specimens recorded as Philautus temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats of India are now considered to be P. wynaadensis. P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus are endemic species of Sri Lanka (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.; Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Philautus microtympanum by Dutta and Manamendra-Arachchi (1996).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This is a broader concept of Pseudophilautus pleurotaenia that now includes all the records from P. hoipolloi, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus papillosus to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus (Günther, 1858) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus nanus (Günther 1869) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species was moved to the genus Philautus from Theloderma by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).

This species is known only from the holotype which has been lost. It is not currently possible to match this name to any known species in the wild. It was removed from the synonymy of Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is currently considered distinct from Pseudophilautus macropus following Ellepola et al. (2021). However, further taxonomic studies on this species are required.

Specimens formerly attributed to Philautus temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats are now correctly assigned to P. wynaadensis. P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus are now considered to be endemic species of Sri Lanka (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.).

Specimens formerly attributed to Philautus variabilis from the Western Ghats of India are now known to be misidentified P. wynaadensis. P. variabilis is endemic to Sri Lanka, where it is now considered to be extinct (K. Manamendra-Arachchi and S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus microtympanum following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
Specimens previously attributed to this species from the Western Ghats of India have been assigned to Polypedates pseudocruciger (Das and Ravichandran 1998).
This species was previously placed in the genera Rhacophorus and Polypedates.

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).
Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).

authority: Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Mannophryne olmonae is not closely related to Mannophryne trinitatis (Lehtinen et al. 2011, Jowers et al. 2011), as was previously thought (Murphy 1997). Chromosome banding pattern data clearly allow a distinction between M. olmonae and Trinidadian M. trinitatis (Kaiser et al. 2003). These two species are not sister taxa; the sister taxon of M. olmonae is Mannophryne riveroi from the Peninsula de Paria, Venezuela (Lehtinen et al. 2011, Jowers et al. 2011).

authority: Sunyer, Wake, Townsend, Travers, Rovito, Papenfuss, Obando & Köhler, 2010

taxonomicNotes:
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Megophrys rubrimera (Tapley et al. 2017).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
The taxonomy of this species is particularly poorly understood, and this species is of doubtful validity (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004).

This species was incorrectly synonymized with Schistometopum gregorii, and was resurrected by Wilkinson et al. (2004). Measey et al. (2012) assigned specimens from Ngaya forest-Nyambne Hills in Meru North to this species, which were included in its 2012 reassessment. However, these specimens were later described as Boulengerula spawlsi (Wilkinson et al. 2017).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus complex (Schiøtz 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Frost (2002), and because it differs rather markedly from adjacent forms in this complex. The taxonomy of this species is highly confused and it is difficult to distinguish from congeners (Hyperolius viridiflavus group e.g H. glandicolor, H, ferniquei), which may account for the lack of recent records. It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this complex are still far from settled, and the species limits should be considered as provisional (A. Schiøtz pers. comm.).
This is a split from the broader concept of Dendropsophus tritaeniatus (Jansen et al. 2019).

Gehara et al. (2014) reported a molecular phylogenetic analysis of the widespread South American species Dendropsophus minutus. One conclusion of that study was that subpopulations of the Venezuelan Coastal Range clustered together with Trinidadian subpopulations and were distinct enough to merit recognition as a separate species, and that the name Dendropsophus goughi was available. However, C. Barrio-Amoros examined the type of Dendropsophus goughi (BMNH 1947.2.13.12) and it is considered to be conspecific with Dendropsophus microcephalus Cope, 1886. A cotype of D. goughi (BMNH 1947.2.13.83) is a subadult of Dendropsophus aff. minutus (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019). According to Barrio-Amoros et al. (2019), the status of other subpopulations once attributed to Dendropsophus minutus still need to be clarified.
This is a split from the broader concept of Isthmura belli, of which it was previously considered a subspecies (Rovito et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Megastomatohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The taxonomic validity of this species is not clear (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

Based on allozymes and mtDNA, this is one of the most distinct species of Mexican ambystomatids. It was previously thought to be a species complex, however, this was resolved by Weisrock et al. (2006) and this is not the case.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

authority: Lourenço-de-Moraes, Dias, Mira-Mendes, Oliveira, Barth, Ruas, Vences, Solé & Bastos, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Molecular phylogenetic studies confirmed the monophyly of the genus Adelophryne and revealed three main clades located in northern Amazonia, northern and southern Atlantic Forest (Fouquet et al. 2012). A. michelin is phylogenetically related to species from the northern clade of the North Atlantic Forest (Lourenço-de-Moraes et al. 2018). In Bahia, A. michelin occurs in sympatry and syntopy with A. mucronata and Adelophryne sp. 2 (species not yet described for the genus), species from which it is morphologically distinguished (Lourenço-de-Moraes et al. 2018).

Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), seven species were recognised under this concept. The distribution of D. brevipollicatus was then restricted and D. lauroi and D. imitator were revalidated, and four new species were described; D. haddadi, D. izecksohni, D. jureia and D. davori.

Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), seven species were recognized under this concept. The distribution of D. brevipollicatus was then restricted and D. lauroi and D. imitator were revalidated, and four new species were described; D. haddadi, D. izecksohni, D. jureia and D. davori.

Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), seven species were recognized under this concept. The distribution of D. brevipollicatus was then restricted and D. lauroi and D. imitator were revalidated, and four new species were described; D. haddadi, D. izecksohni, D. jureia and D. davori.

Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), seven species were recognized under this concept. The distribution of D. brevipollicatus was then restricted and D. lauroi and D. imitator were revalidated, and four new species were described; D. haddadi, D. izecksohni, D. jureia and D. davori.

Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), seven species were recognized under this concept. The distribution of D. brevipollicatus was then restricted to Rio de Janeiro State, and D. lauroi and D. imitator were revalidated, and four new species were described; D. haddadi, D. izecksohni, D. jureia and D. davori.
Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), this species has been revalidated.

authority: Maciel, Castro, Sturaro, Silva, Ferreira, Santos, Risse-Quaioto, Barboza, Oliveira, Sampaio & Schneider, 2019
Santos, Oliveira, Carvalho, Zaidan, Silva, Berneck & Garcia, 2019
Mângia, Koroiva, Nunes, Roberto, Ávila, Sant’Anna, Santana & Garda, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Confused with Proceratophrys cristiceps prior to its naming according to Mângia et al. (2018).
This is a revised concept of this species. Proceratophrys fryi has been synonymized under this species and P. renalis has been removed from synonymy by Prado and Pombal (2008).

authority: Senevirathne, Samarawickrama, Wijayathilaka, Manamendra-Arachchi, Bowatte, Samarawickrama, & Meegaskumbura, 2018
Garg, Senevirathne, Wijayathilaka, Phuge, Deuti, Manamendra-Arachchi, Meegaskumbura, & Biju, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Uperodon variegatus (Garg et al. 2018).

authority: (Wu, Suwannapoom, Poyarkov, Chen, Pawangkhanant, Xu, Jin, Murphy & Che, 2019)
taxonomicNotes:
This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys minor (Wu et al. 2019).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species was confused with Eleutherodactylus sierramaestrae prior to its description.

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: No notable taxonomical issues.
This species may belong in another genus - either Hydrophylax or Indosylvirana - but further research is required (Oliver et al. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

Mirza et al. (2019) recently showed that Philautus similipalensis and Raorchestes terebrans are synonyms of this species. A further comparative study of this species with R. bombayensis was undertaken by Garg et al. (2021) with the findings supporting the synonymy of this species within R. bombayensis, but with the recommendation that further population level studies and more comprehensive sampling across the entire range of R. bombayensis are needed before this can be confirmed.
This taxon has been moved to the genus Paradactylodon (Zhang et al. 2006).
Taxonomic research is ongoing to determine whether all subpopulations are conspecific (Rajkumar K.P. pers comm. October 2020).

This species was kept in Pedostibes by Chan et al. 2016. However, Chandramouli and Amarsinghe (2016) placed it under Bufoides after examining type specimens. The genus Pedostibes is now considered monotypic and is restricted to the Western Ghats.
According to Oliver et al. (2015), this taxon is likely to be either in Hydrophylax or Indosylvirana, pending genetic sampling.

There are taxonomic difficulties with this species, and it is possible that Ansonia rubigina is a synonym of it (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004). We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois et al. (2021), who moved this species to the genus Blaira, on the basis that it was only published as Ghatophryne in an electronic-only journal prior to 2012. This assessment retains it in Ghatophryne, as it is the name registered with ZooBank.

This species might be a synonym of Ghatophryne ornata (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004). We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois et al. (2021), who moved this species to the genus Blaira, on the basis that it was only published as Ghatophryne in an electronic-only journal prior to 2012. This assessment retains it in Ghatophryne, as it is the name registered with ZooBank.
Many museum specimens assigned to Bufo beddomii are misidentifications (Biju 2001).
Records from Kerala are misidentifications (Dinesh et al. 2009).
It may be a species complex (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. August 2020).
This species has been moved from the genus Xanthophryne to Beduka by Dubois et al. (2021).
Several specimens bearing this name, and which are deposited in different museums in India, do not belong to this species (Biju 2001).
It may be a species complex (S.R. Chandramouli and S. Das pers. comm. October 2020).

This taxon is probably a junior synonym of Duttaphrynus parietalis (Dubois and Ohler 1999; Biju in prep.). It is thought that the type specimen of D. silentvalleyensis might refer to a subadult of D. parietalis, and that this taxon is therefore invalid.

Biological subpopulations from Ngengpui Wildlife Sanctuary, Dampa Tiger Reserve and Tura in the Garo Hills of Meghalaya previously reported under this nominal form are now considered to be an undescribed species (Deuti et al. 2012). They have not been included in the assessment of this restricted range species to avoid over estimating its range.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
It may be a species complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
Uperodon minor has been synonymized with this species by Garg et al. (2018).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognized as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Based upon the work of Peloso et al. (2016), Ramanella (Rao and Ramanna, 1925) is now recognized as a junior synonym of Uperodon (Duméril and Bibron, 1841), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. The current spelling for this taxon is Uperodon mormoratus (Peloso et al. 2016, Frost 2021).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognized as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. 

The taxonomy of this species needs to be resolved, as current collections probably represent more than one taxon.
This species has been reported from several additional localities, although these likely refer to undescribed species (S.D. Biju pers. comm.)
The species is named after one of the local tribes within its distribution.
Was transferred from Euphlyctis to the Limnonectes kuhlii species group by Dufresenes et al. (2022).

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). There is significant taxonomic confusion with this species. In particular many specimens are assigned to it potentially in error, making it difficult to determine its distribution accurately (S.R. Chandramouli and S. Harikrishnan pers. comm. 2020).

This species was described based on a single "purchased specimen" from "Pegu", Myanmar (Peters 1871). Boulenger (1920) expressed doubts regarding its type locality. The subpopulation of Wayanad matches the type description, and presumably the type specimen is from the Western Ghats and not from Myanmar.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Several species might be currently confused under this name. Specimens collected in the northern part of its range have been found to belong to Fejervarya pierrei Dubois, 1975 (Biju 2001).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana was then recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence this species has was returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Minervarya kudremukhensis, M. parabikulamana and M. sauriceps were placed in synonymy with this species by Garg and Biju (2021).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). It is thought to be a taxonomic complex, and taxonomic work is required to fully delineate it (India Red List Assessment Workshop February 2021).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana was then recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species was returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Minervarya mudduraja and M. murthii were placed in synonymy with this species by Garg and Biju (2021).

Further taxonomic work is required to determine this species' true identity and distribution (India Red List Assessment Workshop August 2020). Molecular data suggests that Minervarya jhilmilensis (Bahuguna 2018) is a synonym of this species, but confirmation is pending (Prudhvi Raj pers. comm. August 2020).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred in to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), and now the taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Further taxonomic research is required as this may be a synonym of M. agricola (Chandramouli, S.R. and Prudhvi Raj pers. comm. September 2020).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred in to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), and the species was returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon was subsequently moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the reallocation of syntypes, previously assigned to this species, to Indirana sarojamma (Dahanukar et al. 2016). Records from Maharashtra have been re-assigned to Indirana chiravasi (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
A number of specimens referred to this species in the past are likely to have been misidentified (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

The holotype of this species is lost, and designation of a neotype is needed if this proves to be a valid species. It is considered to be incertae sedis for Anura (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus longicrus, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from Philautus to Indirana.
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

This taxon is known only from the type specimen, the generic allocation of which is doubtful. There are some doubts over its validity as a distinct species, and it may be a synonym of another species (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
It may be a species complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
This species is part of the Limnonectes blythii complex.

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species. Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus elegans, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from the genus Philautus to Micrixalus.
Some records attributed to this species might not belong to it (India Red List Assessment Workshop 2004).

The original description of this species, as Nyctibatrachus hussaini (Krishnamurthy et al. 2001), did not provide any information about the type specimen. Hence, its taxonomy and nomenclature required further investigation and amendments (Biju 2001, Das and Kunte 2005, S.K. Dutta pers. comm.). Dinesh et al. (2007) provided the replacement name Nyctibatrachus karnatakaensis.
Biju et al. (2011) designated a neotype for this species after the type specimen was lost.
This species was designated a lectotype and its range redelimited by Biju et al. (2011).
Biju et al. (2011) has revised the taxonomy of this species and designated a lectotype.
The holotype of this species is lost, hence Biju et al. (2011) designated a specimen collected in 2007 at Kempholey, Hassan district, Karnataka State as a neotype.

Further collections of this species are needed to resolve the synonymy of Allopaa barmoachensis with A. hazarensis (M.S. Khan pers. comm.). Allopa barmoachensis may be a synonym of A. hazarensis following Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (2006). However, we are following Chanda (2002) and Khan (2006) in treating them as separate species.
There is some variation between the Nepalese and Indian subpopulations, which needs to be investigated as they may represent two distinct species (A. Ohler pers. comm. September 2020).

Research into the species validity needs to be prioritised. The key recommended conservation measures include taxonomic research on the generic allocation of this taxon (Das 1998, Chandramouli 2017, Harikrishnan and Vasudevan 2018).

This species includes Rana danieli following the revision by Ao et al. (2003). There is some taxonomic confusion around this species (India Red List Assessment Workshop February 2021). Further taxonomic studies of this taxon are required, as it might be a synonym of Clinotarsus alticola (A. Ohler pers. comm. 2004). Specimens referred to Rana danieli from Nepal are now referred to Hylarana chitwanensis.
Transferred from Hydrophylax to Hylarana by Dubois et al. (2021).
The type material is lost and the locality information has been poorly recorded. A neotype has been designated.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Hylarana erythraea by Ohler and Mallick, (2002). It is part of a species group with Hylarana erythraea and H. taipehensis (E. Quah pers. comm. July 2020).

Biju (2001) considers this taxon to be a junior synonym of Spharerotheca pluvialis (which is itself considered here to be a synonym of S. breviceps, pending resolution of this complex). Records from Tamhini, Maharashtra have a considerable genetic divergence from the subpopulations of Bankot and Hasool in Maharashtra and Mangalore coast in Karnataka (Prasad et al. 2019).
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).

Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) suggested that this species could be a synonym of Ixalus beddomii Günther, 1876. However, subsequent studies indicate that both species are distinct (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021).

Specimens of Philautus (now Raorchestes) charius recorded from Ponmudi Hills and surroundings and Wayanad were assessed separately in 2004 as a new undescribed species Philautus sp. nov. "Kalpatta". This species has subsequently been described as P. anili (Biju and Bossuyt 2006).
This species might belong in the genus Rhacophorus, not Philautus (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001) or in another genus such as Raorchestes (K. Deuti pers. comm. September 2020).

The holotype of this species is the only confirmed record, but there are a lot of records assigned to this species that require confirmation. There is significant taxonomic confusion (M.F. Ahmed, J. Purkayastha and K. Deuti pers. comm. October 2020).
Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) designated a neotype for this species after the type specimen was lost.
This species was placed in Philautus by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001), but has now been moved to Nasutixalus by Sivongxay (2016).
While considered a taxonomically valid species its relationship with Philautus garo needs to be investigated (K. Deuti and M. F. Ahmed pers comm. October 2020).
This form is a complex of more than one species.

Garg et al. (2021) compared the two known specimens of Raorchestes thodai morphologically with this species and found there was no clear distinction between the two taxa. In addition despite further surveys over the previous decade, no further specimens of Raorchestes thodai have been collected and no observations of individuals, which further supports the likelihood that Raorchestes thodai is a junior synonym of this species (Garg et al. 2021).
This species was first reported by Inger et al. (1984) from Ponmudi as Philautus femoralis.

Raorchestes punctatus and R. melanensis (collected by Rao in Karnataka) are considered to be synonyms of this species (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001), but further studies are required to confirm this relationship (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

This species was revalidated by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001). It was previously considered to be a synonym of Philautus variabilis. Specimens recorded as P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats of India are now correctly assigned to this species (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This taxon was transfered to the new genus Ghatixalus and is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus asterops (Biju et al. 2008).

This species is not well characterized. Many literature reports in fact refer to Gegeneophis ramaswamii (D. Gower, V. Giri, K. Ramachandran pers. comm. August 2020). Karyological data suggest that this species shares similarities in chromosome and karyotype morphology, for the most part, with Gegeneophis krishni (Venu and Venkatachalaiah 2006).
This is a poorly circumscribed species (D. Gower, K. Ramachandran pers. comm. August 2020).
It is a poorly characterised species. Substantial intraspecific genetic variation has been reported (Gower et al. 2011).
This species is not well characterised ((D. Gower, V. Giri and V. Govindappa pers. comm. September 2020).
