This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2003, R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020).

A study by Gower et al. (2007) found that genetic diversity among unstriped, long-tailed Ichthyophis of the Western Ghats is low, supporting the hypothesis that there is only a single, widely distributed species, Ichthyophis bombayensis (now Uraeotyphlus bombayensis following Dubois et al. 2021).

N. Dahanukar (pers. comm. pre-2010) questions the basis of Gower et al.’s (2007) conclusion that the long-tailed unstriped Ichthyophis of peninsular India comprise a single species (I. bombayensis), because only a small amount of only mitochondrial DNA sequence data were analysed and because they did not present quantitative morphometric analyses.
The species is not well circumscribed. Notable intraspecific genetic variation has been reported (Gower et al. 2002).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic distinctiveness of this species (D. Gower and R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020). Its main reported diagnostic feature occurs more widely within the genus.
This species is poorly characterised (D. Gower, V. Govindappa and R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020).
This species is not well characterised (D. Gower and R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020).
Transferred from Kaloula to Uperodon (Portik et al. 2023).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Further taxonomic work could confirm that this species is a synonym of Polypedates pseudocruciger (Ganesh S.R. and Chandramouli S.R. pers. comm. October 2020).

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Giri, Roelants, Nagaraju & Bossuyt, 2007

taxonomicNotes:
The species named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species was in fact Hylarana nicobariensis. The true Fejervarya nicobariensis was inadvertently omitted from the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists. In 2008 it was assessed. The validity of the species was affirmed by Dubois and Ohler (2000).

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). There is still some taxonomic uncertainty regards this species, and in particular the range limits need to be determined (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. 2020).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species is poorly circumscribed and needs to be re-characterised (D. Gower pers. comm. August 2020).
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This is likely a synonym of Raorchestes parvulus but this taxonomic change is currently awaiting publication (M.F. Ahmed pers. comm. October 2020).

authority: Sengupta, Hussain, Choudhury, Gogoi, Ahmed & Choudhury, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Assignment to Amolops based on association of topotypic larvae that were not grown to adulthood; the generic assignment is therefore provisional (Frost 2020). Molecular analyses are expected to show that some specimens assigned to this species may belong to a different taxa, although this has not been confirmed (S. Jayaditya pers. comm. September 2020).
This taxon is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus variabilis (Biju et al. 2008).
In the Uraeotyphlus malabaricus group according to the original description (Gower et al. 2008).
This species has undergone a name change from Xanthophryne tigerinus, which was deemed invalid as it was published in an electronic journal only prior to 2012 (Dubois et al. 2021).

authority: Agarwal, Wilkinson, Mohapatra, Dutta, Giri & Gower, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys parva (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species was split from the broader concept of Microhyla ornata (Hasan et al. 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Microhyla ornata (Hasan et al. 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Raorchestes bombayensis (Padhye et al. 2013).

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys boettgeri (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Removed from the synonymy of Nanorana annandalii (Ohler and Dubois 2006).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Nyctibatrachus beddomii by Biju et al. (2007).
This is a split from the broader concept of Polypedates leucomystax, although the split has not been well documented (Frost 2019).

authority: Khatiwada, Wang, Ghimire, Vasudevan, Paudel, & Jiang, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Minervarya rufescens (as Fejervarya rufescens) by Garg and Biju (2017).
This species was recently removed from the synonymy of Kaloula baleata (Chandramouli and Prasad 2018).

In the original description, it is not clear whether a comparison was done with the type specimen of Minervarya mysorensis, a species not seen since it was first described in 1922 and still known only from the same type locality (N. Modak pers. comm. October 2020).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Polypedates maculatus by Gogol and Sengupta (2017).
This species could be a synonym of Allopaa hazarensis (India Red List Assessment September 2020).
This species is likely to be a synonym of Fejervarya orissaensis, and taxonomic work is underway but confirmation is pending (Prudhvi Raj pers. comm. August 2020).

Padhye et al. (2015) considers records for Hydrophylax malabarica Haplogroup 1 from Biju et al. (2014) to belong to Hydrophylax bahuvistara. This may be a species complex (A. Padhye and C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. August 2020). Moved to Hylarana by Dubois et al. (2021).

Rao (1937) originally described this taxon as Philautus kottigeharensis based on a single specimen from Kottigehar. Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred the species from Philautus to Micrixalus. The holotype was lost and recently Bossuyt and Milinkovitch (2001) relocated the species from Bhadrea in Chicamangalore District very near to the type locality. 

Micrixalus narainensis and M. swamianus have been synonymised with this species by Biju et al. (2014).
Dubois (1992) removed this species from the synonymy of Paa blanfordii. Nanorana gammii was removed from the synonymy of this species and it is now considered a valid species (Ohler and Dubois 2006).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Nyctibatrachus anamallaiensis which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Biju et al. 2007).
This species was designated a lectotype, its range redelimited, and Nyctibatrachus sholai was synonymized within it by Biju et al. (2011).
Biju and Bossuyt (2009) synonymised Philautus neelanethrus with this species.
This species is very similar to Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni, and might be conspecific with it (Savage 2002). Taxonomic revision of this species is needed (B. Kubicki pers. comm. 2007).
There is a question as to whether both Pseudoeurycea orchileucos and Pseudoeurycea orchimelas are distinct, valid species.

The allopatry of the subpopulations from Uruguay and Brazil has led to the suggestion that it is more than one taxon (Camargo et al. 2005, Machado and Maltchik 2007, Lema and Martins 2011). It was long confused with Pleurodema thaul, until the work of Donoso-Barros (1969). In Paraguay, this taxon was previously confused with Physalaemus fuscomaculatus (Cei 1990, Kolenc et al. 2011).
It is likely that this form consists of two separate species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Pternohyla which was synonymized with Smilisca (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This is a split from the broader concept of Sarcohyla thorectes (Grünwald et al. 2019).

Recuero et al. (2006) partitioned this taxon out of former Pseudacris regilla (where it had been placed by Yarrow 1882) on the basis of mtDNA and allozyme evidence. However, Barrow et al. (2014) suggested that the distinction of this taxon was not supported by nuDNA analysis, thus highlighting a need for additional taxonomic work.

Recuero et al. (2006) partitioned this taxon out of former Pseudacris regilla on the basis of mtDNA and allozyme evidence, but did not detail the range and the zone of contact with both P. regilla and P. hypochondriaca. However, Barrow et al. (2014) suggested that the distinction of this taxon was not supported by nuDNA analysis, thus highlighting a need for additional taxonomic work..

A single subadult specimen (FMNH 64646) from the northeastern slopes of the Cordillera de Montecillos, Depto. Comayagua, was tentatively assigned to Bolitoglossa celaque sensu lato by McCranie and Wilson (2002), and, based on the presumed provenance of the specimen (ca 25 km NNE of the nearest locality for B. copinhorum), this specimen is tentatively referred to as B. copinhorum (Itgen et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eleutherodactylus nitidus (Grünwald et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eleutherodactylus cystignathoides (Grünwald et al. 2018).
Rhinella paraguayensis has been synonymised with this species by Pereyra et al. (2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
It may be a complex of species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

The forms spectabilis and simplex were elevated to species status by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002). These authors also resurrected the species Melanophryniscus pachyrhynus, formerly considered a synonym of M. tumifrons. Records from Cambará do Sul e Canela (Braun and Braun 1980), Santa Catarina state, now refer to Melanophryniscus simplex (Colombo et al. 2007). The current concept of M. tumifrons is considered a complex of additional undescribed species; and some of these subpopulations may be under some degree of threat (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).  It was formerly considered by some authors (i.e., Miranda Ribeiro 1926, Barrio 1962) to be a synonym of Hypsiboas pulchellus.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). It was removed from the synonymy of Hypsiboas pulchellus by Garcia et al. (2003). More than one species could be covered by this name.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). The recently described Hypsiboas curupi was previously confused under H. semiguttatus, which was redescribed by Garcia et al. (2007). This species was moved subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was synonymized with Trachycephalus by Faivovich et al. (2005). Garcia Marsà et al. (2020) reported the species from Argentina and discussed its range, however, this extension was based on a specimen of Kaloula pulchra (Microhylidae), according to Faivovich and Elias-Costa (2020).
The Argentinian population might be Phyllomedusa tetraploidea (see Pombal and Haddad 1992).
Some subpopulations formerly considered under Sphaenorhunchus surdus are now allocated to S. caramaschii (Toledo et al. 2007).
This species is a complex of several species requiring systematic revision (S.P. de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm.).
This species was removed from synonymy of Rhinella crucifer by Baldiserra et al. (2004).

In the Rhinella marina group according to the original publication. Rhinella achavali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Maneyro et al. 2004).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The taxonomy of this species remains confused and its identity is unclear (S.P. Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). Specimens from the state of Espirito Santo have been reassigned to Hypsiboas pombali by Weber (2009).
This is a restricted concept of Thoropa lutzi following the split of T. bryomantis by de Assis et al. (2021).

A strangely disjunct population from Óbidos, Pará State, Brazil, was described as a subspecies by Cochran (1948). Bokermann (1967) doubted the correctness of this locality and assumed that the specimens came from Itatiaia. Whatever the case may be, the species does not occur in Pará State; in fact there are no species from this genus in Pará (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
In the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication. In the Physalaemus olfersii group of Nascimento et al. (2005).

Sachsse et al. (1999), noted that this species was probably most closely related to Gastrotheca microdiscus, and transferred this species to Gastrotheca from Hyla, where it had been placed in the Hyla albomarginata group by Duellman (1970). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species has often been considered a subspecies of Rhinella granulosa (e.g. Gallardo 1965). Céspedez (2000) separated R. pygmaea into two species: R. pygmaea of coastal Brazil and R. bergi in the interior of the continent.

It is possible that Dendrophryniscus berthalutzae is synonymous with D. krausae. However, there is no available genetic material from specimens from Rio Grande do Sul to verify and confirm that it is the same species (P. Garcia pers. comm. 2021). For the time being, the former is considered to occur only in the state of Santa Catarina and the latter in the state of Rio Grande do Sul.

This species has taxonomic problems. It was previously confused with Melanophryniscus tumifrons prior to its description by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002). Subpopulations from Misiones, Argentina, formerly associated with this species (and included in its 2004 assessment) were believed by Baldo and Basso (2004) to pertain to Melanophryniscus aff. tumifrons and were excluded from the 2010 assessment. However, a study not yet submitted found strong evidence that this species needs to be synonymised with M. tumifrons (P. Colombo pers. comm. 2021).
There are concerns that Dendrophryniscus skuki may be synonymous with this species (V.G. Dill Orrico and M. Sole pers. comm. 2021).
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Aplastodiscus perviridis by Garcia et al. (2001).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Sachsse et al. (1999) suggested that it is a complex of more than one species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae by Faivovich et al. (2005). Gastrotheca fulvorufa was removed from the synonymy of G. microdiscus by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla by Faivovich et al. (2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

It was previously known as Hyla biobeba, but taxonomic research has shown that the older name of Hyla lundii is correct (Caramaschi and Napoli 1994). This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species (Napoli 2005) was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla by Faivovich et al. (2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). 

The taxonomic analyses of the D. decipiens lineage by Oliveira et al. (2021) suggest that records for D. haddadi along the Bahia and Pernambuco coasts (presumably including those of Alagoas and Sergipe) require molecular and acoustic analyses as they were identified based on external morphology and might correspond to D. tapacurensis sp. nov., "and showed that sequences identified as D. haddadi from Alagoas are genetically more related to the D. decipiens lineage VII of than topotypical sequences of D. haddadi".
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Estupiñán et al. 2016).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form might not be a valid species (M.T. Rodrigues pers. comm. 2004).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is a complex of a few species (S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm. 2003, V. Dill pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus ;Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and is in the D. decipiens group of Orrico et al. (2021). D. tapacurensis was split from the broader concept by Oliveira et al. (2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic identity of this species because it was described using morphological traits, but it bears great similarities to D. jimi with which it could be synonymous (V.G. Dill Orrico and B. Teixeira pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis by Pombal and Caramaschi (1995). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Nascimento et al. 2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Cruz 1991) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010), but was moved back to the genus Hylomantis (Duellman et al. 2016).

Two species are included under this name (A. Kwet pers. comm.). This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which has since been synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Blotto et al. (2021) suggested that the taxonomic status of this taxon relative to Trachycephalus dibernardoi requires additional study.
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which has since been synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Phrynomedusa fimbriata by Cruz (1985).
This is a reduced concept of Phrynomedusa marginata as many individuals previously assigned to this species have now been assigned to the newly described species P. dryade (Baêta et al. 2016).
This form is probably a complex of several species (O. L. Peixoto pers. comm.). Phyllodytes wuchereri was recently revalidated by Caramaschi et al. (2004).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Ramos et al. 2019).
This species was placed in the synonymy of Pseudis paradoxa by Gallardo (1961), but was re-validated by Caramaschi and Cruz (1998).
Caramaschi and Cruz (1998) revalidated this species and resurrected it from the synonymy of Pseudis paradoxa.
This species was removed from synonymy (as a subspecies) of Scinax catharinae by Peixoto (1988).

In the Scinax catharinae group of Faivovich et al. (2005). Many species in this group - including this one - require further taxonomic work to clarify the identity of certain records and the boundaries of their distributions.
This could be a complex of more than one species (C. Arzabe pers. comm.).
Haddad and Pombal (1987) removed this species from the synonymy of Scinax catharinae, without comment.
This species belongs to the Scinax ruber group of Pombal et al. (1995).

Many of the subspecies cited by Lutz (1973) and by Duellman (1977) are recognizable as distinct species. Although this taxon is probably composed of a complex of species, it was considered as a taxonomic unit for this assessment.
This species is probably a complex of several species (B. Pimenta pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
It is probably a complex of several species (A. Carnaval pers. comm.)

In the Scinax catharinae group of Faivovich et al. (2005). Many species in this group - including this one - require further taxonomic work to clarify the identity of certain records and the boundaries of their distributions.
The species name is a noun in apposition and therefore does not change with the gender of the generic name.
Peixoto (1988) noted that this name covers a complex of species.

Previously this name had not been assigned to a species group or to any known population in the wild (Duellman and Wiens 1992) as the holotype was lost. Pimenta et al. (2007) re-described the species and designated a neotype.
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus orophilus, according to the original description.

Araújo-Vieira et al. (2019) revised the Sphaenorhynchus genus based on molecular and morphological traits, including analysis of genetic material from the S. palustris type series, and based on the results limited S. palustris to its type locality. All other records of this species were assigned to S. botocudo, S. prasinus, S. planicola, S. mirim, or S. carnaeus (J.V. Lacerda, P. Peloso, F. Hepp, J. Gasparini pers. comm. October 2021).

This species was described under the genus Sphaenorhynchus, then moved to the genus Gabohyla (Araujo-vieira et al. 2020) and now it is back under Sphaenorhynchus again (Pereira et al. 2022). It is similar to Sphaenorhynchus prasinus, according to the original description.
Sphaenorhynchus orophilus was synonymized with this species by Araujo-Vieira et al. (2018).
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus planicola according to the original description. Indeed, their ranges overlap in Bahia and Espirito Santo (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
This species is composed of several cryptic species (A. Kwet pers. comm.).
This species is an octoploid species most closely related to Ceratophrys ornata according to Mercedal de Barrio (1986), but it is genetically distinct.

Records from the Serra da Jibóia, municipality of Amargosa, Bahia State over 500 km to the southwest have been proposed as belonging to this species (V.G. Dill Orrico pers. comm. 2021). However, there are questions about the validity of these records owing to the distance from the type locality. They are excluded from this concept pending confirmation of their identity.
The records of this species are old and there is no new material to compare and certify the identity of the species (P. Garcia pers. comm. Brazil Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This could be a species complex composed of at least three lineages. It is uncertain whether all records in the state of Paraná refer to this species. A new species is being described for the Babitonga region (J. Monteiro pers. comm. 2021).

authority: Segalla, Berneck, Canedo, Caramaschi, Cruz, Garcia, Grant, Haddad, Lourenço, Mângia, Mott, Nascimento, Toledo, Werneck & Langone, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This concept previously bore the name Cycloramphus carvalhoi (Heyer 1983). Following the accidental confusion between Zachaenus carvalhoi and Cycloramphus carvalhoi due to changes made by Dubois et al. (2021), C. carvalhoi has been renamed as C. heyeri (Segalla et al. 2021).

Sampling efforts and the use of integrative taxonomy tools are needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Records from Paraná and São Paulo States could be another species instead of Cycloramphus izecksohni (Brazil Red List Assessment 2021).
This species has been moved to the genus Phantasmarana by Vittorazzi et al. (2021).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Cycloramphus asper by Heyer (1983).

Canedo and Haddad (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this species is not an Eleutherodactylus or Ischnocnema, but rather of uncertain position, likely close to Noblella + Barycholos within Holoadeninae (Frost 2015). This species was transferred from Eleutherodactylus to Bahius under the Stabomantidae by Dubois et al. (2021).

In 2004, Ischnocnema guentheri was known to occur in Argentina and Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. Kwet and Solé (2005) removed I. henselii from the synonymy of I. guentheri and reassigned the subpopulations from Argentina and some from Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina, Brazil to I. henselii. However, the map in the 2008 Red List assessment did not remove these records in error. This is corrected in the 2021 map. Gehara et al. (2013) subsequently assigned additional records of I. guentheri from Santa Catarina, Paraná, and São Paulo to I. henselii. In addition to this, Gehara et al. (2013) also identified that some records from Santa Catarina, Paraná, São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, and Minas Gerais states also belong to four other unnamed species (represented as Candidate Species 1–4 in Gehara et al. 2013). These subpopulations are retained within the distribution map until they are formally assigned to other species and coded as Presence Uncertain. Therefore, this concept of Ischnocnema guentheri is restricted to an area within the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

This is a restricted concept of Ischnocnema lactea, that occurs only from São Paulo State. The subpopulations from Minas Gerais, Rio de Janeiro and Espírito Santo states refer to other species, not yet named (Thomé et al. 2020).
This is a complex comprising many species (C.A.G. Cruz pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Canedo and Haddad (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this species falls within the Pristimantis conspicillatus group and may represent a species complex. Included in the P. conspicillatus species group by Padial et al. (2014).

A record for Alagoas, Brazil, provided by Lima and Skuk (2006) may represent P. ramagii. Napoli et al. (2009) provided additional karyological evidence for the distinctiveness of this taxon from P. ramagii and discussed the lack of any definitive morphological features between the two species. This record is omitted from the distribution of this concept.

Records from Sergipe are considered misidentifications and in fact to belong to P. vinhai (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species is in the Ischnocnema parva group of Hedges et al. (2008), Canedo and Haddad (2012), and Padial et al. (2014). There are concerns about its validity.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species and requires taxonomic investigation (Trevisan et al. 2020).
The grammatically incorrect name Hylodes asperus has had some use.

The 2004 assessment reported that this concept "might be a complex of more than one species." Since that time, the 2004 distribution, which extended from the state of Rio de Janeiro to the northeastern corner of the state of Santa Catarina has been revised and records reassigned to species in the Hylodes nasus and H. lateristrigatus groups. For example, inland Rio de Janeiro state records belong to H. lateristrigatus (de Sá et al. 2015); other coastal records from Rio de Janeiro and northeastern São Paulo states belong to H. asper (Canedo and Pombal-Jr. 2007); southeastern São Paulo and eastern Paraná states belong to H. cardosoi (Lingnau et al. 2008); records from Santa Catarina state belong to H. perplicatus (Lingnau et al. 2008).
Lynch (1972) provides a discussion on the nomenclatural confusion surrounding this species, together with a re-description of the holotype.
This form was previously included within Leptodactylus latinasus, but it is now considered to be a distinct species.
Leptodactylus jolyi was redescribed on the basis of adult morphology and calls (Giaretta and Costa 2007).

This species is in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex. It is well delimited after a recent review of the Leptodactylus melanonotus group, however, not yet published (T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020). Formerly called Leptodactylus melanonotus or L. petersii, L. leptodactyloides and Leptodactylus sp. along the Cerrado. Occurrences in the Cerrado were not included in the systematic review published by de Sá et al. (2014).

In the Leptodactylus fuscus species group, L. mystaceus complex, of de Sá et al. (2014). 

This concept is a complex of several undescribed species. L. watu and L. barrioi have been removed from synonymy (Alves da Silva et al. 2020). The records currently assigned to L. cf. mystaceus (Alves da Silva et al. 2020), L. aff. mystaceus (Santana et al. 2010), L. aff. spixi (Ferreira et al. 2019, Rödder et al. 2007, Silva-Soares and Scherrer 2013, Pereira-Ribeiro et al. 2019) are included in this concept as 'Presence Uncertain' until further taxonomic work assigns them to new species.
In the Leptodactylus latrans group of de Sá et al. (2014). This species is a complex of at least three undescribed species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species has been moved to the genus Phantasmarana by Vittorazzi et al. (2021).
Lavilla et al. (2000) do not recognize the presence of this species in Argentina, and there are no specimens from Paraguay in the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural del Paraguay.
As suggested by Amaro et al. (2009), the species Odontophrynus salvatory was formally transfered to the genus Proceratophrys (Magalhães et al. 2020).
This concept is a complex of at least three species (Santos et al. 2020).
This species is a complex comprising several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.). Records from Argentina are apparently based on confusion with Physalaemus biligonigerus.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Pseudopaludicola falcipes by Haddad and Cardoso (1987).
This species was discussed as Thoropa sp. by Maxson and Heyer (1982). It is close to Thoropa miliaris according to the original description.

Following the accidental confusion between Zachaenus carvalhoi and Cycloramphus carvalhoi due to changes made by Dubois et al. (2021), C. carvalhoi has been renamed as C. heyeri and there has been no change in the name of this concept following Segalla et al. (2021).
This taxon is a complex containing several undescribed species (Jennings et al. 2015).

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: When Syncope carvalhoi Nelson 1975 was transferred to Chiasmocleis, the existing C. carvalhoi (Cruz et al. 1997) became a homonym and hence a replacement name was assigned to it by Peloso et al. (2014).
This species is a tetraploid species according to Kasahara and Haddad (1997).
Albuquerque and Izecksohn (2001) separated the populations from Rio de Janeiro as a separate species, reviving the previous name Stereocyclops parkeri.
Albuquerque and Izecksohn (2001) separated the subpopulations of Stereocyclops incrassatus from Rio de Janeiro as a separate species, reviving the previous name Stereocyclops parkeri.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is probably conspecific with Siphonops paulensis.

authority: Ribeiro, Alves, Haddad and Dos Reis, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was separated from Bokermannohyla circumdata (Napoli 2005). It was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was described by reallocation of some specimens originally allocated to Phyllodytes tuberculosus (Caramaschi and Peixoto 2004).

This species was confused with Scinax duartei prior to its description (Pugliese et al. 2004). This concept is a complex comprised of several undescribed species and there remains uncertainty regarding its distribution and that of S. duartei and S. rogerioi (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Hylodes pipilans differs from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Canedo and Pombal 2007).
Brachycephalus alipioi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Pombal and Gasparini 2006).
Leptodactylus sertanejo is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of both morphological characters and advertisement call features (Giaretta and Costa 2007).

Phyllomedusa bahiana was elevated to full species status by Silva-Filho and Juncá (2006) on the basis of differences in vocalizations and tadpole morphology.

Andrade et al. (2018) could not distinguish this species from Phyllomedusa burmeisteri on the basis of morphometrics or acoustic parameters but did not suggest a taxonomic change.
In the Bokermannohyla circumdata group according to the original publication.
Proceratophrys paviotii is related to Proceratophrys boiei. It can be differentiated from the latter species by morphological and advertisement call data (Cruz et al. 2005).
Brachycephalus pombali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colour features (Alves et al. 2006).

A member of the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication. It can be differentiated from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Weber et al. 2006).
Gastrotheca pulchra can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Caramaschi and Rodrigues 2007).
Frostius erythrophthalmus can be distinguished from F. pernambucensis by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Pimenta and Caramaschi 2007).

In the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group according to the original publication. Phyllomedusa nordestina was distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Caramaschi 2006). This species has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016). P. gonzagai was split from the broader concept of this species by Andrade et al. (2020).
In the Scinax perpusillus group. Scinax peixotoi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and distinct advertisement call (Brasileiro et al. 2007).
Scinax camposseabrai was revalidated by Caramaschi and Cardoso (2006) based on morphological comparisons.
In the Physalaemus signifer group. The species can be distinguished from others by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Pimenta et al. 2005).
Adenomera nana was revalidated based on bioacoustic data (Kwet 2007).
Hylodes fredi is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Canedo and Pombal 2007).
Chiasmocleis mantiqueira can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).

In the Physalaemus signifer species group according to the original publication. Physalaeumus irroratus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Cruz et al. 2007).
In the Cycloramphus eleutherodactylus group. It can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

In the Rhinella marina group, Rhinella cerradensis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (adult and tadpole), colour patterns and advertisement call features (Maciel et al. 2007). Ferraro et al. (2018) noted problematic subpopulations of Rhinella cf. cerradensis in Argentina. The taxonomic status of these subpopulations still needs to be defined, so they have not been included in this assessment.
In the Chiasmocleis leucosticta group according to the original publication. Chiasmocleis sapiranga is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).
In the Scinax perpusillus group according to the original publication. Scinax faivovichi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

Phyllodytes maculosus is believed to be related to Phyllodytes kautskyi. It is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Cruz et al. 2006).

Specimens named as P. maculosus would actually represent one of the morphs of P. kautskyi (Novaes-e-Fagundes and Solé 2021).

In the Crossodactylus gaudichaudii group according to the original description. Crossodactylus cyclospinus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological and advertisement call features (Nascimento et al. 2005).
This is a species complex (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
In the Leptodactylus fuscus species group according to the original description (Caramaschi et al. 2008).

Associated with the Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus group according to the original description (Cruz and Fusinatto 2008). 

Species in this genus are very difficult to differentiate morphologically. Because no molecular analysis has been conducted on genetic material from this species, and there are no obvious geographic barriers between it and congener D. berthalutzae, it is possible that these are synonymous (P. Garcia pers. comm. 2021). Taxonomic work is therefore needed to confirm the validity of this concept.
There is a taxonomic issue with this species: Phasmahyla timbo may be synonymous with P. spectabilis (D. Baêta and I. Dias pers. comm. 2021).
There is a taxonomic issue with this species: Phasmahyla timbo may be synonymous with P. spectabilis (D. Baêta and I. Dias pers. comm. 2021).
In the Physalaemus olfersii species group according to the original description (Cruz et al. 2008).
There is considerable uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species, which is currently under investigation (V.G. Dill Orrico pers. comm. 2021).

This is a restricted concept of A. marmorata following the split of the broader concept into this and A. simonstuarti (Angulo and Icochea 2010). Kwet (2007) removed Adenomera nana from synonymy with Adenomera marmorata and suggested that two undescribed species existed under this name within Santa Catarina and Paraná, Brazil. Cassini et al. (2020) rejected that Adenomera marmorata is a complex of species.
Bokermannohyla feioi has been placed in synonymy with this species (Walker et al. 2015).
Proceratophrys renalis has been revalidated and removed from the synonymy of P. boiei by Prado and Pombal, Jr. (2008).
This was split from Thoropa miliaris by Feio et al. (2006).

This is a restricted concept following the split of Thoropa taophora by Feio et al. (2006). This form remains a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Cholak et al. 2020).

authority: Araujo-Vieira, Lacerda, Pezzuti, Leite, Assis, & Cruz, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pelobates syriacus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).

authority: Suwannapoom, Sumontha, Tunprasert, Ruangsuwan, Pawangkhanant, Korost & Poyarkov, 2018

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Sylvirana nigrovittata (Sheridan and Stuart 2018). The species is now placed under the the genus Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Sylvirana nigrovittata (Sheridan and Stuart 2018). The species is now placed under the the genus Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Sylvirana nigrovittata (Sheridan and Stuart 2018). The species is now placed under the the genus Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).

authority: Poyarkov, Suwannapoom, Pawangkhanant, Aksornneam, Duong, Korost & Che, 2018

taxonomicNotes: This species shares many similar morphological traits with Dendropsophus pseudomeridianus, and further taxonomic work is needed to investigate their relationship to each other (Orrico et al. 2021).

authority: Poyarkov, Suwannapoom, Pawangkhanant, Aksornneam, Duong, Korost & Che, 2018
Poyarkov, Suwannapoom, Pawangkhanant, Aksornneam, Duong, Korost & Che, 2018
Grismer, Wood, Quah, Thura, Espinoza, Grismer, Murdoch & Lin, 2018

taxonomicNotes: The subpopulation in the "South Island" of Haiti may likely comprise a new taxon, currently under study (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021). Therefore, the true distribution of Osteopilus vastus may exclude Haiti and the southern portion of the Dominican Republic. However, for the purposes of this assessment, this subpopulation is included in the current assessment until such time as it is formally described.
The subpopulations on the Tiburon Peninsula probably represent an undescribed species (R. Thomas pers. comm.).
Lavilla et al. (2010) determined that the species formerly referred to as Osteopilus brunneus is in fact Osteopilus ocellatus, making O. brunneus a junior synonym of O. ocellatus.
This species can be distinguished from similar species by a combination of morphometrics, body colouration, advertisement call features and habitat association (Rios-López and Thomas 2007).

authority: Díaz, Incháustegui, Marte, Köhler, Cádiz & Rodríguez, 2018
taxonomicNotes: It is suspected that this taxon represents a species complex (Hispaniola Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
Two of the subspecies of Peltophryne longinasus (dunni and ramsdeni) have been elevated to species status (Hedges et al. 2019).
Two of the subspecies of Peltophryne longinasus (dunni and ramsdeni) have been elevated to species status (Hedges et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Sylvirana nigrovittata (Sheridan and Stuart 2018). The species is now placed under the the genus Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

authority: Pham, Sung, Pham, Le, Ziegler & Nguyen, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously reported to occur in Cyprus, however, following genetic analysis, these records are now assigned to Pelophylax cypriensis, previously confused under this name (Plötner et al. 2012).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was described from a single population and may be a synonym of D. jimi, a species morphologically indistinguishable from D. cerradensis and known from several locations in the southern part of the Cerrado, including the municipality of Campo Grande, in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul. Taxonomic and genetic studies are needed to determine whether this species is valid and has a restricted distribution, or whether it is a synonym of D. jimi (P.H. Valdujo pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
Boana phaeopleura was synonymized with this species by Faivovich et al. (2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously in the genus Hyla, but was then moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005). Duellman et al. (2016) created the new genus Julianus for the species in the Scinax uruguayus group, but this assessment follows Baldo et al. (2019) in considering Julianus as a synonym of Scinax.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There are taxonomic uncertainties between B. sazimai and B. nanuzae (P. Garcia pers. comm. 2021).
This name is a complex of several species, which ongoing taxonomic work is starting to resolve (I.F. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
This species is similar to Proceratophrys cristiceps and P. goyana according to the original description.

Carvalho et al. (2015) suggested that on the basis of morphology and acoustic characteristics that Pseudopaludicola parnaiba is not diagnosable from Pseudopaludicola canga but did not make the taxonomic change. Recently it was considered as a junior synonym of P. canga by Andrade et al. (2020).

Bokermann (1952) suggested that Chiasmocleis centralis is allied with C. shudikarensis, but Carvalho (1954), suggested an affinity with C. albopunctata. It has been described from poorly preserved collection-type material and has not been found in the field since the collection of the type specimens in 1950, despite sampling efforts in the region. It is possible that it is a synonym of C. albopunctata, however, morphological and molecular studies are needed before this can be confirmed.

There is a single historical record of the species from central Mato Grosso in the ICMBio database, but this is likely a misidentification and belongs to Elachistocleis matogrosso or E. corumbaensis (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
In the genus Rhinella following Frost (2007). Rhinella veredas can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Brandão et al. 2007).

In the Scinax ruber clade according to the original publication. Scinax cabralensis is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and a distinct advertisement call (Drummond et al. 2007).
Ischnocnema penaxavantinho is diagnosed on the basis of adult morphology, advertisement call, and ecology (Giaretta et al. 2007).

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological populations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including this one.
This species has been identified as part of the Proceratophrys cristiceps group (Martins and Giaretta 2011).
This was previously considered a subspecies of Hyla arborea, until it was elevated to species status by Stöck et al. (2008).

authority: Dinesh, Vijayakumar, Ramesh, Jayarajan, Chandramouli & Shanker, 2020

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously considered to be part of the Lissotriton vulgaris species complex, and is now recognized as a distinct species (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009).

This is a split from the broader concept of Sarcohyla pentheter (Kaplan et al. 2020). Campbell et al. (2018:378) assigned the only known specimen (IBH 138072) of S. floresi from Estado de Mexico (then S. pentheter) to S. hapsa “based on distribution and morphology,” but did not report which characters they examined. Kaplan et al. (2020) found that this specimen has the diagnostic characters of S. floresi, and thus assign it to that species.

authority: Schneider, Cardozo, Brusquetti, Kolenc, Borteiro, Haddad, Basso & Baldo, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Leptodactylus mystacinus (Schneider et al. 2019).
This is a restricted concept of Polypedates maculatus following the split of the broader concept into this and P. himalayensis (Gogol and Sengupta 2017).

Pristimantis charlottevillensis differs from other Caribbean and South American members of the genus by its vocalizations, morphology, sexual size dimorphism, and chromosome complement. This is a presumed sister taxon to P. terraebolivaris (Kaiser et al. 1995).

There is uncertainty about the taxonomic status of this name in Venezuela. Pristimantis urichi was listed by Rivero (1964), but that name was misapplied according to Kaiser et al. (1994) and Barrio-Amorós et al. (2007) because P. urichi is indeed restricted to the island of Trinidad (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010). J. Hardy (pers. comm.) has seen specimens from Venezuela in North American institutions; these are in poor condition and are misidentifications of P. urichi.

authority: Anstis, Price, Roberts, Catalano, Hines, Doughty & Donnellan, 2016
taxonomicNotes:
This is a split from the broader concept of Cyclorana platycephala (Anstis et al. 2016).

We depart from the placement of this species within Ranoidea as proposed by Frost (2020) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species was previously considered as belonging to an indeterminate subspecies of Bufo verrucosissimus (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Historical records in Iran assigned to Bufo bufo may also represent this species (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Iranian records are included in this assessment on the basis that their affinities are uncertain, but probably don't represent true Bufo bufo (Litvinchuk et al. 2008).

This account follows the suggested Salamandra monophyletic group distribution presented in Steinfartz et al. (2000). Populations in the eastern part of the range might represent a separate species (S. semenovi).
Largen (2001) emended the name from Afrixalus clarkei to Afrixalus clarkeorum. However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.6, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2013).

This species was elevated from subspecies level of Zhangixalus dennysi by Ohler (2009). Rhacophorus gongshanensis was synonymised with Rhacophorus taronensis by Wilkinson and Rao (2004), the latter which was subsequently synonymised with this species by Ohler (2009).

This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Alcalus sariba (Brown et al. 2015). 

There may be a zone of sympatry for this species and Alcalus sariba in the northern Sarawak and Brunei area, but this needs requires further research for verification (I. Das pers. comm March 2018).

This is a split from the broader concept of Alcalus baluensis by Brown et al. (2015), who recognised this species as distinct and placed it in this genus (it was previously known as Ingerana baluensis - Inger and Tan 1996).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Allobates brunneus by Silverstone (1971).
Most of the recent publications have treated this as a species of Spinophrynoides (Gower et al. 2012).

This species was previously considered to be a nomen dubium by Bain et al. (2003), but was recognised as a distinct species by Ohler and Deuti (2018). The lectotype was identified as the species Rhacophorus maximus, so it has been synonymized under this species by Ohler and Deuti (2018).

authority: Serrano-Rojas, Whitworth, Villacampa-Ortega, von May, Gutiérrez, Padial & Chaparro, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and now also includes the name Amietia amieti.
Formerly known as Amietia angolensis and, potentially, partially Amietia viridireticulata, which has now been synonymized under Amieita tenuoplicata (Channing et al. 2016).
This name was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and includes A. lubrica.
The species occurs in sympatry with Amietia nutti (Channing et al. 2016).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).
The taxonomic status of this species requires resolution as it is likely to comprise several species  (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

This species can only reliably be distinguished from Anodonthyla boulengerii with detailed morphological examination. It is therefore impossible to establish with certainty which historical records of A. boulengerii refer instead to this recently-diagnosed species (M. Vences pers. comm. December 2010).
Anodonthyla vallani was recognised as a distinct species by Vences et al. (2010), having previously been confused with A. nigrigularis.

A taxonomic review of this species is urgently required, since it almost certainly comprises more than one species [e.g. Ansonia latiffi, previously synonymized under A. leptopus, was recently described from Pahang, West Malaysia (Wood et al. 2008)].

Blackburn (2008) stated that its molecular data indicates this species is actually Arthroleptis aureoli and it was reported as a direct developer, which confirms it as belonging to the genus Arthroleptis (M.-O. Rodel pers. comm. June 2012).

This species was treated as belonging to Arthroleptis adolfifriederici prior to its formal description (Perret, 1966; Amiet, 1975). Confusion may also have occurred with A. variabilis (Blackburn et al. 2009).

In West Africa, at least two species are included under this name (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is very likely that all subpopulations in western African, from Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Guinea and Ghana, are distinct from those in central Africa and will be described as new species or assigned to other species in the future (Rödel and Bangoura 2004, Ernst et al. 2008, Blackburn et al. 2009).

It is also thought that all records of this species west of Nigeria are misidentifications (Rödel et al. 2009).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. Given taxonomic uncertainties, individuals collected outside of the East Usambaras are not referrable to Arthroleptis xenodactylus (J. Poynton and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012), but to the more widespread species A. xenodactyloides or currently undescribed species.

authority: Rödel, Hillers, Leaché, Kouamé, Ofori-Boateng, Diaz & Sandberger, 2012
taxonomicNotes: The sister taxon of Astylosternus occidentalis and confused with that species prior to its naming according to the original publication (Frost 2014).

authority: De la Riva, Castroviejo-Fisher, Chaparro, Boistel & Padial, 2011

taxonomicNotes: The name Boophis difficilis was previously used incorrectly for this species, B. difficilis in fact being a synonym of B. tephraeomystax (Glaw et al. 2001).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).

There is a specimen that has been collected in central Democratic Republic of the Congo, which has been assigned to Cardioglossa gratiosa, that possibly belongs to this species (Hirschfeld et al. 2015). However, it is far from this species' type locality (>850 km) and there is currently a lack of genetic data to verify this (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
We follow Jdeidi et al. (2001), Plötner and Ohst (2001) and Plötner et al. (2001) in treating this as a species distinct from Pelophylax bedriagae.
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Mertensiella lushchani. It has now been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
Chiasmocleis magnova can be distinguished from other similar species through a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Moravec and Köhler 2007).
This is a restricted concept of Tylototriton vietnamensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Tylototriton pasmansi (Bernades et al. 2020).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This is some doubt as to the taxonomic assignment of the subpopulations from Yoro and Olancho Departments, based on differences in habitat and biogeographic patterns (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
In the Craugastor alfredi group. Craugastor cyanochthebius differs from all other species in the group by a combination of morphological characters (McCranie and Smith 2006).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

Cryptobatrachus remotus (Infante-Rivero et al. 2009 "2008"), could be a junior synonym of this species based on preliminary evidence (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015, Meza Joya pers. comm. August 2016).

Subpopulations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Gracixalus sapaensis (Matsui et al. 2017).
Was previously treated under the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species belong to the Gephyromantis asper group and was previously confused with Gephyromantis ambohitra (Frost 2015).

authority: Coloma, Carvajal-Endara, Dueñas, Paredes-Recalde, Morales-Mite, Almeida-Reinoso, Tapia, Hutter, Toral-Contreras & Guayasamin, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloscirtus larinopygion (Coloma et al. 2012).
The taxonomic distinctiveness of this species needs confirmation. Historically, all unstriped Ichthyophis from Southeast Asia were assigned to this species (Taylor 1968).
Records of Ingerophrynus biporcatus from mainland Southeast Asia probably refer to this species, and are treated as such here.
This is a split from the broader concept of K. baleata (Chan et al. 2014).
This is a species complex which may comprise at least two distinct evolutionary lineages (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).
We follow Perret (1985) and Rödel et al. (2002) in considering this to be a species distinct from Kassina cochranae.
According to Amiet (2007), this species was removed from the synonymy of Kassina maculosa.

This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella dringi following the split of the broader concept into this, L. fritinniens (Dehling and Matsui 2013) and L. sabahmontana (Leptolalax sabahmontanus - Matsui et al. 2014).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and L. platycephala (as Leptolalax platycephalus - Dehling 2012).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella hamidi (formerly Leptolalax) following the split of the broader concept into this and L. marmoratus (Matsui et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept following the recognition of Leptobrachella juliandringi as a separate species (Eto et al. 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax dringi (Matsui et al. 2014). This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
Taxonomic work is required to verify whether both subpopulations belong to this species, or whether they belong to two different species (I. Das and Y.M. Pui pers. comm. March 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachium abbotti (Hamidy and Matsui 2014).
This species was confused with Leptobrachium hasseltii prior to its naming (Brown et al. 2010 "2009")
Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here treated as a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)).

This species is not mentioned in the review of African treefrogs by Schiøtz (1999), nor in the Field Guide to the Amphibians of Central and Southern Africa by Channing (2001). It might not be a valid species (Schiøtz pers. comm.).

This species is only known from the original description (Parker, 1936), from a single female specimen of the escarpment forest of Kwanza Sul. It was considered as the escarpment forest representative of the widespread Leptopelis aubryi in the rain forest. Further research is needed to decide on the validity of this species.

Taxonomic studies are needed to determine the status of the various subpopulations of this species. The subpopulation on Mindoro Island is considered to be a different species to that of the other subpopulations in the Philippines, and further taxonomic work is required to verify its identity (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018).
The Sulawesi subpopulations previously referred to this species belong to another Limnonectes species (Setiadi et al. 2011, Iskandar et al. 2014).
Candidate species from the subgenus Brygoomantis (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megophrys montana by Iskandar (1998), where it had been placed by Inger (1954).
This species has been moved from the genus Borneophrys to Megophrys, following the synonymy of the former genus with the latter by Chen et al. (2016).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megophrys montana by Iskandar (1998), where it had been placed previously by Inger (1954).

This is a restricted concept of Meristogenys amoropalamus following the split of the broader concept into this and Meristogenys dyscritus (Shimada et al. 2011). Shimada et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence for at least three cryptic species in addition to nominal Meristogenys amoropalamus.
This genus is thought to be in the same clade as Phrynella and further investigation into this matter should be undertaken (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This species might be synonymous with Microhyla palmipes (see Berry 1975). However, Iskandar (pers. comm.) considers that it is a separate species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Bufotes variabilis, with the latter now synonymised with B. viridis (Dufresnes et al. 2019). While currently recognized as a distinct species, there is still ongoing discussion whether it may be a subspecies of Bufotes viridis (Speybroeck et al. 2020).

According to Stöck et al. (2001) this is a member of the Pseudepidalea viridis subgroup. The Bufo viridis group is now treated under Bufotes. It is partly in sympatry with Bufotes turanensis, which is sometimes confused with the species.
Elevated from subspecies level of Lissotriton vulgaris by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2009).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nothophryne baylissi, and N. ribauensis (Conradie et al. 2018).
Sivongxay et al. (2016) maintain this species as Nyctixalus spinosus.
It is considered as a species complex (W. Bolívar pers comm. 2016).
Nymphargus puyoensis has been synonymized under this species by Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin (2014).
A taxonomic review of the specimens assigned to this taxon (especially those of Sumatran origin) is recommended.

A recent expedition to the eastern peninsula of Sulawesi recorded a species that is presumably closely related to Occidozyga semipalmata, however due to issues regarding its generic position, it remains undescribed (Iskandar et al. 2011).
Additional work differentiating this species from nearby populations of Ambystoma velasci is needed (Shaffer and McKnight 1996).

Based on both allozymes and mtDNA, this is a very distinctive salamander (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.). The Ambystoma salamanders occurring in other natural lakes around Alchichica are not closely related to this species.

Based on both allozymes and mtDNA, this is one of the more differentiated of the Mexican Ambystoma species; morphologically, it has evolved a superficially similar body plan to the distantly related A. dumerilii from Lago Pátzcuaro (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).
There is a question as to whether both Pseudoeurycea orchileucos and Pseudoeurycea orchimelas are distinct, valid species.
Specimens of this species have been included in Pseudoeurycea smithi by some previous authors (Parra-Olea et al. 2005).
The sister taxon of, and previously confused with, Oedipina gephrya according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012

taxonomicNotes: We acknowledge the discussion in Sanguila et al. (2016) regarding the morphological variation in Oreophryne species and maintain the restricted range of this species on the island of Camiguin (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This is the revised taxonomic concept for this species. Records from Peninsular Malaysia are now thought to belong to either Pelophryne signata or an undescribed new species (Chan et al. 2010, Chan et al. unpubl. data).

From genetic analysis, both this species and Philautus vittiger may belong to another genus (D. T. Iskandar and A. Hamidy pers. comm. Indonesian Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). However further taxonomic research is required to verify this. Due to morphological similarities, there is also some confusion over identifying this species and P. vittiger in the field and there is uncertainty that these two species are distinct (A. Hamidy pers. comm. Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This is the only Philautus species known on Mindoro Island, but additional records of Philautus-like specimens were made during surveys at Mount Calavite, Mount Halcon, Mount Baco, Abra de Ilog, Sablayan, and Blue Mountain between 2005-2017; these are tentatively assigned to this species but require analysis and confirmation of their identity as they may represent undescribed species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

authority: Ofori-Boateng, Leaché, Obeng-Kankam, Kouamé, Hillers & Rödel, 2018
Rödel, Burger, Zassi-Boufou, Emmrich, Penner, & Barej, 2015
taxonomicNotes: There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Phrynobatrachus ruthbeateae due to morphological similarities (Rödel et al. 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Phrynobatrachus steindachneri (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
This species is probably a synonym of Phrynobatrachus werneri (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.).
This species is a taxonomic complex and contains several cryptic species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

authority: Brown, De Layola, Lorenzo, Diesmos & Diesmos, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Pristimantis flavobracatus has been synonymized with this species (Catenazzi and Lehr 2018).

authority: Ortega-Andrade, Rojas-Soto, Valencia, Espinosa de los Monteros, Morrone, Ron & Cannatella, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Pristimantis limocochensis was originally confused with P. acuminatus (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).
Tentatively placed in the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Duellman and Chaparro 2008).

authority: Moravec, Lehr, Perez-Peña, Lopez, Gagliardi-Urrutia & Arista-Tuanama, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).

The holotype of Hynobius stejnegeri Dunn, 1923, the name for this species for almost 100 years, was found by Matsui et al. (2017) to be a member of the species known as H. yatsui Oyama, 1947, taking priority over that name and requiring a new name for this species, namely H. ikioi.
This is a split from the broader concept of Pulchrana grandocula (Brown 2015).
This species was formerly classified as Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014).

Previous taxonomic uncertainties regarding this species have now been resolved and its taxonomic status appears to be valid (Brown et al. 2011). It is considered to be in the Ranitomeya vanzolinii species group by Brown et al. (2011).
Ranitomeya intermedia is now considered to be a junior synonym of Ranitomeya imitator (Brown et al. 2011).

This species was originally thought to be a morph of Ranitomeya flavovittata based on a similar dorsal pattern. However, it possessed one unusual characteristic in that its limbs were solid bronze and lacked black markings. Based on additional specimens collected in 2009, Perez-Peña et al. (2010) determined that this unusual color pattern is a fixed trait within the population, and that this species is distinct from R. flavovittata on the basis of both morphology and genetics.

This is a restricted concept of Rhacophorus gauni following the split of the broader concept into this and Rhacophorus malkmusi. The two species occur sympatrically at Poring Hot Springs on the eastern slope of Gunung Kinabalu.
Rhinella manu can be distinguished from all known Rhinella by a unique combination of external and osteological characters as well as by molecular data (Chaparro et al. 2007).
This species is assigned to the festae species group (Moravec et al. 2014).
This is likely to represent a species complex (C. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
The sister species of Rhombophryne testudo according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful, and it might be a complex of several species (F. Andreone, F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm.).
It is not clear that the populations on the mainland of Madagascar belong to the same species as those on Nosy Be and Nosy Komba (M. Vences, F. Glaw, F. Andreone and C.J. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
This species has been split from the broader concept of Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014).

authority: Fuiten, Welton, Diesmos, Barley, Oberheide, Duya, Rico & Brown, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

authority: (Barej, Schmitz, Menegon, Hillers, Hinkel, Böhme & Rödel, 2011)
taxonomicNotes:
Formerly considered under the Amietophrynus superciliaris species complex, Amietophrynus channingi has been elevated to full species status (Barej et al. 2011). The biological populations that had been formerly assigned to A. superciliaris in eastern Lower Guinea now correspond to A. channingi (Barej et al. 2011).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

This nominal form is considered to be a complex of several species (V. Gvozdik pers. comm., November 2012) and as a result has been confused with numerous cryptic species in the lowland forests of Central Africa (E. Greenbaum pers. comm. May 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
Removed from synonymy with Staurois guttatus by Arifin et al. (2011).

authority: Klages, Glaw, Köhler, Müller, Hipsley & Vences, 2013
Glaw, Vallan, Andreone, Edmonds, Dolch & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Removed from synonymy under Stumpffia psologlossa by Köhler et al. (2010).
Hynobius tenuis was synonymized with this species by Matsui et al. (2002).
There are two subspecies: Bufo japonicus japonicus and B.j. formosus.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Hynobius boulengeri by Nishikawa et al. 2007.
Aoki et al. (2013) suggested that this is a species complex.

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014
