taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been regarded as a subpopulation of Ecnomiohyla rabborum, but is now regarded as a distinct species as a result of morphology and molecular examination of specimens (Batista et al. 2014).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa et al. 2013).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Poyarkov et al. 2012).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Onychodactylus japonicus until it was described by Yoshikawa and Matsui (2013).

We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in separating this species from Microhyla ornata. Tominaga et al. (2019) demonstrated that this nominal taxon is composed of four lineages. The lineage from the Southern Ryukyus has recently been described as Microhyla kuramotoi (Matsui and Tominaga 2020).
This species was considered a subpopulation of Glandirana rugosa prior to its description by Sekiya, Miura and Ogata (2012).
The population on Amami Island formerly identified as Odorrana ishikawae has been identified by Kuramoto et al. (2011) as a separate species named O. splendida.
According to Kuramoto et al. (2011) this species was confused with Odorrana ishikawae prior to its naming.
Matsui and Maeda (2018) elevated the two subspecies into two distinct species Rhacophorus viridis and Rhacophorus amamiensis supported by molecular phylogenetic analysis (Matsui et al. 2019).
Genetic analysis by Nishizawa et al. (2011) documented three distinctive haplotype regions (Eastern, Central, and Western Japan) that may correspond to separate species.

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011).

This is the only surviving species of an ancient lineage from the early evolutionary history of the endemic family Mantellidae. It is therefore evolutionarily distinct and should be a high priority for efforts preserving Malagasy amphibian biodiversity.

This species is one of a group of cryptic species resembling Xenopus fraseri but which is distinguished from it by chromosome number (2n = 72) and a mating call of a single note (found elsewhere within the genus only in X. borealis).

Uniquely among vertebrates (except Xenopus eysoole, X. kobeli and X. ruwenzoriensis), this is a dodecaploid species, and it is therefore of considerable scientific interest. It was probably formed by both hybridization and polyploidization (Loumont and Kobel 1991).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

This species has recently been identified as pertaining to Hynobius naevius yatsui and has been elevated to full species rank (Tominaga and Matsui 2008). Matsui et al. (2017) showed that the holotype of Hynobius stejnegeri Dunn, 1923, applied for almost 100 years to another species (now H. ikioi), was the senior name for the species known as H. yatsui Oyama, 1947, hence it takes priority.

Subsequently, a taxonomic revision of this species by Tominaga et al. (2019) recognized three additional species (H. guttatus, H. tsurugiensis, and H. kuishiensis), and limited the range of this species to Kyushu.

According to Stöck et al. (2001) this is was considered a member of the Pseudepidalea surda subgroup. What was referred to as the Bufo viridis group is now treated under Bufotes.

Mertens (1971) and Stöck et al. (2001) considered B. luristanicus as distinct species because of the existence of externally visible tympanic membrane in all B. luristanicus samples and its absence in all B. surdus samples.
This is a split from the broader concept of Hyla savignyi (Gvoždík et al. 2010).
This species was under the generic name Bufo but is now treated under Sclerophrys following Ohler and Dubois (2016).
Biton et al. (2013) removed this species from the genus Discoglossus and placed it into the fossil genus Latonia.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).

This species was synonymized with Amolops marmoratus by Dubois (2000). However it was later revalidated as a distinct species by Khatiwada et al. (2020). This taxon might be a junior synonym of Amolops monticola (Anderson, 1871).
This species has been separated from Alytes obstetricans (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003, Martínez-Solano et al. 2004, Fromhage et al. 2004).
Telmatobius albiventris and T. crawfordi were synonymized with this species by Benavides, Ortiz and Sites (2002).

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011).

Pelophylax porosus is divided into two very distinct allopatric subspecies: P. p. porosus (Cope, 1868) and P. p. brevipodus (Okada 1966). In addition, within P. p. brevipodus two forms (Nagoya and Okayama race) have been reported. It is still unknown whether the two forms are geographically separated or distributed sympatrically with mutual genetic introgression (Nagai et al. 2018).
This form might be a complex of more than one species.

The taxon Mertensiella caucasica includes two allopatric phylogenetic species (yet to be formally described), reciprocally monophyletic, separated since the Pliocene. Mertensiella sp.1 lives in the basin of the Kura River, Mertensiella sp.2 in the basin of the Black Sea. The validity of the subspecies M. caucasica djabaschvilii is in doubt (S. Kuzmin pers. comm.).
Subpopulations of this species were previously considered Rana tagoi, prior to its description (Ryuzaki et al. 2014).
This species was previously considered Rana tagoi, prior to its description (Matsui and Matsui 1990).
This species was formerly confused with Amietophrynus vittatus.

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to P. nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northern Algeria. The two species hybridize in a broad contact zone in the east of the coastal plain of El Taref (Berrihane and Lac des Oiseaux) and in the west in Guerbes-Foret des Senhaja (Djendel, Skikda) (Escoriza et al. 2016).

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to Pleurodeles nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northeastern Algeria. The two species hybridize in a broad contact zone, in the east of the coastal plain of El Taref (Berrihane and Lac des Oiseaux) and in the west in Guerbes-Foret des Senhaja (Djendel, Skikda) (Escoriza et al. 2016). Three geographically distinct haplotype clades have been identified: the eastern clade, present in north-eastern Tunisia to the Algerian border (between Cap Bon and El Ayoun); the central clade, present between the wilaya of Skikda and Constantine (Algeria) to southern Jendouba (Tunisia) and the western clade; between the wilaya of Jijel and Algiers (Carranza and Arnold 2004, Escoriza et al. 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Aneides flavipunctatus (Reilly and Wake 2019).

Molecular studies conducted by Santos et al. (2020), report the cryptic status of the northern subpopulation of this species, naming it "Rupirana cardosoi Lin-B" but did not describe it as a separate species. This subpopulation is retained in the current concept of R. cardosoi until further work confirms its identity as a distinct species.

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). It is unclear that all biological populations within its large range are conspecific. However, these are included in the current assessment until their taxonomic identities can be clarified.
In the Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis group. Bokermannohyla oxente can be distinguished from other species of the group by acoustic and morphological features (Lugli and Haddad 2006).
This species was previously within the genus Strabomantis but has been moved to the genus Haddadus (Amaro et al. 2013).

It was described as Hyla pelidna by Duellman (1989) and later transferred to Dendropsophus (as D. pelidna) by Faivovich et al. (2005). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) amended the specific name ending (as pelidnus) to be consistent with the masculine grammatical gender of Dendropsophus. The species was assigned to the labialis group by Duellman (1989), and Faivovich et al. (2005) and phylogenetically corroborated by Guarnizo et al. (2012) using genetic evidence. Guarnizo et al. (2012) suggested that D. pelidnus could be a junior synonym of D. meridensis based on the low genetic divergence between them; however, they refrained from taking any taxonomic decision in the absence of further evidence (e.g., bioacoustics and morphological data).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
The subspecies Aneides flavipunctatus niger was raised in rank to a full species by Reilly and Wake (2019).

authority: Chandramouli, Vasudevan, Harikrishnan, Dutta, Janani, Sharma, Das & Aggarwal, 2016
Khatiwada, Shu, Wang, Zhao, Xie & Jiang, 2020

taxonomicNotes: Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This is a split from the broader concept of Scutiger nyingchiensis, from which it has been resurrected from synonymy (Hofmann et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hydromantes shastae (Bingham et al. 2018).

This is a split from the broader concept of Anaxyrus boreas (Gordon et al. 2017). This species should also be recognized as a distinct management unit according to microsatellite data, which demonstrated that this species exhibits one unique allele and high allele frequency (FST > 0.151) differences from any other A. boreas complex populations (Forrest et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Anaxyrus boreas (Gordon et al. 2020).

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The holotype and paratypes were collected since 1969, but this species has only been recently described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on morphometrics and osteological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence. Parra-Olea et. al. (2020) hypothesize that specimens reported as C. chiropterus from 11,000 feet on Cofre de Perote by Smith and Taylor (1948) actually belong to C. perotensis.
Previously considered a subspecies of Bufotes pseudoraddei, it was recently elevated to species status by (Dufresnes et al. 2019).

This species has been elevated from sub-species level of Bufotes viridis by Dufresnes et al. (2019), although there is some contention about whether or not it should be a valid, distinct species (Speybroeck et al. 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Anaxyrus boreas (Gordon et al. 2020).
This is a restricted concept of Hydromantes shastae following the split of the broader concept into this, H. wintu, and H. samweli (Bingham et al. 2018).
Sphaerotheca paschima has been synonymised by Jablonski et al. (2021).
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species (Pereyra et al. 2021).

Several still undescribed species with exotrophic larvae have been confused with A. baeobatrachus (Vacher et al. 2017) in Suriname (Ouboter and Jairam 2012) and in Pará state, Brazil  (Avila-Pires et al. 2010). Fouquet et al. (2019) noted that subpopulations from southern French Guiana and Amapá, Brazil, differ genetically, morphologically, and in calls from each other and the subpopulations bearing the name in northern French Guiana.

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) restricted the range of Allobates fuscellus based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and noted that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was moved from the genus Leptodactylus to the genus Hydrolaetare by de Souza and Haddad (2003).

Based on morphometric and call differences, Funk et al. (2007, 2008) suggested that Engystomops petersi (termed Physalaemus petersi by those authors) encompasses the northwestern Amazon clade while the southwestern Amazon clade corresponds with E. freibergi (termed Physalaemus freibergi) corroborating the proposal of Ron et al. (2006).
This species might consist of more than one species (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2003).

Leptodactylus lauramiriamae is provisionally included in the genus Leptodactylus. It is differentiated from other species through a combination of morphological, myological and osteological features (Heyer and Crombie 2005). The type series of L. lauramiriamae was revised and has characteristics that may be of another genus (T. Carvalho pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hypsiboas but has been moved to Boana following Dubois (2017).
This species is commonly misidentified in collections with Chiasmocleis bassleri and C. shudikarensis (P. Peloso pers. comm. 2009).

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological populations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including this one.

Tentatively placed in the Dendropsophus microcephalus group according to the original publication. Dendropsophus juliani is characterized by a combination of morphological and advertisement call features (Moravec et al. 2006).

According to Stöck et al. (2001), the taxonomy and nomenclature of this species requires additional research, since the specimen considered the “holotype” by Balletto et al. (1985) is not that one described by Heyden (1827). Bufo hadramautinus Cherchi 1963 was synonymized with Bufo arabicus by Schätti and Desvoignes (1999). 

This species was under the generic name Duttaphrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nymphargus chancas (Guayasamín et al. 2020).

The taxonomy of this species (its species definition, synonyms and generic allocation) is very dynamic. It is variously reminiscent of Paa species, the Limnonectes kuhlii complex, or the L. blythii complex.

authority: Bernardes, Le, Nguyen, Pham, Pham, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton vietnamensis and T. asperrimus (Bernardes et al. 2020).

authority: Bernardes, Le, Nguyen, Pham, Pham, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2020

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Andrias davidianus (Turvey et al. 2019).

Because of the previous lack of molecular data in the past, this species has been mistakenly identified as Pristimantis riveti (e.g., collections at the QCAZ museum). Páez and Ron (2019) formally recognize it as a different species and assign it to the P. phoxocephalus species group.

This species is in need of taxonomic revision (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

Specimens of this species were previously referred as Pristimantis riveti based on Lynch (1979) characterization of the species (e.g., Almendáriz and Orcés 2004, Heinicke et al. 2007; Padial et al. 2014). Through morphological and molecular evidence, Páez and Ron (2019) recognize P. lutzae as a different species and assign it to the P. phoxocephalus species group.

authority: Urgilés, Székely, Székely, Christodoulides, Sánchez-Nivicela & Savage, 2019
taxonomicNotes: Individuals of this species have been previously identified as Pristimantis orestes, however, molecular evidence together with morphological evidence suggest that the subpopulation of Cajanuma, at the entrance to the Podocarpus National Park, belongs to this newly described species, Pristimantis cajanuma (Urgilés et al. 2017).

This species was collected for the first time in 2015 by personnel from the QCAZ museum during expeditions to Yacuri National Park, when it was identified as Pristimantis aff. riveti. Páez and Ron (2019) formally recognize it as a distinct species, Pristimantis multicolor, and assign it to the P. phoxocephalus species group.

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis phoxocephalus (Páez and Ron 2019). Pristimantis teslai has been mistakenly identified as P. phoxocephalus (e.g., collections at the QCAZ museum). This species could be a synonym of P. modipeplus (M. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis phoxocephalus (Páez and Ron 2019). Pristimantis totoroi has been mistakenly referred to as P. phoxocephalus (e.g., Hedges et al. 2008).

authority: Reyes-Puig, Reyes-Puig, Ron, Ortega, Guayasamin, Goodrum, Recalde, Vieira, Koch & Yánez-Muñoz, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species appears extremely similar to Nymphargus siren, with the only difference being that males are ca 3 mm smaller in size. Other collections of N. siren should be revisited to better elucidate the distributions of both N. siren and this species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2020).

This is a split from the broader concept of Boana geographica (Caminer and Ron 2020). A 16S sequence of ‘Boana cf. geographica’ from Valle del Guamuez, Colombia, published by Meza-Joya et al. (2019; GenBank accession number MF583739) is identical to the homologous sequence of specimen QCAZ 61767 of B. appendiculata from Limoncocha, Ecuador (539 bp). This similarity indicates the presence of B. appendiculata in Colombia (Caminer and Ron 2020).

authority: Wu, Huang, Tsai, Li, Jhang & Wu, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Kurixalus eiffingeri (Wu et al. 2016).

authority: Wu, Huang, Tsai, Li, Jhang & Wu, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Kurixalus eiffingeri (Wu et al. 2016).

This is a split from the broader concept of Kurixalus appendiculatus. Prior to this split, this species has been confused with K. chaseni due to superficial morphological similarities (Mediyansyah et al. 2019).

As a result of molecular phylogenetic analysis (Tominaga et al. 2019), this species has been separated from M. okinavensis and described as M. kuramotoi (Matsui and Tominaga, 2020). The closest relative of this species, M. mixtura is distributed in inland China (Tominaga et al. 2019, Matsui and Tominaga 2020).
This species was recently separated from Buergeria japonica (Matsui and Tominaga, 2020).
Matsui and Maeda (2018) elevated the two subspecies into two distinct species Rhacophorus viridis and Rhacophorus amamiensis supported by molecular phylogenetic analysis (Matsui et al. 2019).
This species is in the Dryophytes immaculatus group, and is a split from the broader concept of Dryophytes suweonensis (Borzée et al. 2020).

This is a restricted concept of Gastrotheca litonedis following the split of the broader concept into this and G. cuencana based on the discrete morphological and acoustic differences between the two species (Carvajal-Endara et al. 2019).
This is the new broader concept including Centrolene scirtetes and C. gemmatum synonymised with this species, following Guayasamin et al. (2020).
In the Melanophryniscus moreirae group according to the original description (Maneyro et al. 2008).

This species was re-delimited by Guyer et al. (2020) who placed N. lodingi in synonymy with this species and split N. mounti and N. moleri. The Mobile, Pearl, Pontchartrain, and Western lineages identified by Chabarria et al. (2017) may represent multiple cryptic species (Guyer et al. 2020)
Lötters (1996), suggested that the Cauca localities (by Cochran and Goin 1970) were doubtful on geographic grounds.

Following the review of the genus Oedipina by Brodie et al. (2012), where the presence of Oedipina salvadorensis was confirmed for El Salvador, E. Morán and V. Henríquez reviewed nine specimens of Oedipina from the departments of San Salvador and Ahuachapán, El Salvador [deposited in the El Salvador Museum of Natural History (MUNHES)].

The taxonomic characteristics of the specimens from San Salvador corresponded to those of Oedipina salvadorensis, while the specimens from the department of Ahuachapán corresponded to Oedipina taylori (V. Henríquez pers. comm. June 2019).

authority: Formas, Northland, Capetillo, Nuñez, Cuevas & Brieva, 1999
taxonomicNotes: The species may be a synonym of T. vilamensis (Sáez et al., 2014).
May be a synonym of T. dankoi (Sáez et al. 2014).

authority: Quah, Grismer, Wood, Thura, Oaks & Lin, 2019
Pomchote, Khonsue, Thammachoti, Hernandez, Peerachidacho, Suwannapoom, Onishi & Nishikawa, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton verrucosus (Pomchote et al. 2020).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Quah, Thura, Espinoza & Murdoch, 2019

taxonomicNotes: We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana hmongorum, described by Bain et al. (2003), as a synonym of this species.

Subpopulations in the Cumberland Plateau of Tennessee that were previously known as this species were assigned to Desmognathus abditus (Anderson and Tilley 2003). One specimen of a juvenile from central Vermont may belong to this species, but this requires confirmation.

This species is not distinguished from the very similar Hyla chrysoscelis in most published literature; it is distinguished by chromosomes, erythrocyte size (Matson 1990), and call characteristics.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

Some authors include Gyrinophilus subterraneus in this species (Blaney and Blaney 1978). Bonett et al. (2013) phylogenetic hypothesis has been interpreted as either Gyrinophilus porphyriticus being conspecific with G. palleucus and G. gulolineatus or Gyrinophilus porphyriticus being a species complex (Frost 2014 and references therein).

A recently recognized but unnamed new cryptic species with a sister relationship to Lithobates palustris (Newman et al. 2012) suggests that a revision of the species' distribution may be needed to assess geographic variation and if there could be more cryptic species concealed under this nominal form.
Some published literature on this species actually pertains to Plethodon serratus, which was given species status in mid-1970s.

A molecular phylogeny of Pseudacris based on mtDNA data (Moriarty and Cannatella 2004) revealed four strongly supported clades within Pseudacris: (1) A West Coast Clade containing regilla and cadaverina, (2) a Fat Frog Clade including ornata, streckeri, and illinoensis, (3) a Crucifer Clade consisting of crucifer and ocularis, and (4) a Trilling Frog Clade containing all other Pseudacris. Within the Trilling Frog Clade, brimleyi and brachyphona form the sister group to the Nigrita Clade: nigrita, feriarum, triseriata, kalmi, clarkii, and maculata. The Nigrita Clade shows geographic division into three clades: (1) populations of maculata and triseriata west of the Mississippi River and Canadian populations, (2) southeastern United States populations of feriarum and nigrita, and (3) northeastern United States populations of feriarum, kalmi, and triseriata. Moriarty and Cannatella (2004) found that subspecific epithets for crucifer (crucifer and bartramiana) and nigrita (nigrita and verrucosa) are uninformative, and they therefore discouraged recognition of these subspecies. They concluded that further study is needed to determine if illinoensis warrants status as a distinct species. Molecular data were consistent with retention of regilla, cadaverina, ocularis, and crucifer in the genus Pseudacris.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now known as P. fouquettei). Based on mtDNA data, Pseudacris maculata and P. clarkii did not emerge as distinct, monophyletic lineages but, given the degree of morphological and behavioural divergence between the taxa, Lemmon et al. (2007) chose to recognize them as separate species, until further data suggest otherwise.

A molecular phylogeny of Pseudacris based on mtDNA data (Moriarty and Cannatella 2004) revealed four strongly supported clades within Pseudacris: (1) A West Coast Clade containing regilla and cadaverina, (2) a Fat Frog Clade including ornata, streckeri, and illinoensis, (3) a Crucifer Clade consisting of crucifer and ocularis, and (4) a Trilling Frog Clade containing all other Pseudacris. Within the Trilling Frog Clade, brimleyi and brachyphona form the sister group to the Nigrita Clade: nigrita, feriarum, triseriata, kalmi, clarkii, and maculata. The Nigrita Clade shows geographic division into three clades: (1) populations of maculata and triseriata west of the Mississippi River and Canadian populations, (2) southeastern United States populations of feriarum and nigrita, and (3) northeastern United States populations of feriarum, kalmi, and triseriata. Moriarty and Cannatella (2004) found that subspecific epithets for crucifer (crucifer and bartramiana) and nigrita (nigrita and verrucosa) are uninformative, and they therefore discouraged recognition of these subspecies. They concluded that further study is needed to determine if illinoensis warrants status as a distinct species. Molecular data were consistent with retention of regilla, cadaverina, ocularis, and crucifer in the genus Pseudacris.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now known as Pseudacris fouquettei). Based on mtDNA data, Pseudacris maculata and P. clarkii did not emerge as distinct, monophyletic lineages but, given the degree of morphological and behavioural divergence between the taxa, Lemmon et al. (2007) chose to recognize them as separate species, until further data suggest otherwise.

Duellman (2015) placed Gastrotheca lauzuricae (De la Riva 1992) under the synonymy of G. coeruleomaculatus (Werner 1899) (previously in the synonymy of G. marsupiata) based only on the original species' descriptions, and mainly on the fact that presence of blue spots were mentioned in both descriptions. However, no direct comparisons of the types were made. The fact that the type localities of the two species (known only from the respective type material —one specimen for G. lauzuricae and two for G. coeruleomaculatus) are separated by ca 370 km (airline) make it very unlikely that both names represent a single taxon. In addition, Gastrotheca subpopulations in the two areas involve other complex taxonomic problems which affect the use of these names. Preliminary, unpublished data indicate that G. lauzuricae is a junior synonym of G. splendens, and G. coeruleomaculatus might be the available name for a rare, poorly known species from the Yungas de La Paz area (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2019). 

We depart from the placement of Gastrotheca lauzuricae in synonymy of G. coeruleomaculatus proposed by Duellman (2015) and accepted by Frost (2021), and retain G. lauzuricae as previously recognised, following Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2015).
This form is not universally accepted as a valid species.
This is a split from the broader concept of Alytes obstetricans, for which it was previously considered to be a subspecies (Dufresnes and Martínez-Solano 2020).

This taxon was previously considered a synonym of Leptodactylus latrans (Gallardo 1964, Lavilla 1994) and is now recognized as a separate species (Magalhães et al. 2020). Ferraro et al. (2018) noted that the taxonomic status of Leptodactylus latrans in Argentina remains problematic (note that nominal Leptodactylus latrans in Argentina is now Leptodactylus luctator).

This species might be a synonym of Chiromantis vittatus.

This species has been moved from the genus Chiromantis to Feihyla (Aowphol et al. 2013), and then Feihyla to Rohanixalus (Biju et al. 2020).

This species is considered distinct from Philautus nanus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005), and from Pseudophilautus sordidus following Ellepola et al. (2021). However, further taxonomic studies on this species are required.

authority: (Baldo, Araujo-Vieira, Cardozo, Borteiro, Leal, Pereyra, Kolenc, Lyra, Garcia, Haddad & Faivovich, 2019)
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Scinax uruguayus according to Baldo et al. (2019).

authority: Carvalho, Moraes, Lima, Fouquet, Peloso, Pavan, Drummond, Rodrigues, Giaretta, Gordo, Neckel-Oliveira & Haddad, 2021
Carvalho, Moraes, Lima, Fouquet, Peloso, Pavan, Drummond, Rodrigues, Giaretta, Gordo, Neckel-Oliveira & Haddad, 2021
Carvalho, Angulo, Kokubum, Barrera, Souza, Haddad & Giaretta, 2019
taxonomicNotes: It is a cryptic species and the sampling can be skewed. Previously it could be confused with A. andreae and A. hylaedactyla (T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020). Call data are still needed to further confirm species identities of samples from the foothills of the Andes (Carvalho et al. 2019).

Carvalho, Moraes, Lima, Fouquet, Peloso, Pavan, Drummond, Rodrigues, Giaretta, Gordo, Neckel-Oliveira & Haddad, 2021

taxonomicNotes: Nanohyla (Microhyla) pulverata has been synonymized with this species (Gorin et al. 2020). This species has also been moved from the genus Microhyla to Nanohyla by Gorin et al. (2021).

authority: Townsend, Herrera-B., Hofmann, Luque-Montes, Ross, Dudek, Krygeris, Duchamp & Wilson, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Atlantihyla spinipollex (Townsend et al. 2020).

The use of this name has been clarified by McCranie and Wilson (1993). This species was moved from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla (Faivovich et al. 2018). This is a restricted concept of Atlantihyla spinipollex following the split of the broader concept into this and A. melissa (Townsend et al. 2020).
Centrolene bacatum (Wild 1994) and C. guanacarum (Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch 1995) have been placed in synonymy under C. sanchezi (Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch 1991) by Guayasamín et al. (2020).

authority: Magalhães, Lyra, Carvalho, Baldo, Brusquetti, Burella, Colli, Gehara, Giaretta, Haddad, Langone, López, Napoli, Santana, de Sá & Garda, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was formerly confused with Leptodactylus latrans, according to Magalhães et al. (2020), where the morphology, calls, and molecular relationships are outlined.
Anaxyrus baxteri was formerly included in this species.

This species is not easily distinguished from the very similar Hyla versicolor in most published literature; it is distinguished by chromosomes, erythrocyte size (Matson 1990), and call characteristics.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

The subspecies Pseudacris streckeri illinoensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991) (without supporting data), but this subspecies was recognized by Phillips et al. (1999), Johnson (2000), and Crother et al. (2000, 2003).
Shaffer et al. (2004) presented genetic evidence supporting the recognition of Rana aurora and R. draytonii as distinct species.
Green et al. (1997) recognized Rana luteiventris as a distinct species from Rana pretiosa.

Scaphiopus hurterii formerly was regarded as a subspecies of S. holbrookii, but checklists (Crother et al. 2000, Collins and Taggart 2002) have treated it as a distinct species. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Scaphiopus hurterii was formerly regarded as a subspecies of S. holbrookii, but checklists (Crother et al. 2000, Collins and Taggart 2002) have treated it as a distinct species. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

(2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.
This species was removed from synonymy with Desmognathus ochrophaeus (Tilley and Mahoney 1996, Frost 2014).
Camp et al. (2002) elevated the form Desmognathus folkertsi to specific status.
This polytypic, ring species includes taxa that form a semicomplex of more than one species.
Bonett et al. (2013) indicate that this species is the sister taxon to Eurycea longicauda longicauda.

Eurycea guttolineata was formerly included in this species. Bonett et al. (2013) study suggests that the two nominal subspecies Eurycea longicauda longicauda and Eurycea longicauda melanopleura could potentially be two distinct species as they are more closely related to other taxa than to each other.
Bonett et al. (2013) study suggests that this is the sister species to part of Eurycea cirrigera.

Rovito (2010) indicates that there are two very divergent mtDNA lineages within this species which correspond to the northern and southern parts of the range, with a break between the lineages occurring in the Mammoth Lake region of central Sierra Nevada.
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998). It was accepted as a distinct species by Crother et al. (2000).
Plethodon ventralis and P. angusticlavius were formerly included in P. dorsalis (Highton 1997).
This species was included in Plethodon richmondi prior to 1972. Plethodon virginia was formerly included in this species (Highton 1999).
This species was removed from synonymy with Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was split from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
Highton (1999) removed certain biological populations from this species and recognized them as a distinct species, Plethodon electromorphus, based on allele frequencies.
This species includes the junior synonym Plethodon longicrus, which was resurrected in 2006 (Wiens et al. 2006) but subsequently synonymized with P. yonahlossee again by Highton et al. (2012).
Pseudobranchus axanthus was formerly included in this species (Frost 2021).

This species has had a complex taxonomic history with other Ambystomatids such as Ambystoma tigrinum, A. velasci and A. californiense (Frost 2011). There are five recognized subspecies of A. mavortium (Crother 2012), based mainly on colour patterns and geographic distribution; the validity of the subspecies has not been examined recently.
This is a restricted concept of Ambystoma tigrinum following the split of A. mavortium from the broader concept.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
This species has been removed from the synonymy of Philautus petersi, and Philautus similis has been synonymised with this species by Wostl et al. (2017).
Plethodon idahoensis was formerly included in this species.
We follow Song et al. (2006) in removing Rana coreana from the synonymy of R. amurensis.
We follow Veith et al. (2003) in considering this species to be distinct from Rana macrocnemis at the species level.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Pelobates fuscus (Litvinchuk et al. 2013, Suryadnaya 2014).

Fu et al. (2005) synonymized Bufo andrewsi, Ye et al. (1993) synonymized Bufo minshanicus, Zhan and Fu (2011) synonymized Bufo tibetanus, Fei et al. (2009) synonymized Bufo wolongensis, and Fei et al. (2009) synonymized Bufo kabischi with Bufo gargarizans (Frost 2015).
This species has been separated from Aneides ferreus (Jackman 1998).
This is a restricted concept of Anaxyrus boreas following the split of the broader concept into this, A. nevadensis, A. monfontanus, and A. williamsi (Gordon et al. 2017, 2020).

authority: Guayasamin, Cisneros-Heredia, Maynard, Lynch, Culebras & Hamilton, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was recently resurrected from the synonymy of Litoria watjulumensis by Donnellan et al. (2021).

Provisional generic placement based on statement of relationship to Theloderma albopunctatum. 

Subpopulations, previously assigned to T. albopunctatum have now been reallocated to this species.

authority: Guyer, Murray, Bart, Crother, Chabarria, Bailey & Dunn, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Necturus beyeri (Guyer et al. 2020).

This species was considered a synonym of Plethodon mississippi by Himes and Beckett (2013). It was tentatively resurrected from this synonymy by Pierson et al. (2020). This species is currently recognized as valid, although further taxonomic work is recommended.
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus silvaticus to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus silus to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
This is a broader concept of Pseudophilautus fergusonianus that now includes all the records from P. hallidayi, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
This is a broader concept of Psudophilatus hankeni that now includes all the records from P. dilmah, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).

authority: Firneno, Itgen, Jacobs, Mcdaniels, Luque-Montes, Wilson & Townsend, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hypopachus barberi based on molecular and morphological differences (Firneno Jr. et al. 2021).
This is a restricted concept of Hypopachus barberi following the split of the broader concept into this and H. guancasco based on molecular and morphological differences (Firneno Jr. et al. 2021).
Most closely related to Allobates masniger and Allobates nidicola according to the original publication (Moraes et al. 2019, Frost 2021).

authority: Magalhães, Lyra, Carvalho, Baldo, Brusquetti, Burella, Colli, Gehara, Giaretta, Haddad, Langone, López, Napoli, Santana, de Sá & Garda, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was formerly confused with Leptodactylus latrans, according to Magalhães et al. (2020), where the species characteristics, including call, morphology, and molecular differentia were discussed.

authority: Leal, Leite, Costa, Nascimento, Lourenço & Garcia, 2020
Andrade, Haga, Ferreira, Recco-Pimentel, Toledo & Bruschi, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pithecopus nordestinus (Andrade et al. 2020).

This species is assigned to Dendropsophus minuta species group based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies, and some morphological characteristics (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is distinguished from other species of the genus by its noticeably smaller size (2.26 cm), homogeneously dotted back, presence of interdigital palms, smooth dorsal skin, and cloaca with fleshy fold, among others. A survey conducted by the Ministry of Ecosocialism in 2011 reports D. minutus, D. minusculus, D. microcephalus and D. luteoocellatus for the locality (González-Fernández and Nieves 2011), species that noticeably differ from the description of the holotype. However, updated data on taxonomic and genetic traits are still necessary.
This species was elevated to species status by La Marca (1983).

The nomenclatural history of this species was detailed by Lötters et al. (1998) and Lötters and La Marca (2001). This species was redescribed by Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004) after the discovery that the original type material represented Atelopus varius of Central America. The former junior synonym Atelopus vogli is considered to be a distinct species following (Lötters et al. 2004)
This species was recognized as distinct from Atelopus cruciger by Lötters et al. (2004).

Until now, this species had not been included in any phylogenetic study, and its relationships with Rhinella alata and the others members of Rhinella margaritifera group are still unknown (dos Santos et al. 2015). The records of “Bufo typhonius alatus” from Curimagua (Falcón state) and Bejuma (Carabobo state) by Rivero (1961, 1964) may correspond to Rhinella sclerocephala.

Señaris et al. (1994) described this monotypic genus based on osteological and morphological characters of adults. Until now, this taxon has not been included in phylogenetic studies. Barrio-Amorós (1998) emended the name sosai to sosae, without explanation. However, recently Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) justified this change.
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
In the Centrolene prosoblepon group according to Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1991), and Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006).

Myers and Donnelly (1997) elevated the subspecies Centrolene buckleyi venezuelensis (Rivero 1968) to species level without explanation. Señaris and Ayarzagüena (2005) supported this decision based on morphological and acoustic differences with respect to typical buckleyi populations. More recent phylogenetic studies support the validity of this species (Guayasamin et al. 2009, Castroviejo‐Fisher et al. 2014, Amador et al. 2018).
Based on a molecular phylogeny, Guayasamin et al. (2009) reallocated this species in the genus Vitreorana.

This species has not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

This species has not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

Based on a molecular phylogeny, Guayasamin et al. (2009) described the new genus Celsiella to reallocate two endemic species – C. revocata and C. vozmedianoi - from the northern mountain system in Venezuela.

Based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies and some morphological characteristics, this species was assigned to Vitreorana, and designated as the type species of this genus (Guayasamin et al. 2009).
This species had been included in phylogenetic studies by Guayasamin et al. (2008, 2009), and Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2014).

Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2008) examined morphological characters of this species and its phylogenetic relationships with other Hyalinobatarchium populations from the Venezuelan Cordillera de la Costa.

In the genus Hyalinobatrachium based on morphological and behavioral characteristics (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2005, Guayasamin et al. 2009). Until now this species has not been included in any phylogenetic study.

Originally described in the genus Centrolenella (Rivero, 1985). Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) transferred this species to Hyalinobatrachium, and posteriorly to the genus Cochranella (Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch 1998). Based on a molecular phylogeny of the family Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) described the genus Celsiella to reallocate this species (as the type species of the genus) and other endemic glass frog from the northern mountain system in Venezuela: C. vozmedianoi.

This species is assigned to the genus Anomaloglossus based on the phenotypic synapomorphies of this clade that is the presence of the median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006). Other features, such as morphological characters, differentiate this species from most species of the genus (La Marca 1998).

Originally assigned to Phyllobates (Test 1956) but subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971), and to Allobates by Grant et al. (2006). In both cases, taxonomic changes were based only on morphological evidence. Its phylogenetic position and its relationships with other Allobates species are unknown as this species has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.

Originally assigned to Prostherapis by Rivero (1961) and later transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971). Grant et al. (2006) did not include this species in their phylogenetic hypothesis, however, agree with La Marca (2004) in that its phylogenetic relationships remain enigmatic, and refer it as insertae sedis within Aromobatidae.

This species can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters (La Marca 1997). Its inclusion in this genus, Anomaloglossus, should be confirmed with the presence of the generic synapomorphy of a median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006).
Misidentified specimens of Allobates humilis reported by Barrio-Amorós and García Porta (2003) from Táchira State actually represent A. algorei (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009).

Originally described as a member of Phyllobates (Schmidt 1932) but subsequently transferred to Prostherapis (Rivero 1961), Colostethus (Edwards 1971), and finally to Allobates (Grant et al. 2006) where is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Although the last change was made in the contexts of an exhaustive phylogenetic study (Grant et al. 2006) this species was not included in the analyses and its reallocation was only based on its overall morphological similarity with other Allobates. Therefore, its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown and its generic position should be considered provisional and pending corroboration.
This species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis, so its relationships are unknown (Grant et al. 2017).

This species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis, so its relationships are unknown (Grant et al. 2017). Barrio-Amoros et al. (2019) commented that Anomaloglossus tamacuarensis (Myers and Donnelly 1997) must be compared to this species, because they could represent the same taxon.

This species can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters (La Marca 1997). Its inclusion in this genus, Anomaloglossus, should be confirmed with the presence of the generic synapomorphy of a median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006).

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide new information for this species and suggest that the subpopulation in Colombia referred as Aromobates saltuensis by Grant et al. (2006) is an unnamed species most closely related to Aromobates cannatellai. Also, these authors have doubts about the Colombian references of Anganoy-Criollo (2012) of A. cf. saltuensis.

Originally described as Colostethus sanmartini (Rivero et al. 1986) and later transferred to Allobates (Grant et al. 2006) where it is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Although this generic change was made in the context of an exhaustive phylogenetic study (Grant et al. 2006) the species was not included in the analyses and its reallocation was only based on its overall morphological similarity with other Allobates. Hence, its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown and its generic position should be considered provisional and pending corroboration.
This species can be distinguished from other closed Guianan species by a combination of morphological characters (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2004).

This species is assigned to monophyletic genus Allobates based on its phenotypic synapomorphies (Grant et al. 2006). A conspicuous nonglandular pad thickening and melanosis above the wrist of A. undulatus males (Myers and Donnelly 2001) is not present in other species of this genus (Grant et al. 2006).

This species is recovered in various places throughout the dendrobatine phylogeny, either as sister to the genus Adelphobates or to all other dendrobatines aside from Phyllobates and C. ruthveni (see Frost 2020 for a complete review of the systematic of this taxon). Currently, Minyobates is a monotypic genus, but additional phylogenetic research is needed (La Marca 2016).

Originally described as part of the genus Dendrobates (Gorzula 1990) but subsequently transferred to Epipedobates (Myers 1997), Allobates (Jungfer and Böhme 2004) and lastly to Anomaloglossus (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2011). This last change was justified by the occurrence in this species of a median lingual process, a phenotypic synapomorphy of Anomaloglossus (Grant et al. 2006, 2017). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Anomaloglossus beebei group was inferred by Grant et al. (2017) and corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Hyloxalus collaris by Boulenger (1912) (misspelled Hylixalus). Successively moved to Prostherapis and Colostetus by Rivero (1961) and Edwards (1971), respectively, and finally allocated in Mannophryne by La Marca (1992), where still remains. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).
Since its description (La Marca 1994) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Santos et al. 2014, Grant et al. 2017).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
This taxon is suspected to be a synonym of Mannophryne yustizi (Manzanilla et al. 2009, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019; J. Manzanilla pers. comm. 2020).

Originally described as Prostherapis neblina by Test (1956) and subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971) and to Mannophryne by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been recently corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Colostethus oblitteratus by Rivero (1984) and later transferred to Mannophryne by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been repeatedly corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019). Colostethus guatopoensis Dixon & Rivero-Blanco 1985, is a junior synonym of this species.
Mannophryne larandina is suspected to be a junior synonym of this species (Manzanilla et al. 2009, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019, J. Manzanilla pers. comm. 2020).

Previous to Grant et al. (2006) the genus Aromobates was known only by a single species: A. nocturnus (Myers et al. 1991). Then, Grant et al. (2006) moved all Colostethus of the alboguttatus group (sensu Rivero 1988) or Nephelobates (sensu La Marca 1994) to Aromobates and provided a well-corroborated phylogeny of the genus. Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide a phylogeny and a list with current threats for all species of the genus. Rivero (1982a) included Colostehus inflexus Rivero, 1978 in the synonymy of C. alboguttatus. Myers, Paolillo and Daly (1991) and La Marca (1997) revive the species as Nephelobates inflexus in their works without explanation. Recently, Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) consider inflexus different from A. alboguttatus and a valid species, but without supporting evidence.

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Rivero (1980). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and most recently reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Dole and Durant (1972). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and lastly reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) suggested that the type material of Aromobates orostoma requires additional examination to confirm its status, and its relationship with A. inflexus should be evaluated.
It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by the skin co-ossified with the skull and transverse occipital ridge bearing spinous elevations (Duellman 1980).

It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by triangular dermal calcar present on heel and triangular dermal process present on margin of eyelid (Duellman 1980). It could be a junior synonym of Gastrotheca williamsoni, so its taxonomic status requires further investigation (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters (Duellman 1980). Gastrotheca walkeri could be a junior synonym of G. williamsoni. The taxonomic status of this species requires further investigation, because it has not been collected since the original description (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear since its description was based on two old and poorly preserved specimens from distant bioregions (holotype from Cagua in Cordillera de La Costa, and paratype from Kunana in Sierra de Perijá). A preliminary examination of the holotype suggests that it could be related to Boana punctata whereas the paratype could be a juvenile B. aff. xerophylla. Additional specimens from Kunana (Zulia state) and from Caracas (Distrito Capital) referred as likely pertaining to B. alemani by Rivero (1964), correspond to juveniles of B. aff. xerophylla. The identity of the specimens recorded from Cojedes and Falcón states must be verified (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Faivovich et al. (2013) reexamined the holotype of Myersiohyla loveridgei and based on its morphological similarity with M. aromatica suggested the possibility of a senior synonym. More samples of M. aromatica and M. loveridgei are needed for further phylogenetic analyses of the genus, and a reevaluation of their taxonomic status.

This species has not been included in any phylogeny and its current taxonomic position is doubtful, mainly due to the fact that it is only known from a single and poorly preserved male individual, collected in Caracas (Rivero 1961), which was described initially under the genus Hyla, and later transferred to Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Mijares-Urrutia (1998) mentioned that this species is apparently related to Dendropsophus amicorum and D. minutus.

Originally described as a member of Hyla by Rivero (1961) and then transferred to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) on the basis of morphological evidence. Its phylogenetic position was corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018) using molecular data. Centrolenella estevesi Rivero, 1968 is a junior synonym of this species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Faivovich et al. (2013) reviewed the holotype of the species, complemented the former descriptions of Myersiohyla loveridge by Rivero (1961, “1971” [1972]), and discussed its close morphological similarity with M. aromatica, suggesting the possible synonymy of the latter. More samples of M. aromatica and M. loveridgei are needed for further phylogenetic analyses of the genus, and a reevaluation of their taxonomic status.

Originally described under the genus Hyla by Roux (1927). It was transferred to Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and allocated into the Dendropsophus parviceps species group. This taxonomic change was based on morphological characteristics shared with other species of that group, but its phylogenetic relationships remain untested.

Originally described as a subspecies of Hyla vilsoniana by Rivero (1961) and later elevated to the species level by Duellman (1989), who also assigned it to the labialis group. It was moved to the genus Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) on the basis of molecular phylogenetic evidence. According to Guarnizo et al. (2012), D. pelidnus could be a junior synonym of this species but it is still considered valid for this assessment.

Removed from the synonymy of Hyla (as Hypsiboas), and placed in the Hypsiboas benitezi Group by Faivovich et al. (2005, 2006). Dubois (2017) concluded that Boana is the appropriate generic name for Hypsiboas.

Originally described under the genus Hyla by Mijares-Urrutia and Rivero (2000). It was transferred to Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) based only on morphological similarity and remained unassigned to any species group. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) assigned it to the Dendropsophus parviceps species group, but also on the basis of its overall similarity with the other species in that group. Its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown.

This species was transferred to Agalychnis by Faivovich et al. (2010), but was not assigned to any species group. Until now this leaf frog is still missing in phylogenetic analyses and its evolutionary relationships are unknown.

In the Scinax ruber clade, but not assigned to any species group (Faivovich et al. 2005). Scinax lyndsayi described by Pyburn (1992) from the Vaupes River between Brazil and Colombia, could be a junior synonym of Scinax baumgardneri according to Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019).
Faivovich et al. (2005) placed this species in the Scinax ruber clade, but unassigned to any group.

Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2016, 2017) and Salerno et al. (2012). In the ginesi clade sensu Kok et al. (2017), who also noted unnamed species covered by this species name in the Chimantá massif.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Pantepui, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of Eastern Guianan Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Guianan Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Guiana Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.

Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of Eastern Guiana Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species. One sample of Stefania riae has been incorporated in these phylogenetic analyses (Castroviejo et al. 2015; Kok et al. 2012, 2016, 2017).

This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005). Some specimens of this species resemble Stefania ginesi, but in these cases their general aspect is that of a somewhat slimmer and slightly smaller frog. Specimens from Terekeyuren (Murisipan) tepui and Kamarkawarai tepui, from the Los Testigos massif, closely resemble S. satelles, but were not assigned to this species pending further specimens becoming available.
Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2017). Not assigned to any clade, and pending further investigation (Kok et al. 2017).

Several recent phylogenetic studies suggest that the species of Tepuihyla (including a sample of T. aecii) evolved recently from a common lowland ancestor, and not a long time ago as usually suspected for endemics amphibians in the Pantepui (Kok et al. 2012; Salerno et al. 2012, 2015; Jungfer et al. 2013).

This species has been placed in various families (Lynch 1979, Hedges et al. 2008, Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014). It differs greatly in external morphology from the other Guiana genus Ceuthomantis and all other Terraranae. However, the phylogenetic position of genus Dischidodactylus has never been evaluated using molecular data. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted the uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic placement of this genus, and the need for further research to clarify its relationships.

This species has been placed in various families (Lynch 1979, Hedges et al. 2008, Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014). It differs greatly in external morphology from the other Guiana genus Ceuthomantis and all other Terraranae. However, the phylogenetic position of genus Dischidodactylus has never been evaluated using molecular data. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted the uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic placement of this genus, and the need for further research to clarify its relationships.

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008). This species has not been included in any phylogenetic study, and has not been assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the family Strabomantidae sensu Heinicke et al. (2018).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

Originally described in the genus Hylodes by Peters (1863), and subsequently transferred to Eleutherodactylus by Stejneger (1904) and Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007) where it is currently placed (Frost 2020). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014). Its evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis are unknown as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis. According to Lynch and La Marca (1993), Eleutherodactylus lancini Rivero 1961, E. racenisi Rivero 1961, and E. williamsi Rivero 1961, are junior synonyms of this species. Lynch and La Marca (1993) further suggested that Eleutherodactylus rozei Rivero 1961 could be an additional junior synonym of Pristimantis reticulatus, but this must be evaluated.

Originally described as Strabomantis biporcatus (Peters 1863) but later transferred to Eleutherodactylus (Dunn 1931), Craugastor (Crawford and Smith 2005) and again to Strabomantis (Hedges et al. 2008) where it is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Its phylogenetic relationships based on molecular data, were first inferred by Hedges et al. (2008) and later corroborated by Padial et al. (2014). Hylodes maussi Boettger 1893 is a junior synonym of this species (Savage and Myers 2002).

The genus Paramophrynella was proposed by La Marca (2007); Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Paramophrynella in the synonymy of Pristimantis, which includes Pristimantis boconoensis. Recent genetic studies confirm the distinctiveness of the group, but does not guarantee its full genus status (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Further genetic studies are needed to determine the degree of differentiation of this group of species which share a morphological synapomorphy (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Paramophrynella for this and related species. This genus had been considered a synonym of Pristimantis by Hedges et al. (2008), and later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) reinforced this synonym with molecular data. Not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014).

The species was named in 1965 by Roberto Donoso Barros as Eleutherodactylus lancinii, but the formal description was published later (Donoso-Barros, 1968). Other descriptions are in Rivero (1982) and La Marca (2007). La Marca (2007) created the new genus Mucubatrachus for this and related species, that was afterwards regarded as a synonym of Pristimantis by Hedges et al. (2008) and later confirmed by molecular data (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2013).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.

Not assigned to any species group in the original description (Myers and Donnelly, 1996), neither in the molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014). The phylogenetic relationships of this species are totally unknown.

Originally described in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Walker and Test 1955) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014) as it was not included in any phylogenetic analysis. Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown. Lynch and La Marca (1993) mentioned that Eleutherodactylus rozei Rivero 1961 could be a junior synonym of Pristimantis reticulatus, but this awaits corroboration.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Lynch and La Marca 1993) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Rivero 1961) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group of Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014) as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis. Its evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis remain unknown. According to Lynch and La Marca (1993), this species could be conspecific with Pristimantis reticulatus.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Walker and Test 1955) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Hedges et al. (2008) and Padial et al. (2014) also listed this species as part of Pristimantis but did not assign it to any species group as it was not included in their phylogenetic analyses. Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown.

This species is assigned to the unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), based on its morphological characteristics, although it has not been assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014).

There are two available descriptions for this frog: Eleutherodactylus vanadise by La Marca (1984) and that of its synonym Eleutherodactylus cerasoventris (Rivero 1984 “1982”). Even though these descriptions were based on 29 and 36 specimens respectively, the variation in nature was not fully represented. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) reported four chromotypes, based on 98 specimens. In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original publication (La Marca 1984) and Hedges et al. (2008); not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

This species is assigned to Leptodactylus melanonotus species group based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies, and some morphological characteristics (de Sá et al. 2014). This species is known only from the Cerro Socopó region in Venezuela. There are no other described species having toe fringes and lacking dorsolateral folds in the area where the Venezuelan states of Falcón, Lara and Zulia converge (de Sá et al. 2014). However, updated data on taxonomic and genetic traits are still necessary, considering several populations in Venezuela and Colombia (Magdalena and Maracaibo basin) could not be assigned to diagnosable species (Heyer 1994).

This species was the first endemic salamander described from Venezuela. It was described by Trapido in 1942 using a single specimen collected in the vicinity of the Borburata River Valley in Carabobo state. This author suggested that a specimen from Río San Esteban, Carabobo state, was B. borburata and not B. altamazonica as previously suggested by Dunn (1926). Specimens reported from Falcón state (Linares 1974, Mijares-Urrutia and Arends 2000) and Yaracuy state (Barrio-Amorós 1999, Lotzkat 2007) might represent a different taxon (Mijares-Urrutia and Arends 2000, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). We tentatively consider the populations from Yaracuy as part of the same taxon although a taxonomic assessment is required. The phylogenetic position of this species is unclear. Parra-Olea et al. (2004) assigned this species to the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group based on its South American distribution.

Schargel et al. (2002) mentioned that this species is morphologically more similar to B. adspersa, B. borburata, B. savagei, B. taylori, and B. vallecula than the geographically close species, B. orestes. Apparently, such difference is also applicable to the most recently described species B. mucuyensis, which is the sister species of B. orestes (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). This species was tentatively assigned to the B. adspersa group by Schargel et al. (2002). Parra-Olea et al. (2004) placed B. guaramacalensis in the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group based on its South American distribution.

As stated by Maciel and Hoogmoed (2018) “the systematics of the genus Caecilia is one of the major challenges to be solved in the Neotropical region”. We agree with the authors as many species have been described based on only a few collected specimens (that is the case for this species) and in some cases without localities known. Recently, a similar species was described by the aforementioned authors from French Guiana. However, both differ in several morphological traits used traditionally in the taxonomy of Caecilia. Despite the fact that this species was based on a single individual, the species has been validated by different authors (p.e. Taylor 1968, Nussbaum and Wilkinson 1989, Maciel and Hoogmed 2018).

Originally assigned to Colostethus by La Marca et al. (2004) and later transferred to Allobates by Grant et al. (2006) based on morphological similarities. Recently, Grant et al. (2017) corroborate it as part of Allobates (and sister to A. humilis from Venezuelan Andes) in their revisited phylogeny of Dendrobatoidea.

This species can be distinguished from other Guianan species by a combination of morphological characters (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2004). Its name could be a synonym of A. parkerae (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Originally assigned to Colostethus (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2004) but then transferred to Anomaloglossus by Grant et al. (2006). Anomaloglossus verbeeksnyderorum Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010, could be a junior synonym of this species based on preliminary evidence (Kok et al. 2012, Grant et al. 2017, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019, Rojas-Runjaic 2019). Further studies are required to determine the taxonomic status of the latter.
This species can be easily distinguished from other Guiana Shield species by a combination of morphological characters (Fuentes and Barrio-Amorós 2004).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group of Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the Pristimantis conspicillatus group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Pantepui, and noted several unnamed species.

This species was originally described in the genus Mucubatrachus by La Marca (2007). Hedges et al. (2008), however, placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Further genetic studies are needed to determine the degree of differentiation of this group of species which share a morphological synapomorphy (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

The species was originally described within the genus Paramophrynella, which Hedges et al. (2008) placed in synonymy with Pristimantis. Pristimantis jabonensis belongs to a group of small-sized páramo frogs usually found in sympatry with members of another group of frogs to which Pristimantis lancinii belongs (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020). The latter group of species, originally placed in the genus Mucubatrachus (also currently in synonymy with Pristimantis) are larger frogs with a unique derived character that was used as a synapomorphy for the group (La Marca 2007). Further molecular genetic studies are needed to ascertain the phylogenetic relationships among those frogs (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

This species appears as a sister species to Phyllomedusa trinitatis, suggesting P. neildi could be conspecific with the former (Faivovich et al. 2010), despite the striking morphological differences in size and call structure (Barrio-Amorós 2006).

Possibly related to some of the green tree frogs of the punctatus group (sensu Faivovich et al. 2005) according to the original description of the species (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2006). Dubois (2017) concluded that Boana is the appropriate generic name for Hypsiboas species. The specimens from Chimantá massif and Cerro Guanay referred as cf. jimenezi by Señaris and Ayarzagüena (2006) require additional studies to define their full identity.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis thyellus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
Pristimantis flabellidiscus can be distinguished from other similar species by very expanded discs and a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Barrio-Amorós 2006).

Described originally in genus Eleutherodactylus (Barrio-Amorós and Molina 2006), subsequently transferred to Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007), and posteriorly to Ceuthomantis by Heinicke et al. (2009) whom also erected a new family, Ceuthomantidae, for this taxon.
