The diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis have been suggested (Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019 and Frost 2019 for a summary). In all these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (direct-developing frogs).

This species was originally described as Colostethus caribe, but a year later was moved to the genus Allobates based on its morphological characteristics (Lötters et al. 2007).

Lötters et al. (2007: 60) in an apparent transcription mistake made reference to this species as Anomaloglossus caribe.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis rhigophilus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position within Mannophryne has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

authority: Manzanilla, La Marca, Jowers, Sánchez & García-Paris, 2005
taxonomicNotes: Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne and belonging to the M. trinitatis species group, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus pentadactylus species group based on morphological characteristics and traits (Heyer 2005).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes and there are no doubts about the validity of this species. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne and belonging to the M. trinitatis species group, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

This species can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters. It is assigned to this genus by the presence of the generic synapomorphy of a median lingual process (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías 2008). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) state that this species should be compared to Anomaloglossus ayarzaguenai, as both could represent the same taxon, since they are from neighboring tepuis.

The validity of this species has been questioned, and it has been suggested that it could be conspecific with Hyalinobatrachium iaspidiense (Guayasamin and North 2009, Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009, Castroviejo-Fischer et al. 2011).

This species can be easily distinguished from other Tepui species of Pristimantis by a combination of morphological characters, such as the absence of calcars, shagreened dorsal skin, distinct iris color, and distinct dorsal pattern (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías 2008).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original description (Myers and Donnelly 2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the family Strabomantidae sensu Heinicke et al. (2018).

Assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group in its original description (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2008), but listed as unassigned to a species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown.

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to Barrio-Amorós et al. (2008) but unassigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Their evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis are unknown because it has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) but later referred as not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships within Pristimantis remain unknown, but its validity is not questioned. Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2013) amended its definition and described the variation in its external morphology.

Its phylogenetic position has been inferred by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2015). Its phylogenetic relationship with Cryptobatrachus pedroruizi Lynch, 2008 must be assessed in order to determine if these two species are conspecific, as both are geographically close and morphologically similar.

Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) noted that it shares morphological similarities with the Pristimantis lentiginosus species group of Rivero (1984). Padial et al. (2014) recognized P. lassoalcalai as part of Pristimantis but as unassigned to species group. Heinicke et al. (2015) moved it to Tachiramantis.

The diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis had been suggested (Heinicke et al. 2009, Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Frost 2019 for a summary). In these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (New World direct-developing frogs).
Its phylogenetic position, as part of Aromobates, has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Not assigned to any species group in the original description (Rödder and Jungfer 2008) or in Padial et al. (2014). The specimens mentioned as Pristimantis cf. yuruaniensis by Rödder and Junger 2008) from the Kukenán-tepui correspond to P. aureoventris (Jablonski et al. 2017). In a recent exploratory molecular analysis of the phylogenetic relationships within the genus Pristimantis in the Guiana Shield, Kok et al. (2018) considered this species to be in the “unistrigatus” group.

Originally described by Rivero (1968) as Centrolenella orocostale. Cannatella and Lamar (1986) considered this species as a junior synonym of Centrolenella orientalis, and later Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) placed it in the genus Hyalinobatrachium. Based on phylogenetic analysis and new natural history data, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009) removed this species from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium orientalis. More recently Jowers et al. (2014) reanalyzed the phylogenetic relationships of this species and its closely related sister species Hyalinobatrachium fragile, and H. orientale (from Venezuela mainland, and Trinidad and Tobago).

Fermin et al. (2012) synonymized Bolitoglossa spongai (described by Barrio-Amorós and Fuentes-Ramos in 1999), also from Sierra La Culata, under B. orestes based on molecular evidence (16S, cytb and cox genes sequence analysis) and morphological data. Specimens from Sierra Nevada de Mérida, previously considered as B. orestes, are actually specimens of its sister species, B. mucuyensis (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). Bolitoglossa orestes was placed in the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group by Parra-Olea et al. (2004).

Preliminary evidence from several phylogenetic studies (Kok et al. 2012, Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019) indicates that it could be a junior synonym of Anomaloglossus wothuja (Barrio-Amorós, Fuentes & Rivas, 2004). Further studies including comparative morphology and bioacoustical data are required to determine its taxonomic status.

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position was inferred from molecular data by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) and then corroborated in the total evidence analyses of Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position was inferred from molecular data by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) and then corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), and in the total evidence analyses of Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Since its description (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2012) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).

authority: García-Gutiérrez, Escalona, Mora, de Pascual & Fermin, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Specimens of this species were previously identified as B. orestes (Barrio-Amorós and Fuentes-Ramos 1999, García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). The molecular and morphological analyses of Fermin et al. (2012) shed light on the species diversity and its known distribution in the vicinity of Mérida city. Thus, B. mucuyensis was described from La Mucuy region, at Sierra Nevada de Mérida, and B. orestes was restricted to the Sierra La Culata, the close parallel mountain chain (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). It is unclear if specimens from the road Mérida-El Morro, at Sierra Nevada de Mérida (stored at the Museo de Historia Natural La Salle, MHNLS), belong to B. mucuyensis. B. mucuyensis is the sister species of B. orestes and it is member of the B. adspersa group (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019) based on total evidence analyses.
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019) based on total evidence analyses.

Originally assigned to the non-monophyletic Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2013) but later referred to as unassigned to a species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships have been inferred by Kok et al. (2012, 2018).

This species has not been included in any phylogenetic study, and was not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne and belonging to the M. trinitatis species group, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Prostherapis herminae by Boettger (1893). It was synonymized with Phyllobates trinitatis by Barbour and Noble (1920) although that synonymy was not widely accepted. Edwards (1971) considered it a valid species but in Colostethus. Rivero (1984) in turn, treated it as a subspecies of Colostethus trinitatis (C. t. herminae). Finally, it was transferred to Mannophryne and again recognized as a full species by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been repeatedly corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Discovered during the 2010 RAP to Calderas by Conservation International (Rial et al. 2010), and described afterwards by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) among the tuberculated Pristimantis of Venezuela. A basic phylogenetic analysis was performed including this species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2013), showing that P. conservatio is sister and apparently vicariant of P. vanadise from the other side of the Sierra Nevada de Mérida. Not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

This species was described in 1984 by Juan Rivero, but the type material remains in bad condition. Since the description, no other information was gathered about the species, until Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) redescribed the species with fresh material, including its advertisement call and phylogeny. In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original publication (Rivero 1984), but not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) and Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original description (Schlüter and Rödder 2007) and Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). After a detailed morphological review of the type material from the Guaiquinima-tepui, Kok and Barrio-Amorós (2013) considered Pristimantis tepuiensis as a junior synonym of P. guaiquinimensis.

Faivovich et al. (2013) described two new species from La Neblina massif and changed the nominal type species of the genus from Hyla inparquesi to Myersiohyla neblinaria. The monophyly of Myersiohyla remains a matter of debate (Pinheiro et al. 2018)

Faivovich et al. (2013) described Myersiohyla neblinaria based on the external morphology of adults and tadpoles, on bioacoustical analyses of advertisement calls, and on molecular phylogenetic evidence. They also commented on the phylogenetic relationships of this species with M. chamaeleo and M. kanaima, and redefined M. neblinaria as the type species for the genus after confirming that the specimen from Cerro La Neblina, miss-identified as M. inparquesi by Faivovich et al. (2005), was M. neblinaria.
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015).
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015). With the adult male measuring 13 mm, this species may be the smallest frog species in Venezuela and rank among the smallest in South America.

Several recent phylogenetic studies suggest that the species of Tepuihyla evolved recently from a common lowland ancestor, and not a long time ago as usually suspected for endemics amphibians in the Pantepui (Kok et al. 2012; Salerno et al. 2012, 2015; Jungfer et al. 2013). So far this species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis.

authority: Pansonato, Motta, Cacciali, Haddad, Strüssmann & Jansen, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Oreobates heterodactylus (Pansonato et al. 2020).

authority: Alves da Silva, Magalhães, Thomassen, Leite, Garda, Brandão, Haddad, Giaretta & Carvalho, 2020
taxonomicNotes: Records previously assigned to Leptodactylus spixi have been reassigned to this species by Alves da Silva et al. (2020). It is in the L. mystaceus complex, Leptodactylus fuscus group; distinguishable only by molecular or acoustic characteristics.

Pristimantis phoxocephalus was formerly considered a single highly polymorphic species (e.g., Lynch 1979, Lynch and Duellman 1997, Duellman and Lehr 2009). Páez and Ron (2019) showed that most subpopulations previously ascribed to P. phoxocephalus represent other species (e.g., Pristimantis atillo, P. jimenezi, P. teslai sp. nov., P. torresi sp. nov., P. totoroi sp. nov., P. verrucolatus sp. nov., Pristimantis sp. (CCS2), Pristimantis sp. (UCS2), Pristimantis sp. (UCS3)). This is the new narrower concept of Pristimantis phoxocephalus.

In the Hypsiboas calcaratus complex and differentiable from H. alfaroi only by genetic markers or call (Caminer and Ron 2014). Some specimens collected from Madre de Dios and Ucayali Regions in southern Peru resemble this species (Padial et al. 2016), however, they are thought to belong to an undescribed species from Clade G in the phylogeny provided by Caminer and Ron (2014) (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. 2018) and are excluded from this assessment. This species was moved to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Meza-Joya et al. (2019) examined specimens identified as B. fasciata from Colombia and found them to be B. tetete and B. maculateralis.

This species is genetically most closely related to Necturus beyeri and N. alabamensis (Guttman et al. 1990). Some authors have included in this species certain subpopulations in the Black Warrior River drainage; those apparently comprise two species, N. alabamensis and an undescribed species (see Guttman et al. 1990). The subspecies N. m. louisianensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991, 1997), but supporting data were lacking. Petranka (1998) and Crother et al. (2000) treated louisianensis as a subspecies, however, Fouquette and Dubois (2014) recognize N. louisianensis as a distinct species and this has been accepted by Frost (2021). Chabarria et al. (2018) and Greenwald et al. (2020) both contributed to the delimitation of this species, however, additional work is needed.

authority: Alves da Silva, Magalhães, Thomassen, Leite, Garda, Brandão, Haddad, Giaretta & Carvalho, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Leptodactylus mystaceus, according to Alves da Silva et al. (2020).

authority: Alves da Silva, Magalhães, Thomassen, Leite, Garda, Brandão, Haddad, Giaretta & Carvalho, 2020
taxonomicNotes: Split from Leptodactylus spixi by Alves da Silva et al. (2020), who placed it in the L. mystaceus complex, L. fuscus group.

authority: Dias, Novaes-e-Fagundes, Mollo, Zina, Garcia, Recoder, Vechio, Rodrigues & Solé, 2020
Oliveira, Alves da Silva, Guimarães, Penhacek, Martínez, Rodrigues, Santana & Hernández-Ruz, 2020
Oliveira, Alves da Silva, Guimarães, Penhacek, Martínez, Rodrigues, Santana & Hernández-Ruz, 2020
Oliveira, Alves da Silva, Guimarães, Penhacek, Martínez, Rodrigues, Santana & Hernández-Ruz, 2020
Oliveira, Alves da Silva, Guimarães, Penhacek, Martínez, Rodrigues, Santana & Hernández-Ruz, 2020
Andrade, Haga, Lyra, Carvalho, Haddad, Giaretta & Toledo, 2020
taxonomicNotes: Recovered as the sister species of Pseudopaludicola atragula + Pseudopaludicola facureae according to the original publication (Andrade et al. 2020).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Kurixalus appendiculatus by Matsui et al. (2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Quasipaa courtoisi by Dubois and Ohler (2009).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Nanorana yunnanensis by Huang et al. (2016), where it had been placed by Liu and Hu (1961) and Dubois (1987 "1986").

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). 

Köhler et al. (2010), in accordance with Faivovich et al. (2004), Faivovich et al. (2005) and Koscinski et al. (2008), considered Boana riojana (Hypsiboas riojanus) and Boana andinus (Hypsiboas andina) conspecifics. Pinheiro et al. (2019) indicate that the holotype of Boana varelae is conspecific with Boana riojana and corrected the type locality of Boana varelae to "Horco Molle, Yerba Buena, Tucuman, Argentina". Faivovich et al. (2021) placed Boana albonigra in synonymy with Boana riojana.

authority: Brown, Siu-Ting, von May, Twomey, Guillory, Deutsch & Chávez, 2019
taxonomicNotes: Brown et al. (2019) restricted the range of Ameerega hahneli and A. picta with the naming of this species.

authority: Brown, Siu-Ting, von May, Twomey, Guillory, Deutsch & Chávez, 2019
taxonomicNotes: Brown et al. (2019) restricted the range of Ameerega altamazonica and A. picta with the naming of this species.

authority: Patton, Apodaca, Corser, Wilson, Williams, Cameron & Wake, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Aneides aeneus (Patton et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus marmoratus (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009, Beamer and Lamb 2020).

This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus marmoratus (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009). It was initially named as D. melanius, but was then found to be the same taxon as D. intermedius (an older name) (see Raffaëlli 2022 and Frost 2023).
This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus auriculatus (Means et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eurycea spelaea (Phillips et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eurycea spelaea (Phillips et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eurycea quadridigitata (Wray et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eurycea quadridigitata (Wray et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eurycea quadridgitata (Wray et al. 2017).

authority: Stuart, Beamer, Farrington, Beane, Chek, Pusser, Som, Stephan, Sever & Braswell, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Eurycea cirrigera (Stuart et al. 2020).

This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudotriton montanus (Collins 1991). There is considerable taxonomic uncertainty surrounding this species (T. Pierson pers. comm. June 2021). It was originally split by Collins (1991) due to its allopatry and consistent diagnosability from Pseudotriton montanus. Highton et al. (2017), however, retained this species as a subspecies of P. montanus citing a lack of information on genetic differentiation between the species. It was considered a valid species during the expert consultation process in 2021, however further taxonomic work is needed.

authority: Guyer, Murray, Bart, Crother, Chabarria, Bailey & Dunn, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Necturus beyeri (Guyer et al. 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudacris brachyphona (Ospina et al. 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudacris streckeri (Collins 1991, Barrow et al. 2014).
Discoglossus jeanneae has been synonymized under this species by Dufresnes et al. (2020).
This is a broader concept of this species including formerly separated Hyla perrini (Dufresnes et al. 2018), now again recognized as subspecies of H. intermedia (Dufresnes et al. 2021).

This species was formerly regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos (Greece); However, recent evidence based on complete mitogenome sequencing showed that individuals from Karpathos and Rhodos form a well-supported monophyletic group with very low genetic distance between them, thus placing the Rhodos population to P. cerigensis and not to P. bedriagae (Toli et al. 2023). The species should be considered endemic to the islands of Karpathos and Rhodos.
Although Speybroeck et al. (2020) do not consider the Karpathos Frog as a separate species, recent phylogenetic analysis based on complete mitogenome sequences support the taxonomic distinctiveness of P. cerigensis (Toli et al. 2023). The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).
This taxon was removed from the synonymy of Lissotriton boscai by Sequiera et al. (2020) and Speybroeck et al. (2020).

authority: Fouquet, Marinho, Réjaud, Carvalho, Caminer, Jansen, Rainha, Rodrigues, Werneck, Lima, Hrbek, Giaretta, Venegas, Chávez & Ron, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This species was confused with Boana fasciata prior to its naming (Fouquet et al. 2021).

authority: Fouquet, Marinho, Réjaud, Carvalho, Caminer, Jansen, Rainha, Rodrigues, Werneck, Lima, Hrbek, Giaretta, Venegas, Chávez & Ron, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This species was confused with Boana fasciatus prior to its naming (Fouquet et al. 2021).

The Ecuadorian records were removed from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni by Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1998) and are now treated as H. petersi. Records from Venezuela are now referred to Hyalinobatrachium guairarepanensis (Señaris 2001, Barrio-Amoros 2004). Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2011) referred all records of nominal Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni from the east side of the Andes to other species, and Hyalinobatrachium cappellei was removed from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni. Mendoza-Henao et al. (2020) redelimited the species (on the basis of DNA, calls, and morphology), partitioning Hyalinobatrachium viridissimum out of former Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni and moving South American records to Hyalinobatrachium tatayoi.

Removed from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni by Mendoza-Henao et al. (2020). The boundary between this species and H. fleischmanni is currently unclear, particularly in El Salvador. Subpopulations in the Mexican states of Chiapas, Oaxaca, Veracruz, Puebla, and Tabasco, as well as those on both sides of the Motagua-Polochic- Jocotan fault system through lowlands of Guatemala and Honduras are assigned to this taxon, but further work is necessary to identify the species status of those subpopulations (Mendoza-Henao et al. 2020).

This is the new broader concept of Hyalinobatrachium tatayoi which now includes many animals previously assigned to the old concept of H. fleischmanni, from lowland Costa Rica to South America (Mendoza-Henao et al. 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hynobius leechi (Borzée and Min 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hynobius leechi (Borzée and Min 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hynobius leechi (Borzée and Min 2021).

We follow Thorn and Raffaëlli (2001) in considering Hynobius mantchuricus to be a synonym of H. leechii. We follow Kim et al. (2003) in removing subpopulations in extreme southeastern South Korea, formerly considered to belong to this species, as Hynobius yangi. This concept was restricted further when H. unisacculus was split from this species by Min et al. (2016), and has been further restricted by the description of three new splits - H. geojeensis, H. notialis and H. perplicatus (Borzée and Min 2020).

Some specimens from Brazilian Amazonia were previously confused with both Atelopus pulcher (e.g., Gascon 1989, Zimmerman and Simberloff 1996) and Atelopus spumarius, both of which differ in morphology and advertisement call, and now belong to a separate species, Atelopus manauensis (Jorge et al. 2020).
This species was previously confused with both Atelopus pulcher and Atelopus spumarius (both of which differ in morphology and advertisement call), according to Jorge et al. (2020).

Afrixalus brachycnemis and Afrixalus septentrionalis had been synonymized and treated as subspecies of A. stuhlmanni in some literature (e.g. Pickersgill 2005, Ohler and Frétey 2014), but they are retained as separate species here until the taxonomy has been resolved (M. Menegon pers. comm. April 2015).

authority: Melo-Sampaio, Prates, Peloso, Recoder, Vechio, Marques-Souza & Rodrigues, 2020

taxonomicNotes: Maciel and Hoogmoed (2011) noted no substantial diagnostic differences between Caecilia marcusi and Caecilia mertensi, but having not examined the holotype of the latter, refrained from placing Caecilia marcusi in the synonymy of Caecilia mertensi, which was subsequently done by Segalla et al. (2021)
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
Elevated from subspecies level of Lissotriton vulgaris by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2009), validated by Wielstra et al. (2018).

authority: Dufresnes, Mazepa, Rodrigues, Brelsford, Litvinchuk, Sermier, Lavanchy, Betto-Colliard, Blaser, Borzée, Cavoto, Fabre, Ghali, Grossen, Horn, Leuenberger, Phillips, Saunders, Savary, Maddalena, Stöck, Dubey, Canestrelli & Jeffries, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyla intermedia (Dufresnes et al. 2018).

authority: Díaz-Rodríguez, Gehara, Márquez, Vences, Gonçalves, Sequeira, Martínez-Solano & Tejedo, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pelodytes punctatus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017).
This is a split from Rana temporaria, where it was previously considered a subspecies (Dufresnes et al. 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Kalophrynus pleurostigma (Matsui et al. 2017).

Although, Correa et al. (2017) synonymized Eupsophus altor with E. migueli extending the range of E. migueli south to the Lingue River, Suárez-Villota et al. (2018) hypothesized that both are good species restoring the previous taxonomic arrangement. The taxonomic criteria used by Cuevas and Sanhueza (2020) agrees with the results obtained by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), recognizing this taxon as a specific taxonomic unit different from E. altor.

The first concept of Eupsophus roseus -- assessed in 2004 – was a ‘narrow’ concept (not including E. contulmoensis, E. nahuelbutensis, E. queulensis and E. septentrionalis, but including Eupsophus altor).

Following the 2004 assessment, Nuñez et al. (2012) described Eupsophus altor, which was previously confused with Eupsophus roseus prior to its naming. In addition, Correa-Quezada et al. (2017) placed Eupsophus contulmoensis, E. nahuelbutensis, E. queulensis and E. septentrionalis in synonymy with Eupsophus roseus. This revised, broader concept of E. roseus was reassessed in 2017.

Following the 2017 assessment, Eupsophus contulmoensis, E. nahuelbutensis, and E. septentrionalis were removed from synonymy of E. roseus (and E. queulensis seems to be considered a synonym of E. septentrionalis) by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018). Therefore, this reassessment is based on the revised, narrower concept of Eupsophus roseus (not including E. contulmoensis, E. nahuelbutensis, E. queulensis, E. septentrionalis, or Eupsophus altor).

Eupsophus queulensis was synonymized with E. septentrionalis by Blotto et al. (2013). Correa-Quezada et al. (2017) then placed E. septentrionalis in synonymy with E. roseus, but the more recent proposal by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018) restored the previous taxonomy, resurrecting E. septentrionalis as a valid species.
Known only from the holotype which is now lost (Frost 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Rana culaiensis (Luo et al. 2012). However, its taxonomic status is unclear.

Nishikawa et al. (2021) have clarified the taxonomic identification of Hynobius sonani and H. formosanus . Based on the descriptions and measurement data in the original description, Nishikawa et al. (2021) they confirmed that H. sonani has been treated as H. formosanus and vice versa. As the holotypes could not be found, neotypes have been assigned to avoid future taxonomic confusion.

Nishikawa et al. (2021) have clarified the taxonomic identification of Hynobius sonani and H. formosanus . Based on the descriptions and measurement data in the original description, Nishikawa et al. (2021) they confirmed that H. sonani has been treated as H. formosanus and vice versa. As the holotypes could not be found, neotypes have been assigned to avoid future taxonomic confusion.

authority: Neira-Salamea, Ofori-Boateng, Kouamé, Blackburn, Segniagbeto, Hillers, Barej, Leaché & Rödel, 2021

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Litoria littlejohni (Mahony et al. 2020).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

Caramaschi (2008) discussed reasons for retaining it as a valid taxon within Leptodactylus. Recently, the genus Leptodactylus was reviewed by De Sá et al. (2014), and this work indicated that this nominal species is likely not a member of Leptodactylus, but is a member of Leptodactylidae. There remains considerable uncertainty regarding the taxonomic identity of this species, and even concerns that it may be synonymous with another species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
Chiasmocleis jimi had been placed under synonymy with C. hudsoni by Peloso et al. (2014), but was reversed by de Sá et al. (2018 "2019").
This species was formerly confused with Plethodon ventralis (formerly a form of P. dorsalis); the two species are morphologically similar but genetically distinct (Highton 1986).
Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), this species has been revalidated.

Records from central Africa refer to Sclerophrys latifrons. Following morphological analysis, Sclerophrys cristiglans has been synonymised with this species (Ohler and Dubois 2016). 

This species has been moved from Amietophrynus to Sclerophrys by Ohler and Dubois (2016).

Aubria occidentalis has been synonymized with this species by Ohler (1996) and Rödel et al. (2005). This has been disputed by Perret (1994), Schätti et al. (2002) and M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. (2022). There is ongoing debate between the validity of A. occidentalis, and further taxonomic work is required for confirmation. It is treated here as a synonym of this species.
This species is a complex of five species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm., Rödel et al. unpubl. data).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
Boistel et al. (2005) in Rueda-Almonacid et al. (eds.) and Lötters et al. (2011) suggested that this taxon might be a synonym of Atelopus flavescens.

authority: Oliveira, Magalhães, Teixeira, Moura, Porto, Guimarães, Giaretta & Tinôco, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Oliveira et al. (2021) remarked that "Because D. tapacurensis sp. nov. and D. haddadi are considered morphologically cryptic species, it is plausible that records assigned to D. haddadi from Pernambuco and Alagoas might actually represent D. tapacurensis sp. nov., considering that the identification of these subpopulations was based solely on external morphology. Therefore, the identity of these subpopulations should be further investigated including acoustic and molecular evidence to better evaluate the distribution range and conservation status of D. tapacurensis sp. nov." In addition, D. tapacurensis is currently syntopic with D. branneri, D. elegans, D. soaresi, D. minutus and D. oliveirai (Oliveira et al. 2021).

authority: La Marca, Escalona, Castellanos, Rojas-Runjaic, Crawford, Señaris, Fouquet, Giaretta & Castroviejo-Fisher, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This species was differentiated out of Boana xerophylla, and placed in the Boana faber group, based on external morphology, molecular markers, and advertisement call (Escalona et al. 2021).

The high genetic distances between the specimens analyzed by Peloso et al. (2014) suggest the existence of more than one species within Chiasmocleis antenori. Peloso et al. (2014) implied some controversy over the identity of some Peruvian records. A specimen identified as Chiasmocleis carvalhoi from San Martin, Peru (de Sá et al. 2012) is regarded as a confirmed record of this species for Peru (Peloso et al. 2014).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Duttaphrynus scaber by Bisht et al. (2021). Safaei-Mahroo et al. (2023) transferred the species from Duttaphrynus to Firouzophrynus on the basis of the assignment to the D. stomaticus group by Bisht et al. (2021).

authority: Jowers, Othman, Borzée, Rivas-Fuenmayor, Sánchez-Ramírez, Auguste, Downie, Read & Murphy, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Previously confused with Elachistocleis ovalis (Jowers et al. 2021). Two Venezuelan specimens from the southern Maracaibo lake basin and the eastern versant of the Cordillera de Mérida showed close genetic affinities to Elachistocleis nigrogularis and could belong to this species (Jowers et al. 2021). Further investigation and additional sequencing of these subpopulations is necessary (Jowers et al. 2021).

authority: Chaves-Portilla, Salazar, Gil-Acero, Dorado-Correa, Márquez, Rueda-Almonacid & Amézquita, 2021
Santana, Alves da Silva, Sant’Anna, Shepard & Mângia, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Previously confused with Proceratophrys concavitympanum and removed from synonymy with this species by Santana et al. (2021).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Rhinella marina. The systematics of this taxon require further investigation.
This is most likely a species complex.

The species is known only by the type series collected at the beginning of the 20th century. Apparently, all the collected specimens have been lost, and no other records are known. Based on the description of the holotype, this seems to be a valid species. However, there is doubt that it belongs in this genus (Borzée and Min 2021).

authority: Nunes, Guimarães, Moura, Pedrozo, Moroti, Castro, Stuginski & Muscat, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Prior to its description, this species was confused with Brachycephalus ephippium (Nunes et al. 2021).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus petersii by Gazoni et al. (2021).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus petersii by Gazoni et al. (2021).

authority: Assis, Lacerda, Guimarães, Peixoto, Luna & Feio, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Thoropa lutzi (Assis et al. 2021).

This species was formerly included in the genus Diaglena, and is now in the genus Triprion (Faivovich et al. 2018). The southern subpopulations probably belong to a different species (C. Grunwald pers. comm. October 2019).

authority: Mahony, Hines, Mahony, Moses, Catalano, Myers & Donnellan, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Assa darlingtoni (Mahony et al. 2021). The original description also includes some localities for which the identity of specimens are still uncertain. For this assessment they have been kept within Assa darlingtoni.
This species was elevated from subspecies level of Lissotriton vulgaris (Pabijan et al. 2017), although there is ongoing discussion about this (Speybroeck et al. 2020).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Rowley, Mahony, Hines, Myers, Price, Shea & Donnellan, 2021
taxonomicNotes: A recent analysis by Rowley et al. (2021) revised the taxonomy of Litoria dentata, restricting its range and describing two new species, L. quiritatus and L. balatus.

authority: Rowley, Mahony, Hines, Myers, Price, Shea & Donnellan, 2021

taxonomicNotes: This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Rana graeca.

authority: Cusi, Gagliardi-Urrutia, Brcko, Wake & von May, 2020
taxonomicNotes: Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Bolitoglossa awajun is the sister taxon to the clade composed of B. altamazonica and B. peruviana (Cusi et al. 2020). Additionally, B. awajun is morphometrically similar to these species yet it exhibits several morphological and color differences.

This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius kivuensis, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. There is some dispute in literature on whether this species is valid or not, and for the purposes of this assessment we are retaining it as a valid species following Lötters et al. (2004).

We follow Iskandar and Colijn (2000) in considering this species to be distinct from Rhacophorus pardalis. It may be a species inquirenda (D. Iskander pers. comm. April 2022), but further research is required.
This is a split from the broader concept of Micryletta inornata (Miller et al. 2021).
Rana zhengi has been synonymised with this species by Wan et al. (2020).
Platymantis rhipiphalcus has been synonymised with this species by Kraus (2008).
Dufresnes et al. (2019) revised the taxonomy of the B. viridis complex, synonymizing B. balearicus and Bufo variabilis within it.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pelodytes atlanticus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017). It was thought that subpopulations in low and mid-elevation montane areas of eastern and central Spain did actually belong to P. hespericus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017), however the two species are thought to be conspecific (Dufresnes et al. 2020).

Due to its morphological intermediacy between Duttaphrynus and Sclerophrys, Frost has returned this concept to the uncertain status of "Bufo" scorteccii. It is kept under Duttapphrynus on the IUCN Red List for now.
This form is a nomen dubium (Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc 1991, Guibé 1978, Vences et al. 2003), and it has not been matched to any known living species in the wild.

This account follows the suggested Salamandra monophyletic group distribution presented in Steinfartz et al. (2000). See also Burgon et al. (2021).

The identity of some subpopulations of Salamandra species reported from western Anatolia (Türkiye) require further investigation and are not included within this concept.

Some of the subpopulations north of the Alps, in Austria and Germany, show degrees of hybridization with Triturus cristatus and with T. dobrogicus (Mačát et al. 2019, Wielstra et al. 2021). Triturus carnifex is not included in the German list as all subpopulations there are considered hybrids (Fahrbach et al 2021).

The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans. The former subspecies macedonicus has been split off as a separate species following Arntzen et al. (2007).
Theloderma kwangsiensis has been synonymised with T. corticale by Hou et al. (2017).
Proper characterization of this species will depend on obtaining new specimens, and recording of its vocalizations from the type locality (R.G. Zweifel pers. comm.).

The confused taxonomic history involving the names Hylodes anonymus Lutz 1927, Hylodes incertus Lutz 1927 and Eleutherodactylus terraebolivaris Rivero, 1961 was clarified by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019). Thus, all previous references to Pristimantis terraebolivaris are attributed to Pristimantis incertus. In the Pristimantis conspicillatus species group (Hedges et al. 2008, Padial et al. 2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Rana kunyuensis has been synonymized under this species by Zhou et al. (2015).

The name Rana balcanica Schneider and Sinsch, 1992 is occasionally used, but this is a junior synonym of Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Dubois and Ohler 1995). The species status of P. kurtmuelleri is controversial (Speybroeck et al. 2010, 2020 ), mostly due to its low mtDNA divergence and shared interspecific polymorphism with P. ridibundus (e.g., Lymberakis et al. 2007; Akin et al. 2010; Plötner et al. 2012; Hofman et al. 2015; Litvinchuk et al. 2020) and weak morphometric differentiation (Papežík et al. 2021). The taxon is thus considered conspecific with P. ridibundus (Speybroeck et al. 2010, Sindaco and Razzetti 2021).



[Several references need entering and attached here]

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to the genus Aquiloeurycea (Rovito et al. 2015). The species has not been seen since the 1940s and is only known from the type locality, which is somewhat vague and now seems to all be converted to sugarcane fields (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Philautus mjobergi (Dehling et al. 2016).
Previously confused with Limnonectes laticeps (Matsui and Nishikawa 2014), which is now considered a synonym of L. khasianus (Ohler and Deuti 2013).

authority: Smart, Sarker, Arifin, Harvey, Sidik, Hamidy, Kurniawan & Smith, 2017

taxonomicNotes: Removed from the synonymy of Guibemantis bicalcaratus by Vences et al. (2013) where it had been placed by Blommers-Schlösser (1979) and Glaw and Vences (1992).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015). The karyotype of Pristimantis nubisilva consisting of 36 exclusively telocentric chromosomes (2n = 36, FN = 36), is considered to represent the ancestral condition in the taxon Terrarana (Schmid et al. 2010).

Subpopulations on the two islands may be taxonomically distinct and need to be evaluated with call analysis (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019). Records reported by Menzies from the mainland are Oreophryne equus (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).

Prior to the description of this species by Vieites et al. in 2020, only one species of Blommersia, B. transmarina, was known from Mayotte (Glaw et al. 2019). Some of the records assigned to B. transmarina could, in truth, represent the newly described B. nataliae.

This species and Mantella milotympanum might be colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm.). Populations with intermediate characteristics between Mantella crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2017). In the riveroi clade sensu Kok et al. (2017).
